DOC.HEAD: Lukens to File Petitions as GOP Candidate
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Donald Lukens, convicted last year in a sex scandal involving a 16-year-old girl, will file petitions as a GOP candidate but hasn't decided whether to seek re-election, a spokesman said Wednesday. ``He has decided to file petitions because it leaves his options open,'' said William Jarrell, Lukens' Washington press secretary. The deadline for filing is Feb. 22. The Republican congressman was convicted last May on a misdemeanor charge of contributing to the unruliness of a minor after the Columbus girl alleged she had sex with him. Lukens has appealed the conviction. Jarrell said Lukens would await a ruling on his appeal before making a decision whether to run.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Grounds Training Helicopters for Landing Strut Repair
DOC.TEXT: The Navy has grounded nearly all of its Bell TH-57 Jet Ranger training helicopters because of cracks in landing-skid supports, officials said Wednesday. All 140 of the Navy's orange-and-white TH-57s are based at this air station in the Florida Panhandle, the only installation where the service trains new helicopter pilots. Only 25 TH-57s were flying as of Wednesday, said Lt. Tara LaCavera, public affairs officer for Training Air Wing 5. ``No accidents have happened because of it,'' she said. Cracks were found in 123 of the aircraft, reducing flight operations by 80 percent as of Monday, but repairs are being made, said Petty Officer 1st Class Jon Gagne. He said the reduction is expected to be down to only 10 percent by March 15. ``What caused it has not yet been determined,'' Gagne said. Aviation maintenance personnel from Bell and the Naval Aviation Depot at the Pensacola Naval Air Station about 30 miles southwest of here are investigating, he said. LaCavera said the defective parts are being replaced but it will be mid-March before sufficient quantities will be available to repair all of the helicopters. She said costs of the repair work haven't yet been determined. The first crack was discovered during a routine maintenance inspection Jan. 24 and all 135 TH-57s on the base were checked last week, Gagne said. Five helicopters are away from Whiting for other maintenance. In an effort to make up lost training time, the Navy will begin conducting training flights on Saturdays and Sundays beginning Feb. 17 and continue operations seven days a week for an indefinite period, LaCavera said.

DOC.HEAD: Cranston Popularity Drops To New Low
DOC.TEXT: Despite an aggressive effort to bolster his image, Sen. Alan Cranston's popularity has sunk to a new low among California voters skeptical of his explanation of the Lincoln Savings & Loan scandal, a new survey says. The results of the California Poll come after Cranston tried to restore his reputation by attacking one of his main accusers in the savings and loan debacle, former thrift regulator Edwin Gray. ``People aren't buying it,'' said Mervin Field, director of the statewide poll. ``They've already made their judgment.'' Californians said by 69 to 20 percent that they would not be inclined to vote for Cranston were he to seek a record fifth term in 1992. Cranston has said he will seek re-election. By 56 percent to 31 percent, Democrats in the poll said they were not inclined to vote again for Cranston. The survey was conducted by telephone Feb. 2 to 10 among a statewide cross-section of 754 registered voters. The sampling has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.7 percentage points. Cranston and four other U.S. senators are being investigated by the Senate Ethics Committee for intervening with federal regulators on behalf of Lincoln after accepting more than $41.3 million in contributions from Charles Keating Jr. , Lincoln's chairman. Cranston has said repeatedly that he did not impede regulators and only asked them to make a decision whether to close Lincoln or allow it to remain in business.

DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported on Feb. 13 that Carl H. Pforzheimer& Co. is owned by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Pforzheimer is an independent firm that clears Drexel trading accounts at the New York Stock Exchange. The story also erroneously said the firm of Spear, Leeds & Kellogg temporarily cleared trades for Drexel. The firm provided financial backing for Drexel trades but did not clear them.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Government Still Under Siege After Soviet Departure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: One year after the Soviet Union withdrew its soldiers from the war against U.S.-backed Moslem guerrillas, President Najib's government points proudly to its survival. But it is still a government under siege, militarily, politically and economically. Najib, former chief of the dreaded KHAD secret police, has confounded his most strident critics, notably those in the United States, who predicted a bloodbath and a guerrilla victory within months, if not weeks, of the Red Army's departure. But at best, Najib and his Soviet-style People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan are survivors, not victors. The capital today is best viewed from afar early in the morning, when it glistens under a dusting of snow. Up close, it's a city of war-weariness and poverty where men, women and children slog through slush and mud, many of them sockless in cracked, second-hand shoes and plastic sandals. It's a city where a 13-year-old schoolboy like Ismail can earn 4,000 afghanis a month pulling a cart loaded with bags of flour weighing three times as much as he does. His father is paid 3,000 afghanis a month as an office worker at the Culture Ministry. At the official exchange rate, Ismail's earnings are worth $72, while his father's are worth $55. But at the more realistic black market rate, Ismail makes the equivalent of $8 while his father earns $6. Ismail competes with other young boys and old men for full-time work during the annual November-February school vacation. He boasts _ dubiously _ that because of his earnings, his family of nine can afford a little meat almost every day. The afghani has become an almost meaningless currency. Its dollar value has been cut in half in the past year, while fixed wages have not changed. It's more appropriate to view earnings in the context of meat, which costs between 800 and 1,000 afghanis per 2.2 pounds. Ismail's wages are worth about 11 pounds of mutton, his fathers's 8.25 pounds _ hardly enough to feed a family of nine for a month, let alone buy rice, bread and cooking fuel. Kabul salaries are especially sobering for the foreign visitor who plunks down 3,000 afghanis to purchase a fistfull of notebooks and a dozen batteries. Militarily, the Afghan forces have expanded their control, both around Kabul and the countryside. But guerrilla rockets still hit Kabul every day, although with less accuracy and fewer verified deaths than a year ago. The government claims to have expanded its ``security belt'' around the city and pushed back the guerrillas since the Soviets completed their withdrawal Feb. 15, 1989. ``Our defensive line extends between 65 kilometers (40 miles) and 80 kilomters (50 miles) from the center of Kabul,'' Brig. Gen. Gulbahar Salim told reporters. While visits to the front indicated those figures are exaggerated, the government has indeed expanded its control. Not only did it defeat the guerrillas when they tried to capture the eastern city of Jalalabad last year, it has re-opened key highways leading east and south of Kabul toward the guerrilla strongholds. Proof of this comes not only from the statements of the government and foreign diplomats but _ perhaps more convincingly _ from the lush displays of oranges, tangerines and pomegranates throughout Kabul. At this time of year, Afghanistan produces such fruit only in the warmer climates near the Pakistani border, guerrilla turf since the civil war started in 1978 between the Soviet-backed government and the mujahedeen, or Islamic holy warriors. Politically, Najib has spent the year attempting to convince the world he is ready to share power. Through speeches and the dispatching of envoys to both Eastern and Western Europe, invitations have been extended to Afghan exiles, There have been no public takers. In Kabul, there is a sense of change in the People's Democratic Party, which seized power nearly 12 years ago and initially but unsuccessfully tried to impose Marxism on a tribalistic and capitalistic society. Sources in Kabul, speaking on condition of anonymity, say Najib wants to rename the party to give it a less socialist-sounding name. The party has long been denounced by the guerrillas as a collection of ``godless Communists.'' Such efforts by Najib appeared to have been hurt this week by a change of leadership in the National Front, a purportedly multiparty umbrella group set up about four years ago. The National Front, which the mujahedeen consider nothing but a pseudonym for Najib's party and its followers, on Manday accepted the resignation of its chairman, Abdul Rahim Hatif. Hatif, a non-party man, is Afghanistan's vice president and technically the No. 2 man in government after Najib. The official explanation for his resignation was that Hatif, a businessman in his late 60s, needed more time for his vice presidential duties. More telling was the fact his successor is Farid Ahmad Mozdak, a member of the Politburo and secretary of the central committee of Najib's own party, still the only real player in Kabul politics.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan-Bush Campaign Official, Partners, to Repay HUD $720,000
DOC.TEXT: The general counsel of Ronald Reagan's presidential campaign and his partners in a Georgia housing development are to pay back nearly $720,000 in misspent federal money under an agreement reached Wednesday. Under the plan worked out between the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban development, the Brunswick City Commission and developers of Cypress Mill Plantation, the developers will repay the money, plus interest, over 20 years. The developers, partners in Brunswick Housing Development Group Ltd., are Edward L. Weidenfeld, the Washington lawyer who served as general counsel to the Reagan-Bush campaign; Michael E. Yates of Savannah; and Stephen M. Botnick of Akron, Ohio. None of the three could be located for comment Wednesday. The developers received about $3.1 million in federal housing money for the $6 million low-income project, a 152-unit complex completed in 1987. HUD officials found financial discrepancies last year and ordered an audit. Conducted by the agency's regional inspector general, the audit said $757,667 of the federal financing allocated for the Cypress Mill project was misused. The money was spent on expenses ineligible under federal guidelines, including some development costs related to Plantation Oaks, a sister project in Savannah, HUD officials said. The audit followed an April report by HUD Inspector General John A. Adams that alleged mismanagement within the agency and influence-peddling by prominent Republicans to win housing contracts. HUD officials said, however, the Brunswick audit was unrelated to the influence-peddling scandal. The developers, the agency said, had failed to put enough of their own money, a required ``equity injection,'' into the project, instead improperly charging certain expenses against the grant. Subsequent review of the expense figures resulted in the final HUD order for repayment of $718,605. With interest and a $54,000 fee, the total due HUD came to $920,088, according to HUD documents.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Accord Requires Sharp Reductions, But Many Troops Remain
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union will send home thousands of their troops stationed in Central Europe under a new deal struck by the two sides. But the Kremlin may have a hard time finding a welcome mat in the increasingly independent East bloc for the 195,000 soldiers allowed under the agreement worked out by foreign ministers this week in Canada. Even so, the European continent will still be crowded with hundreds of thousands of soldiers, ranging from those who are part of alliance forces to those in their own national armies. ``It's a very substantial reduction. (But) it's still a lot of troops around by historical standards,'' said John Cross, deputy director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. ``It will still be fairly densely populated with military,'' he said. Under the agreement, the Soviet Union and the United States will slash their troops stationed outside national territory to equal ceilings of 195,000 in Central Europe. The region covers West Germany, East Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Hungary and Denmark. In a surprising concession, the Kremlin agreed to let Washington maintain an additional 30,000 soldiers outside that zone, in Britain and southern Europe. The United States wants the extra men to reassure its allies and make up for the vast distance between the United States and Europe. ``The presence of U.S. troops in Europe ... is at the express wish of the allies,'' said Manfred Woerner, secretary-general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``It is necessary due to the geographical distance from the continental United States, and as a concrete expression of the American commitment to Europe,'' he said in a statement welcoming the accord. To meet the new levels, the Soviet Union will have to pare 370,000 soldiers from its estimated total of 565,000. The United States will have to trim 60,000 in Central Europe and 20,000 outside that region from a total of 305,000 troops in all of Europe. Terms of the deal require that the units be disbanded. The agreement will be part of a final accord to be wrapped up by year's end on reducing tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. The talks are between the 16 NATO nations and the seven of the Warsaw Pact. In accepting the troop cuts, the Soviet Union recognized the changing situation in Eastern Europe, where a wave of political reform has ousted long-faithful Communist regimes. The Kremlin opened talks with new governments in Hungary and Czechoslovakia after they demanded quick pullouts of troops sent decades ago to keep them in line. Poland could also join the drive. ``The Soviets could well find themselves in due course in some difficulty in maintaining 195,000 troops (in Eastern Europe),'' said Cross. Richard Fieldhouse, a military analyst for the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, said, ``The Soviets are going to make troop reductions with or without (an arms treaty).'' The result, he said, might be ``very few Soviet troops in Eastern Europe.'' Some 10,000 Soviet soldiers already have left Hungary and Czechoslovakia under a withdrawal plan announced in December 1988 by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. About 52,000 Red Army soldiers are still in Hungary, and 70,000 in Czechoslovakia. Poland has an estimated 40,000, and more than 380,000 are assigned to East Germany. Marshal Sergei Akhromeyev, an adviser to Gorbachev, said in an interview this week that the Kremlin had not received a formal request from Poland to discuss troop withdrawals. ``Once we have ... such an initiative on the part of Poland, this is not going to be a problem,'' he said. ``We are going to engage in the talks and have our forces removed from there.'' Analysts say Poland may see a contingent of Soviet forces as protection, fearing possible designs on its territory by a reunified Germany. Reductions of the Red Army in East Germany will depend on security arrangements worked out for the reunification of the two German states. But it would be unlikely that a huge number would be allowed under any solution that joined the eastern sector to its powerful western neighbor. West Germany has about 240,000 American soldiers on its soil. Belgium, Britain, France and the Netherlands have sent more than 100,000 there. Even under the troops accord, there will still be a substantial American presence in West Germany. Moreover, the agreement does not affect the forces of other NATO allies. ``Germany is not going to be demilitarized of foreign forces,'' said Fieldhouse.

DOC.HEAD: Passion Play Emphasizes Jewishness of Jesus, But Retains `Blood Curse'
DOC.TEXT: The 3-century-old Oberammergau Passion Play is eliminating some anti-Semitic stereotypes, but an ancient ``blood curse'' still divides American Jewish leaders and villagers in the small town in the Bavarian Alps. The script for the 1990 production _ expected to draw more than 200,000 American visitors _ emphasizes the Jewishness of Jesus, drops horns from the heads of Jewish high priests and presents Judas as confused rather than a cold mercenary figure. ``We have tried to ... show the Jewish tradition in a positive light,'' said Otto Huber, one of the directors, in an interview from his home in Oberammergau. But American Jewish leaders who have been meeting with village officials are concerned the anticipated half-million spectators for the play will still hear the passage from Matthew 27:25 that has plagued Jews for 19 centuries: ``His blood be on us and our children.'' ``For 1990, we still have the same basic text with the blood curse,'' said Rabbi James Rudin, national interreligious affairs director for the American Jewish Committee. The Passion Play dates from 1663, when bubonic plague ravaged the mountain valley where Oberammergau sits. When the Roman Catholic villagers vowed to stage a passsion play every 10 years if the plague abated, the epidemic vanished in what was considered a miracle, according to historical accounts. The play, to be performed this year from May 21 to Sept. 28, was last performed in 1984, when a special jubilee production attracted 470,000 spectators. Americans accounted for about 45 percent of the visitors to the daylong production. Since then, leaders from the American Jewish Committee and the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith have sought to change aspects of the play they believed maligned Jews and blamed them for the murder of Christ. Among the changes for 1990: _ Jesus' identity as a Jew is emphasized, including having him and his followers wear traditional prayer shawls. ``We have tried to show Jesus really as a Jew coming out from Jewish tradition and Jewish faith,'' Huber said. _ Jesus has a larger popular following among Jews, and there is no longer a separation of Jesus and his followers and the rest of the Jewish community in light and dark clothing. ``You had the good guys and the bad guys in the 1984 text,'' Rudin said. _ There is no longer any connection between the temple merchants and Jesus' persecutors. Rudin said that connection was ``one of the worst stereotypes of the play,'' playing on anti-Semitic images such as ``Shylock.'' _ The Jewish high priests who presided at the trial that led to the condemnation of Jesus will no longer have horns, an image carried over from the Middle Ages. _ Pontius Pilate, who before 1984 was portrayed a noble Roman and in 1984 was shown as ambivalent in sentencing Jesus to death, is presented in the 1990 text as an unsympathetic, brutal character. _ Judas Iscariot, the disciple who betrayed Jesus, is portrayed as a confused character who lost faith in Jesus, rather than as a man motivated only by the 30 pieces of silver he received for giving Jesus up. Rudin said Jewish leaders are sensitive to the efforts made by the German village, but while there were many positive developments, ``The retention of the `blood curse' is very problematic.'' The idea that Jewish people have collective guilt for the death of Jesus has been devastating in its impact on Jews throughout the centuries. Rudin said a new script should be written in light of the Holocaust and advances in Jewish-Christian relations. Rudin said American Jewish groups are not urging a boycott of the play, but plan to make available background materials on the play and hold briefings for people planning to visit Oberammergau. Huber said the changes show Oberammergau is ``very conscious about all the questions of anti-Semitism.'' He noted the passage from Matthew was barely retained by an 11-9 vote of the text committee, and with certain provisions: that a five-page explanation be included in scripts that tourists purchase to follow the German-language play. The explanation says the passage does not apply to one race and outlines the history of anti-Semitism surrounding it. ``With all the changes, I think that anti-Semitism is not the problem of the play in 1990,'' Huber said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: CBS executive Laurence A. Tisch and publishing mogul Malcolm Forbes are part of a corporate bridge team taking on British parliamentarians as the lords of American finance meet real British nobility. Sir Peter Emery of London and the selector Duke of Atholl will co-captain the British Parliament team in the Feb. 23 match in London, said Kathy Wei of the American Contract Bridge League. Ms. Wei, one of the top world bridge players, said Wednesday she will be master of ceremonies for the event. The U.S. team also includes Alan Greenberg and James Cayne, executives of Bear Stearns and Co. Inc.; Warren Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway Inc.; George Gillespie III, of the law firm of Cravath, Swaine and Moore; and Milton Petrie, of Petrie Stores. The Britons include Kenneth Baker, a senior Cabinet member; socialist parliamentarian John Marek; Lord Lever; Lord Smith; and Baroness Sally Oppenheim.

Kathleen Battle, the American lyric soprano, is making a hit at the Royal Opera House as Norina in a revival of ``Don Pasquale.'' She was given a rapturous reception Monday night after her first performance of the role in the comic work by Gaetano Donizetti. The Times of London called it an ``astute performance, with the renowned Battle coloratura on full display with every note hit dead center.'' Miss Battle first appeared in Covent Garden in 1984 in Richard Strauss' ``Ariadne auf Naxos,'' and was the first American to win the Laurence Olivier Award, an honor for best performance of a new production. Miss Battle, wonderfully lively in the footlights, keeps to herself offstage and has refused to pose for newspaper photographers or give interviews during this visit.

Diana, Princess of Wales, says ``very simple'' values can triumph over the complex difficulties encountered in modern marriages. ``Sadly, for many of these marriages, reality fails to live up to expectations. When that happens most couples discover and draw on new reserves of love and strength,'' Diana said Wednesday. ``But for many, their own resources are not enough.'' The princess, patron of the marriage guidance organization Relate, made her comments while presenting the charity's Family of the Year award. The winners were Rico and Heather Gopaul, both 30, and children Rico Jr., 7, Ryan, 6, Ricky, 3, and Rosita, 2. The mother and father are nurses who care for mentally handicapped people. ``The award celebrates the victory of very simple values over the very complex difficulties confronted by so many modern marriages,'' said Diana, who married Prince Charles in 1981. The couple has two sons.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX3 of Feb. 14
DOC.TEXT: Transsexual Terri Pohrman is running for mayor of this conservative town and making inroads among senior citizens with the slogan, ``The Change Will Do You Good.'' The former Las Vegas show girl was a regular entertainer at the California Veterans' Home before she entered the race, but now the home is a campaign stop _ more than 700 of the 1,800 registered voters in this wine-country town live there. She visited the home last weekend wearing roller skates and a tight body stocking with huge red cardboard hearts over her front and back. Later, she donned a red sequined cocktail dress with a plunging neckline. ``All the guys got a big kick out of her,'' said Gene Sockness, 61. ``She's really welcome up here and shows us a good time. So what the heck, live and let live.'' The big-shouldered blonde with spiky hair faces two opponents in the April 10 election. Her ambitions have panicked some residents of this town of 3,200 people, about 40 miles north of San Francisco. ``These people are scared,'' she said. ``They think I'll open a bunch of massage parlors and adult bookstores.'' Pohrman was a teen-age female impersonator before having a sex change operation in in the 1970s.

Actress Glenn Close scooped up another Ivy League honor, this time from the Dartmouth Film Society, joining Robert Redford and Lillian Gish as recipients of the organization's award. ``I hope I can keep doing the kind of work that warrants this overwhelming response,'' the actress said at Wednesday's ceremony at Dartmouth College. ``It's deeply moving and I thank you from the bottom of my heart.'' Close, a five-time Academy Award nominee, made her film debut opposite Robin Williams in 1982 in ``The World According to Garp.'' Since then, she has starred in such films as ``Fatal Attraction,'' and ``Dangerous Liaisons.'' On Tuesday, Close received the Woman of the Year award from Hasty Pudding Theatricals at Harvard University.

Rock 'n' roll stalwart Elton John will play the inaugural concert at Donald Trump's Taj Mahal Casino Resort six weeks after its scheduled April 2 opening, casino officials said. The British rock star known for his outlandish outfits and musical longevity will perform May 18-19 at the casino's 5,200-seat Mark Grossinger Etess Arena. ``I want the biggest and the best to play at the Trump Taj Mahal, and when Elton John takes the stage, the future of entertainment in Atlantic City will never be the same,'' Trump said in a statement Wednesday.

Tom Schulman, who wrote ``Dead Poets Society,'' is a little stunned to be in the company of Woody Allen and Nora Ephron as a nominee for an Academy Award for best original screenplay. He is competing with Allen, nominated for ``Crimes and Misdemeanors''; Ephron (``When Harry Met Sally''); Spike Lee (``Do the Right Thing'') and Steven Sonderburgh (``sex, lies, and videotape''). ``My God, Woody Allen is one of my idols. I'm really proud to be a part of that lineup,'' Schulman, who hails from Nashville, said in an interview from his Los Angeles-area home.

DOC.HEAD: Litter from Dogs Owned by Thurmond, Dole in Hot Demand
DOC.TEXT: People are clamoring for eight ``power'' puppies from a schnauzer owned by Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., and fathered by a schnauzer belonging to Sen. Robert Dole, R-Kan., and Labor Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole. Thurmond's wife, Nancy, said the Doles will get the pick of the black-and-brown pups and the others likely will go to people in Thurmond's hometown of Aiken. ``A lot of people want them, and we are going to give them away,'' said Mrs. Thurmond. The mother, Chelsea Marie, is a miniature schnauzer, and the father is Leader, a schnauzer with suspect lineage. Leader was rescued from a shelter when Dole was the majority leader. ``The Doles are known as the Washington power couple, so we called Leader the power dog,'' Mrs. Thurmond said. Leader spent three weeks at the Thurmond home last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Key Issues Still Stand in Way of Treaty, US Officials Say
With PM-NATO-Troops Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite an agreement on European troop ceilings, the United States and the Soviet Union are still arguing over combat aircraft and anti-cheating procedures for a 23-nation treaty to reduce forces on the continent, Bush administration officials say. The agreement, reached by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze at an ``Open Skies'' conference in Ottawa, Canada, on Tuesday, prompted U.S. allies to begin preparing for a 35-nation summit meeting later this year. The treaty _ now in negotiations in Vienna between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact _ would be signed at the session which would be attended by the United States, Canada, the Soviet Union, 31 European nations and the Vatican. Baker is scheduled to meet next with Shevardnadze sometime in the first two weeks of April in Washington, a U.S. official said. The talks in Moscow last week and the April meeting are in preparation for Bush's summit meeting with Gorbachev in Washington in June. The agreement on manpower provides a ceiling of 195,000 American and Soviet troops in Central Europe and an additional 30,000 U.S. soldiers in such countries as Britain, Italy and Spain. For treaty purposes, Central Europe is defined as West Germany, Denmark, Belgium, Luxembourg and the Netherlands for stationing American soldiers and East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary for Soviet troops. Two Bush administration officials, at a background briefing for reporters at the State Department on Wednesday, cautioned against assuming the treaty is about to be wrapped up following the agreement on troop ceilings and the start of summit preparations. For one thing, the United States and the Soviet Union are at odds over combat aircraft. Baker said in a speech Monday in Ottawa that Moscow's position would require NATO to add 2,000 planes to reach an equal level. ``This is one of the major outstanding issues for everybody who wants to get this treaty done,'' one of the U.S. officials said. He described the Soviet response to the U.S. position on distinguishing combat aircraft from defensive interceptors, which would not be subject to limits, as ``patently unreasonable.'' The official said he could not predict the outcome of the dispute. ``The positions are very difficult, and there is substantial distance between them,'' he said. Among other difficult and unresolved issues, he said, is verification _ or what measures to use to make certain the cutbacks ordered by the treaty are implemented. ``As a matter of treaty drafting, verification is a tremendously time-consuming and difficult task,'' he said. ``So there is a lot of work to be done.'' Under the treaty, ceilings would be set for troops, tanks, artillery, armored personnel carries and helicopters from the Atlantic across the vast expanse of Europe to the Ural Mountains in the Soviet Union. Monitoring compliance ``is immensely more complex'' than dealing with the U.S. and Soviet intermediate-range nuclear missiles that were banned in a treaty in 1988, the official said. Bush on Tuesday called Soviet acceptance of his troop reduction proposal as ``an important breakthrough'' that removes a major obstacle to the treaty. ``Now, let's close the deal. That's what I want to do. Conclude this CFE (Conventional Forces in Europe) agreement and get it done and signed,'' he said. But Bush said, ``there's still some technical problems.''

DOC.HEAD: Reports Circulate That Vietnam Involved Again in Cambodia Conflict
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese forces may be operating again in Cambodia just five months after Hanoi reported all of its troops had been withdrawn for good, according to reports reaching top U.S. officials. The officials said Wednesday the reports indicate renewed Vietnamese involvement in the conflict was the result of battlefield setbacks suffered by the Hanoi-backed government in Cambodia. Representatives of the United States and the four other permanent members of the United Nations Security Council compared notes on the issue on Monday and Tuesday in New York where they discussed ways to advance the Cambodian peace process. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978 and installed a friendly government after ousting the Khmer Rouge regime, which has been held responsible for the deaths of more than 1 million Cambodians during almost four years in power. Under heavy international pressure, Vietnam gradually scaled back its troop deployment and Hanoi officials announced in September that the last of its troops had been withdrawn. The Vietnamese invasion touched off the formation of three Cambodian insurgencies aimed at driving Hanoi's forces from Vietnam. The United States and a number of other interested parties have been attempting to end the conflict through a process ending in free and fair elections. U.S. officials who briefed reporters Wednesday said the Chinese delegate at the New York meeting and two others commented on the purported Vietnamese military role in Cambodia. The officials, asking not to be identified, indicated they considered the reports concerning the Vietnamese presence to be accurate. One participant at the New York meeting, according to the officials, said about 1,000 Vietnamese troops may be operating in the area of Angkor, site of temples and other buildings of historic significance. It was not clear to the officials whether the Vietnamese soldiers had returned to Cambodia or whether they had never left, if indeed the reports of their presence there are accurate. According to the officials, the army of the pro-Vietnamese government of Cambodia has suffered setbacks in the most recent fighting against resistance forces of the Khmer Rouge and of former Cambodian Premier Son Sann. The fighting has tapered off recently but could intensify before the end of the dry season this spring, the sources said. In a bid to end the fighting, the permanent members of the Security Council have been discussing proposals in which the United Nations would provide a peacekeeping force once a cease-fire is agreed to and to play an administrative role in the process leading to free elections. The Bush administration has said prevention of a Khmer Rouge return to power is a major policy objective. Nonetheless, the two resistance groups which the United States supports have formed a tactical alliance with the Khmer Rouge, prompting some critics to warn that U.S. policy could be paving the way for a Khmer Rouge comeback. The Khmer Rouge's main backer is China, which seeks to reduce Vietnamese influence in Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEAD: A Single Germany: No Fear of Jackboots, But Worries Nonetheless
DOC.TEXT: Historians say the world need not fear that German jackboots will echo again on European pavements, but some still see the rush toward German reunification as a setback _ a step away from the integration of Europe. For the most part, the historians say an East Germany collapsing into chaos represents a greater threat to stability than a united German state. ``The West Germans are moving ahead not out of nationalistic fervor, but a perceived need to deal with a crisis,'' said Henry Ashby Turner of Yale, author of ``The Two Germanies Since 1945.'' ``There is no such a thing as indelible national character,'' Turner said. ``I don't think there is any chance that the young men of Germany are going to slip out of their Adidas running shoes and pull on jackboots and start running around saying, `Heil!'' He was one of several experts in German history discussing the implications of reunification following the decision Tuesday by the four World War II allies _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ to accept the reunification of a Germany they divided 45 years ago. University of Chicago historian Michael Geyer, a native of Germany, said he feared the creation of a ``strong, sovereign nation in the center of Europe'' could reverse a more important development _ the 40-year drive toward an integrated Europe in which industries, banks, trade unions and even government ministries have been collaborating across borders. ``The East German state is collapsing,'' said Geyer. ``So something has to happen very dramatically. But they have a choice _ the Europeans and Germans and Americans. Do they want to opt for the European card or for the German card? I think they are opting for the German card.'' ``I hear these days very little about what Gorbachev called `the house of Europe,''' he said. The result of a dominant ``uncomfortably strong'' German state, Geyer added, could be a setback to the diminishment of national borders. It could also mean, he said, that American troops might have to stay in Europe as a counterweight to Germany. ``If I had my druthers reunifications would have happened after 1992, after the integration of the West German economy into the economy of Western Europe,'' said Charles J. Herber of George Washington University, expressing similar concern. ``Then there would have been fewer chances for German adventurers,'' he said. West Germans were aware of their European neighbors' misgivings, said Richard Breitman of American University, and so they presented reunification within the context of European integration. They wanted to avoid arousing fear of a united Germany again dominating Europe. ``Even if the history did not exist, there would be fears of that kind,'' he said. ``We're dealing not just with rational calculation but a whole host of emotional memories.'' For all that, Breitman said, ``One Germany is not only inevitable, but given the successful record of West Germany over the last 40 years, my feeling is it is better than having a regime in chaos.'' ``The only alternative to reunification,'' added Turner, is an East Germany in ruins, ``a basket case, a Bangladesh of Europe.'' He said Germans have ``no significant interest in territorial revisions. Those misgivings are misplaced.'' Gerhard Weinberg of the University of North Carolina, considered a leading historian of the Nazi era, cautioned that reunification, if mishandled, could prove explosive. While the people of West Europe have gotten over nationalistic distrusts, East Europeans, living in closed societies, have not, he said, and fear of Germany is a reality in East Europe and Russia, he said. ``I don't think the Germans are heading for Moscow again, but we have to give people _ and the Germans have to give people _ time to think this through and get used to it. ... Mishandled, reunification could scare one or the other of the participants into starting something and scare others and goodness knows where it would end.'' Gordon Craig, emeritus professor at Stanford, said the division of Germany has been the basis of a peace settlement ``which worked pretty well'' but was ``abnormal and sooner or later had to be corrected.'' German reunification, said Craig, gives the world the chance to build a new international system, one that ``will prevent the use of international violence.'' He added, ``We have to be careful that we don't fall back into the kind of system that existed before the Second World War, a Europe filled with nations that were suffering various grievances, rivalries, disputed frontiers, driven by what they considered to be legitimate reasons but pitted against each other _ the sort of things that gave rise to Hitler in 1933.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Limited Contraceptive Choices Force Sterilization, Abortions
DOC.TEXT: A limited choice of contraceptives in the United States is leading to increases in abortions and voluntary sterilizations, according to a report by the National Research Council. Called ``Developing New Contraceptives,'' the study released Wednesday said Americans have fewer contraceptive choices than in other countries due to government policies that discourage research and product development. The contraceptive methods now available in the United States, the report said, ``leave major gaps in the ability of people to control fertility safely, effectively and in culturally acceptable ways.'' Contraceptives are used at some point in the lives of 95 percent of the 54 million sexually active American women between ages 15 and 44, the report said. It said about 20 percent of this number have been voluntarily sterilized. Among sexually active men with partners at risk of pregnancy, about 15 percent have had vasectomies. ``Limited contraceptive methods force many women and men to make difficult choices _ to have an abortion or to be sterilized at a young age _ that could be avoided if additional safe, effective, acceptable and affordable contraceptives were available,'' the report says. The 193-page report said a greater availability and variety of safe and effective contraceptives could ``significantly reduce the frequency of abortion'' in the United States. One recent study, the report said, ``indicates that as many as half of all unintended pregnancies resulting in abortion were the result of contraceptive failure.'' About one-third of American women at risk for unwanted pregnancies use oral contraceptives, with about 3 percent of the pill-takers becoming pregnant in the first year of use. Three percent of women use intauterine devices, with 6 percent of these having an unintended pregnancy in the first year. The report said condoms continue to be the contraceptive method for 17 percent of the partners of women ages 18 to 49. But it said about 12 percent of these women become pregnant accidentally in the first year of use. For 4 percent to 6 percent of women, the diaphragm is the contraceptive of choice, even though this method has been shown in some studies to have failure rates of up to 23 percent, the report said. Contraceptive sponges, which have a failure rate of 18 percent, are used by 3 percent of the women, and vaginal contraceptives, such as foams, jellies and creams, are used by 2 percent of women, with a 21 percent failure rate, it said. The report said 44 percent of all American women who use contraceptives and who are married for 15 years or longer have been sterilized. Another 24 percent of women are married to men who are sterilized. ``These figures confirm that at some point American women are ready to stop childbearing,'' the NRC report said. ``These data also suggest that there are problems with available temporary (contraceptive) methods.'' The report said regulations by the Food and Drug Administration and the risk of product liability lawsuits have caused all but one of the major U.S. pharmaceutical firms to stop contraceptive research over the last 20 years. As a result, it said, many contraceptive implants, devices and injectables that are available in Europe cannot be sold in this country. Many of the techniques now in use in other countries, the report said, are safer, longer-lasting and more effective than the methods available to Americans. Rigid FDA safety regulations, which evaluate contraceptives by a different standard than is used in Europe, keep products off the market here. The report, for instance, noted the FDA blocked marketing of an injectable contraceptive in this country because the manufacturer could not prove that it was safe. In the United Kingdom, however, the logic was turned around and the product was approved after it could not be demonstrated that it was unsafe. Some companies have halted attempts to market contraceptives in the United States because of stringent product liability laws that can hold manufacturers liable for damages even if a product meets federal food and drug standards. ``Product liability rules can be changed to remove most of their undue negative consequences for contraceptive development without increasing the health risks of contraceptive users,'' the report said. The report was produced jointly by the National Research Council and the Institute of Medicine. Both are affiliated with the National Academy of Sciences, a congressionally chartered private organization that does research for government agencies.

DOC.HEAD: A United Germany's Prospects Look Bright, But Other Nations Have Jitters
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A united Germany will have 77 million people. The two German states now have more than 500,000 soldiers. Within a few years, the economy of a single Germany could overshadow that of any other European nation. Is the world really ready for one Germany? Friends and allies of East and West Germany say ``yes.'' But many of them _including Britain, France and Poland _ have apparently not overcome their unification jitters despite German assurances. The French worry that plans for European unity could be jeopardized and Poland is preoccupied that German conservatives will demand some of its territory. Britain's prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, supports eventual German unity but has recalled the Nazi past by saying Poland and Britain have had experiences this century that ``we are determined should not happen again.'' Europeans are greatly concerned about the economic power a united Germany would eventually wield, said Dominique Moisi, a French specialist in international politics. ``In the short term there will be a slowdown of German initiative and power as the West Germans digest East Germany,'' said Moisi, of the Paris-based French Institute for International Relations. ``But in five to 10 years, economically, we will be confronted with a very strong country.'' In land area alone, a united Germany would be a sizeable presence. Combining East Germany with West Germany would result in a country of more than 137,600 square miles _ smaller than France but still a considerable expanse at Europe's heart. Merging East Germany with West Germany would add 16 million people to the West's population of 61 million. Unification is apt to cause many discomforts for Germans: increased joblessness and factory shutdowns in the East, and a new economic burden for West Germans. Experts say West Germany's rescue of East Germany will cost billions of dollars. But they also say that because of West Germany's financial muscle _ it has Europe's mightiest economy _ and East Germany's industrial potential, the transition may not have to last too long. West German companies like Volkswagen are already launching plans to bring their technical know-how to East Germany, and the signs of giant West German concerns like Siemens could soon be a common sight in the neighboring land. Peter Pietsch, an economist at West Germany's Commerzbank, says there are excellent possibilities for investment in East Germany once free-market economic conditions are established. Allies and friends of the two Germanys have come to accept the inevitability of unification, since the only other option would likely be East Germany's collapse. But fears about a united Germany's strength persist, along with bitter memories of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. Poland's prime minister, Tadeusz Mazowiecki, on Wednesday demanded his country be included in the newly agreed talks on German unification, which are to include the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. President Francois Mitterrand of France has thrown his support behind German unification, but also has words of caution. According to French newspapers, Mitterrand said ``the Germans must remember that we are bound together by certain commitments: security in Europe, the future of the (European Economic) Community and the balance of power in Europe.'' Concerns about a united Germany's military stance also persist. The Soviet Union says a united Germany should be neutral, while the United States insists it should be a part of NATO. West Germany is one of the strongest NATO partners with nearly 400,000 troops. East Germany has about 200,000. Opposition politicians in West Germany have begun calling for troop cutbacks as unification nears. But a united Germany's military might is an open question. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has assured the world that German unity will present no foreign threat. Kohl says German unity will strengthen all of Europe and will be a positive factor in the EEC's plans for a barrier-free internal market by 1992. Moisi, the French political scientist, said European unity will undoubtedly slow as West Germany focuses more on unification. Moreover, he believes that East Germans must learn a sense of European identity, which he contends is shared more by budding East bloc democracies such as Hungary and Poland. ``It is the duty of the West Germans as they swallow East Germany to give them a sense of European identity. If they do so, we will have a stronger Europe. If they don't, we will have a strong Germany within a weak Europe,'' said Moisi.

DOC.HEAD: Thumbnail Sketches of Drug Summit Leaders
With PM-Drug Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are thumbnail sketches of the four hemispheric leaders meeting today at Cartagena, Colombia, to map drug war strategy:
DOC.HEAD: GEORGE BUSH
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has stressed eradication and strict law enforcement rather than education and treatment as the major U.S. weapons in the war against drugs. But Bush was ready to show his three summit partners a national survey showing a steady decline in illegal drug use among U.S. high school students. He was expected to argue that the Bush administration is working to reduce the demand for drugs, a major concern of Latin American nations that produce much of the cocaine and other illicit narcotics that are sold on U.S. streets. The president's safety was a major worry in advance of his scheduled six-hour meeting with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia at a heavily guarded military base outside Cartagena. There were fears that Colombian drug lords might try to attack Bush's entourage. The drug war has been a major feature of Bush administration policy, but his efforts have been criticized as inadequate because the U.S. narcotics trade is still flourishing one year after he took office.
DOC.HEAD: VIRGILIO BARCO
DOC.TEXT: Before President Virgilio Barco of Colombia began an all-out assault against cocaine traffickers last August, most of his countrymen considered him an unlikely commander in the drug war. An engineer and an economist by training, the bespectacled Barco, 68, is a studious man with a halting speaking style often ridiculed by Colombians. Barco was born into a family whose fortune was made in the petroleum industry. A member of the ruling Liberal Party, Barco entered politics 45 years ago as a city councilman in Durania, a small town in eastern Colombia. He was elected to the national congress in 1949 and over the decades built a network of political contacts in Bogota, the capital, as a legislator. Barco served as Colombia's development minister in the late 1950s, was named agriculture minister in 1963, and was mayor of Bogota from 1966 to 1969. In 1986 Barco was elected president for a four-year term ending this August. Polls have shown that while Barco has he has gained international prestige for his hardline stance against drug traffickers, many Colombians disapprove of his performance because of their country's economic difficulties.
DOC.HEAD: ALAN GARCIA
DOC.TEXT: Peruvian President Alan Garcia's trip to Cartagena was one of the last major acts of his roller-coaster presidency before Peruvians choose their head of state in elections scheduled for April 8. Garcia vigorously condemned the U.S. invasion of Panama and said he would boycott the summit if U.S. troops were still in Panama by then. When Bush said U.S. troops would be reduced to pre-invasion levels, Garcia agreed to go to Cartagena. The charismatic young leader came to power in mid-1985 and was hugely popular in the first years of his presidency. Strongly nationalistic, Garcia imposed limits on foreign debt payments, pumped available dollars into Peru's languid economy and produced three years of growth. But the economy faltered when the money ran out. Hyperinflation sent prices skyrocketing and Garcia's popularity plunged. Many blame his populist, free-spending policies for the economic slide, which resulted in 2,775 percent inflation last year and a 10 percent drop in the gross national product. The violent Shining Path guerrilla movement expanded during Garcia's presidency and has gone on the offensive in many parts of Peru.
DOC.HEAD: JAIME PAZ ZAMORA
DOC.TEXT: Bolivian President Jaime Paz Zamora came in third in the May 1989 president elections but took over as Bolivia's 76th president last August with the support of the country's former military dictator, Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez. Paz Zamora, leader of the social democratic movement of the revolutionary left, had been jailed and exiled by Banzer's government. Paz Zamora, 50, the son of a general, studied for the priesthood in Argentina and was educated in Belgium. In the 1970s he was considered a Marxist leader. Since he became president his government's main goal has been to maintain economic stability. On the drug front, Paz Zamora has linked coca leaf eradication to development aid in an effort to ease the disruptions of switching from coca leaf production to other crops. The government says it needs several hundred million dollars to wean farmers away from coca farming to other crops. Paz Zamora says eradication must take place, but without leaving farmers and the rest of the country poorer. He also expelled former Interior Minister Luis Arce Gomez in December to face cocaine trafficking charges in Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Letter Found in Attic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Boucher pronounced bow'-cher
DOC.TEXT: A collector paid $55,000 for a letter by George Washington in which the former president thanks an author for dedicating a book to him, but _ since he cannot tell a lie _ admits he hasn't read it. Charles Hamilton, a handwriting expert and autograph dealer, said Wednesday that the letter was recently discovered in an attic trunk in Cincinnati and sold Tuesday to Joe Maddalana of Beverly Hills, Calif. In the two-page letter, which Washington wrote Aug. 15, 1798, he thanks the Rev. Jonathan Boucher for sending him a copy of Boucher's ``Causes & Consequences of the American `Revolution''' and for dedicating the book to him. But the man who supposedly admitted to chopping down his father's cherry tree also admits he hasn't had time to read the book. Here's how he breaks the news: ``I know not how it happened, but the fact is that your favour of the 8th of Nov. last year is but received; and at a time when both public and private business presses so hard upon me as to afford no leisure to give the (book) ... a perusal.'' Washington wasn't kidding. According to John Riley, a research librarian at the Washington homestead at Mount Vernon, relations between the United States and Napoleonic France were so tense at that time that the old general was officially reactivated briefly. Washington alludes to those troubles, describing France as ``a nation whose intermeddling & restless disposition, and attempts to divide, distract and influence the measures of other countries'' threatens peace. Washington writes that since he hasn't read the book ``it follows of course that I can express no opinion with respect to its political content'' _ an inhibition that, if widely shared, would have severely curtailed cocktail party conversation in the years to come. But he tells Boucher that ``there is no man in either country (England or America) more zealously devoted to Peace and good understanding between the two nations than I am. ... ``PEACE with all the world is my sincere wish. I am sure it is our true policy. And ... the ardent desire of the Government.'' Washington's declarations of love of peace, Hamilton claimed, are what makes the letter ``probably the most important Washington letter still in private hands.'' That's debatable, Riley said. He noted that peace is generally popular, and he cited a 1789 letter still in private hands in which Washington tells Secretary of War Henry Knox that his impending inauguration as president makes him feel ``not unlike a culprit ... going to his execution.'' Dorothy Twohig, another Washington scholar, said the letter is particularly interesting because Boucher was a well-known loyalist who spent time in England during the revolution. She said that although Hamilton sold the original, poor copies of the letter are on file in some libraries. Hamilton said the letter was part of a Cincinnati man's autograph collection that was discovered recently at the late collector's house by his two elderly daughters. The letter was framed and in good condition, he said, except for a small portion which was nibbled away by mice.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Sleeps Aboard Air Force One: `Not a Security Thing'
DOC.TEXT: Question: How does frequent flyer George Bush avoid jet fatigue when he has a pre-dawn flight? Answer: He sleeps on his plane overnight in a heavily guarded airport hangar. That was the solution Bush chose in order to arrive refreshed in Colombia today for a four-nation drug summit. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush's unusual sleeping arrangements had nothing to do with elaborate security precautions surrounding the summit. ``It's a sleep thing, not a security thing,'' Fitzwater said. ``He feels it's the best way for him to get the most sleep without having to wake up in the middle of the night.'' Bush said he did the same thing a few times while he was vice president. To reach Colombia by mid-morning, Air Force One had to take off well before dawn. Bush decided to sleep aboard Air Force One in a hangar at Andrews Air Force Base, Md., instead of waking up early to catch a helicopter flight to the airport. Bush's stateroom on the plane is equipped with a full-size bed. Fitzwater said experience has shown that Bush can sleep right through takeoff.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Surveillance Used as Workplace ``Technological Whip''
DOC.TEXT: Employers use electronic devices to keep tabs on workers at an alarming rate that is increasing stress in the workplace, according to a report released today by a workers' advocacy group. Computers and other electronic equipment are used for several types of worker surveillance, such as allowing employers to listen in on phone calls, count keystrokes and gauge the amount of time workers spend on transactions, said the report by a Cleveland-based group called 9to5, Working Women Education Fund. Computer monitoring _ used to evaluate about 10 million American workers, many times without their knowledge or permission _ has become a ``technological whip'' for keeping workers in line, the report said. Businesses contend monitoring is merely an extension of normal supervision. ``Employer monitoring is a necessary tool for employers to review work progress,'' said Roger Middleton, an attorney for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. He said monitoring is also used to train workers and promote those who perform well. In addition, hidden video cameras serve security functions, he said. Sharon Danann, research director for the group that conducted the report, said a certain degree of monitoring is acceptable, but managers rely too heavily on it to assess workers' efficiency. ``Supervisors seem to go berserk with this stuff. It becomes an overboard effort at control,'' she said. The report included case studies of workers who had complained about job surveillance to the group's ``Computer Spying Hotline'' that was established last year. The studies showed computers are often used by airlines and phone companies to time how long workers spend on the phone with customers. For ticket agents, the computers show how successful the agent was at booking flights. Some hospitals require nurses to carry a small computer for logging data so supervisors will know how much time they spend with each patient, the report said. In addition, a growing number of truck drivers are required to turn in printouts showing their speed, the gears they use and the time and length of their stops, it said. Surveys show that monitored workers are more likely than non-monitored workers to describe their jobs as stressful, the report said. Workers who complained to the hotline believed monitoring too often ``sets up an atmosphere of suspicion and results in heavy-handed and demeaning discipline,'' the report said. A woman who worked as a data entry operator for a manufacturer in Minnesota said the firm used keystroke monitoring to track the number of invoices processed, time per job, keystroke rate and the number of errors. ``I don't think workers should be judged solely by the cold hard data of a computer printout. As a worker, I want to be treated like a human being, not a machine,'' the woman said. A software specialist who worked for a Georgia computer manufacturer said managers could listen to any phone call without notice and tracked the origin and destination of phone calls. Hidden video cameras were in the ceiling and doorways of the work room and in the lunch room, the woman said. Congress is considering a measure that would require employers to give workers prior notice of the types of electronic monitoring that would be used.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Sees Farm Income on the Upswing
DOC.TEXT: A rise in farm income is helping financially pressed rural banks and other lenders recover from the tough 1980s, according to Agriculture Department analysts who forecast further gains this year. ``Barring major weather problems, farm sector adjustments in the last half of the 1980s indicate a more stable farm sector and agricultural credit situation in the early 1990s,'' the department's Economic Research Service said Wednesday. But the agency also cautioned that loan delinquency rates will remain high by historical standards ``because farm financial stress is still present, especially in certain areas adversely affected by weather.'' Farmers appear ready to take on new debt for expansion after years of belt-tightening and paying off heavy debt loads that persisted through much of the 1980s. ``The large paydown in farm debt held by major farm lenders appears to be over, and debt is expected to grow $1 billion to $2 billion in 1990, or approximately 1 percent,'' the report said. ``Borrowing for both real and non-real estate loans should expand in 1990, and creditworthy farmers should have ample access to operating credit.'' As a result banks and other commercial lenders are once again focusing on competitive efforts to attract low-risk borrowers. The economic recovery in agriculture was also reflected in a drop in agricultural bank failures last year to 24, the fewest since 1983, the report said. Net cash income of farmers nationally in 1990 is currently forecast at $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with an estimated $53 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988. That is money left over from gross cash income after paying cash expenses. However, another USDA method shows net farm income _ which takes into account changes in inventory values, depreciation and other factors during a calendar year _ may be in the range of $44 billion to $49 billion, compared with last year's record of $48 billion. For hard-pressed farmers who may not be qualified for loans from banks or other commercial lenders, the report said the Farmers Home Administration could see demand for its direct loans exceed the supply. But FmHA guaranteed loans made by commercial lenders ``should be relatively unchanged'' from last year. ``After steadily increasing throughout the decade, the FmHA's direct farmer (loan) program delinquencies fell slightly to just under $8.7 billion at mid-1989,'' the report said. ``Despite the decline, the share of delinquent loan payments to outstanding loan volume increased to 37.1 percent as loan volume dropped.'' Only 35 percent of FmHA's $3.4 billion available for loan guarantees was obligated in the 1989 fiscal year, reflecting weak demand and greater lending authority, the report said.

Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has created a new senior-level job to coordinate the Agriculture Department's rural development efforts. Yeutter said Wednesday that Walter E. Hill, a former Oklahoma state legislator will be assistant undersecretary for small community and rural development. Since last July, Hill has been special assistant to Roland Vautour, the undersecretary. The new job pays $83,600 a year. Before coming to USDA, Hill served more than 10 years in the Oklahoma House of Representatives. Hill, 47, was born in Liberal, Kan. The Bush administration has been under pressure from many rural advocates, including many in Congress, to push harder on rural development, to help small towns and rural people acquire better living standards. ``The key to development of our rural areas is the proper coordination of programs and policies between local, state and federal governments, and Walt's vast experience will make him a valuable member of our USDA rural development team,'' Yeutter said. Hill has been manager and owner of a 2,000-acre irrigated farm in Beaver and Texas counties since 1973. From 1984 until last year, he also was chairman of the board of Added Assets Inc., an Oklahoma City real estate firm.

The National Farmers Union says drought aid was the major agricultural accomplishment of Congress in 1989. Michael V. Dunn, the NFU's chief lobbyist on Capitol Hill, said the $900 million disaster aid bill for farm losses due to last year's drought was hindered by a dispute about whether the bill should be limited to winter wheat losses or expanded to include general crop losses. ``At the end, the comprehensive approach favored by NFU prevailed,'' Dunn said in a review of 1989 legislation. But there were a number of setbacks, including the failure of Congress to pass rural development legislation. ``It was the Senate which passed a good rural development bill, but the House which failed to get the measure out of committee,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Students Say They'll Take Environmental Concerns to Ballot Box
DOC.TEXT: College students say they are concerned about the environment and many say it will be a factor when they vote, a new survey shows. The National Wildlife Federation, the nation's largest conservation organization, announced the results of a poll of 500 undergraduates in four-year colleges and universities Wednesday. When asked what environmental issues they were familiar with, 96 percent named oil spills, with acid rain and smog in second place at 92 percent. When asked what the most pressing environmental problem was, 23 percent named air pollution, 20 percent ozone depletion and 11 percent trash and garbage. Acid rain was one of the least frequently mentioned at 4 percent, followed by loss of tropical rain forest at 3 percent and global warming at 2 percent. Three out of 10 students said they believed strongly that a candidate's position on protecting the environment would be an important factor in their decisions as voters and additional 41 percent said they felt ``somewhat'' that it would be. Tom Hughes, president of Hughes Research Corp. of Rockville, Md., which conducted the survey, said, ``I think it's going to be one of the issues of the '90's, if not the issue of the '90's. ``This is a large group of people,'' Hughes said. ``There are 8 million in four year colleges and 5 million in two-year colleges. It is also a group with very, very strong concerns.'' Three percent of the students said they were not at all active on environmental issues, 32 percent somewhat inactive and 18 percent somewhat active. An additional 32 percent described themselves as neither active nor inactive. However, 76 percent said they thought there was something they personally could do to help protect the environment, such as not littering, reducing their use of environmentally harmful products and taking part in environmental organizations. Ninety-four percent said they would be willing to pay more for products that are safe for the environment. ``We are tremendously encouraged by these results,'' said Jay B. Hair, president of the federation. ``College students are expressing a deep concern for the environment, and the overwhelming majority are clearly willing to do something about it.'' Sean Captain of Scranton, Pa., a student in the Georgetown University school of foreign service in Washington, described efforts to discourage use of Styrofoam cups on the Georgetown campus. ``Everybody complains about Styrofoam, but they didn't have time to get into it full time,'' he said. ``But when we organized a program to see how we could get rid of it, how it could be done economically and feasibly, we got support.'' Three-quarters of the students said recycling of newspapers, glass and cans should be required by all communities. Asked whether people should be willing to sacrifice environmental quality for economic growth, 42 percent said they disagreed strongly, 28 percent disagreed somewhat, 8 percent agreed strongly, 18 percent agreed somewhat and 4 percent had no opinion. The survey was conducted in November. The students, ranging in age from 17 to 24, were about evenly divided between men and women. The federation said the survey had a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,471.99, up 316.10 points, or 0.85 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Deep Troop Cuts Save Little Money Next Year, Analysts Say
DOC.TEXT: Dramatic cuts in the size of U.S. fighting forces, phased in over the next five years, would do little to help budget writers shrink next year's federal deficit, congressional analysts say. The Congressional Budget Office said in its annual overview of potential spending cuts and tax increases Wednesday that cutting troop strength by one quarter by 1995 would save just $510 million next year from the Bush administration's plans. That would be a small fraction of the $36.5 billion the administration estimates it needs to save to reduce the fiscal 1991 deficit to $64 billion, as required by the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law. The projection for the relatively small savings came as the prospects for an armed confrontation with the Soviet Union and its allies are dropping rapidly, and as Congress prepares to scrutinize the Pentagon for budget savings. The CBO, Congress' budget analysis arm, examined 160 ways to save money. These included a two-year delay in work on the superconducting super collider, the research atom smasher planned for Texas, for a savings of about $100 million next year; a $440 million gain by slightly raising the amount federal workers contribute to their retirement benefits; and a $1.6 billion boost by imposing a 50-cents-per-pound tax on water pollutants. In defense, CBO studied a scenario in which the U.S. military of 2.1 million forces would be reduced by 500,000 men and women by 1995. The first part of the reduction would occur in fiscal 1991 _ which starts Oct. 1 _ with a cut of 60,000 troops. The report said the reduction would save $70 billion over the next five years when compared to the spending that would be necessary to keep pace with the costs of inflation. But that total is probably unrealistically high, since the diminishing threat from Warsaw Pact nations has put pressure on President Bush and Congress to seek reductions in Pentagon spending, rather than increases. The study acknowledged that making such steep reductions over just five years ``could cause significant disruptions.'' The authors said retirements and reduced enlistments would probably not produce enough cuts, making layoffs of career soldiers likely. By reducing U.S. forces by 250,000 troops over the same five years, CBO said $60 million would be saved next year from Bush's current plans, and $38 billion over five years compared to increases with inflation. In his 1991 budget released last month, Bush proposed reducing troop strength by 38,000. The report said canceling further spending for the radar-evading B-2 stealth bomber would save $1.1 billion from an inflation increase. Limiting spending on Star Wars _ the proposed antimissile research system _ to just research, rather than deployment, would save $860 million from an increase with inflation. And retiring all four Navy battleships in 1991, rather than the two the administration plans to mothball, would save $75 million next year. The government would earn $2.8 billion next year by doubling the 16-cent per pack tax on cigarettes. Placing a one-time tax on motor vehicles based on the sulfur oxides and other pollutants they emit, averaging $250 per vehicle, would raise $1.9 billion in 1991. Of the 36 ideas for raising revenues CBO analyzed, none involved cutting the capital gains tax rate, a favorite idea of Bush. In the past, CBO has argued that the proposal loses money in the long run. Bush says cutting taxes paid when real estate and other property is sold would stimulate the economy and produce more revenue for the government. CBO's options, which the agency studies but does not endorse, usually share the same fate that awaits most plans to reduce the deficit: they offend one constituency or another and rarely are enacted into law.

DOC.HEAD: Placido Domingo Sings Samson at Met
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Placido Domingo and Shirley Verrett sang the title roles in ``Samson et Dalila'' when the Metropolitan Opera presented the Saint-Saens opera for the first time this season. Alain Fondary of Paris, who made his Met debut in 1988, sounded rich and authoritative as the high priest before the capacity audience Wednesday night. All three principals were singing their roles at the Met for the first time in this production, which dates from 1964. Charles Dutoit conducted the orchestra, which performed well. The chorus, which is so important in this opera, sounded fine. Domingo sang splendidly, making for a strong, heroic Samson. He made final ringing phrases very stirring and acted effectively. Miss Verrett looked absolutely dazzling. However, the weakness of her singing diminished the dramatic aspects of the tale. She was so shaky that one wondered whether she could finish the opera. Some of her singing wasn't audible. On the plus side, she wasn't shrill and conveyed a honeyed, seductive tone, especially in the lower part of her register. In Act 3, Zachary Solov choreographed a hot dance for a couple in flesh-colored leotards. Kimberly Graves and Richardo Costa were spellbinding, never looking silly. Costa caused gasps _ even from people who'd seen the routine before _ when he swung Graves around and dropped her from the Temple of Dagon altar into the arms of other dancers. Michael Devlin of Chicago and John Macurdy of Detroit were excellent as the Philistine commander Abimelech and the old Hebrew who warns Samson against Dalila. But Samson, who had enjoyed a good look at her, paid no heed.

DOC.BYLINE: Airline Industry: Only `Pockets of Problems' ^By DAVID BRISCOE
DOC.TEXT: Airlines are pleased with a study that finds only ``pockets of problems'' in the industry, but there's concern on Capitol Hill some travelers may be paying too much in cities where there's little competition. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner said the results of a nine-month study of airline competition released Wednesday shows deregulation of the industry a decade ago has brought more service and lower fares. But the report also confirmed congestion and higher fares at some key airports. ``Deregulation has worked and the study clearly points out that competition in the airline industry remains strong ... with only pockets of problems,'' Skinner told a news conference. The problems, he said, include increased congestion at some major airports and 18.7 percent higher-than-average fares at eight hub airports where a single airline dominates. ``If one lives in the pocket of a problem, it's serious,'' said Steve Hilton, spokesman for Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., a strong critic of decreasing airline competition. Hilton said Danforth believes the Transportation Department study adds to evidence of excessive fares on routes where competition is minimal and underscores the need for legislation to increase competition. ``The report shows that deregulation is not delivering to the traveling public fare benefits if you happen to live near a non-competitive airport,'' said Hilton. He said Danforth believes it is ``intolerable to have an industry that is neither regulated nor competitive.'' Several bills are pending in Congress to strengthen government control over airlines and encourage competition. One would restore some government authority to regulate fares and routes. Only about 10 percent of the total passenger hours flown are in the higher fare markets, Skinner said. Passengers generally get better service, including non-stop flights and more frequent flights, for the higher fares, he said. ``Air travelers have benefited under deregulation through more service at lower cost,'' the secretary said. ``How can you complain when 90 percent of people in this country today are flying with discount fares? The number of airlines increased from 30 to 38 between 1978, when airlines were deregulated, and 1984, but there are only 29 large carriers, with eight of them providing 90 percent of the service. The study, which analyzed data from 1979 to 1988, brought criticism from a business travelers group and praise from the airline industry. ``In terms of day-to-day operations and for people who are really biting the bullet and out there flying, I think there are a lot of problems in this report,'' said Margie Crace, president of the National Business Travel Association. She said deregulation has brought delayed flights, lost luggage and ``air fares that are increasing at a rapid rate.'' American Airlines Chairman Robert L. Crandall said the study confirms that deregulation has created ``a strong, vibrant and dynamic marketplace in which to compete.'' He said it has saved consumers over $100 million in 10 years with a wide range of discount fares and has given smaller communities ``air service they would get no other way.'' Robert Aaronson, president of the Air Transport Association, which represents major carriers, said the study underscores the healthy competition among airlines and ``demonstrates that there is no basis to reregulate the industry in any way.'' A study conducted last year for the association concluded there was no correlation between high fares and the reduced number of airlines or the concentration of airlines around hubs through which they feed most of their flights. The DOT study, however, said fares at eight airports where a single carrier has established an operating hub averaged were higher than fares at other airports. A more limited study by Congress' General Accounting Office last year also found higher fares in and out of hubs. Airlines set up hub operations to consolidate their operations at one airport, saving administrative and maintenance costs. The most concentrated hubs are Minneapolis, Cincinnati, Dayton, St. Louis, Pittsburgh, Memphis, Salt Lake City and Charlotte, N.C. Fares also are higher for flights to larger cities between 250 and 1,000 miles from these hubs, the report said. Fares overall have increased 14 percent since deregulation, but that represents a decline when adjusted for inflation, the study said.

DOC.HEAD: Oscar Voters Favor Predictable Over the Daring
DOC.TEXT: Oscar voters all but ignored acclaimed, daring films like ``Drugstore Cowboy,'' and ``Do the Right Thing'' and cast their lots for mainstream titles such as ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' At the same time, the voters overlooked the year's box-office blockbusters ``Batman,'' ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' and ``Lethal Weapon 2.'' The nominations by the more than 4,700 members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences suggested that if independent filmmakers were looking for praise from Hollywood, they were looking in the wrong place. ``Do the Right Thing,'' writer-director Spike Lee's fiery account of racial confrontation in New York City, landed on 81 film critics' top 10 lists, and took the best picture, best director and best music awards from the Los Angeles Film Critics Association.
