Yet when nominations for the 62nd Academy Awards were announced Wednesday, ``Do the Right Thing'' could do no right, collecting just two nominations _ supporting actor for Danny Aiello and original screenplay for Lee. ``In a little way I'm happy, in a little way I'm disappointed,'' Lee said. ``We got jerked outta best director, best film, I think my cinematographer ... did a great job, I think my editor did a great job. ... I know in my heart that my father, Bill Lee, deserved a nomination for best score.'' While ``Do the Right Thing'' was financed and distributed by Universal Pictures, the film's inventive style and rough tone ran against the Hollywood grain. So did ``Drugstore Cowboy'' and ``sex, lies and videotape,'' both made and distributed outside the studio system. ``Drugstore Cowboy,'' a gritty examination of drug addicts on the lam, was named film of the year by the National Society of Film Critics. It collected no Oscar nominations. ``Sex, lies and videotape,'' the provocative character study considered one of the decade's most successful independent films, took the top prize at last year's Cannes film festival. Academy voters gave it just one nomination, for best original screenplay. Among the more unconventional movies collecting multiple nominations were ``My Left Foot'' with five nominations and ``Henry V'' with three. The blockbusters _ ``Batman,'' ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' ``Lethal Weapon 2,'' ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids'' and ``Look Who's Talking'' _ captured only five nominations combined. ``Batman'' co-star Jack Nicholson wasn't nominated, and music composer Danny Elfman was shut out, too. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' focusing on a difficult Southern Jewish widow and her black chauffeur, carried off the most nominations, nine, including best picture and best actors for Morgan Freeman, Jessica Tandy and Dan Aykroyd. Aykroyd's nomination was one of most unusual, as the actor has rarely been taken seriously in the critical community. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' director Oliver Stone's account of Ron Kovic's painful passage from blind patriotism to anti-war protester after a Vietnam war wound that left him a paraplegic, drew eight nominations, including best picture. Also nominated for top picture were ``Dead Poets Society,'' ``Field of Dreams'' and ``My Left Foot.'' ``My Left Foot'' best supporting actress nominee Brenda Fricker said from Ireland that she was surprised, and her comments hinted at the wide gulf separating the Academy from the critical community. ``I had won the Los Angeles Film Critics' awards, and thought, well, in the film center of the world, the critics said you've done something right. It never crossed my mind for one second I would be nominated,'' she said. In the studio race, Universal led all comers with 17 nominations, 20th Century Fox and Warner Bros. had 11, Tri-Star collected nine, Paramount and Disney had eight, Miramax seven, Orion six, Columbia five, Samuel Goldwyn three and MGM-UA collected one. For the second time in two years, voters did not nominate the year's most acclaimed documentary. ``Roger & Me,'' filmmaker Michael Moore's satirical perspective on General Motors and the people of Flint, Mich., was overlooked. In 1989, the Academy failed to nominate Errol Morris' ``The Thin Blue Line,'' which led to freedom for Randall Dale Adams after more than a decade on Texas' death row. The winners, selected by members of the academy, will be presented March 26 and broadcast live by ABC-TV.

DOC.HEAD: As Reunification Process Picks Up Steam, Bonn Offers Limited Aid
DOC.TEXT: Its unification drive bolstered by the Allied agreement in Ottawa, West Germany is giving crippled East Germany $3.6 billion in immediate aid to tide it over until free elections next month. Another $1 billion will go to resettle some of the hundreds of thousands of East Germans who have abandoned their homeland and fled to the West. The amount of aid fell far short of what East German Premier Hans Modrow had requested. West Germany made it clear it would not commit more funds until after the March 18 balloting, the first free elections for a country founded as a Communist state 40 years ago. Though the money is earmarked for specific East German programs, none of it will go directly to the government of the Communist premier, who likely will be ousted by voters. Several East German Cabinet members who accompanied Modrow for two days of talks in Bonn were displeased with how the delegation was received; one described the tone of the talks as ``somewhat condescending.'' Modrow had requested $9 billion in immediate direct aid on Tuesday but was turned down by the government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The two-day summit in Bonn, which ended Wednesday, was overshadowed by the landmark agreement in Ottawa by the Soviet Union, the United States, France and Britain that sets up a procedure for formal talks on reunification. The agreement by the four World War II Allies that defeated and divided Germany 45 years ago is the first step to a timetable for unification and clear recognition that such a merger is inevitable. The talks will take place in two parts. The two Germanys first will discuss merging their economies and other domestic issues. The second phase, to include the four wartime powers, will deal with the strategic and global implications of a united Germany, particularly its military allegiance. During the talks between the Germanys, West Germany has a commanding position because of its vibrant economy, which will be needed to bail out the financially ailing eastern state. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said Wednesday that the government agreed at a Cabinet meeting to spend $2.4 billion to modernize East Germany's aging factories, repair roads, install a new phone system and other ``immediate measures.'' The 1990 budget supplement also provides $1 billion to cope with the costs of tens of thousands of East Germans resettling in West Germany and another $1.2 billion for a contingency fund for unforeseen expenses related to East German reforms. Officials said the funds were designated for specific projects and would not be at Modrow's disposal to cover daily expenses and the East German government's mounting debts. Modrow, whose interim government includes non-Communists and opposition figures, lacked a consensus in his Cabinet to reach any significant agreement on West Germany's plan to unify the two countries' economies. Modrow and Kohl agreed only to set up a commission to study the issue. Such a step would make the mighty West German mark East Germany's currency. East Germans are concerned about protecting their savings, social security benefits and subsidized rents, and are also worried about massive unemployment expected to result form such a move. West Germany has pressed Modrow's government to introduce radical free-market reforms before pouring massive aid into East Germany. The East German government, while making cautious moves to free the economy, has resisted going further with capitalist reform. The main stumbling block to a unified Germany is expected to be a decision on its military alignment. The Soviets want it to be neutral, while the West expects it to be part of NATO, the Western alliance that includes West Germany. Poland, twice conquered by Germany, has insisted that it be allowed to take part in the reunification talks. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has called for a peace treaty recognizing the present Polish-German border. German unification became more than an oft-spoken idea after a popular revolution last fall ousted East Germany's hard-line Communist leaders, opened the Berlin Wall and led to democratic reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers to Consider Changes in Deposit Insurance Ceiling
DOC.TEXT: Congress is taking the first tentative step toward considering changes in federal deposit insurance, an issue regarded as too hot to handle in last year's savings and loan bailout. Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas, chairman of the House Banking Committee, scheduled a hearing on the subject Feb. 21, saying Wednesday, ``Congress should not regard the $100,000 per account insurance as a divine right.'' The hearing, with Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. Chairman L. William Seidman and General Accounting Office head Charles A. Bowsher, promises to be the opening shot in the most explosive financial industry question before Congress in the next few years. Many private experts say deposit insurance helped encourage the risky behavior that created mammoth S&L losses. But others fear tinkering with the insurance could destabilize the entire financial system, making banks much more prone to runs by depositors. Last year, Congress did not even consider changing the $100,000 limit, postponing the question by ordering the Treasury Department and GAO to prepare comprehensive studies of the subject. Federal insurance of accounts up to $2,500 began in 1934. Over the years, the limit was raised, with the last big step, from $40,000 to $100,000, coming in 1980. Gonzalez said few people have bank accounts that large and questioned ``the public policy of government guarantees for the most affluent in the society.'' Coverage of $100,000 ``was enacted under great secrecy ... in 1980 and was never fully examined,'' he said in a statement. ``Not only do we need to examine the absolute limits of the coverage, but to determine whether the multiple accounts maintained by some depositors are unnecessarily increasing the risks to the funds.'' Congress isn't expected to act until next year after completion of the Treasury and GAO studies, but already the battle lines are being drawn. Small banks, in particular, are opposing any reduction of deposit insurance. They argue that, no matter what the rules, big banks would continue to enjoy de facto protection because regulators will bail them out rather than risk the collapse of the banking system. Two weeks ago, budget director Richard Darman, in the administration's 1991 budget, suggested consideration of several sweeping reforms. Without endorsing any option, Darman listed a range of possible changes, including: _scrupulously enforcing the existing $100,000 limit and forcing big depositors and other creditors to accept some loss. _forcing all depositors to bear some loss through a deductible. _allowing insured deposits to be used for only a limited range of safe investments. _charging banks with risky investments a higher deposit insurance premium. _making the government the ``catastrophic'' insurer that steps in only after the failure of private insurance. ``Darman has laid out the system he would like to see and it's very different from the system we have now,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association of America. ``Financial confidence is a very fragile commodity and I really think if you begin (changing) deposit insurance, you're undermining the stability of our financial system,'' Guenther said. However, President Bush's economic report, issued last week by White House economic adviser Michael Boskin, says deposit insurance ``can encourage excessive risk taking'' but also has ``worked very well in preventing ... panics.'' The only reform option mentioned by Boskin is charging higher insurance premiums to banks posing a greater hazard to the insurance fund. Last fall, in hearings conducted by Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., chairman of the panel's financial institutions subcommittee, private analysts said the commercial bank insurance fund, although solvent, is dangerously weak. Seidman, however, has said there are enough reserves to cover foreseeable bank failures.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Blacks More Susceptible than Whites to Tuberculosis
DOC.TEXT: Black Americans suffer six times more tuberculosis than whites do, and one important reason appears to be a genetic susceptibility to the disease, according to a study today. The research found that when living conditions are identical, black people are twice as likely as whites to get infected with the TB bacteria. The relatively high rate of TB among blacks has traditionally been blamed on crowded housing and other conditions of poverty. While social factors undoubtedly play a central role, the study suggests that innate susceptibility also contributes. ``We found that there is a systemic difference between whites and blacks,'' said Dr. William W. Stead. ``Whites seem to be more able to fend off the organism without it's ever being able to establish an infection.'' Stead, a tuberculosis specialist at the Arkansas Department of Health, discovered the racial difference while analyzing health statistics from nursing homes and prisons. ``It's a very intriguing finding,'' commented Dr. George Comstock of Johns Hopkins University. ``I never quite believe anything until somebody replicates it. But I don't know of any real holes in this one.'' At the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Dr. George Curlin called the findings ``plausible and provocative.'' However, he added: ``I'm scared to death that people are going to say this explains it all and forget everything else. Of the total six times difference, what proportion is attributable to biology and what to social factors? I would say that biology is relatively minor.'' Stead's study, published in the New England Journal of Medicine, was based largely on a review of 25,398 elderly people who were free of TB infection when they were admitted to Arkansas nursing homes. When they were retested at least two months later, 14 percent of blacks and 7 percent of whites showed evidence of new infections. Prison data from Arkansas and Minnesota also found that black inmates were twice as likely as white prisoners to catch the bacteria while incarcerated. Another soon-to-be published study reports the discovery of a racial difference in the way blood cells respond to the TB bacteria, which could help explain why blacks seem to be more prone to tuberculosis. About 22,000 cases of tuberculosis are reported annually in the United States, resulting in 1,700 deaths. In the population at large, tuberculosis is about six times as common among blacks as whites. An estimated 10 million Americans are believed to be infected with the bacteria but not sick. The disease, which attacks the lungs, has long been associated with poor, crowded living conditions. Stead's study found that blacks got infected more readily than whites, regardless of the race of the person who initially brought the infection into the nursing home. In homes where the initial source of the disease was white, 17 percent of blacks and 12 percent of whites caught the infection. When the primary source was black, 12 percent of blacks and 8 percent of whites contracted the bacteria. This phase of the study also suggests, however, that infected whites are more potent spreaders of the infection than are blacks. Stead speculated that whites have evolved better defenses against TB, because the bacteria has long been common in Europe and parts of Africa north of the Sahara, but is traditionally rare in sub-Saharan Africa. By contrast, blacks are genetically more resistant than whites to malaria, which is common in Africa. In the other study, Dr. Alfred Crowle of Webb-Waring Lung Institute at the University of Colorado found differences in the resistance of germ-eating blood cells called macrophages. In blacks, these cells are more likely to harbor TB infections. ``This helps explain why black people are more susceptible to tuberculosis than are white people,'' said Crowle. At the turn of the century, TB was the nation's leading cause of death. The number of cases fell steadily in recent decades until 1984. Experts believe the decline has leveled off in part because of the emergence of the AIDS virus, which weaken the body's resistance to TB bacteria. Others possible factors include homelessness and immigration of people from areas where the disease is still common.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Reassures Koreans While Bush Weighs in on Aquino
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs grafs 11-15, previously beginning ``Cheney is xxx, with two new grafs, now beginning, ``Officials traveling xxx to update with new troop withdrawal figures
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney promised ``unequivocal'' support for South Korea Wednesday while bracing for a cooler reception in the Philippines. President Bush offered ``a little free advice'' to Corazon Aquino, who has pointedly declined to meet Cheney when he arrives this weekend. Cheney's trip to Seoul was the first leg on a two-week tour designed to reassess the U.S. military posture in Asia and the Pacific _ including talks on reducing the numbers of American troops and getting the allies to pay more for their support. But with Cheney's visit to Manila still days away, Bush signaled his displeasure with the Philippines president for saying she wouldn't meet with Cheney after his arrival Monday. ``She clearly feels that a visit at this time might complicate the status quo there today in the Philippines and that's her right to see or not see who she wants,'' Bush said. ``My own view is that she can learn a great deal from Dick Cheney about the way we view the very important United States presence in the Pacific,'' Bush said in an interview with Newsday. Saying he would offer Mrs. Aquino ``a little free advice,'' Bush said, ``Maybe you could learn from the man _ or he could learn from you, Madam President.'' Cheney arrives in the Philippines on Sunday after a stopover Saturday in Hong Kong. He also will visit Japan before returning to Washington Feb. 24. Upon arrival late Wednesday, Cheney hastened to reassure his South Korean counterpart, Lee Sang Hoon, of America's intention to help support the South against any threat from communist North Korea. ``The U.S. commitment to Korea remains firm and unequivocal. U.S. troops will remain in Korea as long as they are needed to guarantee the peace and the Korean and American peoples and governments want them to remain,'' Cheney said following a review of a color guard by Korean troops at the Seoul air base. Cheney also offered assurances that there would be no ``drastic reduction'' of the 43,000 U.S. troops that have been based in Korea under a 1954 mutual defense treaty. Officials traveling with Cheney said he told South Korean officials the Pentagon wants to slash its forces in Asia by 10 percent to 12 percent _ at least 12,000 troops _ over the next three years. They said said some 5,000 of the troops would be pulled out of South Korea, with an additional 7,000 to 9,400 being withdrawn from the Philippines and Japan. There are 120,000 U.S. troops based in the three nations. A senior Pentagon official told reporters the secretary and his delegation also intend to ask South Korea to increase its $300 million annual contribution to the U.S. defense to around $700 million by 1993. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said he expected the discussion to be ``a very difficult one'' for both sides and that no resolution was anticipated during the secretary's visit. The official said he thought a final decision on any increased South Korean contribution may not be hammered out until another round of discussions, scheduled for fall. The official said the delegation intends to suggest some numbers to the South Koreans but he didn't expect a resolution until October. The official said the Asian nations hosting U.S. forces ``are very sensitive to being pushed around about money.'' ``The important thing is the trend. Are they moving in the right direction?'' the official said, describing the negotiations as ``sort of a Kabuki,'' referring to the stylized Japanese drama. Cheney is slated to spend three days in Korea, meeting with U.S. and Korean military officials as well as South Korean President Roh Tae Woo. He is also slated to spend a day traveling north of Seoul to the demilitarized zone to observe the barriers separating North and South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Farmers Say They Want to Keep Program; Congressmen Say Changes Needed
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Agriculture Committee says the president's proposal to scrap federal spending on crop insurance will force Congress to restructure the program this year. ``I say the program as it now stands is dead, but not the concept of crop insurance with federal involvement, restructured hopefully in a better way,'' Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said Wednesday. De la Garza said a Bush administration plan to eliminate the program was ``forcing our hand'' into enacting reforms. Although President Bush proposed scrapping federal participation in the multimillion-dollar crop insurance program in his 1991 budget, the administration is now backing away from that recommendation. ``President Bush does not necessarily favor elimination,'' Cooper Evans, the president's agriculture adviser, said Wednesday. ``This action was a good way to get Congress's attention'' to the need for changes. ``There aren't too terribly many happy with the way it's working now, including the administration, so it's probably just as well that they used the budget so that kind of helped us to work and come up with a better program,'' de la Garza said. Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., chairman of the House Agriculture subcommittee on conservation, credit and rural development, is preparing to introduce legislation to restructure crop insurance, an aide said. The federal government spends about $450 million to $500 million a year for its share of the crop insurance program as Congress has been approving almost yearly disaster relief legislation to bail out farmers whose uninsured crops were destroyed by extreme weather. Bush's proposal to scrap the program appears to be unsettling farmers as well as farm belt lawmakers. One complaint has been that the premiums are too high and the coverage too low. The Bush administration and members of Congress say farmers have also been wary of buying crop insurance because of Congress' willingness to spend huge sums on disaster relief. Evans said the Bush administration's believes the government can't continue to fund the expensive crop insurance program at the same time Congress passes yearly disaster bills. ``It's fair to say on the administration's side that it isn't clear to us how a pure crop insurance program can preclude the Congress from doing disaster bills when it sees fit,'' Evans said. About half of all acres in production in 1989 were covered by crop insurance, said Kellye Eversole, executive director of the Crop Insurance Study commission, up from about 30 percent to 35 percent in 1988. But part of the increase was due to a requirement that farmers receiving disaster aid in 1988 take crop insurance in 1989. Rep. Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas, said members of Agriculture Committee have ``accepted the fact'' that the program must be reformed. ``The question is, how do you pay for it,'' said Sarpalius.

DOC.HEAD: Slain Family an Example of Increasing Violent Crime
DOC.TEXT: The slayings were horrifying _ a couple and their two children bound hand and foot, shot in the back of the head, doused with gasoline and set on fire in their suburban dream house. The motive was heartbreaking. Robbery. The take: a pair of women's sneakers and some underwear, diamond earrings, a television and VCR and $200 cash. With one suspect killed in a police shootout and another in custody but not talking, police remain baffled by the brutality of the slayings. But criminal justice experts say seemingly random crimes are becoming more common in this country as a society obsessed with feeling good becomes desensitized to violence. ``More and more we see criminals who are willing to use lethal force if necessary,'' said James Alan Fox, professor of criminal justice at Boston's Northeastern University. ``To a sociopath, even $5 could be more important than the lives of four people.'' State police allege that robbery was the motive that led Michael Kinge and his mother to the large gray house in the affluent Ellis Hollow community the night of Dec. 22. Credit cards and a bank access card taken from the home were later used to make about $1,650 worth of purchases at malls in suburban Syracuse and Auburn and to withdraw $200 from a cash machine. But the robbers decided to leave no witnesses, Capt. Carl Shaver said. Pillowcases were tied over the heads of Dolores and Warren A. ``Tony'' Harris and their 11-year-old son, Marc. Their feet and hands were bound, and each was shot in the back of the head. The Harrises' 15-year-old daughter, Shelby, was found in a different room. She had been sexually assaulted before being shot in the head. Michael Kinge, who would have been charged with the family's murders, died in a shootout Feb. 7 as police tried to arrest him at his Dryden apartment. His 54-year-old mother, Shirley, a petite woman with gray-streaked hair, was arrested and charged with arson, murder and possession of stolen property. Police say she has told them little. The involvement of Mrs. Kinge, a cook and cleaner with no criminal record, remains unclear. Police said her fingerprint was found on a gasoline can at the crime scene, but they have not said whether she took part in the killings or even if she was in the house when they occurred. Dryden Town Judge Edwin Sweetland on Tuesday ordered Mrs. Kinge held in lieu of $25,000 cash bail or $50,000 property bond on the arson charge. But because prosecutors presented no evidence on the murder and stolen property charges, Sweetland said Mrs. Kinge could be released on her own recognizance on those charges if she raised the bail for the arson charge. Michael Kinge had run afoul of the law before. The 33-year-old sometime maintenance worker had a record of arrests for burglary and robbery. After a 1982 arrest for weapons possession, Kinge told police he regretted not ``shooting it out'' with the arresting officer and killing as many police as possible, said state police Superintendent Thomas Constantine. Jack Levin, a sociologist at Northeastern University and co-author with Fox of a book on mass murder, said the brutality and precision of the Harris slayings suggests a killer who took pleasure in causing pain. FBI statistics show the incidence of violent crime _ rapes, murders, robberies and aggravated assaults _ has climbed by 18 percent during the past five years. Local officials backed up those statistics. ``We've seen more robberies, more injuries during the course of robberies, and more violent homicides where the victims are tortured,'' said Howard Relin, Monroe County district attorney. Much of that increase is drug-related, though police say drugs apparently were not a factor in the Harris killings. Officials also blame other factors _ violence on television and movies and the disintegration of societal restraints. Fox and Levin say the pop psychology messages of ``guilt is bad'' and ``be assertive'' have led to a more sociopathic society in which people feel little concern for others. ``For those who already lack the capacity for remorse, who lack a strong moral sense of what is right or wrong, this is giving them license to commit hideous crimes,'' Levin said. ``It used to be `I'm OK, you're OK,''' Fox said. ``Now it's `I'm OK and you're dead.'''

DOC.HEAD: Students Taking Longer to Finish
DOC.TEXT: College students are taking six to 10 years to earn a degree, according to a study that says only 15 percent complete a bachelor's degree four years after high school. ``The picture of the average American college student today is not the picture that many of us have in our minds, based upon our own experiences 15, 20 and 25 years ago,'' said Oscar F. Porter, author of the study released Wednesday. ``It's clear that completing an undergraduate college degree in four years is not the norm in either the public or independent sector,'' he said. The National Institute of Independent Colleges and Universities said the survey showed that six years after high school graduation, 46 percent of the students had earned a degree. Counting both those who went straight to college and those who took some time off after high school, 55 percent had either earned a degree or were still working on one six years after high school graduation. ``While students in the independent sector are more likely to have completed their degrees in the traditional four years than students in the public sector, the overall degree completion rate offers little solace for either sector,'' Porter added. Among private colleges, 54 percent of students who enrolled straight out of high school completed the degree in six years; for public institutions, 43 percent finished in six years. The study noted a half-century of research has shown a remarkable stability in the fraction of students starting college who win a degree _ about 50 percent. But Institute President Richard Rosser said it took less time in the 1950s and 1960s. However, he offered no figures from those decades for comparison. ``The (completion) rates are historically still essentially the same,'' said Rosser. ``We'll probably see many more students taking 10 years to complete a degree,'' he added. The study drew its conclusions from the Education Department's ``High School and Beyond'' data base, a national survey of what happened to 28,000 high school seniors in the class of 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Close Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar closed higher agaisnt the yen Thursday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange surged. The dollar closed at 144.45 yen, up 0.10 yen from Wednesday's 144.35-yen finish. It opened at 144.58 yen and ranged between 144.42 yen and 144.75 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 316.10 points, or 0.85 percent, closing at 27,471.99. It rose 48.86 points Wednesday. Dealers attributed the stock index's jump to opinion polls released by major Japanese newspapers showing a probable victory for the governing Liberal Democratic Party in Sunday's national election. ``Reassured by the polls, many market players became quite optimistic about the election results, which boosted buying,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a dealer with Daiwa Securities Co. The market's major concern has been whether the pro-business governing party can maintain its control of the lower house of Japan's parliament, which is up for grabs in the election. The party lost its majority in the upper house last summer. In currency dealings, the dollar strengthened as market players reckoned little fallout from the bankruptcy filing of Drexel Burnham Lambert would hit Japanese financial markets, traders said. A Bank of Tokyo dealer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the U.S. currency's trend was not strong, as the majority of market players stayed on the sidelines.

DOC.HEAD: `Senior Prom' a Success, at Least for the Men
DOC.TEXT: Ten elderly men danced the night away when 80 female senior citizens showed up for a Valentine's Day ``Senior Prom'' staged by Indiana High School. ``We brought in some teachers and some of the students to dance with the ladies,'' economics teacher Fred Yun said Wednesday night. ``We've been trying to spread ourselves around, but we're really kind of outnumbered.'' About 90 senior citizens attended the event, which was staged by the school's Key Club, a service organization sponsored by Yun. The school is about 45 miles northeast of Pittsburgh. Students served meat loaf, salad, vegetables and cake in the cafeteria. After dinner, one student put on a magic show. High school singers serenaded the crowd with love songs. ``I think everybody here's having a good time,'' Yun said. ``They all say they're going to come back next year, so we'll have a lot more.''

DOC.HEAD: Death Penalty Extended for Drug Traffickers
DOC.TEXT: Singapore intensified its anti-drug campaign today by extending the death penalty to cover traffickers in cocaine, opium and marijuana. Execution by hanging is now mandatory for those convicted of trafficking, manufacturing, importing or exporting more than 1.06 ounces of cocaine, 17.6 ounces of marijuana, 7.05 ounces of hashish and 2.6 pounds of opium. Under the new law, possession of those amounts is equated with trafficking. ``We have contained the drug problem but it has not been eradicated. Drugs are still quite readily available in the region,'' said Poh Geok Ek, director the Central Narcotics Bureau. Before the law was amended, the death penalty applied only to people convicted of trafficking in more than half an ounce of heroin and more than 1.06 ounces of morphine. ``We recognize the potential of addicts going for substitute drugs,'' said Poh. ``That is why there is a need for stiffer punishment for cocaine, cannabis and opium offenses.'' The drug law was amended Nov. 30 by Parliament, and it took effect today. Since 1975, 37 people have been sentenced to death under the law and 26 hanged. Home Affairs Minister Shunmugam Jayakumar said extending the death penalty would cut the inflow of marijuana and help deal with Singapore's drug problem. Narcotics experts said addicts in the country of 2.6 million often start using marijuana before switching to heroin. Officials estimate there are 9,000 addicts, about 85 percent of them using smokeable heroin. By extending the death penalty to include other drugs, the authorities also hope to deter international crime syndicates from using Singapore as a relay point for shipments to other countries. Southeast Asia is the main supplier of heroin smuggled into the United States and a leading supplier to Europe. Most of it comes from eastern Burma, Thailand and northern Laos, a region known as the ``Golden Triangle.'' Opium use has a long history in the region, especially among migrant Chinese laborers imported by the British, who controlled the opium trade early in this century. There were about 75,000 registered opium smokers at the time it was outlawed after World War II.

DOC.HEAD: After Seven Years, Times Beach Cleanup May Be Ready to Begin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Nelson said his ...' to CORRECT tense
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto ST4
DOC.TEXT: Times Beach has been a boarded-up ghost town since the federal government bought up all 801 homes and businesses seven years ago and moved the people out after the discovery of dioxin. Now, the government is finally close to building a huge incinerator to clean up the highly toxic compound and heal the deserted town, a grim reminder to former residents of lives turned upside down by their evacuation. The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency plans to burn all the soil that was contaminated in the 1970s by dioxin-tainted oil sprayed on unpaved streets to keep the dust down. The agency also wants to treat contaminated soil from other sites in eastern Missouri, leaving it almost 100 percent clean. It says the incinerator would be dismantled afterward, but a vocal contingent of neighbors who fear for their safety is trying to block the incinerator, which they say will become a permanent fixture. ``It's spooky,'' said Eureka Mayor Otis Nelson. ``How would you like to live next to it? How would you like to encourage development next to it?'' Nelson is so concerned he's advocating that his town annex the neighboring wasteland of Times Beach to gain some leverage about what happens there, even though it would mean increased liability. ``We have no choice but to take that risk,'' Nelson said. Former residents of the community, about 20 miles southwest of St. Louis, just want the cleanup to begin, which all sides agree is long overdue. ``If this cleanup doesn't take place, I'm afraid Times Beach is still going to be sitting there like it is today, five to 10 years down the road,'' said Marilyn Leistner, a former mayor. ``It's been eight years. Something needs to be done.'' Dioxin, an unwanted byproduct in the manufacture of other chemicals, is suspected of causing disorders of the nervous system, liver, kidneys and bladder. It also has been linked to cancer in laboratory animals. Beth-ann Eichenser, an EPA spokeswoman, said the incinerator plans were too far along to be threatened by last-minute opposition from Nelson's Times Beach Environmental Task Force. Nelson said his group opposed the incinerator, to be built alongside the Meramec River, because it would be vulnerable to flooding and because of fears that the EPA might not dismantle it, thus making Times Beach the nation's dioxin dump. ``We feel that once this incinerator gets here, it'll never leave. There's no doubt in my mind that it'd be permanent,'' Nelson said. ``Maybe they do need a permanent incinerator. But is St. Louis County the place to put it? This makes no sense.'' Nelson said he has received support from other municipalities and residents. A rally is scheduled this month. Bills have been introduced in the Legislature to prohibit the building of an incinerator in a flood plain and within five miles of a school. Nelson's group wants the EPA to either bury the soil in a permanent container or use a commercial incinerator that already exists in Sauget, Ill., across the Mississippi River from St. Louis. Eichenser said work could begin as early as summer on the $118 million cleanup, which could take 10 years. ``I know that there are many residents in Eureka who say, `Well, it's in our backyard.' But Times Beach is 400 acres of unpopulated land. It's a viable, obvious location to do this project,'' Eichenser said. ``People view incinerators like Chernobyl,'' she said. ``They think it's going to blow up and dirt will fly everywhere. This would be safe.'' The EPA said the so-called thermal treatment unit would ``roast'' the contaminated dirt, breaking the dioxin molecules into carbon, oxygen, chlorine and hydrogen. Eichenser said the treated soil would be 99.999 percent clean and could be turned back into regular soil. Eichenser said the incinerator, which would process soil from Times Beach and up to 27 other eastern Missouri sites, would be surrounded by a levee to protect it from floodwaters. Flooding is a big part of Times Beach, which sprung up in the 1900s as a weekend retreat for St. Louis residents. The worst flood came at the end of 1982. Rain had fallen for days, but many residents were caught by surprise and forced to flee when the Meramec spilled it banks, reaching the second floor of homes. Many residents never returned. Days later, the Centers for Disease Control and the Missouri Divison of Health announced the dioxin findings and recommended that the town be evacuated. The town officially ceased to exist when Times Beach's alderman voted to disincorporate in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: FCC Rule Change Would Allow Dial-A-Porn Under Limited Conditions
DOC.TEXT: Dial-a-porn services could transmit to adults by telephone, with certain restrictions, under pending Federal Communications Commission rules drawn to Supreme Court standards. The services would have to require credit card payments, issue access codes, scramble their messages and ask telephone companies to list 900 calls to their services on customers' bills. The FCC is seeking public comment by March 2 on the rules, which the commission first adopted in 1987. Congress, concerned that the rules were not tough enough to prevent enterprising youths from gaining access to the sex messages, banned dial-a-porn services outright in April 1988 but the Supreme Court overturned the ban, saying the statute could apply only to commercial material that was judged obscene, not merely indecent. The court said the technological safeguards proposed by the FCC were enough to ensure that minors would not reach the dial-a-porn services and, therefore, the government was left with no compelling reason to ban such calls for adults.
DOC.HEAD: Toymaker Recalls Doll Cradles
DOC.TEXT: A toy manufacturer says it will replace the cradle sold with a doll it makes because small parts may break off and pose a choking hazard. The New York-based Uneeda Doll Co., Inc., will voluntarily replace the cradles from the approximately 161,245 ``Tots 'N Toys in Cradle'' sets sold nationwide since 1988, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday. The commission said the sets, model number 70620, consist of a six-inch doll in a seven-inch by }-inch yellow plastic cradle whose rockers are embossed ``Uneeda Doll Co., Inc, MCMLXXXVII, Made in China.'' Neither the agency nor the manufacturer is aware of any injuries or complaints involving the cradles, which customers should return to the company at 269 37th St., Brooklyn, N.Y. or call 718-768-9200.
DOC.HEAD: FDA Approves Drug to Ease Symptoms of Reproductive Disorder
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a new drug that relieves the symptoms of endometriosis, a disorder of the reproductive tract that affects more than 4 million U.S. women. The drug, Synarel, is the first drug of its class to be approved for this condition. It will be marketed by Syntex Corp. The approval announcement was made Wednesday. Synarel is administered as a nasal spray twice daily for six months and works by stimulating and then suppressing production of estrogen, which controls the growth of the endometrial tissue that lines the uterus. Endometriosis occurs when this tissue, which usually is shed monthly with menstruation, migrates outside the uterus, most often into the abdominal and pelvic region, where it swells and bleeds during menstruation. This tissue implants on the ovaries, the intestines and the fallopian tubes, where it can cause blockage and infertility. Symptoms of endometriosis include severe menstrual cramps, pain during sexual intercourse, painful urination and painful bowel movements.
DOC.HEAD: Michigan Company Blows the Whistle on Its Own Product
DOC.TEXT: More than 555,000 whistles are being recalled by a Michigan manufacturer because they pose a potential choking hazard to small children. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday that the Hayes Specialties Corp., based in Saginaw, Mich., recalled approximately 553,000 ``Siren Whistles'' because they break apart easily and release small parts that may choke children who swallow them. The CPSC said the solid-colored, cylindrical, }-inch plastic whistles, which come in red, blue, pink, orange, green and yellow, were sold nationwide over the last 2{ years. Although there have been no reports of injuries associated with the Hayes product, the agency said it is ``aware of a number of incidents with siren-type whistles.'' ``Consumers having these Siren Whistles should take them away from children and return them to the store where they were purchased for a full refund of the purchase price,'' said CPSC Chairwoman Jacqueline Jones-Smith.

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Says He Might Seize Opposition Newspaper, Homes If Re-elected
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega has threatened to seize property owned by opposition leaders, including the country's lone opposition newspaper, if his leftist Sandinista party wins this month's elections. ``If we win, I say we will hand them a complete bill, so they will be left without a newspaper _ La Prensa _ and the homes of the candidate and the vice presidential candidate will be converted into children's homes on the day after the elections,'' Ortega told 80,000 people at a campaign rally in Matagalpa, 75 miles north of the capital, Managua. Also Wednesday, thousands of people turned out to hear his main opponent, La Prensa publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, at two rallies on the sparsely populated Atlantic Coast. The rallies in Puerto Cabezas and Bluefields followed endorsements of her United National Opposition by leaders of the Yatama Indians, who dominate the region. Ortega's threat was in response to a recent speech by opposition vice president Virgilio Godoy, who said if the 14-party opposition coalition wins the Feb. 25 election, ``we are going to make the Sandinistas pay the bills one by one'' for alleged violations of human, civil and political rights. The Sandinista leader challenged the leaders of the U.S.-backed opposition to repeat Godoy's words before international observers monitoring the elections. Ortega repeated accusations he made Tuesday that the U.S.-supported Contra rebels and opposition leaders were planning to disrupt the campaign. After meeting with Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, the Roman Catholic archbishop of Managua, Ortega told reporters late Tuesday that about 2,000 rebels had infiltrated northern Nicaragua from bases in neighborhing Honduras to disrupt the voting. Ortega also accused opposition leaders of planning to call the elections fraudulent. ``Since they know they have already lost the elections, they have this plan of saying there was fraud and the elections would be invalid,'' Ortega said Wednesday. He also said the army was taking action to neutralize any Contra infiltrators. About 1.7 million voters go to the polls Feb. 25 to choose a president and vice president, a National Assembly, municipal councils for 144 towns and two regional councils for the Atlantic Coast. The United States cut off military aid to the Contras in February 1988 but has continued to supply them with non-lethal aid as a means of putting pressure on the Sandinistas so they stand by their promise to conduct free elections.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged up against the yen today after a three-day slide, while share prices surged on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 316.10 points, or 0.85 percent, closing at 37,471.99. It rose 48.86 points Wednesday. Dealers attributed today's rise to stability in the foreign exchange and bond markets and newspaper poll reports that predicted victory for the governing Liberal Democratic Party in Sunday's national elections. Investors had been wary about whether the pro-business party could keep its control of the powerful lower house of Parliament after losing its majority in the upper house in elections in July. ``Market players bought actively today, but I don't think it was for real,'' said a dealer with Nikko Securities Co., adding, ``Volume is still very small.'' An estimated 500 million shares changed hands on the first section, up from 350 million the previous day. Other dealers said institutional investors remained on the sidelines amid speculation of another discount rate increase after the election. Following three increases last year in the rate charged by the Bank of Japan for borrowings by commercial banks, Japan's official discount rate now stands at 4.25 percent. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 144.45 yen, up 0.10 yen from Wednesday's 144.35-yen finish. It opened at 144.58 yen and ranged between 144.42 yen and 144.75 yen. In the previous three trading days, the dollar had fallen a total of 1.15 yen. The dollar opened higher today in Tokyo as market players decided that little fallout from the bankruptcy filing of the parent of U.S. securities firm Drexel Burnham Lambert would hit Japanese financial markets. But selling for profit-taking in the afternoon pushed it back down, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. Market players were in a wait-and-see mood before Sunday's election, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mob Covers the New York Waterfront, Lawsuit Charges
DOC.TEXT: Six dockworkers' union locals sued for racketeering by the federal government were likened to puppets whose strings were pulled by the mob for more than 50 years. The lawsuit, filed Wednesday in federal court, says three organized crime groups, including one allegedly led by John Gotti, controlled the waterfront of New York and New Jersey. The puppet comparison was made the FBI, which called the investigation ``Operation Marionette.'' The lawsuit was brought under the Racketeer Influenced, Corrupt Organizations Act to oust corrupt officials from the International Longshoremen's Association. Organized crime has controlled the six ILA locals for decades through murder, extortion, embezzlement of union funds and illegal payoffs, according to the lawsuit, which also named 32 present and former union officials, including the union's international president, John Bowers. ``In response to this shocking pattern of criminality, ILA officers have done virtually nothing,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Chad Vignola said in court papers. ILA spokesman Jim McNamara was unavailable for comment, his office said. The 90,000-member ILA has been under a cloud for years due to alleged mob domination. In 1953, it was expelled from the American Federation of Labor for corruption. The lawsuit named the Gambino crime family and Gotti, its reputed boss; the Genovese family and boss Anthony ``Fat Tony'' Salerno; and the Westies, a violent gang from Manhattan's West Side, and Westies boss James Coonan. Salerno and Coonan are in prison. Gotti's attorney, Bruce Cutler, denied his client had anything to do with waterfront corruption. ``They throw his name around just to throw it around,'' Cutler said. ``It's a continuing vendetta.'' Gotti, known as the ``Untouchable Don,'' was acquitted last week for the third time in a criminal case. Instead of pursuing criminal charges, the government filed the lawsuit in an attempt to remove from office ILA officers linked to organized crime. It also seeks appointment of trustees to oversee union elections and discipline ILA officials. The defendants also could be forced to pay back illegal profits. ``We're trying to take the ILA away from the mob and give it back to the ILA rank and file,'' said James Fox, FBI agent in charge of the New York office. According to the lawsuit, the Genovese family controlled the New Jersey locals; the Gambino family controlled a local in Brooklyn; and the Westies, through the influence of the Gambino family, controlled the Manhattan locals. Leonard Newman, the executive director of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor, said that despite numerous convictions of ILA officials, the mob bosses were able to appoint successors from jail. ``Out of office is not out of power,'' he said. U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the lawsuit was needed to attack corruption as ``a systemic problem.'' The case is similar to one the federal government brought against the International Brotherhood of Teamsters last year and a failed lawsuit concerning alleged mob influence at at Manhattan's Fulton Fish Market. The ILA suit was assigned to U.S. District Judge Leonard B. Sand, who will hold a hearing on the case Feb. 26.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Owa in 3rd graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A high school's 22-year-old tradition of a father-son banquet is getting a makeover _ mothers are now welcome. The change came about after a quarterback at Mohawk Trail Regional High School said he would boycott the event, which for years was sponsored by the Friends of Mohawk Football, unless his mother could attend. ``A lot of people supporting us through hard times were mothers, but they couldn't come to our banquet,'' Quarterback Owa Brandstein said. ``It was blatant discrimination and just plain wrong.'' After Brandstein complained late last year, the banquet was canceled. But a group of parents stepped in and arranged the new event, scheduled for Saturday night with Boston College Coach Jack Bicknell as speaker. ``In most cases, whole families _ mothers, fathers, sisters and brothers _ are coming,'' said Stuart Eisenberg, Brandstein's father. ``What we are trying to do is not be divisive, but recognize that we are a football family. Even the coach's wife can come.''

Pun-lovers 341, killjoys 94. Voters faced with choosing between a time-honored slogan and clean language have decided that this Livingston County village of 3,400 will once again greet motorists with signs that read ``Best Town by a Damsite.'' The village, 30 miles south of Rochester, had the slogan removed from signs last summer after some residents complained that the pun was distasteful. But after the new signs went up, other residents said they missed the slogan and wanted it restored. In a vote Tuesday, slogan defenders defeated opponents who wanted it removed by a count of 341-94. ``I think it belongs there,'' said resident Pat Crowley, who voted to restore the slogan. ``It's been there for years and years and years and years and what's wrong with saying `damn?' I say a lot worse than that.'' The nearby Mount Morris dam was completed in 1952 to control flooding from the Genesee River.

The challenge: How to save as many trees as possible while clearing underbrush for a $13 million municipal complex. The problem: Heavy machinery used to clear land often damages root systems, which can kill trees. The solution: Betsy the mule. ``The mule doesn't make near the mess that a tractor does,'' said Wayne Mabry, the subcontractor responsible for clearing the 30-acre site. He borrowed Betsy from a Cherokee County sawmill where the animal usually works to haul sled loads of underbrush from the building site to a shredder at the edge of the property. ``I pondered on the thought of using manpower, but that would have cost me a fortune,'' Mabry said. ``Being a country boy like I am, I just decided to use a mule, because economics made it feasible.'' Renting a light tractor and buying fuel for it would have cost about $2,000, Mabry said. Betsy works for $500 a month, and a friend is providing room and board.

DOC.HEAD: Forty-Seven Reported Killed In Guerrilla Attack On Train
DOC.TEXT: Insurgents ambushed a train carrying Mozambican miners and refugees home from South Africa, killing at least 47 people and injuring more than 50, the national news agency reported. The news agency, AIM, said the attack occurred late Wednesday morning about 45 miles west of Maputo. A relief train brought the victims back to the capital, and ambulances and trucks ferried the injured to a hospital, AIM said. Witnesses quoted by AIM said the attack began with the detonation of a remote-controlled mine that knocked over two of the passenger cars and derailed others. Guerrillas of the Mozambique National Resistance then opened fire, looted the train and abducted several survivors before withdrawing, AIM said. The rebels have been accused of several previous large-scale massacres during their 13-year insurgency against the leftist government. South Africa provided aid to the rebels for several years, but has insisted that this assistance has stopped.

DOC.HEAD: Two Satellites To Test Star Wars System
DOC.TEXT: Ground controllers readied two new satellites for tests of a ``Star Wars'' plan to destroy ballistic missiles with laser beams bouncing off orbiting mirrors. ``Both spacecraft are doing almost exactly what we expected them to do,'' said Air Force Col. Tom Meyer, a project official, three hours after the spacecraft were launched Wednesday by a Delta rocket. Meyer said that after several days of checking out the satellite systems, controllers will be ready for preliminary tests. Full scale tests of both satellites should begin in a month or so. One satellite carried a mirror designed to reflect lasers fired from a Hawaiian mountaintop back to a ground target to test the accuracy of such a system. The other held sensors for measuring how successfully scientists can correct distortions caused by dust, moisture and gases as the laser beam shoots through the atmosphere. Meyer said the experiment was the most ambitious yet in the Pentagon's program to develop a space-based shield against missiles. He emphasized the use of ground-based lasers, also called directed energy, is just one part of the project. Also being studied are space-based lasers and other weapons that would collide with an enemy missile. A success in the current $313 million mission could help preserve the $4.5 billion that President Bush is seeking for research in budget year 1991 for the Strategic Defense Initiative, or ``Star Wars.'' Some members of Congress want to cut that amount. In the missile-intercepting project called Relay Mirror Experiment, two ground stations on Maui, Hawaii, will aim low-powered laser beams simultaneously at the 2,300-pound satellite orbiting 270 miles above Earth. The satellite holds a 24-inch mirror designed to point a laser beam with an error of less than 57 millionths of a degree. The experiment will use the first two beams as signals to orient its mirror. When an Air Force station atop Mount Haleakala aims another beam at the satellite, the beam should reflect off the mirror and strike a sensor target at the base of the mountain 12 miles away. The second satellite, called LACE for Low-Power Atmospheric Compensation Experiment, will test a set of 210 laser-sensitive sensors mounted on its side. The Mount Haleakala laser to be used on the 3,175-pound payload has a special flexible mirror for distorting the laser beam on Earth to compensate for atmospheric disturbances. The beam should be sharp and powerful by the time it reaches LACE orbiting 340 miles high. LACE also carries an experiment to track the exhaust plumes of rockets to determine which wavelengths are most useful in detecting these plumes. Another experiment will measure neutron levels in space to help scientists develop a means of distinguishing between enemy warheads and decoys.

DOC.HEAD: Creative Touches in Drive to Get Across Safe Sex Message
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of grafs 7-9, `A West ...' may be offensive to some readers.
DOC.TEXT: The Minnesota Department of Health provides bowls of condoms at pow wows with tribal medicine men to teach Indians about AIDS. A computer software tax in Michigan brings in $4 million to $5 million a year for AIDS and public health education. In California, white cocktail napkins are printed with the warning: ``Before you pick up a hot number, pick up a condom.'' These were some of the creative touches being used by health agencies around the country that were discussed at a Centers for Disease Control-sponsored seminar on getting across the safe-sex message. The four-day meeting ends today. Messages about a disease that is often transmitted sexually are, of necessity, frequently graphic, state health officials said. A West Virginia health department poster shows photographs of six rear ends clad in a variety of dress, from evening gown to a pair of blue jeans. Above the photographs, the large black type says, ``No ifs, ands or butts ...'' Below, an admonition: ``Medical evidence PROVES that having anal sex is the easiest way to infect your male or female partner with the AIDS virus.'' A health department poster from rainy Oregon shows a good-looking man, apparently naked under a bright yellow slicker, with the caption: ``Good boys always wear their rubbers.'' Simple, explicit messages seem most effective, say state health officials, although there isn't enough data available to know for sure what works best. In Michigan, a well-financed educational program seems so far to be working, said Jan Ruff, deputy chief for the Center for Health Promotions in Lansing. ``Extensive evaluations indicate that 31 percent could identify components of the AIDS campaign,'' she said. The department's television ads promote condom use and the use of bleach to clean needles by intravenous drug users, a high-risk group. The campaign includes slogans like, ``Are you a big enough man to wear a condom?'' ``It doesn't mince words,'' Ruff said. ``There are always people who don't like it.'' Minnesota's culturally sensitive work with American Indians is entering its second year, so the success rate hasn't been determined, said Roy Nelson, an information specialist with the AIDS-Sexually Transmitted Diseases Services Section in Minneapolis. The department works with tribal medicine men and healers, focusing on tradition and heritage. ``They have a certain way of saying things,'' he said. One theme is ``Teaching our children well is the Indian way. Talk to them about AIDS.'' In Dallas, pocket-size packages containing a bright red condom, instructions and an AIDS information telephone number are distributed as safe-sex street kits. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. As of the end of January, the Atlanta-based CDC had recorded a cumulative total of 117,781 cases of AIDS in the United States, with 70,313 deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Quadruples Projections of Unemployed Under Economic Plan
DOC.TEXT: The non-Communist government, quadrupling earlier estimates, now says nearly 10 percent of Poland's workers will lose their jobs under the crash transformation from central planning to capitalism. It also says prices rose nearly 79 percent in January, the first month of the market-oriented reform program. It said the higher prices, combined with smaller wage increases, produced a 43.3 percent drop in real earnings. The announcements Wednesday were the latest indications of the mounting difficulties facing the Solidarity-led government in trying to break with the damage wrought by four decades of Communist rule and revive a moribund economy. There are frequent news reports of forced vacations as plants suspend production, and the government anticipates that unprofitable companies, kept functioning by Communist government subsidies, will close. The previous forecast of 400,000 jobless was raised substantially Wednesday by Labor Minister Jacek Kuron in a report to a parliamentary committee, the official PAP news agency said. However, PAP said the new estimate of 1.7 million unemployed, based on a World Bank assessment, includes a large group of employees old enough to get pensions and farmers also working in industry. The total workforce is about 18 million of Poland's 37 million people. Last week, there were about 55,000 unemployed, the report said. The pro-Solidarity Gazeta Wyborcza newspaper said Wednesday that a survey of 500 enterprises in an industrial region of southern Poland found 25,000 workers were expected to be dismissed in the first half of 1990. The newspaper said the largest layoffs were planned in the mining industry, and that several mines were considering bankruptcy. The new economic policies that went into effect Jan. 1 force government-run enterprises to become self-sufficient while absorbing huge increases in the prices of gas, electricity and other costs no longer kept artificially low by subsidies. The price of food increased 79 percent and non-food articles by 72 percent during January, the statistics office said. A 149 percent increase in the price of services stemmed from higher rents and increased charges for heat, electricity, transportation and telecommunications, the report said. The statistics office of the 5-month-old Solidarity-led government reported some leveling of prices, and even decreases, were noted toward month's end as the drive continued to turn the centrally controlled socialist economy into a market-driven system. Higher prices have forced down demand, which is causing a drop in production. Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has asked for the freezing of the Polish debt to the governments informally represented by the Paris Club, which totals about $30 billion of the nearly $40 billion owed to the West. Mazowiecki, who in August became the first non-Communist to head an East bloc government, said the foreign debt burden is the most critical factor in Poland's effort to emerge from economic crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Coretta King Calls for Peaceful Ending of Apartheid; ANC Warns of Bloodbath
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Coretta Scott King urged a peaceful dismantling of apartheid. But an African National Congress leader at her side warned of a struggle that would make the French Revolution look like a ``children's picnic'' if negotiations with the South African government fail. The comments came during a torch-lighting ceremony Wednesday at the crypt of slain civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr., in celebration of the release of ANC leader Nelson Mandela. ``I hope and pray that the anti-apartheid movement in South Africa will be able to adhere to the non-violent strategy that has begun to produce the historic reforms we have witnessed in recent months,'' Mrs. King said. ``If the South African people cannot come together, I'm afraid to think of what is going to happen. The French Revolution would look like a children's picnic,'' said ANC member Sifiso Makhathini. Mandela was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1964 along with seven of his ANC colleagues for their role in a conspiracy to overthrow the minority white government by force. Despite the promise of negotiations with the government, Mandela continues to support the ANC's ``armed struggle.'' Asked how the ANC has managed to maintain Mrs. King's support in light of her fierce opposition to the use of violence, Makhathini said: ``They understand our history. They understand why we had to take up arms. They know for decades and decades we were involved in a non-violent struggle.'' The activists, however, were in unanimous agreement that stronger, stiffer sanctions should be enacted until the South African government lifts the 3-year-old state of emergency and releases all political prisoners unconditionally.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Delegation: Leads Must Be Pursued in Jesuit Slaying
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. congressional commission contends the Salvadoran government has not yet fully investigated ``important leads and allegations'' in the November massacre of six Jesuit priests. Rep. Joe Moakley, D.-Mass, commended President Alfredo Cristiani's government for ``good police work'' in the technical aspects of the investigation. But the commission led by Moakley said Wednesday that doubts remain as to whether the people who planned the slayings have been identified, even though a Salvadoran army colonel has been arrested. It also said some members of the armed forces may have conspired to protect others implicated in the killings. ``The investigation is not over and important leads and allegations remain to be fully investigated,'' said a three-page statement read by Moakley at a news conference. The 14-person delegation was on a four-day visit to El Salvador to evaluate the government's investigation of the Jesuit killings. Before dawn on Nov. 16, five days after leftist rebels launched their biggest offensive of the 10-year-old civil war, a contingent of 30 soldiers from the elite U.S.-trained Atlacatl infantry battalion raided the campus of the Jesuit-run Central American University. The soldiers awakened the rector, Rev. Ignacio Ellacuria, the vice-rector, Rev. Ignacio Martin-Baro and four other priest-professors, as well as the domestic servant and her 15-year-old daughter. Five of the six priests were taken to the yard behind their residence, ordered to lay face-down and shot in the head, according to accounts from witnesses and court documents. The sixth priest was killed inside, as were the housekeeper and her daughter. An army colonel, three lieutenants and five soldiers have been charged with murder in the case. Col. Guillermo Benavides, one of the accused, became the highest-ranking Salvadoran soldier indicted on a human rights-related charge. The Salvadoran Roman Catholic hierarchy and the Society of Jesus have expressed concern that Benavides may be a scapegoat for other high-ranking officers who might have been involved. In El Salvador, Jesuit intellectuals have for years been considered subversives by the far right. Moakley said that a central question is ``whether the human rights problems in El Salvador, including the Jesuit killings, are the actions of a few renegade military figures or whether they stem from attitudes and actions that go to the very heart of the armed forces and other major institutions in this country.'' ``Encouraging genuine change in these institutions remains the greatest challenge facing El Salvador: a challenge that despite enormous investments of money and effort, has not yet been fully met,'' the U.S. official said. The United States has provided more than $4 billion in economic and military aid to El Salvador in the past decade. Several senators have proposed legislation that would condition further aid on improvement of the government's human rights record and progress toward a negotiated peace.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Tells Koreans to Expect Troop Cuts, More Costs
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Changes Thursday to today in 1st and 5th grafs to conform to style; further top prospects uncertain; it is now late afternoon in South Korea with nothing further on Cheney's public schedule until tomorrow
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told South Korean officials the Pentagon wants to slash its forces in Asia by 10 percent to 12 percent _ at least 12,000 troops _ over the next three years, U.S. officials said today. Cheney said some 5,000 of the troops would be pulled out of South Korea, with an additional 7,000 to 9,400 being withdrawn from the Philippines and Japan, officials said. There are 120,000 U.S. troops based in the three nations. ``We aren't going to move precipitously ... our commitment remains strong,'' Cheney said at a news conference. ``The threat remains undiminished.'' Cheney is on a two-week tour of Asian nations that hosting U.S. forces _ South Korea, Japan and the Philippines _ to respond to congressional demands for a reassessment of the U.S. military role in the Pacific. He met today with South Korean President Roh Tae-woo and Defense MInister Lee Sang-hoon to discuss U.S. troop cutbacks and increased burden sharing for the upkeep of U.S. forces based in South Korea. Lee, speaking at the same press conference, said his country had ``accepted in principal the gradual cutback in troop strength'' of the non-combatant U.S. forces. He pledged to work with U.S. military officials to work out the precise numbers and details of the drawdown. Cheney also said progress was made in the talks on the issue of turning command of the joint U.S.-Korea military structure over to a South Korean general. Operational control of the majority of South Korea's 600,000 forces now is under the senior U.S. commander, a four-star general. ``We talked about the U.S. playing more of a supportive role as the R.O.K. (South Korea) takes the lead,'' Cheney said. The Korean minister, asked about a possible withdrawal of 5,000 U.S. troops, said the exact numbers would be determined by the military commanders of both nations. The minister also pledged to give ``positive consideration'' to increasing payments for sharing costs for the U.S. forces in Korea. Cheney did not personally refer to the 10 percent to 12 percent U.S. troop reduction in Asia that was given earlier by U.S. officials, but noted that the Republic of Korea was only one of several nations being asked to increase its contributions, primarily due to congressional pressure. ``Korea has by no means been singled out in this process,'' Cheney said. Cheney wants Seoul to nearly double its $300 million annual contribution to support the 45,000 American troops over the next three years, officials said. Prior to the news conference, an American official familiar with the discussions said the Koreans ``reacted with horror'' to the suggestion of a U.S. troop reduction. ``Mr. Cheney is laying out what we would like to see done,'' said the U.S. official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified by name. ``We're laying out goals. It's the first step in consultations with the Korean government to see what we'd like to have happen.'' He said the Koreans were horrified at first because they believe any cutback in American soldiers would be the first step in a total U.S. troop withdrawal and ``the American security blanket is gone.'' Cheney is telling the Koreans that Congress would make sharper cuts if South Korea does not assume a greater role in its own defense. Some lawmakers have suggested dropping the U.S. troop level to 10,000 men and women. The Seoul government has balked at suggestions that it pay more for such things as libraries, theaters and pool halls to make life easier for U.S. troops because they provide none of those things for their own 680,000 military personnel, the official said. U.S. lawmakers are unhappy that the United States spends around $2.4 billion a year on U.S. troops on the Korean peninsula while South Korea enjoys a trade surplus with the United States. The official in the Cheney party said he expected the Koreans to raise their contribution by about $30 million this year, but that U.S. officials hoped to put the Korean government on a path for a ``substantial increase'' over the coming years. The official said he wouldn't argue with reports that estimate the United States will call for the Koreans to increase their $300 million contribution to nearly $700 million by 1993. By South Korean estimates, Seoul contributes nearly $2 billion annually to the U.S. forces in South Korea; the Pentagon places its contribution at around $300 million. The Koreans count such things as rent-free use of land for military installations.

DOC.HEAD: Newly Restored Superintendent Dismisses 86 High School Students
DOC.TEXT: One of the first acts of a school superintendent reinstated after his suspension sparked racial protests was to suspend 86 high school students for chanting civil rights slogans in a school cafeteria. Norward Roussell, the superintendent, also said Wednesday he would file a lawsuit against the white majority school board that voted not to renew his contract in December. Roussell, who is black, said the lawsuit would allege racial discrimination. Most of the black students who were suspended had taken part in disruptive protests outside Selma High School on Tuesday, when all 11 public schools reopened for the first time since they began closing Feb. 6, Roussell said. He was restored as superintendent that day. His dismissal a week earlier led to protests, but his restoration failed to immediately end the turmoil, as the student protesters called for a renewal of his three-year contract, which ends in June. James Carter, an aide to Roussell, said attendance was 92 percent for the school system Wednesday. About 23 percent missed classes when they resumed Tuesday. Students passed through a metal detector at Selma High, where National Guardsmen, state troopers and Selma police provided security and school officials worked to bring school operations back to normal. Roussell said expulsions may be in store for some of the students who began chanting during the first lunch period and continued in the second period with a slogan they had used marching to school Tuesday. ``The only way we're going to solve our problem in Selma is to cut the rotten core out of the apple,'' city attorney Henry Pitts said of the suspensions. Officials said 143 students, about 2 percent of the 6,000-student public school system, have withdrawn since classes resumed Tuesday. The city is 52 percent black and its public school system is about 70 percent black.

DOC.HEAD: Ted Turner Urges Advertisers To Take High Road, Says Networks Take the Low
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with additional quote from Turner; picks up 5th graf pvs, ``I'm not..'
DOC.TEXT: Cable TV mogul Ted Turner urged advertisers to take the high road in considering programs to sponsor, and accused the three largest networks of being more concerned with audience size than program quality. ``They don't take the high ground,'' said Turner, who operates four cable networks, including CNN. ``They take the low.'' He offered no examples of shows that would illustrate his accusation. Turner, chairman of Atlanta-based Turner Broadcasting System, spoke Wednesday at a workshop of the National Association of Advertisers. He urged the advertising community ``to take the high road and to take the long-term outlook'' in shows they sponsor. Turner was ambivalent when asked how advertisers should respond to viewer boycott calls. ``I'm not asking anybody to stand up to a boycott threat _ unless you want to,'' he said. ``That's everybody's individual choice. I'm easy on it.'' Turner said he could recall only one occasion when ads were pulled from his programs. All 10 advertisers withdrew last summer from ``Rage Over Trees,'' an Audubon Society special criticized by loggers and the logging industry that was broadcast on TBS network. ``I really didn't feel too bad about it,'' he said. The show lost about $800,000 in advertising revenue because of pressure from northwest loggers, a TBS spokesman said. Turner, who in 1985 tried to buy CBS, said he has been holding ``wide-ranging'' talks with that network about possible ventures in news and sports projects, including joint newsgathering by CNN and CBS News. Warren Littlefield, NBC's executive vice president for prime time program, later made a jab at cable television in a separate panel discussion. Littlefield _ who wasn'ex and violence. He proposed one solution for families with young children. ``If you're a concerned parent, yank the cable out,'' Littlefield said.

DOC.HEAD: Robot's `Girlfriend' Dies Before Valentine's Day
DOC.TEXT: The long-distance courtship of Toby the robot by an infatuated doll named Jodi ended just before Valentine's Day when Toby learned that Jodi had gone to the big dollhouse in the sky. Toby's owner, Jim Barclay, a printer and handyman at a medical clinic, said the last of a string of cards and letters arrived Monday with the bad news that Jodi died in a head-on collision on the way from Royal Oak, Mich., to the North Pole. ``I had tears in my eyes when I started reading that letter,'' Barclay said Wednesday. His wife, Margene, ``started crying, too,'' he said. Toby seemed to lose his juice. ``He is just standing over there with a blank stare on his face with his black arm band on,'' Barclay said of the battery-powered, 18-inch-tall robot. Of the practical jokers behind the correspondence _ Mrs. Barclay swears it isn't her _ Barclay said: ``Maybe now, somebody will come forward.'' The romance began when Barclay came to work one morning before Christmas 1988 and found the gold-toned robot propped in his chair. The note attached to Toby said he was a gift from Santa. Soon after, Jodi began sending Toby cards and letters, expressing her longing for the time they would be reunited at Santa's workshop. The missives arrived about once a month from across the country. With each card, the Barclays and the 50 other employees at the clinic became more curious about the identity of Jodi and of the architect of the elaborate scheme. Interest hit a peak when the Barclays received a hefty ham this past Christmas from Jodi and Toby. No one could figure out how the lovebirds got the gift into Barclay's locked car. No one expected the romance to come to such a sad ending. ``I thought we would come in here someday and Toby would be gone and then we would get pictures of them on the beach at Waikiki wearing bikinis and grass skirts,'' Barclay said. While Jodi's death has brought an end to the romance, it answered a few questions that had nagged at the Barclays. They had assumed that Jodi was a robot like Toby, but the death notice included photographs that revealed her to be a red-haired, bespectacled Cabbage Patch doll. She posed with the nutty television alien ALF, her Cabbage Patch sister, Lori, a stuffed pony, Corky, and a stuffed dog named Porky. The photos and letter were all sent by ``Jackie,'' described as a friend of Jodi. Barclay dismissed bets by his co-workers at a medical clinic that the correspondent would convince Cabbage Patch sister Lori to pick up the romance where Jodi left it. Jodi's death means ``they are trying to bring it to an end,'' Barclay said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Higher in Europe
