DOC.TEXT: The dollar firmed slightly against most major foreign currencies in early European trading today. Gold prices also rose. Currency dealers in Milan, Italy, said investors were closing positions and watching for the outcome of the West German Bundesbank's policy-making Central Bank Council meeting later in the day. While most analysts don't expect the central bank to raise West German interest rates today, a cautious outlook has slowed activity and put pressure on the mark, they said. ``Things are very calm right now, people are just twiddling their thumbs and watching the Bundesbank,'' one trader said. Analysts said the dollar was also benefiting from expectations that Friday's U.S. trade figures will show an improvement in the trade gap. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.10 yen to a closing 144.45 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 144.50 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.6778 West German marks, up from 1.6715 _1.4940 Swiss francs, up from 1.4920 _5.7055 French francs, up from 5.6845 _1.8907 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8832 _1,246.25 Italian lire, up from 1,242.25 _1.2055 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2062 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6948, compared with $1.6963 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $416.90 a troy ounce, up from $416.25 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $417.05. In Zurich, the bid price was $416.80, up from $415.52 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 32 cents to close at a bid $415.33. Bullion dealers attributed gold's movement to speculative play rather than any fresh fundamental or market-affecting news. They said the metal was being supported by economic and political turmoil, particularly in South Africa and Germany. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.35 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $5.32.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't to Lift Some Emergency Regulations
DOC.TEXT: The government has decided to partially lift emergency regulations, including a law that allows security forces to dispose of bodies without inquest, a senior minister said today. The announcement came hours after Amnesty International harshly criticized the restrictions and said thousands of people had disappeared or were murdered by the government forces and death squads last year. Foreign Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told reporters six emergency regulations imposed in June would be repealed at midnight. They involve restrictions on publications, political parties and travel on rail and public tranport. President Ranasinghe Premadasa assured rival politicians on Wednesday that he would revoke some of the emergency rules imposed to try to quell a 2-year-old uprising by ultranationalist Sinhalese extremists. More than 6,000 people have been killed in the fighting in south and central Sri Lanka. A separatist rebellion by minority Tamils in the north and east has cost 11,000 lives since 1983. Sinhalese militants began attacking the Sinhalese-dominated government when it tried to make peace with the Tamil rebels, contending it was making too many concessions. The emergency regulations, which need the approval of Parliament each month, give broad powers to security forces to search, arrest or detain suspects for indefinite periods. Amnesty International said reports of killings increased sharply after emergency regulations were introduced. In a report released today, the London-based human rights group said also said Indian peacekeeping troops in Sri Lanka were ``reported to have committed extrajudicial executions and there were numerous allegations of torture of prisoners by members of the (Indian force).'' Sri Lankan and Indian officials had no direct comment on the report. Indian soldiers arrived in Sri Lanka 2{ years ago to supervise an arms surrender by Tamil separatists under a pact signed in July 1987. Most groups gave up their weapons, but the dominant Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam reneged on the peace plan. The Indian troops, who were supposed to maintain law and order in the strife-torn northern and eastern provinces, instead fought the Tamil Tigers. At least 1,100 soldiers died in the fighting. The presence of the Indian troops and the peace accord sparked a Sinhalese backlash. Indian forces started leaving Sri Lanka last year and the last troops are to be gone by March 31. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, claim they are denied jobs and education by the Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Launches Minuteman Containing Maneuvering System Technology
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force launched a Minuteman missile in a test of a re-entry system used for ICBMs. The Air Force said the launch occurred at 2:40 a.m. Wednesday. The payload was propelled 4,100 miles down the Western Test Range toward the Marshall Islands. The launch was the first of a program to test the payload component called the missile's Maneuvering System Technology, said Capt. Tom DeSantis, an Air Force spokesman. The payload was aboard a Minuteman I booster, a three-stage solid propellant ballistic missile that has been refurbished to meet special research and development requirements. Data gathered during and after the launch will be studied as part of the Advanced Strategic Missile Systems program of the Air Force Systems Command's Ballistic Systems Division.

DOC.HEAD: Idol Recovering from Fourth Leg Operation After Motorcycle Crash
DOC.TEXT: Spiky-haired rock star Billy Idol underwent a fourth operation for leg injuries suffered in a motorcycle crash, his publicist said. The rocker, whose hard-driving hits ``White Wedding'' and ``Rebel Yell'' made him a star, was listed in fair condition. Doctors at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center performed skin grafts on the singer's right leg, which suffered a compound fracture Feb. 6 when his Harley-Davidson hit a car. Doctors also worked to repair muscle damage suffered in the accident. ``He is out of recovery and back in his own room,'' Idol's publicist, Ellen Golden, said Wednesday afternoon. Police say Idol, 34, ran a stop sign and sideswiped a car while driving home from a Hollywood recording studio where he had completed work on a new album.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl: Elections Key to Unification; No NATO Troops on East German Soil
With PM-West Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl told Parliament today that unification will begin to take shape quickly after East Germany's elections, and that no NATO troops should be stationed on what is now East German soil. It was one of the stormiest parliamentary sessions in recent memory, with Kohl accusing his political opponents of being too close to the disgraced East Germany Communist Party in years past. The opposition Social Democrats responded with hoots and shouting, and Parliament's president, Rita Suessmuth, harshly admonished the lawmakers. West Germany is to hold national elections in December and the Social Democrats decisively defeated Kohl's party in recent state elections. The rival parties are also vying to win support among the East German electorate. Kohl laid out to Parliament the results of his talks over the weekend with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and on Tuesday and Wednesday with Hans Modrow, East Germany's Communist premier. ``Never before since the division of our land ... have we been so close to our goal _ the unity of all Germans in freedom _ as we are today,'' Kohl told Parliament. He said he and Gorbachev had agreed on the singular importance of East Germany's March 18 elections: ``I was able to underscore my firm belief that the result of the elections will not only be a democratic and negotiations-capable government, but also a government program with the clear goal: `Unity as soon as possible.''' Kohl vowed that the security concerns of ``neighboring states'' will not be ignored on the road to German unification. He reiterated his position that a united Germany must be a NATO member and not demilitarized, and that Germany will remain committed to European integration. ``The history of this century shows nothing is more detrimental to European stability than a Germany that swings between two worlds, between East and West,'' said Kohl, referring to World War II. ``The imperative stability factor needed in the middle of Europe is a free and democratic Germany as part of a secure alliance, and a growing political and economic integretation within the European Community,'' said Kohl. The chancellor seemed to be addressing concerns among many Europeans that a united Germany could derail attempts to create closer European unity, or seek to reclaim land ceded to Poland after World War II. Kohl also said he favors keeping any NATO troops off the territory of what is now East Germany. The Soviet Union has insisted that a united Germany be neutral, a demand rejected by the United States and its alliance partners. Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German foreign minister, has proposed that as a compromise NATO troops not be allowed on what is now East German turf. Kohl's address was interrupted several times as he condemned the Social Democrats for having close contacts with East Germany's Communists during years past. ``You were allied with these people,'' said Kohl. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of the Social Democrats, fired back by reminding Kohl that his Christian Democrats are now supporting the East German Christian Democrats, who for years were allied with the Communists. ``Mister Chanceller, whoever supports the East CDU _ which for 40 years went along with everything (the Communists said) _ has no right to point the finger at the Social Democrats,'' said Vogel.

DOC.HEAD: Snow, Sleet, Rain Pelts Northwest, Midwest, East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `High temperature ...', to CORRECT to Wednesday sted today; pick up 14th graf, `Other reports ...'
DOC.TEXT: Precipitation in the form of snow, sleet, freezing rain and thundershowers fell today in the Northwest and from the Plains and northern Great Lakes into New England and New York state. A major storm system moved northeast out of the southern Rockies and across the central Plains. The storm has already combined with an Arctic cold front to leave snow from Arizona to Michigan, including 3 inches in Flagstaff, Ariz., 6 inches in Beaver, Utah, 9 inches in Chicago and 5 in Battle Creek, Mich. Blizzard conditions were expected tonight in Minnesota. A band of sleet and freezing rain 100 miles wide formed below the belt of heavy snow. A windy snowstorm slapped northern Illinois with up to 10 inches of snow Wednesday, closing O'Hare International Airport and clogging traffic in Chicago. United Airlines, O'Hare's largest carrier, cancelled more than one-third of its 800 flights Wednesday because of the weather. Cold air behind the storm has filtered south across California to the San Diego area. Frost and freeze warnings were posted for the San Diego area this morning, and temperatures were expected in the low to mid 20s. Showers and thunderstorms soaked areas from Texas to southern New England. Warm air clashing with an Arctic air mass spawned freezing rain across much of northern Indiana, northern Ohio, and southern lower Michigan. Afternoon thunderstorms may develop today in parts of Missouri and Illinois. A new Pacific storm system spread more snow into Washington and Oregon. Locally heavy snowfall was expected across the western parts of both states today. Winter weather watches for snow were issued for Northern California and Nevada for snow tonight and Friday. On Valentine's Day, rare hail and snow fell in Los Angeles and San Diego, though the evidence melted soon after landing. The Southeast looked for highs today in the 80s and scattered showers. New Orleans received 2.59 inches of rain in 6 hours Wednesday afternoon. Several high temperature records were set on Valentine's Day on the East Coast, including Warwick, R.I., 60; New York City, 62; Beckley, W.Va., 63; Wilmington, Del., 67; Baltimore, Md., 70 downtown, 73 at the city airport; Atlantic City, N.J., 72 downtown, 71 at the city airport; Paducah, Ky., 72; Roanoke, Va., and Washington D.C. 73; High temperature for the Lower 48 states Wednesday was 87 degrees at McAllen, Texas. DOC.HEAD: House-to-House Fighting Reported in Massawa, Port Damaged
DOC.TEXT: House-to-house fighting was reported today between Eritrean rebels and government troops battling for control of the Red Sea port of Massawa. The state-run Ethiopian News Agency called the fighting ``ferocious'' and said both sides had suffered heavy casualties since the Eritrean People's Liberation Front last week launched its first offensive in more than a year. The agency gave no casualty figures for combatants or civilians, but the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, a government agency, said the fighting had created ``a dangerous situation with a likely massive loss of life'' in the northern provinces of Eritrea and Tigre. Massawa, Ethiopia's main port, is the gateway for all goods going to the two provinces. Hundreds of thousands of tons of emergency relief food pass through it annually to feed people threatened by famine caused by drought and aggravated by civil war. The United Nations hoped to ship 1.1 million tons of emergency food through Massawa in the next few months to feed an estimated 4 million people, mainly in Eritrea and Tigre. The Eritrean rebels claimed capture of the port in a radio broadcast Saturday, but a government official in Addis Ababa said the rebels controlled only parts of the town. The news agency reported heavy shelling of Massawa by sea and land, apparently by both sides. It said the shelling had damaged many buildings and the port, where relief food is stored. The rebels claim to have sunk or captured 12 warships. If the claims are true, that would be more than half of the Ethiopian fleet of two frigates and 21 patrol boats listed by the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies. President Mengistu Haile Mariam's Marxist government has repeatedly accused unidentified Arab nations of turning the Red Sea into a Moslem sea, inferring that they have been arming the rebels with naval craft. Delivery of relief food from Massawa to the interior was halted after the Eritrean secessionists began their offensive on Feb. 8, officials say. The Relief and Rehabilitation Commission says 90,000 tons of relief food are stranded in Massawa. The rebel offensive has virtually cut the provincial capital of Asmara from the national capital in Addis Ababa, except by air. The Tigre People's Liberation Front, another rebel group, cut the Asmara-Addis Ababa road when it took control of Tigre province, Eritrea's southern neighbor, early last year. The two rebel groups claim to have killed at least 2,500 government troops since the Eritrean offensive began. The Eritreans took up arms in 1962 to press for independence of their former Italian colony. Late last year, rebel and government emissaries held two unsuccessful rounds of peace talks mediated by former President Jimmy Carter in Nairobi, Kenya, and Atlanta. The Tigrean rebels, fighting since 1975, controls the province Tigre and seek Mengistu's ouster.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Mistrial After Witness Says He Lied
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge who declared a mistrial in the first international drug prosecution brought jointly by Chinese and U.S. officials says the case proves ``you can't meld'' the two legal systems. U.S. District Judge William Orrick halted proceedings Wednesday in the case against three men, accused in connection with $700,000 worth of heroin found inside dead goldfish, after a key prosecution witness said he had lied under pressure and death threats from Chinese officials. The witness, who is seeking asylum in the United States, recanted his testimony and said he had been tortured in a Shanghai prison. Orrick said the breakdown of the trial was ``proof positive you can't meld the legal system in the People's Republic of China with the legal system in the United States.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Eric Swenson told reporters Orrick's conclusion was valid for this case, but ``I'm still confident that this type of problem does not have to affect future cases. ...The legal system in China is almost identical to many of the western European systems.'' No decision has been made on a retrial, Swenson said. Federal drug agents charged that seven pounds of Southeast Asian heroin had been put inside condoms that were sewed into the bodies of goldfish and mixed into shipments of live goldfish from China to the United States. Three men arrested in San Francisco, Leung Tak-Lun, Chico Wong and Andrew Wong, were charged with possessing heroin with intent to distribute. The witness, Wang Zong-Xiao, was arrested in Shanghai in March 1988 and held there for most of the time until last December, when he was brought to San Francisco. He testified Feb. 1 that he took part in the heroin shipment along with Leung. But Wang filed for asylum four days later, saying he had been threatened with death by officials from Shanghai who had accompanied him to the United States. He said in court papers that he had been coerced into confessing and warned by the Chinese officials not to reveal the coercion or the later beatings and electric shocks he received, nor to disclose that students and workers were held and tortured in the Shanghai prison. Wang returned to the witness stand Tuesday, without the jury present, to describe his torture in China. He said he had lied in testimony that implicated Leung. Orrick said Wednesday he was declaring a mistrial because of the allegations of perjured testimony, and because the Chinese government had not provided defense lawyers before the trial with Wang's earlier statements, as the judge's order required. After those actions, any conviction in the case would surely be reversed on appeal, he told the jury. Orrick also noted that two Shanghai officers who accompanied Wang to San Francisco returned suddenly to China on Sunday after the judge issued an order last week prohibiting U.S. officials from returning Wang to China while his asylum application is pending. The officers had been accused of threatening Wang if he changed his testimony. ``I don't think you'll be seeing them again,'' Orrick said. Cedric Chao, a lawyer appointed to represent Wang, said the case for asylum is strong, and described Wang as ``at peace with himself'' after his latest testimony. ``It would be unconscionable to send him back to China to face certain death,'' Chao told reporters.

DOC.HEAD: President Finds Pace of European Changes `Mind-Boggling'
DOC.TEXT: The speed of change in Eastern Europe is ``mind-boggling'' and raises concern about continued stability in the region, President Bush said in an interview published today. ``I never thought you'd see this rapid a change,'' Bush told USA Today. One example, he added, was that ``two weeks ago, the Soviets said they had a problem with our proposals (on troop reductions in Europe). Less than a week later, it's accepted.'' Despite the fast-moving pace of change, Bush said his concerns about continued stability do not have him in a ``sleepless mode.'' ``There's sometime when you wonder, `Is this going to be brought to conclusion,' or `What's going to happen in terms of stability as the change takes place in Eastern Europe,''' he said. ``There's worries, but not in the sense of a crisis environment.'' He said it is ``good'' that political reform is evolving within the Soviet Union and ``no reason to lose sleep ... because our thesis that democracy and freedom should be contagious is proving to be correct. And I hope it proves to be correct in South Africa.'' The president said he would not attempt to oust Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega, as he did Manuel Antonio Noriega in Panama, even if he concludes that the leftist leader has stolen the upcoming elections in Nicaragua. ``No,'' he relied in response to a question. ``There's a lot of non-elected leaders around the world that can sleep comfortable.'' Pressed on that point, Bush called the line of questioning ``too hypothetical, but the answer is no. If you're talking about an effort to protect American life or something, the signal should be loud and clear: I'll do what's necessary to protect American lives. But if you're saying I don't like the results of an election and will be use military force, the answer is no.''

DOC.HEAD: Charges Dropped Against Joyce Ann Brown
DOC.TEXT: The district attorney's office said it would drop attempts to retry a woman whose conviction was overturned after she spent nine years in prison for a 1980 fur store robbery in which the owner was killed. Joyce Ann Brown said the decision Wednesday by the Dallas County office was the ``best Valentine's Day gift in the world.'' ``I really held my breath up until the last moment,'' Ms. Brown said after state District Judge Ron Chapman accepted the prosecutors' decision. Ms. Brown, 43, was sentenced to life in prison by Chapman in October 1980 for aggravated robbery five months earlier that ended in the death of Ruben Danziger. After her conviction was overturned by the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals in November, prosecutors said they would try Ms. Brown again. But prosecutor George West said Wednesday there was ``insufficient evidence to proceed to trial,'' although the case would remain open. West said the decision ``is one in which someone is going to be pleased, someone is going to be upset, and there was no way out for me. I'm going to have to face both of those.'' He declined to give specific reasons for dropping the charges. Despite the lack of physical evidence linking Ms. Brown to the crime, she was found guilty of being an accomplice largely because of the testimony of two prosecution witnesses, including Danziger's wife, Ala. Mrs. Danziger's attorney, David Vaughan, said justice was not been served and that Ms. Brown was guilty. Ms. Brown said of Mrs. Danziger, ``I have to live with the fact that she will probably go to her grave thinking they released a guilty person and they didn't.'' Ms. Brown was the third Texas inmate in a year to have a conviction overturned amid national attention. Clarence Brandley, a former janitor who was six days away from execution after nine years on death row, had his conviction reversed in December. The capital murder conviction of Randall Dale Adams, whose case was the subject of the movie ``The Thin Blue Line,'' also was dropped after he spent 12 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Met Actress Marla Maples at Church
DOC.TEXT: Actress Marla Maples, described as the other woman in the Donald Trump divorce saga, met the billionaire real estate developer at a venerable New York church. Trump and Ms. Maples sat together at Sunday services ``fairly regularly,'' a source told The Associated Press on Wednesday. Trump married his wife, Ivana, at the Marble Collegiate Church, but she did not attend services with him. ``She is the reason the marriage broke up,'' New York Daily News columnist Liz Smith told Larry King, who devoted a half-hour Wednesday night to Trump vs. Trump on his Cable News Network talk show. But rival New York Post columnist Cindy Adams told WABC-TV News that Ms. Maples is nothing more than ``this week's toy'' for Trump. According to a prenuptial agreement made known Sunday, Mrs. Trump gets custody of their three kids, a mansion in Connecticut and $25 million _ less than 2 percent of Trump's estimated $1.7 billion fortune. Despite statements to the contrary, Trump reportedly expects to settle for four times the agreement. ``He's going to pay $100 million'' for a fast settlement, a Trump aide was quoted anonymously as saying in today's New York Newsday. Smith, who broke the story Sunday, agreed, telling King: ``I think Donald is negotiating right now probably to make Ivana an offer a lot bigger than this $25 million settlement.'' Mrs. Trump's lawyer says she deserves more. But Trump said in an interview published today in The Washington Post, ``This prenuptial agreement was signed by a sophisticated woman. They're virtually impossible to break. They're sealed in gold.'' Ivana Trump would not comment when confronted by a horde of reporters Wednesday at her 41st birthday party. Several women shouted ``Get the money, Ivana'' and others cheered as the fur-clad blonde alighted from her black Mercedes at an expensive Manhattan restaurant. Reports indicated Ms. Maples, an actress who has had bit television parts and a bikini-clad airline advertisement pinup, is ready to marry Trump. About 14 months ago, Trump sought counseling from Dr. Arthur Caliandro, the minister of the church, about whether to continue his relationship with Ms. Maples, according to the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Caliandro was at a board meeting on Wednesday and did not immediately return a phone call. Lisa Tolf, a church administrator, confirmed that Ms. Maples in May 1987 joined the church, which is part of the Reformed Church of America. Ms. Tolf said she doesn't know if Trump attends services regularly but said of Ms. Maples: ``I've seen her at the church.'' Asked whether Trump had sought counseling at the church, she replied, ``I'm not the person to talk to about that.'' There also were reports that Trump paid for a room for Ms. Maples at the St. Moritz hotel, which he once owned. Not true, said Ms. Maples' agent, Chuck Jones. ``She was just offered $250,000 by the National Enquirer to tell her story but since there's no story to tell, she turned them down,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Society Photographer Dies In Singapore at Age 76
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 4th pvs, ``His illness...'' to UPDATE with comment from Twiggy. Pickup 5th, ``Among his...''
DOC.TEXT: Society photographer Norman Parkinson, who specialized in photographing women and won fame for his pictures of British royals, died today in Singapore at age 76, his family reported. Parkinson collapsed on Feb. 2 with a brain hemorrhage in his hotel room in Sabah, Malaysia. He had been working in the Malaysian jungle with American model Debra Harris for the U.S. magazine Town and Country. He was taken to a medical center in Sabah, but two days later was flown to Singapore's Mount Elizabeth Hospital, accompanied by his friend Mohamed Al Fayed, one of the Egyptian brothers who own the famous Harrods department store in London. His illness was complicated by bronchial pneumonia and heart problems, hospital officials said. Twiggy, the pencil-thin model who found fame in the 1960s, described Parkinson today as ``one of the great eccentrics of the photographic world.'' ``He was a perfect gentleman and an amazing creative photographer,'' she said. ``We have all lost a great exponent of the photographic art, he was just something really special.'' Among his best known portraits are those of Princess Anne, daughter of Queen Elizabeth II, for Anne's 21st birthday in 1971, and the queen's mother, Elizabeth, on her 80th birthday in 1980. Parkinson said that when he photographed the queen he found her a nervous and difficult sitter. He once described the queen's mother and Princess Anne as ``the most royal of all the royals.'' Friends and the many models he photographed for Vogue magazine and other glossy publications around the world knew him as ``Parks.'' Educated at London's Westminster School, his skill with a camera won him a clientele that included empresses, movie stars, top models and pop stars as well as the royals. His ``snaps,'' as he called his photographs, were often exhibited at the state-funded National Portrait Gallery in London and featured in several best selling publications, including ``Sisters Under the Skin.'' An eccentric dresser who sported a military-style mustache, he listed his hobbies in Who's Who as sun worshipping, bird watching, breeding Creole racehorses and pig farming. His business interest in British pigs led him recently to start selling his own brand of pork sausages to top London stores such as Harrods and Fortnum and Mason. His home for much of the last 25 years was on the Caribbean island of Tobago. Parkinson was married for 42 years to model and biographer Wenda Rogerson, who died in 1987. He is survived by his son Simon.

DOC.HEAD: Priest, Lawyer Say They Got Man a False ID at Ritter's Behest
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for the nation's largest organization for runaways and a priest have acknowledged providing a false identity to a 26-year-old man they believed was a 19-year-old prostitute, a newspaper reported today. The two men have said they created a new identity for Kevin Kite at the behest of the Rev. Bruce Ritter, founder of the Covenant House shelter for runaways, The New York Times reported today. Kite has charged that Ritter gave him money and gifts in return for sex. The 62-year-old Roman Catholic priest has vehemently denied those charges and similar ones since made by three other men. Ritter has been placed on leave of absence from running the shelter pending an investigation by Franciscan leaders. The Rev. Michael Duval has told church superiors that he obtained birth and baptismal documents to falsify an identity for Kite, the newspaper said. Covenant House officials originally said Kite had obtained the false identity himself. Duval and the attorney, Gregory Loken, declined to be quoted, but officials of the Roman Catholic Church and the shelter told the Times how they tried to help Kite, who purportedly was running away from an organized crime ring. According to the Times account: When Ritter brought Kite to New York from a Covenant House shelter in New Orleans in February 1989, he introduced him as his nephew. However, Ritter's niece learned that someone was using her brother's name. So Ritter discussed a new identity with Loken, who called Duval, parochial vicar of St. James Roman Catholic Church in Jamestown. Duval found in church records that a Timothy Michael Warner died of leukemia in 1980 at age 10. The priest filled out a blank baptismal certificate with the names of Timothy and his parents, dated it Dec. 27, 1970, and signed it with another priest's name. Duval also obtained a certified copy of Timothy's birth certificate, which is illegal for a non-family member to do. It was not clear which state agency issued the certificate. The documents were given to Kite. Monsignor David Lee, communications director for the Buffalo Diocese, told the Times Duval's actions were ``absolutely and totally contrary'' to church rules. Duval took a leave of absence from the church in August. He resigned last week from his job as a family services caseworker in Paterson, N.J., the Times said. Loken and Duval have said they believed Kite needed a new identity so he could start a new life.

DOC.HEAD: Newspapers: Pilot May Have Tried to Take Over Computer Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 11th, `The New Delhi-based...' to UPDATE with quote from survivor from Chicago. Pickup 12th pvs: The plane's...
DOC.TEXT: The pilot of a jetliner that crashed with 146 people aboard may have tried to manually override the plane's sophisticated computer control minutes before the disaster, newspapers reported today. At least 91 people were killed Wednesday when the 3-month-old Airbus 320 jetliner operated by Indian Airlines crashed 150 feet short of the runway at Bangalore airport in south India. A spokesman for the state-run domestic carrier tried to discourage speculation in the media about the cause of the crash. ``All these stories are speculations. In cases like such crashes, how can you say what happened without a proper inquiry?'' said the spokesman, who declined to be identified. Press Trust of India said firefighters had found the flight data recorder in the fuselage of the wrecked plane. The Times of India newspaper, quoting unidentified aviation sources, said the crash may have occurred because the pilot ``tried to change the mode of control from computer to manual or vice-versa.'' ``The response time of the in-flight computer for doing this is five to six seconds,'' which is too little to make the switch at the final stage of the landing, the newspaper said. Another daily, The Hindustan Times, said there was a strong possibility of a ``last-minute bid by the pilot to change over from computer to manual control and thus losing a valuable few seconds, leading to the crash.'' One publication, Science Report, said the aircraft's technology includes a pre-programmed ``software that tells the computer _ and not the pilot _ to make judgments.'' If the pilot wanted to make a sharp turn to avoid collision, the report said, the system ``will not let the airplane respond beyond a certain rate.'' The New Delhi-based Hindustan Times said the plane's instruments may have indicated the wrong altitude, which may have misled the pilot to descend earlier than he should have. John Mancosky, 28, of Chicago, said the plane began to shake about five minutes earlier and at he first he thought the pilot made a hard landing. ``Then we heard a loud booming noise and soon we were enveloped in a ball of flame,'' said Mancosky, who, like most of the survivors, escaped through the aircraft's rear door. He suffered a broken leg. The plane's bottom hit a wall while coming down for the landing and it slithered on the rough ground before bursting into flames and breaking into at least four pieces. Among the 146 people on board were the seven-member crew and four infants. The pilot and co-pilot were killed in the fire that engulfed most of the plane, leaving only the tail intact. Most of the 55 survivors jumped down from the rear door. The airline spokesman at least 17 foreigners had been on the flight. They included seven Americans, a Frenchman, two Canadians, three Japanese and a Hong Kong man, embassy and airline officials said. A U.S. Embassy official in New Delhi said one American died, one was missing and five had survived. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said their identities would not be released until families had been notified. The airline spokesman said a four-member team from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that makes the aircraft, had arrived in India to help investigate the cause of the accident. Wednesday's crash was the latest in a series of accidents that have earned Indian Airlines the reputation of being one of the worst-managed carriers in the world. Poor morale among the staff has led to frequent strikes, and flight delays are endemic. Employees allege that pre-flight safety precautions are often ignored. The A320, which had logged less than 400 flying hours since Indian Airlines acquired it in December, was one of 14 purchased last year to try to upgrade the carrier's fleet. The last Indian Airlines disaster occurred Oct. 19, 1988, when a Boeing 737 crashed on final approach in the western city of Ahmedabad, killing 113 people on board. An inquiry blamed pilot error for the crash, the worst in the airline's 27-year history. Wednesday's crash is only the second accident involving an A320 and the first in commercial service. Three people were killed and 50 injured when an A320 crashed at an air show in eastern France in June 1988. The twin-engined, narrow-bodied jet is the first civilian airliner with a fully computerized flight control system. It consumes 40 percent less fuel than similar planes.

DOC.HEAD: Facts and Figures of Drug Trade
With AM-Bush-Drug Summit Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The anti-drug ``war'' brings together the governments of the United States, the biggest consumer of illegal drugs, and of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia, key producing nations. Here are some facts and figures about the drug trade and the nations participating in the anti-drug summit today in Cartagena, Colombia. (Drug trade statistics drawn from 1989 U.S. government report ``National Drug Control Strategy.'')
DOC.HEAD: COLOMBIA
DOC.TEXT: Colombian farmers grow about 10 percent of the coca leaves for U.S.-bound cocaine. The Medellin and Cali drug cartels, supplied with coca leaves from Peru, Bolivia and Colombia, refine at least 80 percent of the U.S. cocaine supply. Illegal cocaine earnings in Colombia bring in an estimated $500 million to $1.2 billion. Coffee, Colombia's chief crop, accounts for about half of the country's $6 billion in annual exports. Other legal exports include bananas, flowers, sugar, oil, clothing, textiles, cotton and tobacco.
DOC.HEAD: BOLIVIA
DOC.TEXT: Bolivia supplies about 30 percent of the coca for U.S. cocaine. Cocaine trafficking brings an estimated $200 million to $300 million to Bolivia each year and provides a livelihood for about 300,000 Bolivians. Natural gas, Bolivia's main legal export, earned $214 million in 1988. Mineral exports totaled $196 million.
DOC.HEAD: PERU
DOC.TEXT: About 60 percent of the cocaine in the United States is derived from coca leaves grown in Peru. About 200,000 Peruvians earn their living growing coca. Peru's legal exports total $2.5 billion annually. Drugs bring in an additional $1.2 billion.
DOC.HEAD: UNITED STATES
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's national drug control strategy for 1991, if approved, will cost $10.6 billion. Of the total spending, 42 percent would be for domestic law enforcement, 29 percent for interdiction and 29 percent for prevention and treatment. The plan includes $423 million in drug law enforcement and economic development aid to Colombia, Peru and Bolivia.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Embalmed, Mutilated Body May Have Been Stolen, Used In Ritual
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents.
DOC.TEXT: A mutilated body found in the Mississippi River had been embalmed, authorities said, leading them to believe they have a case of grave robbery and not murder on their hands. Police Chief Bill McCutcheon said Wednesday that the mutilation of the body of an unidentified boy apparently was part of a ``religious group, a fanatical group.'' ``It's sick. You can't say it any better than that,'' he said. ``I mean, think about it.'' Prints from the boy's foot ruled out the possibility that the body found Tuesday was that of 11-year-old Jacob Wetterling, sending waves of relief through the abducted boy's hometown of St. Joseph in central Minnesota. Jacob disappeared last October. A worker at a Mississippi River dam found the unclothed body Tuesday floating near the dam, authorities said. The hands, feet and head had been severed. McCutcheon said the feet were later found nearby. The body was described as that of a boy between the ages of 9 and 13. Authorities stopped treating the case as a homicide when a coroner found embalming fluid in the body, McCutcheon said. The time and cause of death and how long the body might have been in the river were not immediately determined. Investigators were consulting cult experts to determine what kinds of groups may have performed such a ritual. ``We're interested in knowing if there was a ceremony down by the river,'' McCutcheon said. They also were checking with cemeteries to see if there were unreported grave robberies. Sandy Gallant, a San Francisco police officer who has studied occult crimes in the United States, said there have been cases of grave robbery and mutilation as part of some ritual. But she said she knows of no cases where a body was stolen, mutilated and then discarded. ``It would make more sense if the body was found somewhere, at the center of a ritual scene. They usually leave the body where it can be found,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Intense Christian Fighting Resumes in Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 7-8, `The casualties...Christian enclave.' with two grafs to CORRECT official wounded totals. Pickup 9th pvs, `Hassan Hallak...'
DOC.TEXT: Renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's forces pounded residential districts of east Beirut today and launched tank attacks against the strongholds of a rival Christian militia. Police said eight major fires blazed out of control in the Ashrafiyeh district as Aoun's tanks blasted positions of the Lebanese Forces militia in the low-income district of Ein Rummaneh. They reported several other fires in the districts of Nabaa and Ein Rummaneh, controlled by Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. A police spokesman said Aoun was concentrating his ground offensive on Ein Rummaneh, on the southeastern edge of Beirut, while his gunners hammered Ashrafiyeh and the Lebanese Forces' third stronghold at Nabaa with howitzer shells. The spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said at least three people were killed and 12 wounded in the sudden barrage against Ashrafiyeh and Nabaa. Stray shells also crashed into densely populated residential districts in Moslem west and south Beirut, killing at least four people and wounding 39, by police count. The casualties raised the overall toll from 17 days of Christian fighting to 522 killed and 1,775 wounded. The figures include 31 people killed and 149 wounded in the city's Moslem districts, which have not been involved in the fighting for mastery of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. Hassan Hallak, a Shiite Moslem resident of Shiyah, a district bordering Ein Rummaneh, said the Christian area was burning. ``A huge cloud hangs over Ein Rummaneh. Smoke billows from the whole district,'' said Hallak. Moslem and Christian radio stations interrupted regular programming to broadcast reports of renewed hostilities. A relative lull had prevailed over east Beirut since Monday. Aoun's command, in a communique, blamed the clash on the Christian militia. It said Geagea has ``fired the coup de grace'' at attempts by a mediation committee to work out a settlement to the power struggle for control of the estimated 1 million Christians who live in the enclave. The command of Geagea's militia countered the charge, saying the general's men ``surprised civilians with heavy shelling early in the day.'' A police spokesman said the barrage started around 5:30 a.m., just as a few civilians were venturing out of underground shelters to buy bread from the few bakeries that operated in the besieged districts. Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir went on radio to appeal to both Geagea and Aoun to stop fighting. ``The people are on the brink of despair,'' Sfeir said. ``Monasteries, schools and hospitals are in bad need of supplies to help the the wounded, patients and refugees.'' Both Geagea and Aoun are from the Maronite community that has dominated key government posts, the army command and judiciary since independence from France in 1943. Heavy clashes renewed a few hours after Geagea reiterated his rejection of Aoun's proposal to disband the militia and transform it into a political party. ``We want all Lebanese potentials preserved, including our military forces,'' Geagea said Wednesday. Aoun had said Geagea's militiamen should join his army. ``Lebanese forces militiamen won't join the army. Our militiamen are politically minded fighters. The army doesn't have a cause,'' Gagea told a news conference. Aoun rejects the Syrian-backed Christian-Moslem government of President Elias Hrawi and has vowed to drive out the Syrian forces backing Moslem militias. But his latest attentions have been focused on maintaining his hold on the Christian heartland.

DOC.HEAD: Two in Custody in Drive-By Mugging of Woman Killed Beneath Van
DOC.TEXT: One man has been charged with murder and a second is in custody after they allegedly snatched the purse of a woman as they drove by in a van. The woman was killed when she fell under the vehicle. Angel Hernandez, 27, of New York, was charged with murder and robbery in the Jan. 10 incident, Manhattan Chief of Detectives Ronald Fenrich said Wednesday. The other suspect, whose name was not released, was already in jail. He had been arrested Jan. 17 on car theft charges, the chief said. New charges against him are awaiting a grand jury hearing. The victim, Kim Stapleton, 59, of New York, was crossing a street shortly after noon when one of the suspects leaned out the passenger door of a passing van and grabbed her purse. Mrs. Stapleton was dragged a short distance as the mugger wrested her handbag away and fell under the van's rear wheels, police said. Tips from three people Hernandez allegedly told about the killing led detectives to a hotel, where they arrested him Tuesday after a brief struggle, Fenrich said. The two men are suspects in as many as 20 other drive-by purse snatchings dating from November 1989, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Freed After 8 Years in Prison for Robbery He Didn't Commit
With PM-Brown Release
DOC.TEXT: A man who spent nearly eight years jailed for a grocery store robbery he never committed walked out of prison after being given a full pardon. The release Wednesday of Michael Anthony Woten, 36, marked the sixth time since 1984 that an inmate's conviction in Dallas County has been thrown out or reversed and the person freed after spending years in prison. The most famous case was that of Randall Dale Adams, who served 13 years after being convicted of killing a Dallas police officer but was freed last year after his story was told in the film ``The Thin Blue Line.'' Also free Wednesday was Joyce Ann Brown, after prosecutors decided against trying her again on a charge in connection with the holdup of a Dallas fur store. Gov. Bill Clements signed the pardon at midmorning in Austin. Shortly afterward, Texas Department of Corrections officials picked Woten up at the Eastham prison farm for the drive to the Walls Unit at Huntsville, where he was given a new Social Security card, $200 and his freedom. Woten said inmates, guards and prison officials cheered and clapped when he drove away. ``It was like being at a football match.'' ``I don't think it's quite hit me yet, until a few hours ago,'' Woten said later. ``I was still incarcerated and did only what I was told to do. It's going to take me some time to realize that I'm free and I can start doing what I want to do.'' Woten had been convicted in the April 1982 armed robbery of a north Dallas supermarket and sentenced to 55 years in prison. Five witnesses testified that he was one of two men dubbed the Cowboy Bandits who robbed that store and another grocery. Woten insisted that at the time of the robbery he was hitchhiking from Dallas to St. Louis. He said he got a ride with a trucker he could identify only as Don and ``Kangaroo'' _ the man's citizens' band radio nickname. The Dallas Times Herald launched a search for ``Kangaroo'' after Woten got a statement from another inmate that the inmate and another man had robbed the store. The paper succeeded, and the man, Don Fainter of Claycomo, Mo., told authorities last month he had indeed given Woten a ride the day the robbery. Woten said he plans to open a leather crafts shop, taking advantage of the leatherworking skills he learned in prison. After trading his white prison shirt for a blue one, Woten swore he would never again wear white. ``Even if I become a painter, I'm going to wear plaid,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: With PM Drug Summit Bjt
Bush Arrives In Bad Mood Over Press Coverage
DOC.TEXT: President Bush expressed irritation with the news media today as he flew to Colombia for a four-nation drug conference, criticizing reports that he said suggested he was secretive and deceptive. ``From now on, it's going to be a little different,'' Bush asserted. The president vowed to hold fewer news conferences and to restrict his sessions with reporters in the future. ``I'm not going to be burned for holding out or doing something deceptive,'' Bush fumed. Bush aired his grievances with the news media in a chat with reporters aboard Air Force One, shortly before he landed here to transfer to a helicopter that would take him to Cartagena for a drug summit with the presidents of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru. What apparently riled the president were news stories suggesting that he had sometimes said one thing, then done something else. For instance, his comments at a news conference on Monday that he did not think it was time for a four-power conference on the future of Germany came a day before a major agreement on German reuinification was reached in Ottawa. ``When I told you ... that I didn't think there'd be a deal and there shortly was a deal, then I'm hit for deceiving you,'' Bush said. He said that at his news conference he did not know that an agreement that would involve oversight by the four post-World War II European powers _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ was at hand. The president expressed his testiness from the start of today's exchange with reporters accompanying him here on Air Force One. Bush had slept aboard the plane in a hangar at Andrews Air Force Base in the Maryland suburbs so that he would not arrive in Colombia sleepy after today's pre-dawn flight, and he was asked if he had enjoyed a good night's sleep. ``I had a very good night's sleep. I can't get into the details of that because some will say it's too much sleep, some will say it's too little.'' Then, the president added, ``I think we've had too many press conferences. It's not good. It overdoes it. It's overexposure.'' Bush has had about a news conference a week on the average, since he took office on Jan. 20, 1989. ``I'm taking no answers to questions. I'm not going to discuss what I'm going to bring up,'' Bush said when asked about his agenda for the day's drug conference. ``I'm not going to discuss whether there's any surprises or not. This is a new thing. This is a new approach.'' Asked about an NBC-TV report that Colombian President Virgilio Barco had made a deal with some drug lords in his country not to extradite them to the United States if they turned over drug labs, Bush snapped: ``I have no comment whatsoever on that. I have no comment on whether I know about it or not. I can't comment on whether it's true or not.'' ``So from now on, it's going to be a little different,'' he added. ``We're going to have a new relationship. It will be pleasant. It will be fun. But it's different.'' ``I'm not going to be burned for holding out or doing something deceptive.'' Bush did not mention which news reports he was referring to. However, today's editions of the Washington Post, copies of which were on Bush's plane, had a story on what it called ``the debate between President Bush and the press over secrecy and deception.''

DOC.HEAD: Police: Rebels Throw Bombs at U.S., Panama Embassies
DOC.TEXT: Leftist guerrillas threw bombs at the United States and Panamanian embassies and an American-owned auto parts company office, causing some damage but no injuries, police said today. In separate, nearly simultaneous attacks, the bombs were thrown from passing cars shortly before midnight Wednesday, police said. Authorities found flyers at the facilities linking the three bombings to the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, police said. They said the flyers criticized President Guillermo Endara of Panama and called for new elections in Panama. Endara took over as Panama's president after U.S. troops invaded the country Dec. 20 to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, whose handpicked candidate had defeated Endara in an election widely believed to be fraudulent. The invasion was sharply criticized by Peru's president, Alan Garcia. Police said the bomb at the U.S. Embassy caused little damage. The main door and several windows at the Panamanian Embassy were destroyed. Windows and doors also were damaged at the offices of the auto parts company, Champion S.A., which sells automobile spark plugs. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement is Peru's second strongest guerrilla group after the Maoist Shining Path. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement took up arms against Peru's elected government in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Starts Rebound at Fastest Level
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 1st and 3rd grafs to make percentage increase the highest, not the totals; INSERTS two grafs of Mortgage Bankers' reaction after 5th graf, Some, like
DOC.TEXT: Housing starts, boosted by the warmest January on record, rebounded 29.6 percent for their biggest gain on record last month after falling to a seven-year low during December's cold spell, the government said today. The Commerce Department said new homes and apartments were built at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.63 million units in January after slumping a revised 6.9 percent in December. Starts in December originally were reported to be down 7.9 percent. The department said the January increase, which it attributed to unusually warm weather, was the highest since housing starts first were recorded in 1959. It topped the previous record gain of 29.3 percent reached in July 1982. Analysts had expected a big jump in starts during January because of the contrast in weather from December. Some, like Michael P. Niemira of the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, suggested in advance of today's report that a truer picture of housing activity could be drawn by averaging the starts for the two months. Thomas Holloway, senior economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, also said the jump was weather-related. ``Levels like the ones we're seeing here would indicate a housing boom and there is just simply no fundamental reason to believe that is going on,'' he said. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said January temperatures were the warmest for that month since the government began keeping records 96 years ago. December was the fourth coldest on record, it said. Many analysts also expect starts this year to total about the same as 1989's 1.37 million units because of the sluggish economy. Some, however, said rising move interest rates could slow starts further. Construction of single-family homes rose 24.8 percent in January to an annual rate of 1.14 million units after falling 9.8 percent in December. The increase was the steepest for single dwellings since a 26 percent gain in March 1979. Apartment construction jumped 42.3 percent to an annual rate of 488,000 units after a revised 1.8 percent gain in December. The December figure originally had been reported to be a drop of 2.4 percent. January's gain in apartment starts was the sharpest since a 56 percent advance in January 1985. The Midwest recorded the steepest jump in overall starts, up 42.6 percent, but the other regions also posted sharp gain. Starts were up 38.6 percent in the Northeast, 24.6 percent in the South and 23.1 percent in the West. Applications for building permits, a barometer of future housing activity, jumped 26.7 percent, the highest gain since a 30 percent jump in June 1980. Applications had risen 2.5 percent in December.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Says It Should Be Permitted at Talks; Walesa Presses for Troop Pullout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Walesa comments. Pickup 2nd graf pvs, `Nothing about...' Edits thereafter to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa, distancing himself from the government he helped create, said today that a reunified Germany poses no danger to Poland and he wants Soviet troops out as soon as possible. The Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki has adopted a more tolerant attitude toward Soviet withdrawal, saying the 40,000 troops in Poland should leave only after creation of a new security arrangement for Europe. But Walesa insted that the Red Army withdraws this year. ``I will continue activities so that the Soviet troops are removed from Poland as soon as possible,'' Walesa told reporters. Referring to suggestions from President Wojciech Jaruzelski and the pro-Solidarity newspaper Gazeta Wyborcza that the Soviet troops help ensure Poland's security in the face of a reunifying Germany, the Solidarity union chairman said: ``I don't envision any danger on the part of Germany because Europe has had too many bad experiences to allow the Germans that.'' Walesa also seemed to depart from the government's insistence that Poland be present at planned six-nation German reunification talks involving East Germany, West Germany and the four post-war occupying powers: the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. ``What is important is what role would Poland play'' at such talks, Walesa said. ``...I think Poland could not be very effective there,'' he said. But others in Poland, conquered twice this century by a united Germany and then abandoned by the Allies to the Soviets, says it cannot risk being shut out of talks on the future of Germany. ``Nothing about us, without us,'' government spokesman Henryk Wozniakowski said Wednesday, quoting a Polish proverb. ``Our stand is that our security matters cannot be settled by proxy for us. We must be present,'' Mazowiecki told a news conference in London. East and West Germany and the four powers that occupied Germany at the end of World War II agreed Tuesday on a framework for talks that will lead to German reunification. Some Germans, including West German Finance Minister Teodor Waigel, say Germany still in theory exists within its 1937 borders _ in other words, spreading over much of present-day Poland. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Tuesday passed up an opportunity to allay Polish fears, saying that decision should be left to the future government. ``We are the only country in which the situation is unclear,'' said Wozniakowski. Poland is not seeking full membership in the talks, he said. But it does insist on participating in those sessions that touch on its ``vital interests,'' primarily the question of German borders. Wozniakowski said Britain, the United States and the Soviet Union were sympathetic to Poland's appeal and Mazowiecki ``certainly'' will press for East Berlin's support Friday when East German Premier Hans Modrow visits. Resistance, however, was coming from West Germany. A Bonn government official said Poland or other neighboring states had no reason to be involved in the negotiations. ``The unification proposal involves only the territory of West Germany, East Germany and Berlin,'' he said on condition of anonymity. ``There is no reason for fear in Poland.'' Poles are sensitive to the issue because of past German aggression and because right-wing German politicians have never reliquished claims to the 40,000 square miles of territory Poland was awarded from Germany at the end of World War II _ compensation for an even larger area taken from Poland by the Soviet Union. The territory acquired after World War II comprises about one-third of present-day Poland. Germans fled or were expelled after the war and millions of Poles, mostly expelled from the Soviet-annexed territories, moved in. Today, about 10.4 million of Poland's 38 million people live on formerly German territory. Only about 1 million ethnic Germans live in Poland now.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Work to Raise California's Primary Profile
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts graf 9, Scott Scowry, with Republican comment
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic Party is changing its rules to permit California to hold one of the first presidential primaries of 1992, a move aimed at giving the nation's largest state more influence in selecting the nominee. Party activists say other states may advance the dates of their primaries as well. The Democratic National Committee's rules panel voted Wednesday to allow most states to hold primaries or caucuses as early as the first Tuesday in March, one week after New Hampshire holds the first primary and one week earlier than previously allowed. The change is expected to be approved easily by the full DNC next month. It means a proposal now in the California legislature to set its presidential primaries on March 3, 1992, would be permissible under national Democratic Party rules. The California assembly has approved shifting the state's presidential primary from June to that early March date, and a state Senate vote is expected. ``The obvious intention is to give California the chance to go early and the opportunity to have more say in the process,'' said Donald L. Fowler, cochairman of the rules committee and DNC member from South Carolina. ``I anticipate other states will move up to that Tuesday,'' he said. ``I don't think other states will let California have that Tuesday to themselves.'' Scott Scowry, deputy press secretary for the Republican National Committee, said, ``We're delighted with the prospect'' of California holding both parties' primaries in early March. He said he did not believe any GOP rules would be affected by California's change. The new Democratic rules still allow Iowa's caucuses to be the first presidential delegate-selection event, followed eight days later by New Hampshire's primary. A special provision would permit Maine to begin its caucus process earlier too, but other states would have to fall within the so-called ``window'' from the first Tuesday in March to the second Tuesday in June. California, under this schedule, would become the first big state to vote, holding its primary one week after New Hampshire's. The so-called Super Tuesday round of primaries would follow a week after California, and Illinois would follow a week later. ``It is important that a large state crucial to electing a Democratic president weigh in early in the process,'' Brown said. California's June primary date in past years has placed it at the end of the delegate-selection process, when the nominee was already a foregone conclusion. ``California felt very strongly they wanted to be a player in the process,'' said Alice Travis, a member of the DNC executive committee from California. ``Coming last made it somewhat irrelevant.'' Some believe placing California so early in the primary season will diminish the importance of Iowa and New Hampshire, by tradition the two earliest states. With California following so quickly, they reason, well-financed, well-known candidates may concentrate instead on California, the state with the most delegates. Party strategists hope that advancing primary calendar will enable the party to decide on a nominee earlier in the year and have more time to concentrate on the general election campaign. But Fowler cautioned there could be unintended consequences _ such as splintering the field and prolonging the selection of a nominee. ``This is a mechanical adjustment, the political impact of which is unknown and subject to various interpretations,'' Fowler said. Other changes allow the party to apply a new sanction against states that violate national party rules by holding their primaries or caucuses too early, or violate other delegate-selection rules. The change would provide an automatic 25 percent reduction in the state's total delegates. In the past, the only sanction available to the party was refusal to seat a violating state's delegation _ a sanction so severe the party often ignored violations.

DOC.HEAD: Polls: Governing Party Victory Likely in Sunday's Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd pvs, `Also today...' to CORRECT that candidate was not in the car that was shot at. Pickup 4th, `The five...'
DOC.TEXT: The Liberal Democratic Party is likely to hold on to its majority in the lower house of Parliament following the general election, according to public opinion polls published today. But from 30 percent to 40 percent of voters questioned remained undecided, according to surveys by the Asahi Shimbun, the Yomiuri Shimbun, the Mainichi Shimbun, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun and Kyodo News Service. Also today, a shot was fired at a campaign car of a candidate, slightly wounding one of the politician's assistants, a news report said. The five nationwide surveys _ conducted in the past two weeks and released three days before Sunday's election _ reached similar conclusions. The Asahi survey of 103,200 eligible voters projected the Liberal Democrats will end up with 271 seats in the House of Representatives, down from their current 295 seats but well over 257 seats needed for a majority. The lower house names the prime minister and has the power to adopt the national budget and treaties, even without approval of the upper house, which can block legislation on other issues. The Yomiuri Shimbun put the Liberal Democrats' total at 260 seats, while Mainichi Shimbun estimated 265. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a financial daily, said the Liberal Democrats may lose about 10 seats to the Socialists but that the conservative party's new candidates ``are faring well,'' and will offset some veterans' losses. Yomiuri questioned 100,000 voters; Mainichi 91,520 and Nikon Keizai 52,000. Kyodo News Service, in a poll of 110,000 voters, said the Liberal Democrats will win at least 259 seats and could get up to 285. The polls generally agreed the leading opposition group, the Japan Socialist Party, will do well, reaching 120 seats from its previous 85, according to the Asahi. Other major opposition parties _ the Clean Government Party with 54 seats in the last session, the Japan Communist Party with 26 and the Democratic Socialist Party with 25 _ are all projected to lose strength. The polls were done through interviews of a set number of voters in each of Japan's 130 constituencies. No margins of error were provided. Opposition parties are criticizing the Liberal Democrats for an unpopular 3 percent sales tax instituted in April and for their involvement with the Recruit Inc., a large conglomerate that tried to influence politicians with contributions and cheap stock deals. Opposition candidates are calling for political reform to prevent corruption and are seeking support among traditionally conservative farmers by stressing their opposition to opening Japan's agricultural markets to less expensive imports. Besides the apparent vulnerability of the governing party, the other new wrinkle in this campaign year has been the level of violence. Kyodo News Service said from Yamaguchi, 500 miles southwest of Tokyo, that a shot was fired today from a pellet gun at a campaign car of candidate Shinji Sato, a former transport minister and four-term Liberal Democratic lawmaker. Sato was not in the car, but a woman campaign assistant was slightly injured, the report said. On Tuesday, Liberal Democrat candidate Koichi Hamada, a former vice minister of agriculture, was hit on the head with a club as he was leaving a campaign rally in a city east of Tokyo. He suffered moderate injuries. Police arrested a member of one of Japan's largest criminal syndicates and said he told them he ``wanted to hurt'' Hamada ``because he has a bad personality.'' On Wednesday, a male telephone caller warned that a bomb was aboard an airplane carrying Socialist Party Chairwoman Takako Doi on a campaign trip. No bomb was found. On Sunday, a member of a rightist group walked into a campaign office of former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone and fired three shots at a television set, a campaign poster and a doll symbolizing good luck, police said. Nakasone was out campaigning at the time and no one was injured, they said. Nagasaki Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima was shot in the back on Jan. 18 as he was leaving city hall. The rightist charged in the shooting told police he hated Motoshima because the mayor said the late Emperor Hirohito shared some of the responsibility for World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Lawmakers Debate Whether to Let Citizens Own Property
DOC.TEXT: Soviet legislators clashed today over a proposal to restore private property rights in the Soviet Union, and one Ukrainian lawmaker said such an idea is so radical that it should be put to a national referendum. ``We have to ask the people,'' said lawmaker Leonid Sukhov of Kharkov. ``The people know better.'' While the 35-article property bill does not go as far as to use the word ``private property,'' it does recognize the right for the existence of diverse forms of property and says that citizens can own property, including houses and apartments, for private use. The proposal does not clearly state whether land can be privately owned. State ownership of all land is a fundamental principle of Marxism. In another departure from orthodox dogma, which forbids individuals to own factories and equipment on a large-scale, the bill says citizens can now own the ``means of production'' for farming and other labor activities. The bill also would allow foreigners to enjoy the same rights as Soviet citizens in owning property. Citizens could own stocks and bonds. Deputy Prime Minister Leonid Abalkin urged the legislature today to consider the proposal with great care. Abalkin addressed the packed legislature that had adopted a 22-point agenda, which includes measures to strengthen the presidency now held by Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. After its first reading before the 542-member Supreme Soviet last fall, the bill underwent substantial revisions with at least 10,000 changes written into the lengthy draft, the Tass news agency reported. During the initial debate, conflict arose over who currently owns land and natural resources _ the national government or the individual republics. That issue has been skirted in the draft in favor of phrasing that says the land and its resources ``belong to people living on a given territory.'' The issue is critical because the legislature in Lithuania has already adopted laws that allow the sale of land to individuals. In his report read at the start of the session today, Abalkin, a noted Soviet economist who helped write the draft, told the legislators that attempts have been made to reach a compromise during the course of revision. But already today the bill aroused controversy at the Supreme Soviet, which was meeting in a building in the Kremlin. More than 20 speakers asked to take the floor for a five-minute chance to suggest changes or express approval. One speaker objected to the introduction of private property on the ground that it would favor city dwellers with money rather than collective farm workers who had spent their life on the land but had no savings. Another speaker claimed that the language of the bill was too vague and that it needed to be rewritten in a clearer fashion. At a news conference after the morning session, Abalkin acknowledged that society had mixed feelings about the bill, but that the important thing was that no option could be excluded in the pursuit of economic reform. He said it was important that there should be complete freedom for individuals in economic activity and that local authorities should have greater responsibility in establishing property laws. Debate was continuing today.

DOC.HEAD: Six Air Force Base Guards Suspended While Alleged Klan Activity Probed
DOC.TEXT: Six Carswell Air Force Base security police have been suspended from regular duty pending an investigation into alleged ties to the Ku Klux Klan, a base spokeswoman said. ``Their commander was notified of alleged Klan involvement, and they were removed from normal security police duties,'' said Capt. Barbara Carr. Membership in the Klan does not violate military rules, but disciplinary action could be taken if it is determined that the guards broke civilian laws while engaging in Klan activities, she said. Ms. Carr said she doesn't know whether other base personnel are being investigated. Only one of the six has been identified _ Sgt. Timothy Hall, 24, who also worked for the Tarrant County Sheriff's Department. He was fired from that job after the department learned he is the ``kleagle,'' or chief Klan recruiter, in Texas. Hall was suspended from his Air Force base job Saturday after he was fired from the county job. Ms. Carr announced the suspension of the five other Air Force guards Wednesday. Hall has acknowledged being a Klan official, but says his personal beliefs have not affected his work in the sheriff's deparment. ``Just because I wear a badge does not give me the right to force those beliefs on the public at large,'' he said. Two other sheriff's department workers who were fired because of alleged Klan ties, Charlyn Kay Moore and David White, have declined to comment on the advice of their attorneys pending their appeals.

DOC.HEAD: Newscaster Win Lawsuit for Defamation by ``Shock Radio'' Colleagues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to CORRECT size of judgment from $650,000 to $694,200, and INSERTS one graf after the 4th with details of additional awards.
DOC.TEXT: A jury ordered a radio station and two disc jockeys to pay $694,200 in damages to a news director whom they referred to with risque jokes on a ``shock radio'' program. Liz Randolph, 32, claimed the jokes, which implied she was promiscuous and mentally unstable, caused her to suffer panic attacks and led her to seek psychiatric treatment. Disc jockeys Jim Quinn and Donald ``Banana Don'' Jefferson, and EZ Communication, owner of WBZZ-FM, were found liable for defamation and invasion of privacy and ordered to pay about $260,000 in damages. Ms. Randolph won an additional $390,000 from Quinn and Jefferson for intentional infliction of emotional distress. In addition, the jury awarded Ms. Randolph $30,704 for medical bills and $13,500 for lost wages. Ms. Randolph said she was glad she had endured a two-week trial that made public much of her personal life, including details of her psychiatric history. ``We knew it was going to be tough,'' she said. One of her attorneys, Samuel P. Kamin, said Wednesday's verdict by the Allegheny County Common Pleas jury sends a message to broadcasters about airing risque humor, especially jokes that target co-workers. ``I think that's something the industry's going to have to think twice about now,'' he said. ``The signal this sends is the workplace is no place for abuse.'' ``I think there's no question this will have an impact on the kind of conduct you'll hear on morning shows,'' said Jeff Pollack, a Los Angeles-based media adviser. ``It's clear this case will make a lot of people think twice what they say to fellow workers on the air.'' Pollack said innuendo of the type used on Quinn and Jefferson's show is common in morning radio talk shows around the nation. The verdict could restrict creative freedom and make disgruntled employees more likely to sue, he said. Jimmy Roach, part of the morning team at WMYG-FM in Pittsburgh, said off-beat humor has its place in radio. But members of a broadcast team should agree on jokes and comedy bits before they are aired, he said. Federal Communications Commission Chairman Alfred C. Sikes has been cracking down on ``shock radio'' since he took office in August. Twelve stations have been cited for indecency since then. Ms. Randolph began working for WBZZ in May 1985 and walked off the job Jan. 22, 1988, after Quinn and Jefferson aired a joke she said shocked her. The disc jockeys and station management contended the remarks were not meant to be taken seriously and said Ms. Randolph knew the ``absurdist'' format of the broadcast when she was hired. They also said she did not complain about the jokes to the announcers or to management. Quinn, 46, and Jefferson, 30, were not in the courtroom when the verdict was announced and their attorney, Foster S. Goldman Jr., said no decision had been made about appealing the case.

DOC.HEAD: First Guilty Plea in Noriega Drug Case
DOC.TEXT: A pilot who flew cocaine profits to Panama pleaded guilty today to one count of illegally transporting funds, becoming the first person indicted with former Panama dictator Manuel Noriega to admit wrongdoing. But the attorney for Eduardo Pardo, 44, said he did not know if his client would testify against Noriega and the other defendants in the drug conspiracy case. ``That's all up to him,'' said lawyer William Meadows, a former U.S. attorney in Miami, who said there was no plea bargain with the government. The pilot pleaded guilty to making a flight with $800,000 in drug money from Fort Lauderdale to Panama in 1983. Noriega, who is still arguing with prosecutors over their right to prosecute him, is accused of taking payoffs to protect the cocaine trade. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler told Pardo he could face up to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine on the charges. Attending Pardo's change-of-plea hearing were several attorneys for the other five defendants either in custody or out on bond, including Noriega's lawyer Frank Rubino. Federal prosecutors, who are under a gag order in the case, refused to comment on the plea. Richard Sharpstein, attorney for defendant Brian Alden Davidow, told The Associated Press that even without an agreement to testify for the government, Pardo's plea made him a likely witness. ``Now that he's pleaded guilty, Pardo can be summoned before a federal grand jury to testify, and cannot invoke the Fifth Amendment against self-incrimination,'' Sharpstein said. At a hearing Wednesday, government and defense attorneys wrangled over what the defense said was a failure of the prosecution to turn over an inventory of materials seized in Noriega's homes and offices in Panama. Noriega attorney Steven Kollin told Magistrate William C. Turnoff: ``We haven't received the inventories and we feel we are being stonewalled. I feel we are dealing with two governments _ the military and the U.S. attorney's office.'' But Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael P. Sullivan told Turnoff: ``We have supplied a partial inventory and we are continuing to update all the time and they have been sent to Mr. Kollin.'' Kollin said he had not received the partial inventory, but Turnoff said that he felt the government was making a good faith effort to comply with his orders.

DOC.HEAD: Hackers Convicted of Selling Computer Codes to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: Three West German hackers were found guilty today of selling Western military computer codes to the Soviet KGB and given suspended sentences ranging from 14 months to two years. Dirk Brzezinski, Peter Carl and Markus Hess were arrested in March after an investigation by U.S. and West German officials revealed the three had obtained passwords and codes giving them access to key military and research computers in the United States, Western Europe and Japan. A fourth man, 30-year-old Karl Koch, who was also arrested in the case, committed suicide in May. At the trial, which began Jan. 11, all three admitted guilt in obtaining the codes to sell them to a Soviet KGB agent in East Berlin. In today's decision, Chief Judge Leopold Spiller said the three were given suspended sentences because ``it could not be proven that substantial damage had been done to the Federal Republic (West Germany) or its NATO partners.'' But Spiller also said the three sold the computer codes for money. Carl was sentenced to 24 months, Hess 20 months and Brzezinski 14 months. All three men were freed on suspended sentences as long as they stay out of trouble with the law for the duration of their terms. Carl, 35, told the court during the trial that he could only identify the KGB agent he dealt with as ``Serge'' and said he did not wish to reveal anything more about the Soviets in open court for fear of reprisals. Court records show that Carl made at least 25 contacts with the Soviets and received a total $54,500 for the computer information, which was split among the hackers, amateurs who figure out ways to access private computer systems. Brzezinksi, 30, told the court that Koch had the original idea of selling the information to the KGB. According to Brzezinski, Koch claimed he had gained access to the U.S. Defense Department general databank known as Optimus. U.S. and West German news media reported the hackers also gained access to a NASA and a ``Star Wars'' research computer, and computers linked to nuclear weapons and energy research in New Mexico and the Fermi Laboratory in Illinois.
