However, U.S. officials said last year that although the hackers obtained sensitive codes and passwords to enter the computers, they were stopped short of obtaining any highly classified information. Investigators said at the time of the arrests that codes and passwords for computers in Japan, Great Britain, France, Italy, Switzerland and West Germany were also obtained and sold to the Soviets by the hackers.

DOC.HEAD: UMW To Go Ahead With Pittston Contract Vote
DOC.TEXT: The United Mine Workers is proceeding with a rank-and-file vote on a contract with Pittston Coal Group though $64 million in strike-related fines have not been dropped, a UMW official said today. The union's turnabout means that a vote to end the 10-month strike against the nation's largest coal exporter could come as early as Monday, according to Don McCamey, secretary-treasurer of UMW District 28 in Castlewood. UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts plans to meet with local and district union officials tonight at Castlewood High School to brief them on terms of the contract, UMW officials confirmed. There also will be an emergency meeting of the UMW board in Duffield tonight, they said. Roberts plans to meet Friday with Pittston's 1,700 union miners on strike in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. UMW rules specify that a 48-hour period must pass before a vote so miners have time to study the terms of the contract. A settlement was reached New Year's Eve with the help of William Usery, a special mediator appointed by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole, but terms have not been disclosed publicly. Sources familiar with the agreement, however, said the union won concessions they sought on the two biggest concerns: job security and health and retirement benefits. UMW President Richard Trumka said on Jan. 1 that the union would withhold a rank-and-file vote until all legal action connected with the strike was settled. On Monday, Russell County Circuit Judge Donald McGlothlin refused to dismiss $64 million in fines against the union for several hundred violations of court-ordered strike restrictions. McGlothlin rejected arguments by attorneys for the union and the company, which joined in the motion to drop the fines, and he refused the union's offer of 10,000 hours of community service. However, he gave the attorneys 10 days to come up with another proposal to clear the contempt-of-court fines. On Wednesday, U.S. District Judge Glen Williams agreed to reduce the fines he levied from $960,000 to $280,000 and Trumka responded later in the day that the federal judge's decision to uphold a nearly a third of the fines would not in itself hold up a contract vote.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Experiment Gets Galileo to Send Venus Photos Early
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers were unwilling to wait until October to see the Galileo spacecraft's photographs of Venus, so they used an experimental method to get three of the pictures sent to Earth early. One of the photos released Wednesday shows clouds as small as 25 miles wide as well as clouds rising from lower in the atmosphere. It was taken Monday night when the Jupiter-bound Galileo was about 1 million miles past Venus, the second planet from the sun. ``You can see clouds, and you can see some very interesting detail in the cloud patterns,'' said Neal Ausman, Galileo mission director at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``The engineers and scientists are exceptionally pleased.'' Galileo is scheduled to go into orbit around Jupiter in December 1995 in a $1.35 billion mission to study the solar system's largest planet. Just before 10 p.m. PST last Friday, the spacecraft swooped about 10,025 miles over Venus so that planet could act as a gravity slingshot to help hurl the spacecraft on its way to Jupiter. Most of the photographs and other data collected during and after the flyby won't be sent back until October, when the spacecraft is closer to Earth. Galileo's main antenna now is furled to protect it from the heat of the sun. A smaller antenna, which can transmit and receive information only at a very slow rate, is being used almost exclusively to operate the spacecraft. But NASA engineers were able to get Galileo to send the three photos back to Earth on Monday and Tuesday by transferring separate batches of the computer data that make up each image for radio transmission, Ausman said. NASA spokesman Jim Wilson called the technique ``experimental and difficult.'' Ausman said engineers also were able to get the spacecraft to send back some infrared light measurements designed to study Venus' lower atmosphere, as well as ultraviolet light measurements and data from sensors designed to detect dust and magnetic fields in space around Venus. By the time Galileo's fly-by of Venus formally ends Friday night, the spacecraft's television camera will have taken about 80 pictures of cloud-shrouded Venus. Many other spacecraft have photographed Venus, some from much closer than Galileo. But the new photos still should have scientific value, Ausman said. Galileo was deployed from the space shuttle Atlantis last Oct. 18 on a looping 2.4 billion, six-year route that requires Venus and Earth to be used as gravity slingshots to hurl the spacecraft to Jupiter. It will fly past Earth on Dec. 8, then again on Dec. 8, 1992. Meanwhile, in the outer reaches of the solar system, the Voyager 1 spacecraft sent radio signals indicating it had successfully snapped photographs to make up the first group portrait of the solar system, according to JPL spokeswoman Mary Hardin. Voyager 1, which photographed Jupiter in 1980 and Saturn in 1981, was ordered to shoot the pictures Tuesday evening. But it took five hours and 36 minutes for confirmation of the photographs to travel the 3.7 billion miles to Earth, Hardin said Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Charged in Bombing Plot to Win Freedom for Drug Runner
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Louisville, Tenn., is cq in 7th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A federal indictment charges seven people with plotting to blow up a nuclear plant, airport, dam and other installations to try to spring a jailed drug runner. The indictment was unsealed Wednesday after a four-year investigation by the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said U.S. Attorney Ray Rukstele. Five of those named were already in custody on drug and racketeering charges, including the drug runner whose freedom was allegedly being sought. The two remaining suspects were arrested Wednesday, Rukstele said. The indictment says the seven planned to bomb a nuclear power plant, an East Coast airport, power transmission towers, a dam and a Navy ship in a scheme to barter the release of Jerry Allen LeQuire of Maryville, Tenn. Rukstele declined to identify the intended targets. LeQuire, 46, was convicted last year in an Alabama federal court of importing about 33 tons of cocaine to the southeastern United States. He was sentenced to 20 years in prison, to be served after a 36-year term he was already serving for other drug-related convictions. Indicted with LeQuire Tuesday were Bonnie Sue Anders, 41, of Corbin, Ky.; Michael Carl Jenkins, 40, of Greenback, Tenn.; Charles Allen LeQuire, 26, William Michael LeQuire, 28, and James Thomas LeQuire, 39, all of Maryville, Tenn.; and Gene Edward LeQuire, 42, of Louisville, Tenn. Authorities would not comment beyond information contained in the indictment, so it was not immediately clear how the other LeQuires were related to Jerry Allen LeQuire. The seven are charged with conspiracy to violate federal explosives laws, two counts of detonating explosives to destroy property used in interstate commerce and illegally transporting explosives across state lines. Jenkins also is accused of bombing two transmission towers near Atlanta in 1985. The seven face possible 35-year jail sentences and fines of up to $1 million if convicted. According to the indictment, the plot was supposed to work this way: The group would acquire explosives and rent a house in Orlando, Fla., where some of the explosives would be stored. An innocent dupe of Latin American origin would be found to live in the house. Jenkins was to carry out the actual bombings, the indictment said. After each bombing, The Miami Herald would be phoned and told the bombings were in retaliation for American actions in Central America. Jerry LeQuire then would offer, through his Latin American drug contacts, to help ``find'' the bomber in exchange for his freedom. He would produce the address of the house and the dupe would be arrested. The indictment does not say if a dupe was found. It says the plotting took place between June 1985 and January 1986. The two arrested in Knoxville, Tenn., Wednesday were Gene and William LeQuire, Rukstele said.

DOC.HEAD: Redoubt Erupts Again; Ash Cloud Drifting Toward Kenai Peninsula
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with ash blowing six miles high, FAA warning, moves up reference to previous air travel disruption, adds background on damaged KLM plane.
DOC.TEXT: A strong eruption of Redoubt Volcano this morning blew abrasive ash more than six miles into the sky and across the Cook Inlet toward the port town of Homer. State Seismologist John Davies said the latest eruption began at 4:03 a.m. ``We've got reports from the Drift River (oil) Terminal that there's a lot of lightning around the mountain,'' Davies said. ``They're packing up to evacuate. ``We also got reports from troopers in Homer that they can see the ash clouds ... that the winds appear to be taking the steam and ash plume in that direction.'' The mountain was quiet for 25 years until a series of eruptions began in mid-December, disrupting air travel and mail in and out of Anchorage during the holidays because the airborne ash particles can damage or shut down aircraft engines. The Federal Aviation Administration immediately issued new flight restrictions today, warning aircraft to remain at least 20 miles from the mountain. An airline pilot en route to Anchorage reported an ash cloud ranging from 31,000- to 33,000 feet today, Davies said. ``Winds at that flight level were about 91 knots (105 mph), and they were blowing from the northwest,'' Davies said. ``Seismic signals from the mountain during the initial moments of the eruption were as strong as any we've received since the mountain became active several months ago,'' Davies said. The mountain began generating more earthquake activity a couple of days ago, leading seismologists to believe another eruption was coming, he said. ``We did expect one, but not this soon.'' An state trooper dispatcher in Soldotna confirmed that ash was falling in the Ninilchik area of the Kenai Peninsula. But she said there were no immediate reports of any ash fall around Soldotna. Redoubt Volcano is 115 miles southwest of Anchorage. A KLM Royal Dutch Airlines Boeing 747 encountered an ash cloud from Redoubt on Dec. 15, two days after the mountain began erupting. The ash clogged all four engines and the aircraft fell more than two miles before the engines could be restarted. It made a successful emergency landing at Anchorage International Airport, but preliminary estimates of damage to the three-month-old aircraft were $50 million.

DOC.HEAD: Precede JOHANNESBURG
Mandela Says Government Insallations Fair Game For Guerrilla Attacks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with Mandela comments. Pickup 5th graf pvs, ``Our people...'' Edits thereafter to trim.
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela said today that his guerrilla movement considers government installations to be legitimate targets for attack and that civilians inevitably will be caught in the cross fire. Mandela, released Feb. 11 after 27 years in prison, said there has been no decision to suspend the armed struggle, which has been largely dormant in recent months. ``Our objective is that the targets are government installations,'' Mandela said in an interview from his home in Soweto, the township outside Johannesburg. ``In a conflict civilians must be caught up in cross fire.'' Mandela helped launch the African National Congress' guerrilla campaign in 1961, a year after the organization was outlawed. The official policy always has been to limit attacks to government facilities and personnel, although some ANC leaders have expressed a desire to hit civilian targets. There have been numerous attacks on civilians in recent years, but the ANC has said those were the results of guerrillas who had not undergone proper training. President F.W. de Klerk legalized the ANC on Feb. 2, but the group says its armed struggle remains one of its strategies to put pressure on the government. Asked if the country's 5 million whites would have to change their lifestyles under an ANC government, Mandela said: ``They are already adjusting themselves to changes.'' He cited recently integrated beaches, the fact that a few select neighborhoods have been opened to all races and that some private schools are integrated, although public schools remain segregated. ``Whites in this country are a very important section of the community and without them, without their cooperation, we will have immense problems,'' Mandela said. ``That is why we are so keen to ensure ... that the changes we are demanding are not going to mean domination of whites or blacks.'' De Klerk wants to negotiate a new constitution that will include the 28 million black majority in the national government. But he opposes a one-man, one-vote system and outright black majority rule. He envisions some mechanism that will give whites veto power on major policy decisions. Earlier today, Mandela met Jesse Jackson on his final day of an eight-day visit to South Africa. The former Democratic presidential candidate said South African blacks still were not free and the United States and Western Europe must put pressure, including economic sanctions, on the government to end apartheid. ``We must not lower the standards of democracy or expectations for democracy in South Africa,'' Jackson said. In the capital of Pretoria, supporters of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party held a rally to call for the removal of de Klerk and new elections. ``Our people have kept a low profile up to now, but we have fought for our own fatherland and that fatherland you will not take away from us,'' Conservative leader Andries Treurnicht told a rally Wednesday night in Bloemfontein. The opposition has denounced de Klerk for freeing Mandela and legalizing the ANC and other black opposition groups in an effort to start talks on ending the white monopoly on power. The Conservative Party wants South Africa split into separate states for whites and blacks. It received 31 percent of the vote in September elections, in which only whites could vote. Government officials said 1,000 army troops would be deployed in Natal Province to help police quell fighting between conservative and radical black factions. Police said protesters fired at police vehicles overnight, and one officer was shot and wounded near Durban. Mandela, in news interviews Wednesday, said the ANC is willing to compromise with the white government on a post-apartheid constitution as long as blacks are guaranteed full voting rights. The 71-year-old black leader, in his first interviews since his release Sunday after 27 years in prison, also praised de Klerk, saying that because of his flexibility and integrity, ``the possibility of a settlement is always there.'' Mandela was asked if the ANC was willing to negotiate over its demand for a one-person, one-vote system that would lead to black majority rule. ``Compromises must be made in respect to every issue, as long as that compromise is in the interest not only of one population group but the country as whole,'' Mandela told reporters. The ANC repeatedly has rejected any system falling short of one-person, one-vote, but Mandela's comments indicated the movement would at least be willing to let this be a topic for negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Drug Summit Bjt
Security Unusually Heavy For Drug Summit
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 6-7, Scores of xxx etc., to UPDATE with further security surrounding visiting press corps.
DOC.TEXT: Streets were virtually abandoned and fishing boats were kept away from Cartagena Bay docks today amid unusually heavy security surrounded the convening of a four-nation drug summit. ``First class. We've got the best, the best,'' President Bush said of the extraordinary protective measures taken in his behalf. Security already had been heightened in Cartagena Bay by the time the president arrived aboard Air Force One at Barranquilla, a Caribbean port city some 60 miles northeast of the summit site. Naval authorities closed off Cartagena's bay to private boat traffic and were guarding it with frogmen, frigates, high-speed patrol boats and at least one submarine. Helicopters hovered above high-rise luxury hotels, where guests were being required to submit to fingerprinting. A Colombian frigate had stationed itself just off the coast of the peninsula and small patrol boats were speeding along the shores with machine guns pointed inland. Across the bay from the peninsula, authorities had forced the fishing boats that normally crowd Cartagena's docks to leave, and except for some decrepit ships too damaged to move, the wharves were empty. Scores of troops also surrounded the convention center where much of the international press watched Barco's welcoming speech broadcast on a giant screen television from the guest house across the bay. Soldiers wearing camoflauge uniforms and resting automatic rifles on their hips were standing on the roof of the convention center as military patrols roamed the sun baked streets below. Cartagena's streets, normally packed with traffic and pedestrians in the early morning hours, were practically empty. Public and private schools were closed, and some residents said they were staying home from work for fear that violence might accompany Bush's visit. Bush was meeting with presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Jaime Paz of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru to sign an agreement to combat cocaine trafficking. Already stringent security measures were wound even tighter today as about 5,000 security agents from the four countries represented at the anti-drug summit roamed the city and scouted the Colombian naval base where the meeting was being held. The base houses the presidential guest residence where Barco and Paz stayed Wednesday night. Bush and Garcia arrived today. The U.S. security forces have taken extraordinary measures to guard Bush following a report in December that Colombian drug lords had taken a $30 million contract on the president's life and reports that surface-to-air missiles had been acquired to shoot down his plane. Two U.S. warships, the Nassau and the Sampson, were cruising off the Colombian coast. The Nassau carries a Marine amphibious assault company that can be used in the case of an emergency. Colombian navy frogmen were checking the bay, apparently looking for explosives near the Spanish fortification where the presidents were meeting. Some Cartagena residents, saying they feared such an emergency, told The Associated Press they were staying at home today to avoid any trouble. The Colombians, all of whom asked not to be identified, said they feared possible attacks by drug traffickers as well as leftist guerrilla groups. The government estimates there are 10,000 rebel forces active in the country. Colombians also said they feared protests over the Bush visit like the student demonstrations at Bogota's National University on Wednesday. About 100 hooded students threw rocks at police who had fired tear gas to break up the demonstration. There were no injuries but several arrests were reported. Municipal officials decided to close area schools today. They did not give a reason for their decision, but some parents said they assumed it was because of the threat of violence. The largest U.S. school in the Colombian capital of Bogota, the Nueva Granada school, also was closed as a security precaution. During a 1982 visit to Bogota, Bush escaped an apparent assassination plot in which a load of dynamite was buried under the lone runway at the Bogota airport. The explosives were found hours after Bush's plane took off, and security officials discovered the dynamite was connected to wires running to an electrical generator 300 yards away.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Orders Dumping of 160 Million Bottles Worldwide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lede to remove word `contaminated' and inserts 3 grafs after 8th, `Perrier had...' to UPDATE with insider trading probe. Pickup 9th, `Zimmer said...'
DOC.TEXT: Perrier has ordered distributors worldwide to dump 160 million bottles of its bubbly water because a toxic chemical may be contained in some shipments. Officials say the move will disrupt distribution for three months. In yanking shipments from distribution in 120 countries, Perrier President Gustave Leven said officials ``don't want the least doubt, as minimal as it might be, to weigh on the image of the quality and purity of our product.'' Officials estimated the recall will cost the company $35 million. Earlier this week, 72 million bottles of Perrier were withdrawn from the U.S. market after benzene was detected in tests by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The recall was extended to Canada, and a Japanese subsidiary said it would withdraw Perrier from stores. Traces were also found earlier this week in samples from Denmark and the Netherlands, prompting a recall there. Perrier's distributor in Australia today ordered the recall of 40,000 cases. Leven told a news conference Wednesday that the company halted distribution because ``half-measures were not possible.'' Managing Director Frederik Zimmer said the benzene had passed through a dirty filter and made it into some shipments. Benzene, a naturally occuring toxic chemical used in solvents, entered the water in trace amounts when workers failed to change a pipe filter at Perrier's natural spring at Vergeze in southern France, company officials said. Perrier had known about the filter since Sunday but had waited to assemble all the facts before publicizing the findings, Zimmer said. French securities regulators, meanwhile, launched an investigation into recent trading of Perrier stock. A spokeswoman for the Commission des Operations de Bourse said the probe will attempt to determine whether insider trading took place prior to the announcement the mineral water would be pulled from shelves in North America. No indications have surfaced that insider trading took place, the spokeswoman said, but she noted that options volume on the company's shares was unusually high on Friday. Zimmer said the company is advising importers to to dump about 160 million bottles of the water on site and return the green bottles to the company for cleaning and refilling. Distribution should return to normal within three months, Zimmer said, with the new bottles showing the date they were filled. Computer-controlled instruments will measure water purity to prevent a benzene recurrence. The company will not issue a general recall in its home country after a preliminary ruling by Health Ministry officials that it poses no public danger, Leven said. French distributors will decide independently whether to pull Perrier off the shelves and ask the company for fresh shipments, Leven said. Zimmer ruled out industrial espionage and said disciplinary action has been taken against the workers involved. He didn't elaborate. The water and the natural carbon dioxide gas that makes it bubbly are normally separated underground then carried up separate pipes to the bottling facility, Zimmer said. A filter on the gas pipe that cleans out benzene and other impurities had not been changed in ``several months,'' Zimmer said, which caused a malfunctioning and allowed benzene to seep through. ``We don't know exactly how long the filter had been there, that's the problem,'' said Zimmer. ``It was complete negligence.'' Toxicologists from the University of Clermont-Ferrand said that the amount of benzene found in samples it tested would pose a cancer threat only if consumers drank a liter per day for life. The samples exceeded U.S. standards of 5 parts per billion and European standards of 10 parts per billion, Zimmer said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The number for U.S. consumers to call with questions regarding contaminated Perrier is 1-800-937-2002.

DOC.HEAD: Tadzhiks Set up Barricades, Capital Reported Quiet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Tass death toll now conforming to Tadzhik Interior Ministry's. Pickup 5th pvs, `The republic...'
DOC.TEXT: Residents in the capital of Tadzhikistan formed civil defense groups and set up barricades to protect themselves from rioters who have terrorized the city for three days, Soviet media reports said today. Bread was in short supply because hooligans were looting supply trucks and people were unable to go to work because of the barricades, lack of public transportation and threats from militants, the daily Rabochaya Tribuna wrote. But the capital was reportedly quiet today, one day after three senior officials in the republic resigned. The resignations had been demanded by protesters unhappy about joblessness and rumors that ethnic Armenian refugees were being given preferential treatment for housing. Officials denied Soviet TV reports that 37 people had been killed in the violence in Tadzhikistan, which borders Afghanistan and China. The Tadzhik Interior Ministry and Tass reported today that seven more deaths had brought the toll to 18 dead and 200 injured. The republic is the latest of several to be torn by ethnic strife since President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came to power five years ago. He has repeatedly said the turmoil threatens his reform program and has had to send troops to put down uprisings in several republics, including Tadzhikistan. An editor of the state-run television station in Dushanbe, which has been plagued by riots for three days, said Wednesday night passed without incident. The editor, who declined to give his name, said some factories are working, public transport is operating partially and self-defense units built barricades in the suburbs. Rabochaya Tribuna said the units are trying to protect themselves ``from pogroms.'' A spokesman for the republic's Interior Ministry, which supervises the police and internal security forces, said today that bread was being sold but that lines of customers are very long. The army daily Krasnaya Zvezda said today that hoodlums had ransacked a hospital, ravaging the emergency room and destroying expensive foreign-made equipment. On Wednesday, Tass said villagers threw firebombs and acid at troops protecting the Communist Party headquarters in Dushanbe, and about 5,000 young men looted, set fires and attacked passers-by ``irrespective of nationality.'' The republic's president, premier and Communist Party chief agreed to resign during a meeting of party leaders and activists, who are protesting housing shortages and the arrival of Armenian refugees, said Orif Aminov of the Tadzhik branch of the state television and radio agency. Rabochaya Tribuna said the activists demand measures to combat unemployment. From 70,000-200,000 of the republic's 5 million people are unemployed, it said. The newspaper said, without elaborating, that the activists also demand resolution of youth problems and a ban on the sale of pork, which Moslems, the predominant group in the republic, do not eat. The activists also are pressing language demands, but Rabochaya Tribuna did not detail them. More troops landed in Dushanbe, the capital, on Wednesday to guard strategic points and restore order, Tass said. Soviet TV showed hundreds of people facing a wall of troops carrying riot shields with a barren stretch of street between the two tense groups. The violence began Monday after rumors spread that ethnic Armenians fleeing persecution in the Azerbaijan republic were being moved into the Tadzhik republic, where housing is scarce. Dushanbe-based journalist Anatoly Larenok said the crowd outside Communist headquarters demanded that victims of the three days of violence be buried in the central square.

DOC.HEAD: Historical Court Finds French Origin for Cinderella
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0425 to CORRECT overline.
DOC.TEXT: With her historical origins unveiled, Cinderella started living happily ever after with a prince in a business suit and a missing glass slipper that turned out to be made of plastic. A hilarious courtroom reunion between the hard-working fairy tale wench and her suitor occurred during a just-for-fun court session Wednesday to determine the origin of the classic story. The ``trial'' featured theories that Walt Disney had created Cinderella to brainwash American women, and claims the Cinderella marketed by Disney had appeared earlier in France, Italy, and ninth century China. But the height of the courtroom drama came when attorney Frank Winston jumped from his chair, waving a clear, high-heeled sling-back. ``I think I have it! I think I have it!'' Winston exclaimed, and dashing to the witness stand where Cinderella was testifying, he slipped the shoe on her foot. ``Oh! Someday my prince will come!'' said Cinderella, alias Municipal Judge Diane Elan Wick, who wore a blond wig, patched dress, clogs and carried a basket with three stuffed mice. Municipal Judge George T. Choppelas ruled that while the tale that has delighted children all over the world stems from the 17th century story by French lawyer and writer Charles Perrault, Walt Disney deserves credit as a folklorist for the American version. ``Perrault took the oral tradition and he changed it, he adapted it to the times,'' Choppelas said at the 61st session of the Court of Historical Review and Appeals. ``Disney took the written version and made it an animated film. ... He changed it around just like Perrault.'' Representing the United States and Walt Disney was San Francisco Supervisor Wendy Nelder, who termed Cinderella ``the typical American rags-to-riches story.'' Jo Anne Miller, vice president of the San Francisco Board of Education, testified that the 1950 Disney film was a part of a sinister plot to get women out of shipyards and factories and back behind the stove and ironing board after World War II. ``We were told that only when the prince comes will you life change. And of course, it doesn't,'' she said. Glass, or at least clear plastic, slippers also are American, argued Nelder, who reminisced with Miller about the shoes they wore as adolescents. ``They were great because you could clean them with Windex,'' Miller said. ``The last thing I have to say is if the shoe fits, wear it.'' Winston, while keeping his royal origins secret, called witnesses to support his arguments that Cinderella didn't come from Hollywood. ``We go back to 400 B.C. _ before Cinderella,'' he quipped. In ninth century Chinese stories, the heroine transforms herself into a beauty with the bones of a dead fish. In a Neapolitan version, Zezolla is an abused child who mrders her evil stepmother only to be saddled with another. Gerald F. Uelmen, dean of the School of Law at Santa Clara University, said most of the now-essential elements of the fairy tale _ including the pumpkin turned into a coach and mice changed into horses _ first appeared in Perrault's story, ``Cendrillon,'' published in the 1697 collection ``Tales of Mother Goose.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Kentucky Fried Chicken Owner and Founder of Hospital Chain Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version on financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Jack C. Massey, who helped build Kentucky Fried Chicken Co. into an international success and co-founded Hospital Corporation of America, died today of pneumonia. He was 85. Massey died at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla, said Mimi Scruggs, his secretary at Massey Investment Co. in Nashville. Massey, who retired from the company in 1978, had been staying at his winter home in Florida. From a chain of six drugstores, the Nashville businessman founded Massey Surgical Supply Inc. in 1930. He sold that company for about $1 million in 1961 with the intention of retiring but soon found himself in other business ventures. In 1964 Massey and businessman John Y. Brown, who later became governor of Kentucky, bought Kentucky Fried Chicken from its founder, Col. Harland Sanders. The two built the company into the world's largest commercial marketer of prepared food. They sold the business to the Heublein Corp. in 1969. Massey founded HCA with Dr. Thomas F. Frist, and his son, Dr. Thomas Frist Jr., in 1968. Within 18 months the company had 11 hospitals, and within 10 years had reached $1 billion in sales and was country's largest owner and operator of hospitals. HCA had acquired more than 420 hospitals by the mid-1980s. It has sold many, but still owns or operates 150 and is the country's largest hospital management company, with revenues of about $4.5 billion. HCA management took the company private last year in a $6 billion leveraged buyout. ``He was a titan of a contributor to many causes, including Belmont College (in Nashville) and the Tennessee Performing Arts Center,'' Brownlee O. Currey II, chairman of the Nashville Banner, said when he learned of Massey's death. Massey is survived by his wife, Alyne Queener Massey; a daughter, Barbara Massey Clark, and three grandchildren. Funeral services were scheduled for Saturday at Immanuel Baptist Church in Nashville.

DOC.HEAD: Biologist Phillip Sharp Nominated As MIT President
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts Institute of Technology biologist Phillip A. Sharp has been nominated to become MIT's 15th president, a school spokesman said today. The final vote on Sharp's nomination will be taken March 2 by the 96-member MIT Corporation, which governs the school. He was nominated by a faculty search committee, a faculty advisory committee and the MIT Corporation's executive committee. MIT spokesman Bob D'Iorio confirmed published reports of Sharp's nomination this morning. Sharp, the director of the university's center for cancer research, would be the first biologist to head MIT. His 1977 discoveries about DNA are credited with dramatically changing the field of molecular genetics. Paul E. Gray, who has been MIT president since 1980, said last year that he would step down as of this summer. Robert M. Solow, the Noble laureate in economics who headed the faculty advisory committee, called Sharp ``a superb scientist, a real ornament to MIT.'' Sharp, 45, joined the MIT faculty in 1974 as an associate professor of biology in the center for cancer research. He became director of the center in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Newspaper Calls on Britain to Hand Over Rushdie
DOC.TEXT: A Tehran newspaper Thursday called on Britain to apologize to world Moslems for protecting British author Salman Rushdie from a year-old Iranian death sentence. The daily Jomhuri Islami also said the British government should condemn Rushdie's novel ``The Satanic Verses'' as blasphemous against Islam and hand over the Indian-born writer for execution. On Wednesday, Iranians celebrated the first anniversary of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's Feb. 14 ruling that Rushdie should be killed for writing the novel. The Islamic Republic News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, quoted the Farsi-language Jomhuri Islami as saying London could ``disentangle'' itself from the present controversy over Rushdie. This could be done ``by offering an apology to the Moslem world for its past behavior in that connection, by condemning `The Satanic Verses' and writer Salman Rushie and by surrendering him to world Moslems,'' it said. Jomhuri Islami is considered aligned with the ``radical'' faction in Iran, which advocates preserving the purity of the Islamic Revolution and opposes renewing contacts with the West. The Iranians have condemned London for not handing over Rushdie, who is in hiding in Britain under police guard. Iranian Parliament Speaker Mahdi Karrubi said Wednesday that ``however much Salman Rushdie may be kept under guard, eventually a Moslem will carry out the edict.'' All 12 members of the European Economic Community briefly recalled their ambassadors from Tehran last year to protest the death sentence on Rushdie. Iran's relations were later normalized with all the countries except Britain.

DOC.HEAD: Avalanche Threat in Italy; French Identify Victims of Snowfalls
DOC.TEXT: Italian authorities posted avalanche warnings throughout the South Tyrol region of northern Italy on Thursday after nearly six feet of snow fell. Police said about 40 tourists were blocked by snow and strong winds in one hotel. A huge snowslide shortly after dawn in the Venosta valley damaged a chairlift and a restaurant at San Valentino alla Muta. Police said nobody was hurt. Snow slowed down traffic along the Brenner highway and long lines of trucks formed at Campo Trens, near the Italian-Austrian border. Authorities in Bolzano said an avalanche hazard was likely to continue for several days as a result of an expected rise in temperatures, which would result in ground not frozen hard enough to support the new snow. The snow that fell this week ended a long dry spell that had hurt Italy's winter tourism industry. In the Alps of neighboring France, which also received heavy snow recently, four people died in avalanches in the past two days. The victims were identified Thursday as skiers from Britain and France, who died in avalanches in southeastern France. One victim, a 17-year-old woman, was killed when an avalanche swept her car from the road leading to the ski resort of Les Arc. Three other people were seriously injured when their cars were swept off the road in the same incident Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Rig Adrift Off Dutch Coast
DOC.TEXT: A navy helicopter was used to rescue 33 crewmen from an oil rig Thursday after it broke loose from its anchor in heavy seas. The rig ran aground later, but officials said it did not threaten the environment. Nobody was injured in the rescue operation, a Dutch coast guard spokesman said. He spoke on condition of anonymity. The rig ran aground late Thursday afternoon at Europoort, Rotterdam's seaside deepwater port, the spokesman said. He said attempts to get it floating again would be made during the next high tide. The Dutch-owned Gilbert Rowe was anchored 11 miles west of Hook of Holland when it got into trouble, according to the spokesman. A Dutch navy helicopter picked up the crew while the rig was being blown in the direction of the Dutch coast.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Hunger Striker Feasts on Freedom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th graf, `I can't...', to add comment from prosecutor's office. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Acuna's face...'.
DOC.TEXT: A prisoner who starved himself for nearly a year to proclaim he was innocent of drug charges feasted on soda crackers, cheese and freedom after the Michigan Court of Appeals ordered him released. Rene Acuna, 37, who had vowed not to eat until he returned home, began trying to rebuild his health and his life after the court wiped out a $100,000 appeal bond and set him free Tuesday evening. ``I am here and I don't believe it,'' he said Wednesday as he sat on his living room couch with his daughter, Nuria, 2. The Cuban immigrant was convicted March 3, 1989, in Macomb County Circuit Court of delivery and conspiracy to deliver more than 2 pounds of cocaine. He was given two mandatory life sentences without parole and began his hunger strike a short time later, subsisting on water and coffee with sugar. He was force-fed for a time last fall and again Monday and Tuesday when prison doctors concluded his life was in danger. Prosecutors claim Acuna was a lookout for drug dealers, but Acuna insists he was arrested in August 1988 only because he was a Hispanic in a white neighborhood when undercover agents bought drugs from other Hispanics. The appeals court overturned the convictions for lack of evidence Jan. 23, but an appeal bond of $100,000 still stood. Acuna continued to serve his sentences until this week when the appeals court reduced his bond. Prosecutors are appealing to the state Supreme Court to get his convictions reinstated. But Acuna said he believes the state Supreme Court will uphold the appeals court's decision to throw the convictions out. ``I have something inside my soul,'' Acuna said. ``When I pray (to) God, I listened to the voice of God say, `You will be free. Be patient, You will be free. I know that you are innocent. I am here.''' ``I can't blame the American justice system, no. I can blame some persons who represented the American justice system in the wrong way.'' Carole Murray, chief of the drug unit in the Macomb County prosecutor's office, said after Acuna's release, ``My only comment is I'm sorry to see that.'' Murray said Macomb County prosecutors still believe there was ample evidence to convict Acuna and his bond should have been retained at $100,000 to prevent him from fleeing. ``There's always a concern when you have a large penalty that a defendant is facing,'' she said. Acuna's face was gaunt, his cheeks sunken and his hair, which had begun to fall out, had been shaved off. His weight was down from 180 to about 105. ``I am happy, I am nervous. I feel like running. I feel several emotions at the same time,'' he said. His lawyers marveled at Acuna's stamina during his 11-month hunger strike. ``This guy is the most courageous person I've ever met,'' said Paul Denenfeld, legal director for the Michigan chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union. Denenfeld said Acuna's convictions and the mandatory life sentences were symptoms of American hysteria over drugs. ``I never expected him to live to see his case reversed,'' said Michael Schuck, attorney with the State Appellate Defender's Office. ``It's extraordinary. He survived a good six months on pure guts and the knowledge that he was innocent.'' The longest hunger strike ever, according to the Guinness Book of World Records, is a 385-day strike in 1972-73 staged by an Englishman who said he was wrongly charged with rape. Like Acuna, that man was force-fed by tube.

DOC.HEAD: Holdup Suspect Charged With Murder in Rare Legal Move
DOC.TEXT: A suspect in a McDonald's holdup has been charged with the murder of his three alleged accomplices even though it was police who shot and killed them. In the rare application of state law, Alfredo Olivas, 19, of Hollywood, was charged Wednesday with three counts of murder and one of robbery in the holdup and shootout. He could face the death penalty or life in prison without parole. State law allows a person participating in a crime in which someone is killed to be charged with murder. ``It's somewhat different, but he can be charged and was charged on a theory of vicarious liability,'' said Deputy District Attorney Kenneth Barshop. ``I haven't seen it happen very often.'' Police investigating a string of nine fast-food restaurant robberies had followed Olivas and three other men to the McDonald's Monday. While officers waited, the restaurant was robbed up of several thousand dollars and its manager was tied up. Officers reported seeing one robber holding what appeared to be a pistol and two others apparently reaching for something, and a shootout began. Police said they fired 23 shotgun blasts and 12 .45-caliber pistol rounds. Olivas remained hospitalized in serious condition with gunshot wounds.

DOC.HEAD: Not Even Nudity Can Sell Connecticut Condos
DOC.TEXT: Not even the prospect of a place to frolic in the nude is luring buyers to a proposed condominium project in Connecticut's slumping real estate market. PST Corp. of Westport tried to draw customers to its 42-unit Oak Hill Condominium by offering a ``clothing optional'' recreation area consisting of a clubhouse, sauna, pool and hot tub. ``You have to be creative in a slow market, but this idea is dead,'' said Douglas Nelkin, a marketing consultant on the project. The complex would have been the first of its kind in New England, although they are popular in California and some Southern states, Nelkin said. PST has an option on the land and was trying to drum up interest in condos selling for $179,000 to $199,000. Nelkin said about 1,000 brochures were sent to ``naturalist'' associations. ``Most people said it was a good idea, but they weren't in the market for a new home,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Supreme Court Upholds Turtle Excluder Device Rule for State Waters
DOC.TEXT: The Florida Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a state rule requiring shrimp fishermen in Florida waters to use devices designed to keep sea turtles from getting killed in their nets. Turtle excluder devices are like trap doors that let sea turtles, which need to surface to breathe, escape drowning in shrimp nets. Some shrimpers argue that TEDs also let enough shrimp out to put them out of business. The rule was approved by Gov. Bob Martinez and the Cabinet in August as an emergency measure to help save endangered species of sea turtles. The temporary rule the court reviewed expired last week, but the governor and Cabinet also have approved a permanent rule requiring the use of TEDs. The challenge to the state rule was brought by David Davis, the first shrimper cited under it. He argued that the Florida Marine Fisheries Commission had overstepped its authority in writing the measure and that the state Legislature was the only body that could properly make such rules. A Franklin County judge agreed with Davis on Nov. 27 and found the rule invalid. The state appealed to the 1st District Court of Appeal, which labeled the issue one of ``great public importance'' and passed it along to the state's high court. Charles Shelfer, general counsel for the state fisheries commission, said officials will seek to have challenges to the permanent rule thrown out as a result of today's decision. ``We are very pleased and feel in some respect vindicated by the Supreme Court action,'' he said, adding that ``for Florida, this pretty much settles it.'' The federal government also has rules requiring shrimpers to use TEDs, but Shelfer said that unlike the federal rules, the Florida rule would require the use of TEDs year-round in all parts of Florida. The federal rules require TEDs year-round in some Florida waters, but only in certain seasons in other areas off Florida. Davis still faces trial on the charge, punishable by up to 60 days in jail and a $500 fine. ``I disagree with that, but they're the Supreme Court,'' said J. Patrick Floyd, an attorney for Davis. ``I'm surprised and very disappointed because it appeared clear that the marine fisheries commission's power does not include dealing with endangered species,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Andean Presidents Hold Drug Summit Amid Tight Security
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new graf after pvs 6th graf bgng, Security was, with Bush comment; SUBS pvs 12th graf bgng, At Cartagena, to include reference to coca producers; INSERTS 2 new grafs after pvs 24th graf bgng, The four leaders, with U.S. ambassador's comments.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush held security-shrouded summit talks today with leaders of Latin America's three major cocaine-producing nations, hoping for a ``fruitful and productive exchange'' on intensifying their war against drugs. ``We shall move forward in spite of the sacrifices that we have had to take,'' declared Colombian President Virgilio Barco, who welcomed Bush and the presidents of Peru and Bolivia to the summit site at a heavily guarded naval base. ``No, we will not weaken, we will not let the deaths of thousands of Colombians be in vain,'' said Barco, whose country has been ravaged by bombings, assassinations and other violence from drug lords and leftist guerrillas. At midmorning, the four leaders strolled briefly in 85-degree heat along the shore of Cartagena Bay, admiring the panoramic skyline of the sun-drenched city in the distance, before they entered the rugged old stone Fort Manzanillo to begin their talks. Moments before Air Force One landed safely in Colombia, Bush told reporters that ``it's going to be a good meeting ... because it's four countries cooperating in the fight against drugs.'' Security was extraordinarily tight around the summit site. Patrol boats sped along the shore with machine guns pointed inland, and a Colombian frigate was stationed just off the peninsula. Across Cartagena Bay, the wharves were empty, and the streets of this resort city _ normally backed with traffic and pedestrians _ were virtually abandoned. Bush arrived in a swarm of five helicopters, possibly to thwart the possibility of an attack. Later, while standing next to Barco, Bush was asked if he were afraid. ``Afraid of what?'' he replied. ``Absolutely not, absolutely not.'' In a statement issued after his arrival, Bush said the summit would produce ``a broad, flexible framework which will guide the actions'' of the four hemispheric countries in their battle against drug traffickers. Barco said there was a need to provide ``viable economic alternatives'' to those who grow coca plants _ the raw material for cocaine. ``The only law that the narco-terrorists do not break is the law of supply and demand,'' the Colombian president said. Before he left Washington at dawn _ after a night's sleep aboard Air Force One parked in a hangar _ Bush said in a published interview that the drug summit's success will be measured by a reduction in cocaine production, and ``that's going to take some time.'' During the 4{-hour flight to Colombia, Bush refused comment on an NBC report that Barco had promised not to extradite drug lords to the United States if they agreed to turn their cocaine laboratories over to the Bogota government. Bush landed without incident at the Caribbean port city of Barranquilla and flew 60 miles southwest by helicopter with a small group of top aides to a restored 17th century fort in Cartagena where the six-hour summit took place. At Cartagena, Bush walked down a red carpet with Barco and shook hands with his other summit partners, Presidents Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru, who was accompanied to Cartagena _ but not the summit talks _ by two coca producers whom he invited along as observers. U.S. warships patrolled offshore and 5,000 Colombian troops provided security for the summiteers. Bush pronounded the U.S. security arrangements as ``first class. We've got the best, the best.'' Arriving in Cartagena, Garcia said he would seek a new era of hemispheric cooperation in the drug war. ``We have come to make up for lost time,'' he said. A Colombian radio report said police were investigating the early morning explosion of an electrical transformer near the Cartagena airport, which reportedly was left without electricity. Such incidents occur occasionally in Colombia because of power surges. The Latin-American leaders planned to seek expanded U.S. economic aid to ease their farmers' shift from lucrative coca plants _ used to produce cocaine _ to growing legal crops. But White House officials hinted that any new U.S. offer would be modest. One plan reportedly would include $30 million in assistance, including technical advice from visiting U.S. teams of agricultural experts. ``We don't have unlimited resources,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. In an interview published in today's editions of the newspaper USA Today, Bush said reducing U.S. demand for drugs _ the strategy stressed by the Andean nations _ was only part of the problem. As for coca-growing farmers in Colombia or Peru, Bush had this advice: ``Grow another crop. Grow one that has a useful purpose and not an immoral purpose in the world.'' Some strains were evident before the summit began. Garcia had threatened to boycott in protest of the U.S. invasion of Panama, then invited a group of coca growers to attend with him, and ultimately delayed his arrival until today. The Colombian and Bolivian presidents arrived Wednesday. The Bush administration has said it will ask Congress to approve $2.2 billion in aid to the three countries through 1995 to help them fight drug traffickers, including a $206 million increase for next year. ``Coca reduction in exchange for development _ that is our premise,'' Paz Zamora said earlier this week. Garcia was quoted this week as saying ``massive economic resources are needed'' to switch crops because coca ``is enormously important to our economy.'' The four leaders planned to issue a joint statement following the meeting that officials said would include a U.S. pledge to help track illegal export of U.S.-made firearms and crack down on drug-related chemical shipments. U.S. Ambassador Thomas E. McNamara said both the United States and Colombia must act more aggressively to halt the flow into Colombia of U.S. semi-automatic weapons, which are favored by drug traffickers. ``I think we can do more to control the export of firearms and Cololmbia can do more to monitor imports,'' McNamara told reporters in remarks that appeared to conflict with Bush's opposition to tighter export controls on such weapons. Two U.S. warships were cruising along Colombia's coast while Colombian patrol boats, a Colombian submarine and a frigate were in Cartagena Bay. Helicopter gunships flew continually over the meeting site, and Colombian marines searched vehicles at roadblocks. Nonetheless, Bush was traveling with a sharply reduced staff because of concerns for his safety, Fitzwater said. The purpose was ``to eliminate any excess personnel and for security reasons, to simply not have any more people there than is absolutely necessary,'' he said. In December, there was a report that Colombian drug lords had taken a $30 million contract on Bush's life. Bush's visit was denounced Wednesday by Colombia's four main labor federations, which condemned the U.S. invasion of Panama. Workers marched in Bogota, the capital, and Medelin, home of the powerful Colombian drug cartel. Meanwhile, two U.S. citizens remained in the hands of leftist guerrillas who kidnapped them in the drug capital of Medellin on Tuesday to protest the Bush visit.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister Resigns After Government Loses Confidence Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with prime minister submitting resignation; picks up 9th pvs: The assignment...
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson submitted the resignation of his Social Democratic government today after losing a vote in Parliament over an economic rescue bill. Five opposition parties, from communists to conservatives, united to kill the plan calling for a two-year freeze on wages and prices and restrictions on strikes. The government proposed the bill to quell escalating wage demands and labor strife. The vote was 190-153 endorsing a committee resolution to reject the government's plan. Six members were absent. Immediately following the vote Carlsson went to the chamber of Speaker Thage G. Peterson to hand in his resignation, Swedish Radio and the national news agency TT reported. The resignation set off what could be an extended period of haggling to create a new government. If unsuccessful, an early election will be required. Commentators said Carlsson was the only politician capable of forming a new government, since his Social Democrats and Communists together could block any non-socialist coalition. In an earlier speech, Carlsson said his plan was intended to guarantee continued full employment, ``the basis of a fair society.'' ``If the five opposition parties together reject the Social Democratic proposals, then Mr. Speaker, the government will resign,'' Carlsson had said, winning applause from the packed chamber and the spectators' gallery. The vote came after several hours of debate. All opposition parties said they objected to the measures. ``We happily reject these proposals, which no one believes in,'' said Carl Bildt, leader of the center-right Moderate party, daring Carlsson to call an immediate election. Carlsson would remain head of a caretaker government while Peterson consulted on the formation of another government. The assignment could be given to a coalition of center-right opposition parties or Carlsson, himself, could be asked to try again. If no one succeeded, an election would be called 35 to 90 days after efforts broke down. The next scheduled election is in September 1991. The Social Democrats, who have governed Sweden for 51 of the last 58 years, unveiled the wage-price freeze last week to suppress a convulsion of strikes. All Sweden's banks have been closed for nearly three weeks, drying up retail business and threatening major industries with liquidity and supply problems. A potentially crippling strike of pre-school teachers, nurses and other municipal employees was suspended until next week. Carlsson said the labor chaos was throwing the economy off balance, adding that Sweden cannot afford to meet the wage demands. Salaries rose 28 percent over the last three years, while production grew an average 2 percent, he said. The measures were designed to curb an inflation rate heading toward 9 percent, about double the European average. Economists have blamed the low unemployment of just over 1 percent for adding inflationary pressures. Carlsson said the opposition is so splintered that Sweden's economic crisis would be compounded by a political crisis if the Social Democrats were forced out of office. ``A political crisis might be created that leads to paralysis, uncertainty and insecurity, and that is the last thing Sweden needs today,'' he said. The Social Democrats control 156 seats in the 349-member Riksdag, usually working in cooperation with the 20-seat Communist Party. The three center-right parties have a total of 152 seats, and the balance is held by the Environment Party.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Man Stabbed Mother, Then Watched TV as She Died
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lawrexen cq in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A man stabbed his mother 24 times with a butcher knife and then watched television as she lay dying on the bathroom floor, pleading with him to call an ambulance, police said. Lawrexen W. Jones, 23, then left the house but returned at least four times to see if she had died and to pick up some clothes, Sheriff Allen Sloan said. ``This is the most heartless killing I've ever seen,'' Sloan said. Jones was charged with murder Wednesday in the slaying of his mother, Thomasina, 54. He was being held without bail. Mrs. Jones' body was found Tuesday in the bathroom of the home she shared with her son. She was stabbed Feb. 8 after arguing with him over unpaid bills, Sloan said. ``He dragged her into the bathroom, and she begged him to call an ambulance,'' Sloan said. ``He went into the living room, turned on the TV and debated for about 10 minutes whether to call the ambulance. ``Then he got up, shut the bathroom door, pushed a dresser in front of the door,'' the sheriff said. ``He cleaned off the butcher knife, put it back in the kitchen and took off in her car.'' Mrs. Jones' body was found by her estranged husband, Willie, and a friend who went to the house after she failed to show up for work. Jones said his son had been in trouble several times over the years, mostly for running up bills on Mrs. Jones' credit cards.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush Has Small Cancerous Growth Removed from Lip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to include further medical information
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Bush had a small cancerous growth removed from her upper lip on Wednesday, her press office announced today. ``No side effects or subsequent difficulties are expected,'' it said in announcing the operation. She underwent the outpatient procedure at Bethesda Naval Hospital in Maryland. Mrs. Bush was in New York today, visiting All Children's House, a day care center for homeless children and other youths. In a one-paragraph statement, her press office said: ``At Bethesda Naval Hospital on Feb. 14, Mrs. Bush underwent a routine outpatient medical procedure to remove a small basal cell carcinoma, a common form of skin cancer, from her upper lip. The procedure was performed under local anesthesia by Bethesda's chief of dermatology, Dr. Harry Parlette. No side effects or subsequent difficulties are expected.'' Mrs. Bush recently underwent radiation treatment for a persistent eye problem stemming from a condition known as Graves disease, which also had affected her thyroid. Jean Becker, a deputy press secretary, said the cancer was discovered about a week ago. She was not sure whether Mrs. Bush had undergone the same procedure in the past. Basal cell carcinomas are common skin cancers that occur most often on the face or on other skin areas that have been exposed to the sun. Light-skinned people, such as Mrs. Bush, are most susceptible. The cancer grows slowly, usually is easily removed surgically and only rarely re-occurs at the same site.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Sentenced to Life with No Parole for Torture Death of 4-year-old Boy
DOC.TEXT: A mother of four and her boyfriend were sentenced today to life in prison for the torture-slaying of the woman's 4-year-old son and the beating of his brother, both of whom were hung upside down in closets for hours. Alicia Abraham, 28, and Johnny Campbell, 40, were sentenced by Cook County Circuit Judge Michael B. Getty, who had called the case ``the most heinous, brutally sadistic torture and murder ... that I have ever heard in my 6{ years as a judge, my over 10 years as a prosecutor, or indeed my 51 years on this Earth.'' In sentencing them today to life imprisonment with no chance of parole, Getty said Campbell is mentally ill and Ms. Abraham had not participated directly in the death of her son, making them ineligible for the death penalty. Assistant Cook County State's Attorney James Bigoness had argued that death by lethal injection ``is the only, only just sentence'' for both defendants. Defense attorneys acknowledged the crimes were horrible, but urged the judge to spare their clients' lives. Campbell's attorney, Allan Sincox, said Campbell is psychotic and argued that sentencing him to death would be ``cruel and unusual punishment.'' Clyde Lemons Jr., Ms. Abraham's attorney, said she ``never committed any of the acts'' that led to Lattie McGee's death. Lattie was starved, burned with a hot iron, stuck with pins and needles, singed with cigarettes, beaten with a tree branch, hair brush, belt and hands, scalded with steaming water, and tied up with a clothesline, rope and tights for 2{ months in the family's South Side apartment during the summer of 1987, court records showed. A severe blow to his head on Aug. 14, 1987, was the eventual cause of death, a pathologist from the county medical examiner's office testified. Lattie's 8-year-old brother, Cornelius Abraham, testified that Campbell had twice tied him up with a rope and hung him upside down in the closet, once for two days. Cornelius said Campbell had taken a hot iron and ``put it on my brother's chest and he put that iron on my butt.'' The boy said his mother was ``in the living room watching TV'' at the time. He told of seeing Campbell tie Lattie's wrists to his ankles and hang him upside down in the closet. Once, Cornelius said, his mother helped tie up Lattie. Campbell, a Vietnam veteran, ex-steel worker and heavy drug and alcohol user, pleaded guilty in December to first-degree murder and aggravated battery. He said he beat the boys to curb what he thought was homosexual behavior. Ms. Abraham pleaded innocent, contending that she never actively abused the children. But prosecutors said she never tried to stop Campbell, and Getty convicted her of the same charges Jan. 11. ``There can be no question that when a mother puts her child into an alligator pit that the mother has condemned that child to death,'' the judge said. The boys' father, Lattie McGee Sr., has custody of Cornelius. Ms. Abraham's other two children, by another man, now live with their paternal grandmother.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Who Lost Custody of Children Reunited With 3 of 4 Kids
DOC.TEXT: A couple who lost custody of their four children for spanking them have been reunited with three of the youngsters. Their two sons, 9 and 7, were returned to Stephen and Joann DeCosta on Wednesday, six months after the four children were put in foster care in a case that raised questions about parents' rights to discipline their children. ``It's wonderful,'' Joann DeCosta said. ``They were ear-to-ear grins.'' The DeCostas regained custody of their youngest daughter, 3, last month. Their oldest child, a 14-year-old, has not been reunited with the family. She testified against her parents at hearings on whether the children had been disciplined too harshly. After closed hearings, District Judge Edwin Kelly had affirmed the removal of the children, ruling that the DeCostas had abused them by frequently spanking them with paddles, switches and dowels. The DeCostas insist that the spankings were administered with love in accordance with their Christian beliefs and that authorities interferred with their rights to discipline their children.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Official Suggests Model for United Germany
DOC.TEXT: A senior NATO official suggested Thursday that a united Germany remain in the alliance, but with both Soviet and Western military forces stationed in its territory. The remarks by Henning Wegener, assistant NATO secretary-general for political affairs, rankled a visiting delegation of Soviet legislators. Valentin Falin, head of the Soviet delegation, proposed in response that the Germanys be reunited within the Warsaw Pact and asked Wegener, a West German: ``How would you like that?'' The Soviet Union wants a future German state to be neutral, but the United States and its allies want the reunified country in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. ``A united Germany should not only firmly remain in NATO as a full member, but there must also be reassuring arrangements for Soviet and East European security interests,'' Wegener told a conference sponsored by the North Atlantic Assembly, made up of legislators from the 16 NATO nations. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany has proposed NATO membership for a single Germany, but with only West German territory tied to its military structure and no NATO forces in what is now East Germany. Wegener said officials of the Western alliance ``can very much imagine a transitional model _ where the transition times could be long _ of dual stationing of forces in the two halves of Germany, one belonging to the Soviet Union and the other to the NATO alliance.'' ``All of Germany would be politically part of NATO and none of its parts belonging to the Warsaw Treaty Organization,'' he said. His suggestion prompted discussion in the Soviet delegation, which included Gen. Vladimir Lobov, chief of the seven-nation Warsaw Pact's general staff. Falin said later it was ``improper to think beforehand that you will be better (at) reading our own interests than we are'' and asked Wegener: ``Would you like this option? The Warsaw Treaty Organization includes politically the entire united Germany and takes on a commitment not to place its own military forces on the territory'' of West Germany. ``How would you like that?'' Wegener replied: ``I challenge you: Put it to the test with the German electorate'' in each country, ``and later on in both of them together, and then let's see what comes out of it.'' U.S. Gen. John Galvin, the top NATO commander in Europe, said earlier there was ``definitely precedent for a nation staying within the North Atlantic Alliance under special considerations.'' He did not mention possible arrangements for a united Germany, but noted that some NATO members have special status. Spain and France refuse to link their forces to the joint military structure. Norway, one of two NATO nations bordering the Soviet Union, is in the military structure but does not allow foreign troops to be stationed on its soil or let alliance forces conduct maneuvers in the extreme north, near the Soviet frontier. No NATO forces are stationed in Turkey, the other member on the Soviet border. ``The point is there are many different arrangements that have been made,'' Galvin said. ``I don't think we should forget that.''

DOC.HEAD: Winter Returns _ With a Vengeance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Snow and...' with one graf to UPDATE with I-10 reopening.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DX1
DOC.TEXT: Snow and ice spread from Southern California to New England today, cutting electrical service to thousands in the Midwest, threatening crops and closing a major highway across the deserts of southeastern Arizona. Hundreds of schools were closed across the Midwest and some motorists were stranded in parts of Michigan, where the state House canceled today's session. Only three runways were open this morning at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport and hundreds of flights had been canceled after the airport was shut down Wednesday by snow. Gale-force wind heaved much of what remained from a 400,000-gallon oil spill onto miles of Southern California beaches. Temperatures hit record lows today in northern California, where a second storm out of the Gulf of Alaska was expected. Sacramento hit a record 30 degrees. Cold along the West Coast drove hundreds of homeless people into shelters in Los Angeles, and in Seattle, King County opened its administration building as a refuge for the homeless. The bad weather made traveling treacherous, causing numerous accidents in many states, and abandoned cars in Michigan slowed plows and salt trucks. Slick roads were blamed for crashes that killed a man in Missouri and four people in Kansas. An ice storm knocked out electricity to more than 146,000 customers today across a wide area of northern Ohio, although most service was restored today. authorities said. At least 4,000 customers lost power in Illinois. Outages also were reported in parts of Indiana. Schools were closed in dozens of counties across Wisconsin, Michigan, Indiana, northern Ohio, Kansas and Missouri. Snow and ice forced the closure for 10 hours until late this morning of about 110 miles of Interstate 10 across southeastern Arizona, from the New Mexico border to 20 miles east of Tucson. On Wednesday, an American Airlines jet skidded off a runway at O'Hare, blocking the only runway then open. None of the 158 people aboard was injured. Drifts closed runways almost as fast as the plows could open them, and at 7:30 p.m. the world's busiest airport was closed. A few planes took off late at night and airport officials hoped to have all runways open later today, despite freezing rain and sleet. Heavy snow overnight in Wisconsin closed Mitchell International Airport in Milwaukee. Officials planned to reopen the airport later in the day after drifts of up to a foot were plowed from runways. Snowfall totaled 8 to 10 inches in much of northern Illinois before the precipitation changed to sleet and freezing rain. Southern Wisconsin got 4 to 6 inches. Up to 8 inches fell on parts of Michigan. In the Northeast, up to 6 inches fell across New York state. Icy temperatures in southern California sent citrus and avocado growers scurrying to keep crops from freezing. ``They're predicting temperatures in some areas will go down to as low as 22 degrees,'' said Gail Hutchings, who with her husband manages 250 acres in San Diego County's Pauma Valley. ``We never see temperatures here this low.'' Heavier snow in the Rockies _ as much as 2 feet _ was a blessing for ski resorts heading into President's Day holiday weekend. ``The timing is fabulous,'' said Mike Smedley, spokesman for the Purgatory ski resort in Colorado. ``It really looks like Colorado should look. It looks like winter and it looks like ski country.'' People who fled colder climes for places like Southern California and Arizona were dismayed. ``It's cloudy, it's windy and it hasn't been this cold in a long time,'' said Loretta Taylor in Apache Junction, Ariz., outside Phoenix, which had a low today of 32. ``People can't believe they came out here for this.'' Snow fell Wednesday and today in Phoenix suburbs and in Tucson and other places in southern Arizona, with as much as an inch of accumulation. ``We didn't really expect to find snow and ice,'' said George Gonperts of Southport, Conn., stuck with his wife and hundreds of other motorists at a mountain pass on Interstate 5 about 50 miles northwest of Los Angeles. Gonperts and his wife were celebrating their 25th wedding anniversary with a trip to Mexico and California. ``Next year we're going to Honolulu,'' he said. Elsewhere in Southern California, wind gusting to gale force strength of 39 mph kicked up heavy seas that heaved much of the oil remaining from a 400,000-gallon spill Feb. 7 onto miles of beaches in the Huntington Beach area. Cold drove hundreds of homeless people into shelters in Los Angeles and the city opened at least eight extra shelters. There was a rare snowfall in sections of San Diego and some outlying areas early Wednesday, while hail and snow fell in metropolitan Los Angeles, though it melted on contact.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Two Dead in Flooding in West Germany
DOC.TEXT: At least two people drowned Thursday and 50 were forced to leave their homes after heavy rain and snow caused flooding in the southwestern state of Baden-Wuerttemburg, police said. The storms hit the state near its borders with France and Switzerland in the Black Forest region, flooding highways and streets and causing landslides in the area's steep wine-growing hills. Police in the town of Aalen reported that a 41-year-old woman drowned after a gust of wind tore her umbrella out of her hand and she fell into a flooded creek trying to retrieve it. In the Black Forest town of Trieberg, at least one man drowned when he accidently drove his car into a swollen stream and the vehicle was swept away. Police said the car had not been found as of late Thursday and that two passengers might also have been in it when it was washed away. In the nearby district of Waldshut-Tiegen, 50 people were evacuated from their homes because of flooding and were taken to a local gymnasium for shelter, district official Bernhard Wuetz said. The Alp, Wehra and Wutach streams, all tributaries of the Rhine river, caused widespread flooding in the region, Wuetz said in a statement released to the news media. Residents in some towns used boats to get around, he said. According to police reports, damage in the area was estimated in the millions of dollars, and more flooding was expected from melting snow. The Rhine river was rising at a rate of about seven inches per hour, police said. Police said that two companies of the army and some 600 volunteers and firefighters had been mobilized to help clear roads and carry out rescue work.

DOC.HEAD: Fisherman, Merchants Fear Hardships From Oil Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT to America sted American in oil company name.
DOC.TEXT: Fishermen and others whose business depends on a beautiful coastline fear the oil spill that is coating the beach with gooey Alaskan crude will cost them their livelihood. ``There's a lot of people who are going to sue,'' said Dan McCafferty of the Dory Fleet, a cooperative of 20 fisherman at Newport Beach. ``It's ruined our business. The fishing here will never be the same as it was.'' McCafferty and several others plan to seek compensation from British Petroleum America Inc., which owned the oil and chartered the American Trader, and the tanker's owner, American Trading Transportation Co. A class-action lawsuit was filed Tuesday in Los Angeles, seeking compensation for damage and economic losses caused by the spill and the alleged failure to properly clean up the oil. Among the defendants named were British Petroleum and American Trading. Fish sales in the Huntington and Newport Beach areas have come to a virtual halt since the American Trader spilled 400,000 gallons of crude Feb. 7 as the tanker tried to moor about two miles offshore. ``People heard about the oil spill and immediately assumed we were fishing in the oil,'' said fisherman Matt Breneman, 22. ``We've had the freshest fish for years,'' said Mike Steven Long, a linebaiter with Dory Fleet. ``Now our reputation is ruined.'' Oil had washed ashore and percolated as deep as 3 feet into the sand by Wednesday along about a 12-mile stretch from Bolsa Chica State Beach to Newport Beach, according to cleanup officials. ``It's a sad thing because there's these little sand turtles that the birds eat, and they're all dead,'' said Ralph Gray, 27, in Balboa, about 10 miles south of Huntington Beach. Volunteers and others had found 153 dead birds at last count, and wildlife rescue workers were trying to save another 329 oiled fowl, said Tom Paulek of the California Department of Fish and Game. By evening, no oil was visible to Coast Guard boats at sea, said Newport Beach police Sgt. Andy Gonis, but a sheen was visible on coastline breakers. Many feared that a week of closed beaches had caused irreversible damage. ``I lost my $750-dollar apartment in Costa Mesa in just four days,'' said Newport Beach linebaiter Mike Steven Long. ``Usually, in that time, I make enough to pay my rent. Now I'm on the streets, living here where I work.'' Trips to Catalina and whale-watching excursions were halted as access to the ocean was cut off. ``What happens if the beaches stay closed?'' asked real estate agent Dinah Lewis. ``Are my customers going to get their money back?'' Business improved for some beachfront restaurants because of the influx of wrk crews, journalists and officials. ``I feel sort of like a vulture because my fishermen friends are suffering,'' said Mike Leigh, owner of the Newport Sea Shack. ``But it's been real good for us.'' Cleanup workers also were benefiting from the spill, making about $10 an hour, and more at overtime rates. One man capitalizing on the spill was Larry Sakhrani, owner of Michael's Surf and Sport in Huntington Beach. For $12.95 each, Sakhrani was selling white T-shirts with bold black letters that read: ``Crude is Rude, Dude.''

DOC.HEAD: Cardinal Glemp Leaves Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Cardinal Jozef Glemp, leader of Poland's Roman Catholic Church, was released from a hospital Thursday two weeks after undergoing emergency surgery for bleeding in his digestive system. Glemp, 61, will continue his convalescence at home, his secretariat announced. State television showed the primate shaking hands with his doctors and giving a blessing to the medical staff before he left the hospital. Newspaper reports said Glemp suffered a massive hemmorhage Jan. 30 because of a perforated ulcer and went into cardiac shock. He underwent two emergency operations at a Warsaw hospital to control the bleeding. Glemp, archbishop of Warsaw and Gniezno since 1981, is spiritual leader of the more than 90 percent of Poland's 38 million people who consider themselves Roman Catholic.

DOC.HEAD: Car Wax Recalled
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's largest manufacturers of car cleaning products Thursday recalled about 200,000 cans of a new car wax because the containers may rupture and cause injury. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Connecticut-based SIMONIZ recalled its ``Quick Gloss'' car wax after three incidents in which container corrosion caused a build-up of pressure that ruptured the cans. No injuries were reported. However, CPSC spokesman Dan Rumelt said various parts, including the metal dome, may separate from the container and cause injury. The agency said approximately 200,000 cans of ``Quick Gloss'' were sold nationwide since February 1989.
