Consumers should spray the wax into trash cans away from any open flame and immediately dispose of the metal containers, the CPSC said, warning consumers not to puncture, incinerate or use a trash compactor in disposing of the cans. Consumers should call 1-800-243-6400 for information on how to receive a refund.

DOC.HEAD: 1,200 L-tryptophan Cases Now Reported; 13 Deaths
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: At least 14 deaths and more than 1,200 cases of a rare, painful blood disorder have been attributed to the health food supplement L-tryptophan, the Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. The CDC said it has received reports of 1,269 cases of eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, the disorder first linked in November to L-tryptophan. A total of 210 cases, including four deaths, have been reported in California. The CDC studied files on 118 of those cases and found that 89 percent were female and 94 percent non-Hispanic whites. The median time between use of L-tryptophan and the onset of symptoms was 152 days. The CDC report did not include individual figures for other states. The disorder, marked by an abnormally high number of white blood cells called eosinophils, causes severe muscle pain, or myalgia, and can cause death. About two-thirds of the California patients also suffered coughing and rashes. Other symptoms include arm and leg swelling and fever. Most patients recover. In California, 29 percent of the patients had to be hospitalized. Scientists with the CDC and the Food and Drug Administration are investigating the outbreak. The FDA issued a recall request for L-tryptophan on Nov. 17 and expanded it four days later to block importation of the product, a protein component widely taken as a nutritional supplement. Last month, the FDA cautioned consumers against buying L-tryptophan products from a California company which, the agency said, did not comply with the recall request. More than 300 other manufacturers, packers and distributors did comply with the recall request, FDA officials said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Drug Summit Bjt
Ambassador Urges Crackdown On Gun Shipments
DOC.TEXT: The United States should do more to control the export of semi-automatic weapons into Colombia that end up in the hands of drug traffickers, U.S. Ambassador Thomas E. McNamara said Thursday. McNamara acknowledged that the availability of these U.S.-made weapons aggravates the drug problem. President Bush has voiced opposition to new laws controlling the manufacture or export of semi-automatic weapons, claiming laws already on the books are adequate. At the same time, he has acted to ban the import into the United States of the same type of weapons. McNamara, speaking with reporters covering Bush's visit to a four-nation drug summit in nearby Cartagena, said: ``I think we can do more to control the export of firearms and Colombia can do more to monitor imports.'' He said that the problem of U.S. guns reaching Colombian drug traffickers was mainly a ``smuggling operation.'' U.S. law generally limits sale of such U.S.-made weapons only to other governments, although there is a process under which others can acquire the weapons by obtaining ``end use'' certificates from the U.S. goverrnment. McNamara said Thursday's conference among Bush and the presidents of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru went beyond just symbolism. ``You have all four presidents sitting down for a day, talking about the drug fight _ that's more than symbolism,'' he said. ``For the first time, we'll have a coordinated strategy in the four countries involved.'' McNamara said the Colombians were ``taking pride in being able to host a quiet, calm meeting.''

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Chief Mate Recounts Criticism of Helmsman's Steering Ability
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Thursday testimony. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `LeCain also....'
DOC.TEXT: The chief mate of the Exxon Valdez testified today that he and skipper Joseph Hazelwood discussed w about 18 months, plan a spring wedding, according to an announcement by the bride-to-be's mother, Ethel Kennedy. No wedding date has been set. Cuomo, 32, runs a program to build housing for the homeless in New York state. Ms. Kennedy, 30, is head of the Robert F. Kennedy Center for Human Rights in Boston.

Ed Asner spent two hours in custody after his arrest during a demonstration at the Concord Naval Weapons Station. The actor and 26 other people were released Wednesday after being fingerprinted and booked for investigation of trespassing. ``Peace is breaking out in the world now,'' said Asner after his release. ``It's shameful. Where death is involved we are the purveyors of the tools.'' The protest, attended by about 150 people, was organized by a group of Jesuit priests and religious students from Berkeley. The protesters objected to the alleged shipment of weapons from the station to El Salvador. The marchers carried eight black cardboard coffins they said represented the six Jesuit priests, their cook and her daughter, who were killed in El Salvador in November.

Sophia Loren and husband Carlo Ponti have found a new residence in this village after having to quit the tiny apartment listed for tax reasons as their official home. Their landlord, Alois Blaettler, confirmed Thursday he gave the couple notice to leave the furnished two rooms plus kitchen and bath because his daughter wanted to move in. ``They hardly ever saw the place anyway,'' Blaettler said. Village secretary Ernst Minder said the couple easily found a new, equally modest home in the village, which has a population of 4,000. Fan letters to the new address are unlikely to be answered because their visits there are expected to be equally rare. The Zurich tabloid Blick said Thursday the couple set up base in the low-tax Swiss canton of Nidwalden more than 30 years ago and moved to Hergiswil six years ago. Blick said that Ponti pays about $33,000 per year in taxes under a lump-sum deal negotiated with canton tax authorities.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Houston Oilers nose tackle Doug Smith, wounded in the knee with a hunting rifle during an argument outside a nightclub, is expected to recover and return to his football career, a doctor said. Smith, 30, was listed in good condition at Craven Regional Medical Center on Thursday, two days after he was wounded in his hometown of Mesic, N.C. George Credle, 40, of Mesic, was charged with assault with a deadly weapon with intent to kill. Credle fired two shots at Smith, hitting him once, as the football player tried to run away, said Sheriff Leland Brinson. Credle was arrested a few miles away. ``The knee remains functionally intact,'' said Dr. Carl Hiller, an orthopedic surgeon. ``Barring complications, Smith plans to return to his football career.'' The 6-foot-6, 286-pound Smith was a second-round draft choice of the Oilers in 1984, but he opted instead to sign with the Birmingham Stallions of the short-lived United States Football League. He joined the Oilers in 1985.

It's bad enough when Engelbert Humperdinck looks in his closet. It's even worse when he talks to his lawyer. ``I've got more paternity suits than leisure suits,'' the British singer said in an interview to be broadcast Monday on the syndicated ``Joan Rivers Show.'' Humperdinck admitted that he has fooled around on his wife ``a lot'' _ so much so that he feels bad about it. ``I feel very sorry for my wife. For her to put up with my nonsense, she has to be a very strong and wonderful person,'' said Humperdinck, who also acknowledged his wife is bothered somewhat by the attention of his female fans. ``A little bit. She's used to it,'' said Humperdinck. ``For so many years she's had the adverse publicity. She's had the panties. I have almost three rooms of memorabilia _ panties and bras and everything.''

DOC.HEAD: Ortega Rebuked for Threatening Opposition
DOC.TEXT: The State Department rebuked Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega on Thursday for threatening to seize opposition leaders' property, including an anti-Sandinista newspaper, if his party wins national elections this month. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher called on Ortega to commit his leftist Sandinista party ``to respect the political, civil and human rights of opposition parties.'' ``If we win,'' Ortega told a campaign rally Wednesday night, ``I say we will hand them a complete bill, so they will be left without a newspaper _ La Prensa _ and the homes of the candidate and the vice presidential candidate will be converted into children's homes on the day after the elections.'' Boucher expressed concern about the statement and said that under international agreements signed by Ortega, elections are envisioned as a first step in a national reconciliation process. Ortega's threat was in response to a recent speech by opposition vice presidential candidate Virgilio Godoy, who said if the 14-party opposition coalition wins the Feb. 25 election, ``we are going to make the Sandinistas pay the bills one by one'' for alleged violations of human, civil and political rights. The opposition newspaper La Prensa is owned by the family of Ortega's main rival in the election, Violeta Chamorro. About 1.7 million voters will choose a president and vice president, a National Assembly, municipal councils for 144 towns and two regional councils for the Atlantic Coast. Meanwhile, President Bush said in an interview with USA Today that he would not try to oust Ortega, as he did Manuel Antonio Noriega in Panama, even if he concludes Ortega has stolen the elections. ``No,'' he said in response to a question. ``There's a lot of non-elected leaders around the world that can sleep comfortable.'' Pressed on that point, Bush called the line of questioning ``too hypothetical, but the answer is no.'' ``If you're talking about an effort to protect American life or something, the signal should be loud and clear: I'll do what's necessary to protect American lives. But if you're saying I don't like the results of an election and will be use military force, the answer is no.''

DOC.HEAD: 5,000 Teachers Rally at Statehouse, Storm Legislature
DOC.TEXT: About 5,000 teachers skipped school Thursday, staging a rally on the Capitol steps, laying siege to the House of Delegates and picketing the governor's mansion in their battle for higher pay. State troopers were called in to patrol the aisles of the House after teachers pounded on the doors of the chamber and chanted, ``Let us in.'' At a rally on the Capitol steps, the teachers criticized Gov. Gaston Caperton for not including teacher pay raises in his $1.5 billion budget proposal for 1990-91. Caperton said he was not surprised by their frustration, ``but you can't pay people when you don't have the money.'' The governor invited union leaders to meet with him Thursday, but they refused, a spokesman said. Instead, the governor met informally with about a dozen teachers allowed into the mansion while hundreds of others stood outside. The union said West Virginia ranks 49th in the nation in teacher pay. The average teacher's salary in the state is $21,904. Teachers are also upset with what they say is inadequate funding of the teachers retirement system, which has a deficit estimated at up to $3 billion, and with proposals to charge premiums for health coverage.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: Mouse Model For Human Leukemia May Help Fight Killer Disease, Experts Say
DOC.TEXT: Researchers, using an intricate manipulation of genes and transplantation of bone marrow, have produced a mouse that suffers from a vicious form of human leukemia, giving scientists a new way to test therapies against the killer disease. In a report to be published Friday in the magazine Science, researchers at the Whitehead Institute for Biomedical Research said they have discovered a way to give chronic myelogenous leukemia, CML, to laboratory mice. CML is a form of leukemia that usually attacks adults and is only rarely cured. ``With this new animal model, experimental therapies that might otherwise be tried in human patients can now be tested in these mice,'' said George Daley, lead researcher in the study at Whitehead. ``You obviously can do more with the mice than you could with human patients.'' Daley said the study also proves that CML is initiated by the fusion of parts from two broken chromosomes, a finding that had been suggested by earlier studies in other laboratories. Those parts have been identified as the so-called ABL gene from chromosome 9 and a gene called BCR from chromosome 22. Cells containing this hybrid gene produce a protein, called P210, that changes healthy cells into cancer cells. Daley said his study showed that transferring the BCR@ABL gene into mouse bone marrow and then putting these infected cells into healthy mice could produce CML in those mice. ``It answers a question of basic science, that is, what causes the disease,'' said Daley. ``We now know that the BCR@ABL gene is sufficient to induce the leukemia.'' He said it is still not known precisely what causes the two chromosomes to break and create the hybrid gene, but a high exposure to radiation is thought to be a factor. Dr. George Canellos, chief of medical oncology at the Dana-Farber Institute in Boston, described the Whitehead finding as ``an important advance in understanding the disease.'' He said the new animal model of the disease possibly may help scientists find ways to block the action of the P210 protein produced by the BCR@ABL gene, thus preventing the disease. Daley said that the mouse can be used to test ``biological inhibitors'' that would prevent the P210 protein from transforming normal cells into cancers. Such inhibitors formally could only be tested on human patients, a process that could take years. With a mouse model of the disease, experiments can be speeded up and can be more extensive. To create the mouse model, Daley said he and his collegues inserted the human BCR@ABL gene into a virus. Normal mouse bone marrow cells were then exposed to the virus, which transferred the gene into the marrow cells. Thirty healthy mice were then irradiated to kill their bone marrow cells. The bone marrow carrying the BCR@ABL gene was then transplanted into the 30 mice. Within five months, 13 of the 30 mice developed a blood disease that mimicked human chronic myelogenous leukemia. CML in humans can be controlled by chemotherpy for 3 to 5 years. This remission period usually ends with the sudden increase in abnormal cells, a disease phase called ``blast crisis'' that usually results in death. The only successful therapy now is to kill the diseased bone marrow in the patient and replace it with healthy bone marrow from a compatible donor, but even this treatment often fails. Daley said that continued studies of the CML mice shows that many of the laboratory animals develop the ``blast crisis'' phase of the disease. This, he said, is further verification that the course of the disease in the mice is similar to CML in humans. Co-authors of the study with Daley were Richard A. Van Etten and David Baltimore, both of the Whitehead Institute. Science, which published the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Phoenix Mayor Resigns to Run for Governor
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Terry Goddard resigned today to seek the Democratic Party's gubernatorial nomination, creating a front-runner in the race to fill the post being vacated by Gov. Rose Mofford. Goddard said he was responding to the urgings of ``thousands of Arizonans'' and agreed because ``Arizona needs effective leadership.'' Goddard, son of state Democratic Party chief Sam Goddard, a former governor, was elected to his first term as mayor by a narrow margin in 1983. He won re-election three times with only token opposition, most recently against state Republican Party chairman Burton Kruglick last October. During the campaign, Goddard accused Kruglick of endorsing a whispering campaign labeling him as homosexual. ``For the record ... I'm not gay, I've never been gay and I'm not bisexual,'' the 43-year-old bachelor told a campaign rally. ``But I've been accused of both.'' Goddard, a lawyer and Harvard University graduate, first came to political prominence when he led drives to repeal an unpopular statewide gasoline tax and to scrap Phoenix's at-large system of electing City Council members in favor of a district system. He was the first Democrat in 20 years to be elected Phoenix mayor. Carolyn Warner, a former state school superintendent who is considered Goddard's strongest potential Democratic opponent, was in Hawaii and not available for comment, according to her spokesman, David Bolger. The only other Democrat to have announced formally for governor is Ray C. Brown, a Sedona lawyer. Mofford, a Democrat and longtime secretary of state who was thrust into the governor's office after the removal of Republican Gov. Evan Mecham, dropped out of the race last month. Chief Justice Frank Gordon Jr. of the Arizona Supreme Court and Maricopa County Supervisor Carole Carpenter also opted out. State law required Goddard to resign as mayor to run for governor. City council members must choose his successor from among themselves.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Play Politics With Reunification
LaserPhoto BON4
DOC.TEXT: Opposition leaders accused Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Thursday of using the East German crisis to enhance his political standing and secure a place in history as the man who unified Germany. During a raucous, insult-filled Parliament session, Kohl in turn accused the opposition of being allied with the old Communists who ruled East Germany with an iron fist. The chancellor also came under fire in East Germany, where the Communist-led government accused Kohl of exaggerating the country's economic and political problems to speed reunification. The verbal brawl in Parliament gave West German voters a preview of what is likely to be a bitter campaign for West German elections in December, and the pivotal role reunification will play. The West German campaign is even influencing the campaign for East Germany's first free elections March 18. In anticipation of eventual reunification, West German parties have been aligning themselves with, and in fact influence, the fledgling political parties in East Germany. Kohl outlined to Parliament his weekend talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on reunification. He said both agreed the March 18 elections _ when the Communist government likely will be ousted _ were a key to reunification. ``I was able to underscore my firm belief (to Gorbachev) that the result of the elections will not only be a democratic and negotiations-capable government, but also a government program with the clear goal: `Unity as soon as possible,''' said Kohl. Kohl said his talks ``set the course'' for unification. ``Never before since the division of our land ... have we been so close to our goal ...'' Kohl told Parliament. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of the main opposition Social Democrats, accused Kohl of providing too little financial help for East Germany and of using unification for his own political benefit. ``You have talked, awakened hopes, set conditions ... and meditated over your place in the history books. But there hasn't been much help,'' said Vogel. Vogel also said Kohl was wrong to speak about a ``historic breakthrough'' from his talks with Gorbachev and said that Gorbachev already had said the Soviets supported Germans' right to self-determination before the talks. ``If we are to speak about a historic breakthrough, then it was this decision of Mikhail Gorbachev,'' said Vogel. Kohl's address was interrupted several times as he lambasted the Social Democrats for having close contacts with East Germany's now-disgraced Communists during years past. ``You were allied with these people,'' said Kohl, also charging that the Social Democrats did not favor German unification until it became politically expedient. Vogel reminded Kohl that his own Christian Democrats are now supporting the East German Christian Democrats, who for years were allied with the Communists. ``Mr. Chancellor, whoever supports the East (Christian Democrats) _ which for 40 years went along with everything (the Communists said) _ has no right to point the finger at the Social Democrats,'' said Vogel. In East Berlin, East German government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer also accused Bonn of overdramatizing the political and economic situation in East Germany in an attempt to speed unification. The Kohl government has said that more than 2,000 East Germans daily are fleeing West as the East German economy nears collapse. A key issue to reunification is whether a new German state would be neutral. East Germany is a key member of the Soviet Warsaw Pact and West Germany is a strategic component of NATO. Kohl and the United States want what at least is now West Germany to remain in NATO, while the Soviets want a neutral Germany. Earlier this week, the Germanys and the four World War II allies _ the Soviet Union, the United States, Britain and France _ agreed to talks on reunification that will deal with the alliance issue. In East Berlin, government spokesman Wolfgang Myers attacked Kohl for failing to assure Poles that a united Germany will not try to reclaim large chunks of formerly German land was assigned to Poland after Nazi Germany was defeated during World War II. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher rejected Poland's request to be included in the talks, but he said the discussions will address Polish concerns. Kohl, eager to garner the right-wing vote, has failed to give an unequivocal rejection of any possible territorial claims. In the latest nationwide polls, Kohl was leading the Social Democrats by about six points. A poll last August _ before the historic developments in East Germany _ showed the left-leaning Social Democrats and Kohl's conservative Christian Democrats nearly even. But the Social Democrats overwhelmed Kohl's Christian Democrats in recent Saarland state elections, and the chancellor's party is still trying to recover from the defeat.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Says He's Changed His Views About the Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle, often the voice of skepticism within the White House toward the Soviet Union, said Thursday he has changed his opinion about the communist state. ``I would say anybody that has not changed their mind over the last six or seven months is not thinking correctly,'' he said of the fast-changing reforms that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has ushered in in Moscow. ``Of course you change your opinion,'' Quayle said after a reporter asked if he remained suspicious of Gorbachev's intentions. ``A lot of things have happened, and I have a different assessment of where the Soviet Union is heading and where it may or may not go than I did six months ago or a year ago.'' Quayle spoke outside the Greater Southeast Community Hospital, where he visited a ward filled with ``boarder babies'' _ infants abandoned at birth by drug-abusing mothers. Quayle made the hospital visit on the same morning President Bush was off at the drug summit in Colombia to dramatize what the vice president called ``the end of the (drug) pipeline.'' ``This is the end of the pipeline right here. As it comes out of the fields in Peru or Colombia or Bolivia of elsewhere and comes through the system, the end result is a baby that is born dependant upon drugs,'' said Quayle. ``What I have just seen is the human tragedy of drugs. ... Anybody that advocates the legalization of drugs, saying it is a victimless crime, I suggest that they go up and tour this hospital and see those boarder babies with me,'' he said. At the hospital, Quayle picked up 5-month-old Kevin and held a 19-month-old boarder baby, Dougie, who was rescued from an unsafe home five months ago. The hospital has 11 boarder babies whose care can cost up to $100,000 a year apiece. Most were born inheriting their mother's addiction to cocaine or other hard drugs. Hospital officials voiced concern that they were having difficulties making ends meet, especially due to cuts in the Medicaid and Medicare programs. Quayle said, ``I reassured them of our commitment. Wouldn't we like to do more? Of course we would, but we're dealing with a strained budget environment.'' Quayle, who has generally struck a skeptical and hardline view toward the Soviet Union, said in a Dec. 4 newspaper interview after Bush's summit with Gorbachev at Malta that, ``I don't think they've changed much in foreign policy'' and ``you're still dealing with a totalitarian government.'' He later said that ``authoritarian'' was a more fitting adjective than ``totalitarian'' to describe the Soviet Union. Gorbachev this week agreed to Bush's proposal for dramatic reductions in U.S. and Soviet forces in Europe, limiting both sides to 195,000 troops in central Europe and allowing the United States to keep 30,000 elsewhere in Europe. Quayle also visited Jacqueline Mitchell's home in a largely poor, black neighborhood north of the U.S. Capitol where she and other neighbors have banded together to keep drug dealers and customers from the suburbs out of their street. After chatting in the Mitchell living room with members of the neighborhood watch group, Quayle shook hands with residents out on the street and advised three young men: ``Don't let (the drug-dealers) in. Just keep them out.''

DOC.HEAD: Fertilizer Prices Rising
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department said Thursday that fertilizer prices are going up as spring planting approaches, but probably won't be as high as a year ago. According to a preliminary report by the department's Economic Research Service, fertilizer prices may be up 4 percent from last fall. But despite the increase, spring prices may be down about 4 percent from year-earlier levels. ``Planted areas of corn and wheat, the major fertilizer-using crops, will probably increase by 1 percent to 5 percent,'' the report said. ``Decreases in planted acreage are anticipated for soybeans.'' Analysts said supplies of nitrogen, phosphate and potash should be enough to meet 1990 requirements, although greater nitrogen imports will more than make up for lower domestic production. ``Nitrogen prices will likely show the greatest increase since last fall as domestic supplies tighten,'' the report said. ``Phosphate supplies should be sufficient to meet demand at moderately higher prices than last fall, even with a slight reduction in domestic production.'' Potash inventories are expected to be available at ``stable to slightly lower'' prices than last fall if price cuts initiated by Canadian producers continue, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Of Pro-Apartheid Whites Call For De Klerk's Fall
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of angry whites marched through the city Thursday to demand the resignation of President F.W. de Klerk's government for releasing Nelson Mandela and legalizing black opposition groups. The opposition Conservative Party staged the rally to kick off a drive to oust de Klerk and preserve the apartheid system of racial segregation. Party chief Andries Treurnicht demanded immediate elections and predicted de Klerk would lose. ``Hang F.W. de Klerk'' and ``Keep South Africa White,'' said placards carried by marchers as they passed through the city center. Police said some 15,000 people took part in the peaceful, but boisterous march. De Klerk angered the Conservative Party by freeing Mandela on Sunday after he had spent 27 years in prison and by legalizing his African National Congress movement and other black opposition groups. De Klerk has said he wants to negotiate a power-sharing agreement with South Africa's black majority, which currently has no voice in national affairs. The Conservatives have threatened to stage strikes to force an election if de Klerk refuses to step down. ``F.W. de Klerk is a traitor to white South Africans!'' a leader yelled at the start of the march. Many signs denounced racial integration and called for creation of a separate white state. ``South Africa, South Africa,'' the crowd sang as they marched. Hundreds of uniformed stormtroopers of the neo-Nazi Afrikaneer Resistance Party joined the march with swastika flags and signs saying, ``Hang Mandela.'' Some of them hanged a small black doll representing Mandela, and others marched with a severed black doll head mounted on a stake. But most marchers were middle-class and working-class white men, women and children. ``We want to stay a nation of whites. We're going to fight to stay a nation on our own,'' said Ter Schumann, one of the marchers. ``We are going to stay a white nation.'' A young white man, who would not give his name, said, ``South Africa is for the whites. We will not tolerate F.W. de Klerk's treason.'' Thousands jammed City Hall afterward to hear Treurnicht denounce de Klerk and the governing National Party as traitors to Afrikaners, people of mainly Dutch descent who dominate white politics in South Africa. Thousands of others stood outside, listening to the speech relayed over loudspeakers. Treurnicht said the abolition of apartheid would not bring peace to South Africa. He said de Klerk's reforms would put South Africa under the rule of the ANC and the South African Communist Party. ``Our people have kept a low profile up to now, but we have fought for our own fatherland and that fatherland you will not take away from us,'' Treurnicht said. Ferdie Hartzenberg, deputy leader of the Conservative Party, said de Klerk deceived whites by legalizing black opposition groups. He said the great majority of whites do not support such reforms. ``President de Klerk ... should resign,'' he said as the crowd roared its approval. Local observers said the turnout was an impressive show of strength for the Conservative Party, which won 31 percent of the white vote in elections in September. Dozens of buses from surrounding towns brought people into Pretoria for the march.

DOC.HEAD: Aid To Rebels Suspended Because of Theft
DOC.TEXT: U.S. food aid to the Afghan rebels has been suspended for the second time in three months because some of the assistance has been stolen, the State Department said Thursday. Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said he expects that new arrangements for monitoring the assistance will be in place soon and that the suspension will be brief. Food shipments representing about 30 percent of total U.S. humanitarian aid to the rebels were suspended in late November because of difficulty in meeting government monitoring reqirements, he said. He said the shipments were resumed in January but have been suspended again. The Washington Post reported in Thursday's editions that the suspension was ordered after members of Pakistan's military intelligence agency, which supervises the distribution of the aid, diverted 2,400 tons of the U.S.-supplied wheat. The U.S. humanitarian aid program is listed at $70 million for the fiscal year 1990.

DOC.HEAD: India Sending Data Recorder for Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The government said Thursday it would have the flight data recorder of a crashed Indian Airlines jetliner analyzed in a country other than France, where the Airbus A320 was manufactured. At least 91 of the 146 on the 3-month-old jetliner were killed when it crashed Wednesday, in clear weather, short of the airport at Bangalore. Officials said there were no signs of an emergency on board. The Times of India quoted unidentified aviation sources as saying the sophisticated plane, which had logged 366 flying hours, may have crashed because the pilot ``tried to change the mode of control from computer to manual or vice-versa.'' It said the ``response time of the inflight computer for doing this is five to six seconds,'' and indicated that amount of time could be crucial in landing. Another paper, the Hindustan Times of New Delhi, said the instruments may have indicated the wrong altitude for the jet. Both the pilot and the co-pilot died in the crash. Science Report said the A320 has a pre-programmed ``envelope protection software that tells the computer _ and not the pilot _ to make judgments.'' If the pilot wanted to make a sharp turn to avoid a collision, the report said, the system would ``not let the airplane respond beyond a certain rate.'' Aviation Minister Arif Mohammed Khan told a news conference in Bangalore, southern India: ``Since the Airbus belongs to France, we would like to send'' the data recorder ``to some other country for decoding.'' The plane was made by Airbus Industrie, a European consortium based in Toulouse, France. Khan said preliminary reports on the cause of the crash would be available within 36 hours, United News of India reported. He has ordered separate inquiries by a high court judge and aviation authorities. ``This kind of crash can happen either because of equipment error, or human error or navigational error,'' Khan said. ``The cockpit voice recorder is being sent to Delhi and its contents will be known within 36 hours.'' A U.S. Embassy official in New Delhi said one American on the plane was killed, one was missing and five were known to have survived. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said identities would not be released until their families had been notified. John Mancosky, 28, of Chicago, said the plane began to shake about five minutes before the crash and he thought at first the pilot had made a hard landing. ``Then we heard a loud booming noise and soon we were enveloped in a ball of flame,'' said Mancosky, who suffered a broken leg. Like most of the survivors, he escaped through the rear door. This was the second accident involving an A320 and the first in commercial service. Three people were killed and 50 injured when an A320 crashed at an airshow in eastern France in June 1988. The twin-engined, narrow-bodied jet is the first civilian airliner with a fully computerized flight control system.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Debate Proposal to Legalize Private Property
With AM-Soviet-Unrest, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Private property was a hated concept for generations of Communists, but Soviet lawmakers were asked by government leaders on Thursday to legalize it, not condemn it. ``If we want to have a market economy and take part in the international marketplace, then we need such a law,'' Justice Minister Veniamin F. Yakovlev said in defense of a bill designed to establish private property rights. Mikhail S. Gorbachev's nearly five-year tenure as Soviet leader has led to numerous upheavals in politics and society, but few official proposals have the ideological sweep of the proposed Property Law submitted to the Supreme Soviet legislature. Citizens who were taught for generations that, in the words of 19th-century French philosopher Pierre Joseph Proudhon, ``property is theft,'' are now being asked to accept private ownership along with two other forms of property already in existence _ collective and state ownership. Because of ideological squeamishness, the 35-article bill debated on the second day of the Supreme Soviet's 1990 winter session never uses the words ``private property'' outright. Instead, it speaks of ``the property of citizens.'' ``The words `private property' cause an allergy in us all,'' one lawmaker acknowledged from the tribune. Fellow deputy Leonid I. Sukhov, a taxi driver from the Ukrainian city of Kharkov, said the measure would provoke such a turnabout in law and lifestyle that it should be put to a nationwide referendum. ``We have to ask the people,'' Sukhov said. ``The people know better.'' The driver said he would vote against the measure because it would worsen the lives of average Soviets, already hard-pressed to cope with chronic shortages of food and consumer goods, inadequate salaries and inflation. In 1848, Marx and Engels, the ideological fathers of communism, said they could sum up their theory in a single phrase: ``the abolition of private property.'' For decades Soviet orthodoxy has forbidden the private ownership of farms, factories or equipment on a large scale, seeing in such ownership the roots of economic exploitation. But the proposed Property Law legalizes individual ownership of ``means of production,'' without defining that term, and says foreign firms, once scorned as agents of imperialism or neo-colonialism, can own factories and buildings on Soviet soil. The bill would allow foreigners to enjoy the same rights as Soviet citizens in owning property. Citizens could own stocks and bonds. It follows last week's historic measures by the Communist Party leadership to allow other parties to compete for power. The party also laid the groundwork for the property bill by approving the concept in its revised platform. The law is designed to spur the stagnating Soviet economy through the greater productivity that private enterprise is now recognized to offer over state-owned factories and businesses, and by encouraging Western capital. A companion bill on the legislature's winter agenda, the Law on Land, provides for the private ownership of land. After its first reading before the 542-member Supreme Soviet last fall, the Property Law underwent substantial revision with at least 10,000 changes suggested, the official Tass news agency said. Despite the revisions, the bill drew fire from 30 lawmakers who demanded a five-minute chance to air their views. Vavil Nosov, a machine-operator from the Komi region of northern Russia, said he feared that if the buying and selling of land is allowed, the beneficiaries will be black marketeers with illegal fortunes. A lawmaker from Soviet Central Asia worried aloud that if water resources like rivers and lakes become the property of local administrative bodies, water might be diverted from his parched homeland. Conflict also arose over who now owns natural resources _ the national government or the individual Soviet republics. The issue was skirted in the draft in favor of phrasing that says the land and its resources ``belong to people living on a given territory.'' That issue is critical because the legislature in Lithuania has already adopted laws allowing the sale of land to individuals. Debate was to continue Friday, with the Law on Land also on the agenda.

DOC.HEAD: API Says Imports Reached All-Time High Last Month
DOC.TEXT: Imports accounted for an all-time high of 54 percent of the nation's petroleum consumption last month, the American Petroleum Institute said Thursday. Although the record-high level was spurred in part by a bitter cold snap across much of the nation in December that increased demand for heating fuel, officials said they feared it could signal a trend toward monthly imports of at least 50 percent. Imports last accounted for more than half of the country's petroleum consumption in July, which marked the first time they had crossed the 50 percent level in 12 years. The surge in petroleum imports last month comes during a continued slowdown in domestic drilling activity, prompting a call for congressional consideration of a plan to ensure that the United States does not become dependent on foreign sources for more than half its oil consumption. Monthly oil imports have exceeded 50 percent only four times _ last July, when they reached 50.4 percent, in March and July 1977, when they hit 51.8 percent of consumption, and in May 1977, when the level reached 50.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: First Guilty Plea in Noriega Drug Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS second graf to ADD that pilot from Panama; ADDS 3 grafs at end with attorneys for Panamanian freighter crew charged in drug case seeking Noriega testimony.
DOC.TEXT: A pilot admitted Thursday to flying $800,000 in cocaine profits from Florida to Panama in 1983, becoming the first of Manuel Noriega's co-defendants to plead guilty in the drug trafficking case. Noriega's lawyers said their client had nothing to fear from information the Panamanian pilot, Eduardo Pardo, might give prosecutors. ``If he tells the truth, he can't hurt us,'' said Noriega attorney Frank Rubino. Pardo, 44, was arrested by Drug Enforcement Administration agents in Panama City after the U.S. invasion. His attorney, William Meadows, and Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan said there was no plea bargain in the case. Noriega and Pardo were among 16 people indicted in Miami in February 1988 on charges of taking part in a conspiracy that made Panama a way station and processing center for Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. Shaken and occasionally close to tears, Pardo, who faces up to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine at sentencing April 25 on a single count of illegal travel, admitted to prosecutors' account of the 1983 drug-money flight. Pardo and co-defendant Daniel Miranda flew a Lear jet fitted ``with secret compartments so that money could be hidden,'' Sullivan told the court. ``They were worried that the secret compartment made the plane unsafe to fly, but they were assured it was OK.'' Pardo received $40,000 for the flight and knew it was drug money, the prosecutor said. Meadows said he had no idea whether Pardo would testify against Noriega or any of the other defendants. The defendant most immediately threatened by Pardo, should he testify for the prosecution, appeared to be Miranda, who allegedly accompanied him on the flight. But Miranda's attorney, Michael O'Kane, said his client did not know the money came from drugs. ``I guess Pardo's guilty. That doesn't mean that Miranda is,'' O'Kane said. Richard Sharpstein, attorney for Brian Alden Davidow, the only defendant free on bail, said outside court that even without an agreement to testify for the government, Pardo's plea made him a likely witness. Noriega is accused of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from the cartel. The Panamanian leader, who surrendered to U.S. troops after the December invasion of his country, has disputed the right of a U.S. civilian court to judge him. He and the other defendants, except for Davidow, are being held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami. In New Orleans, attorneys for crewmen of a Panamanian freighter that carried 12,000 pounds of cocaine want Noriega to testify at the crewmen's trial. The Coast Guard seized the freighter in the Gulf of Mexico in October. The defense has argued that U.S. authorities didn't have the permission of Panamanian authorities to board the ship; prosecutors say Panama's President Eric Delvalle gave blanket authorization before his term expired Sept. 1. U.S. District Judge Charles Schwartz Jr. has denied the request for Noriega's appearance, but asked lawyers Wednesday for detailed memos.

DOC.HEAD: News on the Health Front
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Contains AM-CDC-Blood Disorders, a0616; AM-Leukemia-Mouse, a0627; AM-Airliner Pollution, a0606.
DOC.TEXT: Here are some developments on the health front Thursday:
DOC.NOTE: For release 6 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-five million Americans report suffering from arthritis and 6 million admit they haven't seen a doctor about it, according to a nationwide survey released Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control. ``People are seeing (pain-killer) ads on TV and treating their arthritis themselves _ and very possibly doing damage to themselves,'' said Steve Erickson, spokesman for the Arthritis Foundation. The problem will probably get worse if pain relievers are the only treatment, he said. Erickson said too few people are aware of the warning signs of arthritis, such as joint swelling, early morning stiffness, recurring joint pain or inability to move a joint that lasts for more than two weeks.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: At least 14 deaths and 1,269 cases of a rare, painful blood disorder known as eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome have been attributed to the health food supplement L-tryptophan, the Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday. The disorder, marked by an abnormally high number of white blood cells, causes severe muscle pain and can cause death. The median time between use of L-tryptophan and the onset of symptoms was 152 days. The FDA issued a recall request for L-tryptophan on Nov. 17 and expanded it four days later to block importation of the product, a protein component widely taken as a nutritional supplement. Last month, the FDA cautioned consumers against buying L-tryptophan products from a California company that did not comply with the recall request.
DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Researchers using an intricate manipulation of genes and transplantation of bone marrow have produced a mouse that suffers from a vicious form of human leukemia, giving scientists a new way to test therapies against the killer disease. In a report to be published Friday in the magazine Science, researchers said they have discovered a way to give chronic myelogenous leukemia, CML, to laboratory mice. CML is a form of leukemia that usually attacks adults and is only rarely cured. Lead researcher George Daley said the study also proves that CML is initiated by the fusion of parts from two broken chromosomes, a finding that had been suggested by earlier studies. Cells containing the hybrid gene produce a protein that changes healthy cells into cancer cells. Daley said it is still not known precisely what causes the two chromosomes to break and create the hybrid gene, but a high exposure to radiation is thought to be a factor.

A study of airline-cabin environment found that, even with the smoking ban that takes effect in 10 days, passengers and crew still face a health risk from increased radiation from the sun and stars. The study released Thursday by the Transportation Department recommends that airlines schedule cabin crews in ways that will reduce their risk to cosmic radiation, especially those crews who regularly fly near the North Pole and South Pole or at higher altitudes. The study found the risk of cancer death from cosmic radiation comparable to the risk of death from exposure to smoke-filled cabins, although estimates of cancer caused by cosmic rays had a wider range because of uncertainty over the effects of low doses of radiation. It also recommended a total smoking ban but was superceded by congressional action banning smoking on all flights of six hours or less beginning Feb. 25.

DOC.HEAD: Media Warned Not to Publish Anti-Party Reports
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party newspaper Thursday accused Chinese media of failing the party during the spring pro-democracy movement and said in the future they must never veer from the party line. The press was guilty of ``allowing the rotten ideology and way of life of the bourgeois class to corrupt the soul of the people'' during the spring uprising, the People's Daily said. Hostile forces both at home and abroad continue to spread rumors ``to confuse the people,'' it alleged. ``Even during the most arduous period of our struggle against the enemy, our media should advocate the leadership of the party, the party line and general and specific policies and should encourage people to continue the revolution despite all obstacles,'' said the newspaper. Freedom of the press was one of the main demands of the student-led democracy movement, and for a brief time in May the official press, including the People's Daily, broke with party ranks and published remarkably objective reports about the political turmoil. Many reporters from China's main newspapers and radio and television stations marched in demonstrations and expressed support for greater press freedom. The People's Daily said that at a critical time, referring to the period before and during the democracy movement, ``some papers even revealed the dark side of the party and talked about our party and socialist system as if they did not have any redeeming features.'' The media beautified capitalism, it said, and as a result some people wondered ``how long the Communist Party's red flag would survive.'' The article said it is ``strictly forbidden to deviate from the principles of the party,'' and that critical articles should be secondary to positive reporting. ``Total control must be maintained,'' it said. The government quickly regained control over the media after martial law was declared in Beijing on May 20 and troops launched their bloody attack on June 3-4 to crush the democracy movement. The chief editor of the People's Daily was replaced by the head of the army propaganda department. Other editors were sacked, Shanghai's outspoken World Economic Herald and other journals were closed, and numerous reporters were arrested or fired. Since then, articles on party corruption, economic disasters and crime have been allowed only if they illustrate how the party is striving to eradicate such problems.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Barry Indicted on Perjury, Drug Possession Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material; editing throughout
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, undergoing treatment in Florida following his January arrest on a cocaine possession charge, was indicted today by a federal grand jury on eight counts of perjury and possession of a controlled substance. The 14-month probe began after Barry was discovered visiting the hotel room of an associate, Charles Lewis, who later pleaded guilty to conspiracy to possess and distribute cocaine. Barry was said to have told the grand jury that he had never used cocaine. Lewis had testified to the contrary. The indictment comes four weeks after Barry was arrested on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge and on the same day that President Bush and leaders of three Latin American nations met at a drug summit in Colombia. Barry is undergoing treatment for substance abuse at a Florida clinic and has turned over the day-to-day operations of the district government to the city administrator. The lengthy investigation, conducted by the FBI and the internal affairs department of the city police force, moved toward indictment after one-time Barry girlfriend Rasheeda Moore agreed to cooperate with authorities. Barry was videotaped in a hotel room with Moore using crack cocaine, authorities said. Barry has steadfastly denied using drugs. ``I have never used any illegal drugs, nor have I knowingly purchased or been given any illegal drugs, nor have I knowingly been around anyone using illegal drugs,'' Barry said last August after Lewis told prosecutors that he had smoked cracked cocaine with the mayor. At an emotional appearance following his arrest Jan. 18, he admitted having a problem with alcohol but said nothing about drugs. Since his arrest, Barry's political support in the city has dwindled and several supporters have urged him not to seek another term. There are four announced Democratic candidates for Barry's job. Jesse Jackson, who moved to the city last year fueling speculation that he would run for mayor, has said he would not challenge Barry. The U.S. Attorney's Office said in a statement that the indictment resulted from ``an ongoing investigation of public corruption and illegal narcotics activity.'' Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, was not immediately available for comment. The indictment charged that during a Jan. 19, 1989, grand jury appearance Barry lied under oath by stating he was not aware that Lewis was involved with drugs and by stating that the two men had not exchanged cocaine. Lewis, who also is cooperating with the investigation, was recently sentenced to 15 months in prison on drug charges. Four charges against Barry involve alleged possession of cocaine between Dec. 16-22, 1988, the period when Barry was with Lewis at the downtown Ramada Inn. The fifth drug-possession charge stems from Barry's arrest at the Vista International Hotel where he was videotaped with Moore. Each of the three felony false declaration charges carries a five-year prison term and a maximum fine of $250,000. Each of the misdemeanor possession charges carries a maximum sentence of one year in jail and a fine of $100,000. The indictment gave the following description of Barry's appearance before the grand jury: ``Have you ever seen Mr. Lewis with anything that indicated he was involved in drugs of any sort?'' Barry was asked. ``No, I have not,'' the mayor answered. The indictment charged that this statement was false. ``Have you ever talked to Mr. Lewis about drugs?'' the mayor was asked. ``No, not to my recollection,'' Barry responded, in another statement prosecutors alleged was false. In another count, Barry is charged with lying when he said, ``I've never given Mr. Lewis any cocaine or any other drug.'' The prosecutor then asked, ``I believe it's safe to assume you did not ever give Mr. Lewis any cocaine?'' ``Cocaine. Absolutely,'' the mayor replied, according to the indictment. Another count charged that Barry lied when asked ``Did Mr. Lewis ever give you cocaine?'' ``No.'' the mayor replied. ``Have you ever received cocaine from anyone at the Ramada?'' ``No,'' Barry replied. The three-term mayor has been at a Florida substance abuse clinic since Jan. 22, four days after his arrest on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge. He is scheduled to remain in the clinic past the normal 28-day treatment cycle, according to top city government sources. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens has said the investigation of Barry began in December 1988 after city police aborted an attempt to make an undercover drug purchase from Lewis at a downtown hotel after learning that Barry was in the room. Lewis testified under oath that he supplied Barry with crack cocaine. A district employee, Robert McWilliams, who was in Lewis' room with Barry in December 1988, also has appeared before the same panel. Barry, 53, told close advisers on the weekend of his arrest that he was abandoning his bid for a fourth, four-year term in November. If convicted of a felony, Barry would be required to resign, and City Council Chairman David Clarke would become acting mayor. A special election would be held within 120 days of any resignation, unless that date falls within 60 days of the Nov. 6 general election.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Jets Collide Off Florida; One Pilot Dead, One Safe
DOC.TEXT: Two Navy jets collided over the Atlantic on Thursday, killing one pilot and injuring the other, authorities said. The planes were taking part in an exercise around noon when the accident occurred 70 miles southeast of Jacksonville, the Navy said. The pilot killed was flying a single-engine A-4F attack jet from Oceana Naval Air Station in Virginia, said Bert Byers, a spokesman for Cecil Field Naval Air Station. The pilot's identity was not immediately released. The other pilot, Cmdr. David R. Miller, 39, of Orange Park, was rescued and was reported to be alert and talking at a hospital. Miller was flying a twin-engine, single-seat FA-18 Hornet, a strike fighter. The cause of the accident is under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Presidents Agree: They Don't Want the Job Again
DOC.TEXT: None of the four living former presidents shows any interest in having the job again, according to an article in the forthcoming issue of the Sunday newspaper supplement USA Weekend. ``The time has come for younger people to serve the country,'' Gerald R. Ford, 77, told the magazine in an interview for its Feb. 16-18 issue. Ronald Reagan, 79, asked if he would like to president again, said, ``I do not think so ... Nancy and I are happy in our new life now and I like being back out there on `the mashed potato circuit' talking with the people and, I hope, inspiring them to urge their representatives to do some of the things we weren't able to accomplish.'' Jimmy Carter, 65, said he and his wife, Rosalynn, don`t ``miss the pomp, ceremony and perks but we often remember how nice it was to visit Camp David.'' He said he would not want to return to office, but would ``be happy if one of my grandchildren becomes president.'' Richard Nixon, 77, asked if he would want to be president again, replied only, ``Not if I have to answer such silly questions as this one!'' Reagan, Carter and Nixon responded to questions in writing. Ford was interviewed over the telephone. All four said they do not believe former presidents should have any formal role in government, such as a senator-at-large seat that has sometimes been suggested. The magazine is publishing the interview in observance of President's Day, which is Monday. Reagan and Ford both supported President Bush's decision to invade Panama. Carter said he ``deplored the invasion'' but hoped it will lead to ``freedom, democracy and economic prosperity.'' Nixon said, ``I understand why President Bush acted as he did,'' but added that in general the United States should not directly depose foreign leaders. ``When the United States decides by itself who is going to run a country, it runs the risk of ending up running the country itself,'' he said. Reagan said he goes to his ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif., once a month and still enjoys watching movies. Recent ones that he has liked include ``Field of Dreams'' and ``Rain Man.'' He said he has been reading ``Bicycle Days'' by John Burnham Schwartz and has also recently read several Western novels by Louis L'Amour, an old favorite, as well as essays on current events. Carter, commenting on the suggestion of some writers that he is distinguishing himself more as an active ex-president than he did in office, said it ``does not bother me, and I am grateful for the more favorable attitude of the news media in recent years.'' Nixon said he gave up golf because it was too time-consuming, but walks three or four miles daily ``to keep fit and stimulate thinking.'' He is re-reading ``The Coming Soviet Crash.'' ``Most movies and TV today are so bad that I don't see them much, except for an occasional mystery rerun such as `Barnaby Jones,''' the former president said. Nixon's ninth book is scheduled for publication in April.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Denies Imelda's Request for Classified Documents
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Thursday rejected a request by Imelda Marcos for reams of classified government documents for use in her racketeering trial. The widow deposed Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos had asked to review papers from a U.S. government interagency task force her lawyers claimed was assembled to investigate her and her husband. But U.S. District Judge John Keenan ruled there was no such wide-ranging investigation and therefore she had no right to see any classified documents. Mrs. Marcos is scheduled for trial March 13 on charges she and her husband embezzled more than $100 million from the Philippine treasury to buy art and New York real estate. They also were charged with defrauding banks of $165 million. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii on Sept. 28 at age 72. Mrs. Marcos had sought access to documents from more than a dozen agencies, including the Departments of Justice, Defense and Treasury; the offices of the president and vice president; the CIA, FBI, National Security Agency, the Navy and the U.S. Embassy in Manila. Prosecutors opposed the request, calling it a ``fishing expedition.'' The judge noted that the prosecution had already turned over to Mrs. Marcos about 350,000 documents, videotapes and other items seized in its investigation. He said ``voluminous'' documents from the Internal Revenue Service, the FBI, the U.S. Agency for International Development and the Customs Service also were made available to the defense.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Panel Urges Cooperation Against Airliner Bombings
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. presidential panel urged closer Western cooperation Thursday to prevent airliner bombings and called for a tough response to nations sponsoring such attacks. Ann McLaughlin, former U.S. labor secretary and head of the commission, said at a news conference that a ``common purpose exists to combat terrorism'' and called for more sharing of information to protect travelers. President Bush created the commission on Aviation, Security and Terrorism in August as a result of the Dec. 21, 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland. The seven-member panel is traveling through Europe to sound out anti-terrorism policies. At the news conference, Sen. Frank Lautenberg, a New Jersey Democrat, urged Western governments to strike back at any state proved to be involved in terrorist attacks on aviation. ``We have to let these states know we mean business,'' he said. Investigators have suggested there might be an Iranian connection to the Lockerbie bombing, which killed all 259 people on board and 11 on the ground. The jet was bound for New York. In the Sept. 19 bombing of a French UTA jumbo jet over Niger, investigators say they are convinced a Middle Eastern state was involved. French press reports have said it could be Libya. Members of the commission said they did not go into specifics of the UTA crash with French officials. But they said the fact that both nations shared a similar tragedy made their conversations more intensive. Another commission member, Sen. Alfonse M. D'Amato, a New York Republican, said U.S. and French officials agreed that security at African airports was a ``gaping hole'' that must fixed. France has announced a $20 million program to improve security at African airports. The UTA flight, in which 170 people died, originated in Brazzaville, Congo and stopped in N'Djamena, Chad. McLaughlin said it was too early to give any indication of what recommendations the group would make to Bush. Their report is due in mid-May. ``We'll come up with something or we will have failed,'' she said. ``We can't leave the impression the terrorists are winning.'' The group visited Charles De Gaulle airport to look at French security measures, baggage handling and passenger check-in procedures. They said they also discussed new technology aimed at examining baggage to search for explosives.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Fathers Living Near A-Plants Could Cause Leukemia Births
DOC.TEXT: A new study published Thursday said high rates of leukemia in young people living near nuclear plants may be caused by radiation doses their fathers received before they were born. The government said it was concerned and would refer the findings to its committee of experts on radiation for urgent consideration. Men who work at nuclear plants, particularly those who received high radiation doses in the six months before their children's conception, had more offspring with leukemia than men in other jobs, said the study published in the British Medical Journal. One researcher, radiotherapist Michael Snee, said the radiation probably caused a mutation in the fathers' sperm. The researchers' study, headed by Martin Gardner, professor of medical studies at the University of Southampton, examined 52 victims of leukemia and lymphoma under 25 years old, born in the West Cumbria health district and diagnosed between 1950-85. They were compared with 1,001 control children. The Sellafield nuclear reprocessing plant, which has been plagued by radioactive leaks, is in the district on England's northwest coast. Government studies have found a 10-fold increase in childhood leukemia a mile from the plant. One study, by the Medical Research Council and the Imperial Research Fund, reported in November that an increased risk of leukemia is not associated with exposure to radiation, with the possible exception of the Sellafield plant. ``The main finding was of a raised risk for those children whose fathers worked at Sellafield, in particular fathers with the highest recorded exposures to external ionizing radiation before their child's conception,'' Gardner told a news conference. ``The risk was raised by sixfold to eightfold for fathers who had received total doses of over 100 millisieverts (msv).'' One millisievert equals half an individual's annual dose from natural radiation, or 50 times the dose received during a single chest X-ray. When researchers focused on the village of Seascale near Sellafield, they found that the fathers of four of the five victims of leukemia and one lymphoma sufferer were employed at the plant and had higher radiation doses before their child's conception than all their matched controls. Gardner said other theories about concentrated high rates of leukemia, such as viral infections, did not apply to the Sellafield area. Junior health minister Roger Freeman said the government noted the results with concern and ``recognizes the anxieties it must cause to those who might be at risk.'' He said the findings were referred to the govenment-appointed Committee on Medical Aspects of Radiation in the Environment for urgent consideration and advice. The Atomic Energy Authority, the government body responsible for Britain's nuclear industry, said Gardner's study conflicts with previous studies, and said more research is needed. ``We will need to study this detailed report with care ... particularly as it does not seem to be emerging from other studies,'' said Chairman John Collier. ``There are many leukemia clusters distant from nuclear sites which cannot yet be explained, so research must continue.'' The Committee on Medical Aspects of Radiation in the Environment said in 1988 the high levels of leukemia might also be due to exposure to chemicals, viruses or even chance. Martin Bobrow, a geneticist on the committee, called the latest findings a ``very important step forward.'' He said larger studies would be needed to confirm the results, but the idea that a cancer-causing gene mutation could be passed from father to child was theoretically possible. ``These children would then have a head start in terms of developing leukemia,'' Bobrow said. British Nuclear Fuels PLC, which owns the Sellafield plant, said Gardner's conclusions were unexpected, and backed the call for further study. A spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British custom, said the conclusions conflicted with evidence from the Japanese victims of the World War II atomic bombs. Gardner's researchers attributed the conflict to the short but intense burst of radiation at Hiroshima and Nagaski vs. the long-term radiation experience by nuclear plant workers. Leukemia clusters _ occurrences of the disease statistically higher than normal _ have also been found in southern England near the Atomic Weapons Research Establishment, the Royal Ordnance Factory and the Atomic Energy Authority.

DOC.HEAD: Latvian Parliament Condemns Soviet Annexation Act of 1940
DOC.TEXT: The Latvian parliament on Thursday condemned the 1940 declaration that made the Baltic republic part of the Soviet Union, Tass reported. The parliament, or Supreme Soviet, said the declaration was taken without making clear the will of the people and led to loss of Latvia's independence. The vote was 177-40, with 33 deputies abstaining or absent, said Valdis Birzens of the Latvian Popular Front newspaper Atmoda. The parliament also voted to restore the red-and-white flag and the national anthem of independent Latvia, Birzens said. The independence flag replaces one with the Communist hammer and sickle emblem. The action follows a similar but stronger resolution in the Parliament of neighboring Lithuania last week. Lithuanian lawmakers declared ``unlawful and invalid'' the 1940 act that incorporated their republic into the Soviet Union. They demanded talks with the Kremlin on restoring Lithuanian independence. All three Baltic republics, Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, say they were forced to join the Soviet Union while occupied by the Red Army. Tass, the official Soviet news agency, described the Lithuanian action as a step toward full secession. The Latvian parliament also said Thursday that measures must be taken to transform Latvia into a free and independent state in a union of states, following a path of humane, democratic socialism and building its own relations with other states on a foundation of agreements, Tass said. Some Latvians want a completely independent nation. Others would rewrite the treaty to allow the Kremlin limited powers in Latvia while keeping most of the authority in Riga, the Latvian capital. Lithuanians enjoy an 80 percent majority in their homeland, but immigration from other parts of the Soviet Union has left Latvia with a population only half native Latvian.

DOC.HEAD: Doxycycline Recalled
DOC.TEXT: More than 3,000 bottles of an antibiotic distributed by Goldline Laboratories, doxycycline hyclate, are being recalled because one bottle was found to contain a muscle relaxant, federal officials said Thursday. Doxycycline hyclate is used to treat a wide range of infections, including venereal diseases, acne and life-threatening pneumonia. The Food and Drug Administration said the mislabeled muscle relaxant, carisoprodol, could harm patients because it would not treat their infections and could impair their mental and physical abilities, making it dangerous to drive a car or operate heavy machinery. The recalled bottles of Goldline doxycycline hyclate 100 milligrams are in six lots. The bottles carry lot numbers 824039, 844059, 863069, 882079, 883079 and 919099. The carisoprodol tablets are white and round with the Bolar Pharmaceutical Co. Inc. logo on one side _ a ``b'' over an inverted ``b'' _ and the number 0094 stamped on the other side. The FDA said patients who find that they have the mislabeled product should stop using it, contact their physicians and return the prescription to their pharmacy. The distributor, Goldline Laboratories, discovered the mislabeled antibiotic and notified Bolar, the supplier, which is voluntarily recalling the drug, according to the FDA. Bolar said more than 3,000 bottles may be in the hands of pharmacists or consumers. The Copiague, N.Y.-based Bolar has been under fire for giving false test data to the government. It has recalled many of its products, including its largest seller, a generic version of the anti-hypertensive drug Dyzaide. FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit said the doxycycline recall did not appear to be linked to Bolar's other problems with the agency.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Announces Program to Curb Food-Poisoning Organism
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department on Thursday announced a stepped-up program to help curb the spread of a food-poisoning organism in poultry flocks that produce table eggs for consumers. Salmonella enteritidis, which has a number of strains, has been identified with food poisoning in humans who have eaten improperly cooked contaminated eggs. Assistant Secretary Jo Ann R. Smith said the $6.8 million control program will focus on testing and certification of breeding flocks that produce the table-egg layers, and on tracing and testing commercial egg flocks if and when they are implicated in human cases of salmonella enteritidis. The interstate movement of chickens, eggs and associated articles from flocks infected or associated with the bacteria will be restricted, she said. Smith said the organism is a growing problem in the nation's $3.2 billion egg industry, ``and has emerged as a serious public health concern as well.'' Strains of the organism are entrenched in Northeastern and Mid-Atlantic states and are expanding into the Midwest and Northwest, she said. In humans, the bacteria can cause cramps, diarrhea, fever, and sometimes nausea and vomiting five to 72 hours after eating contaminated food. Smith said some people, such as the elderly or those with poor immune systems, can suffer serious and life-threatening effects from eating contaminated eggs or other food. An interim rule will put the program into effect Friday, Smith said. Public comments, accepted through April 17, may be sent to: Chief, Regulatory Analysis and Development, PPD, APHIS, USDA, Room 866, Federal Building, 6505 Belcrest Road, Hyattsville, Md. 20782.

DOC.HEAD: Telltale Sex Tape Found Inside Stolen VCR; Burglar Victim Jailed
DOC.TEXT: The discovery of a homemade child-sex tape in a stolen videocassette recorder led to the arrest of the VCR owner on charges of molesting a 9-year-old neighbor girl, authorities said Thursday. Ward Rafay, 28, was arraigned Wednesday on nine counts of child molestation and one of possessing a kilogram of marijuana for sale, and was being held on $50,000 bail. Two weeks ago, Rafay told police that a VCR was stolen from his apartment in Downey, 10 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles. Deputy District Attorney Dean Shotwell said the thief sold the VCR with the telltale tape inside. The buyer recognized the girl on the tape and arranged through another party for the tape to be turned over to the girl's mother, he said. Authorities do not know the identities of the thief or the buyer. Rafay was arrested hours after the enraged mother contacted police. ``The mother of the victim notified us Saturday that she had a tape depicting immoral acts with her children,'' said Downey police Detective Capt. Bob Williams. He refused to give other details of the case, saying, ``We don't want to hamper the investigation. We have a possibility of possibly three other victims.'' The two-hour tape shows Rafay discussing sex with a child, winning her cooperation and engaging in sexual acts with her, according to police. If convicted of all charges, Rafay faces up to 25 years in prison. The mother's identity wasn't revealed, but Shotwell said she lives with her daughter in the same building as Rafay. The prosecutor said there were no other suspects, but Williams said, ``We are looking at other people.'' In addition to the tape taken with the VCR, police seized nine other tapes from Rafay's apartment, Williams said. Shotwell said those tapes didn't reveal any crimes but one contains some evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Airlines Keep Flying But Schools Close as Alaska Volcano Erupts Again
DOC.TEXT: Redoubt Volcano erupted anew Thursday, sending a jet of ash and steam nearly seven miles high and scattering grit that led authorities to cancel classes for 2,000 students. The ``moderate to strong'' eruption, the first significant eruption since Jan. 15, began around 4 a.m. and was over in minutes. The ash cloud headed for the Gulf of Alaska, away from the more populated Cook Inlet area, said Tom Miller, a spokesman for the U.S. Geological Survey. The Federal Aviation Administration warned aircraft to stay at least 20 miles from the mountain, which is about 115 miles southeast of Anchorage. But Ken Burdette, manager of Anchorage International Airport, said no airline had canceled or diverted flights because of the ash, which can damage or shut down aircraft engines. ``Redoubt should not affect any carriers, international and domestic,'' Burdette said. ``The cloud's going away from the major airways that come and go into Anchorage.'' Classes were canceled for health reasons at more than a dozen schools from Nikiski southward on the Kenai Peninsula, which got a ``pretty good dumping'' of ash, said Dale Sandahl, superintendent of the Kenai Peninsula Borough School District. The mountain was quiet for 25 years until a series of eruptions began in mid-December, disrupting air travel in and out of Anchorage during the holidays. Ash clogged all four engines of a KLM Boeing 747 on Dec. 15, causing the aircraft to fall more than two miles before the engines could be restarted. Redoubt showed more earthquake activity a couple of days ago, leading seismologists to believe another eruption was coming, said John Davies, state seismologist. ``But not this soon,'' he said. More than two dozen workers were evacuated early Thursday from the Drift River oil terminal, a tank farm just a few miles from the mountain. ``We got them out just before the eruption,'' said Larry Duncanson, with Cook Inlet Pipe Line Co. which operates the storage terminal.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Reported Missing
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Robert Ouko was reported missing Thursday and the government media appealed to anyone with information about him to contact the police. Ouko, 68, was last seen Tuesday at his farm in Koru, 215 miles northwest of the capital, government radio and television said. The broadcasts quoted unidentified family members as saying Ouko had said Monday night he planned to travel to Nairobi the following day, but no one saw him leave. ``People are wondering how a full minister can disappear,'' a senior government official said. ``At the moment we have no idea what might have happened to him.'' Cabinet ministers in Kenya are routinely assigned official vehicles and drivers and their homes are always guarded by armed policemen. In a three-paragraph statement, the official Kenya News Agency urged Ouko to contact his family or the nearest police station. The government-owned radio and TV broadcast an appeal from the minister's family members urging Ouko either to contact them or government officials. President Daniel arap Moi first appointed Ouko foreign minister in 1979. Ouko served in other ministries before returning to the renamed ministry of foreign affairs and international cooperation in March last year.

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup Crews Contemplate Reducing Equipment in Oil Spill
With AM-Spill Response
DOC.TEXT: The last traces of oil from an eight-day-old tanker spill washed ashore Thursday, but the blackened coastline was still off limits to beachgoers and boaters. ``We don't want to paint too pretty of a picture,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Dennis Hall. ``We don't want to give the impression we'll open up all these areas. I can't really say it's done and over.'' The 400,000-gallon spill, which occurred Feb. 7 when the tanker American Trader apparently punctured itself on its own anchor, has soiled a 12- to 14-mile stretch of beach. Cleanup crews were focusing on the Huntington Beach and Newport Beach areas, where concentrations were thickest. Warning signs remained posted along the sand, and booms placed to guard against drifting oil continued to block entrances to the Long Beach Marina, Newport Harbor and Santa Ana River, Hall said. With only a light sheen of oil remaining offshore Thursday, experts considered reducing resources, said James L. O'Brien, clean-up coordinator for British Petroleum America Inc., which had leased the tanker. Equipment such as skimmers, which are useful only when oil is thickly concentrated offshore, might be released, O'Brien said. He said any such decisions would be made in consultation with local, state and federal agencies. O'Brien, owner of an oil spill cleanup firm, declined to estimate when work would be finished. ``This early in the game, it would be bad for me to even try to predict,'' he said. About 36 percent of the oil, some 144,600 gallons, was recovered through skimming, according to the Coast Guard. Forty-six percent, or 184,800 gallons, was estimated to have evaporated or dispersed in the ocean. A claims office was set up in Huntington Beach on Wednesday to field calls from fishermen, charter boat owners and others whose livelihoods have been disrupted by the spill. ``We've had the freshest fish for years ,'' said Mike Steven Long, a line baiter with Dory Fleet, a cooperative of 20 fishermen at Newport Beach. ``But now our reputation is ruined.'' Wildlife experts said the environmental impact would be short-lived. ``This is not an environmental disaster,'' said John Grant, a marine biologist with the state Department of Fish and Game. Two wetland areas populated by endangered species were protected from the oil.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Sentenced to Life for Torture Death of 4-Year-Old
DOC.TEXT: A man was sentenced to life in prison Thursday for the murder of his girlfriend's 4-year-old son, who was beaten, burned, stuck with pins and forced to hang upside down in a closet. The woman was sentenced to life for letting it happen. In sentencing Johnny Campbell and Alicia Abraham, Circuit Judge Michael B.
