Getty said if he had let emotions dictate his actions, the two would have received the death penalty for ``the vicious, brutally sadistic torture and murder of Lattie McGee.'' But he said he could not do so under Illinois law. The life sentences carry no possibility of parole. The couple also received 30-year sentences for the abuse of Lattie's brother, Cornelius. Lattie, described as a quiet boy with dark eyes, died in 1987 of a severe blow to the head, authorities said. In the last 2{ months of his life, Lattie was starved, burned with a hot iron, stuck with pins and needles, singed with cigarettes, beaten with a tree branch, hair brush, belt and hands, scalded with hot water, and tied up with a clothesline in the family's South Side apartment. Cornelius, now 8, testified that Campbell tied Lattie's wrists to his ankles and hung him upside down in the closet. Once, Cornelius said, his mother helped tie up Lattie. Cornelius, too, was tied up in the closet, once for two days, he said. He told about seeing Campbell throw a screaming Lattie into a bathtub of hot water, scrubbing the boy with a rag until his skin started peeling off. Campbell, a 40-year-old former steelworker, pleaded guilty but mentally ill in December. He said he beat the boys to curb what he thought was homosexual behavior. Ms. Abraham, 28, contended she never actively abused the children. Getty convicted her in a non-jury trial Jan. 11. Prosecutors had argued that death was the only just penalty for the defendants. But Getty said the evidence that Campbell is mentally ill and that Ms. Abraham had not participated directly in the death made them ineligible for the death penalty. Clyde Lemons Jr., Ms. Abraham's attorney, called the sentence unfair and said he would appeal. But Marijane Placek, Campbell's lawyer, praised the judge for sparing her client's life and added, ``If you kill a sick person, you never find out why they did it.'' Among the spectators was Lattie McGee Sr., the boys' father, who lived with Ms. Abraham several years ago and now has custody of Cornelius. ``I got justice today. I wish he did get the death penalty,'' said McGee.

DOC.HEAD: Peanut Price Supports Up
DOC.TEXT: Price supports for peanuts grown under 1990 quotas will be $631.47 per ton, an increase of $15.60 from last year, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Officials said the increase was mandated by law, which requires annual adjustments in the national support level for quota-type peanuts based on costs of production. As costs increase, so does the peanut support level. Production of non-quota peanuts, which can be grown for peanut oil and meal, and for export, will be supported at $149.75 per ton, unchanged from last year. The Bush administration has asked Congress to eliminate the escalator in the peanut support formula and put the program in line with other farm commodity supports.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Most Targeted Companies Have Reduced Use of Animals in Testing
DOC.TEXT: Most companies targeted by animal rights groups for their use of animal testing in consumer product research have significantly reduced their use of animals, according to a private study released Thursday. However, a leading animal rights group said it wants corporations to release internal information to back up the findings. ``I would challenge the companies to substantiate the claims that the numbers are down,'' said Susan Rich, special projects director for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, the nation's largest animal rights group. ``By looking at the figures of animal use in their in-house laboratories does not give us the true picture,'' Rich said. The report by the Investor Responsibility Research Center examines data submitted to the Agriculture Department by U.S. companies reporting animal use in fiscal years 1986, 1987 and 1988. It also offers in-depth profiles of animal testing from 1984-88 of nine companies that introduced shareholder resolutions on animal testing after being targeted by PETA. The study shows six of nine companies targeted by PETA cut animal testing by 42 percent from 1986-88. Two of the companies _ Avon and Greyhound _ say they no longer use animal testing for cosmetic and household product research, the report said. Other companies highlighted in the study were American Home Products, Bristol-Myers Products, Colgate-Palmolive, Gillette, Johnson & Johnson, Proctor & Gamble and Schering-Plough, which produces Maybelline cosmetics. Only American Home Products showed no reduction in animal testing during the period. Bristol-Myers had an increase from 597 to 743 tests between 1987 and 1988 after an earlier decline. The study said Gillette closed its in-house laboratory in March 1987 and declined to reveal how many animals have been used in testing by contracted outside labs in 1988. Figures for 1988 also were unavailable for Schering-Plough. ``We have not increased the number of animals just to increase the animals,'' said Carol Emerling, spokeswoman for American Home Products. ``The kinds of drugs and number of drugs that we're testing dictates the amount of testing that we do.'' She said most of the company's testing is for pharmaceutical products where she said elimination of animal testing is not likely. The study said companies are turning to non-animal methods of testing. Heidi Welsh, author of the IRRC study, said USDA reporting requirements don't cover ``rats and mice _ an estimated 80 to 90 percent of all animal use _ and do not include animals uses at contract laboratories.'' Consumer product testing studied by IRRC included toxicity testing of non-medical-related cosmetic and household products such as soaps and eyeshadow. Over-the-counter and prescription drug testing was not included. Cosmetic and household testing account for ``less than 10 percent of the estimated 20-70 million laboratory animals'' used annually in the United States, Welsh said. In a related matter, PETA on Thursday filed a $3 million lawsuit against writer Katie McCabe for an article on animal testing in the February issue of ``Washingtonian'' magazine. The organization alleged that the story showed ``malicious intent'' to damage its reputation. ``In 25 years of publication, we've never lost a suit for anything we've published,'' said Washingtonian editor Jack Limpert. ``We're confident and we'll fight ... and win.'' IRRC is a non-profit corporation established in 1972 to do independent research for institutional investors interested in proxy voting.

DOC.HEAD: Withdrawal Of Soviet Troops To Start Next Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Feb. 26 date set. Picks up 9th, `Magyar Nemzet ...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Czech-Secret Police Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Red Army will start leaving Czechoslovakia on Feb. 26 and an agreement on complete Soviet withdrawal from Hungary may come within a month, officials said Thursday. Gen. Anton Slimak, Czechoslovak chief of staff, said the Soviet withdrawal would begin next week in Bruntal, 160 miles east of Prague, the official news agency CTK reported. Later, however, CTK said Soviet and Czechoslovak delegations meeting in Prague agreed the withdrawal would begin Feb. 26, the day President Vaclav Havel starts his first visit to Moscow. Czechoslovakia had sought total withdrawal by the end of this year, but Slimak said that would not happen. Moscow wants until the end of 1991, and sources in Prague said earlier this week June 1991 was a likely compromise. No final date was agreed at Thursday's talks in Prague, but talks will continue ``in the nearest future'' to nail that down, CTK said. In Budapest, a senior Hungarian official was quoted as predicting agreement within a month on ending decades of Soviet military presence. Soviet soldiers arrived in Hungary to suppress the 1956 anti-Stalinist uprising and in Czechoslovakia to crush the ``Prague Spring'' political liberalization of 1968. With their first free elections in more than 40 years nearing, Hungary and Czechoslovakia are on the threshold of full democracy and see removal of Soviet forces as a symbolic affirmation of independence. Havel hinted Tuesday that a personal letter he received from Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev might help resolve the question of how soon all 73,500 Red Army soldiers would be out of Czechoslovakia. Talks on the withdrawal began in Prague in January. Foreign Ministry spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky told journalists Tuesday a deadline agreement could be reached by Sunday, which means Havel could sign it when he goes to Moscow after a visit to Washington. Magyar Nemzet, a Hungarian daily, quoted Foreign Ministry official Ferenc Somogyi as saying Hungary could ``count on working out the agreement within a month.'' Czechoslovakia has insisted the Soviets withdraw whatever the results of East-West talks in Vienna on reducing conventional forces in Europe, but Hungary has not. Officials on both sides appear confident of a Vienna agreement this year, now that the Soviets have accepted President Bush's proposal to reduce the number of U.S. and Soviet soldiers in Central Europe to 195,000 for each side. Hungary wants all 50,000 Soviet soldiers off its territory by early 1991, but Somogyi said compromise was possible because of Kremlin concerns about transportation and providing facilities for the returning soldiers. ``We have to take into account our negotiating partner's position,'' he was quoted as saying. Slimak said withdrawal from Czechoslovakia could not be completed by the end of 1990 for technical and social reasons. Both governments have mentioned the bottleneck likely to be created by withdrawing large numbers of soldiers from neighboring countries simultaneously through one Soviet border point, where trains would have to be changed because of different track widths. Soviet officials also cite a lack of housing for most of the 16,000 families of Soviet soldiers and civil workers based in Czechoslovakia, Slimak said. A preliminary agreement indicates about 35 percent of the soldiers will be withdrawn by the end of May, along with 40 percent of the tanks, 30 percent of other combat vehicles and nearly one-third of helicopters and artillery, he said. Czechoslovakia has asked that a substantial part of the Soviet forces be out before elections scheduled for June.

DOC.HEAD: Trump vs. Trump: And the Winner Is?
DOC.TEXT: ``The Donald'' wasn't talking, though the press tried to catch him walking. And Thomas ``Hit Man'' Hearns made a prediction Thursday you can take to the bank: a Trump will win in Trump vs. Trump. Donald Trump experienced the same media crush his wife, Ivana, was treated to on Wednesday when a pack of reporters and TV cameras dogged her outside a fancy restaurant. Like Ivana, Trump said nothing. Surrounded by beefy, serious-looking security men, the developer-casino operator-airline owner was kept at arms length from the press before and after a news conference at his Plaza Hotel. The topic was the April 28 Hearns vs. Michael Olajide fight at Trump's new ``$1 billion baby,'' the Trump Taj Mahal in Atlantic City, N.J., but it was obvious more than a few of those on hand were boxing neophytes. Trump referred to the unusually large number of reporters, telling Hearns, ``It's a great turnout for you, Tommy.'' The dapper megabuilder said nothing specific about the breakup of his 13-year marriage, though innuendos flew. Hearns' manager, Emanuel Steward, referred to Trump as ``The Donald,'' Ivana's pet name for her husband, saying: ``I want to thank `The Donald' for getting the crowd out for us today.'' But the most profound statement came from Hearns, who was asked who he thought would win in Trump vs. Trump, a battle with Trump's estimated $1.7 billion fortune at stake. ``A Trump is gonna win somewhere,'' he said. Trump, 43, moved out of his penthouse apartment Sunday amid reports he was involved with 26-year-old actress-model Marla Maples, whom a source said he met at the church where the Trumps were wed. Ms. Maples has not commented on the Trump split. but her agent, Chuck Jones, denies she's involved. Maples' father, Stan Maples of Cohutta, Ga., said Thursday that his daughter won't be hurt by all the publicity. ``This is not a big staging to boost her career,'' he also told the Atlanta Journal, refusing to confirm or deny that his daughter is involved with Trump. Rumors also have circulated that Trump was involved with skater Peggy Fleming, but she angrily denied those reports. Fleming, 41, convened a news conference Wednesday in Los Gatos, Calif., the suburb where she lives with her husband and two children. ``I've been around Donald Trump four times in my life,'' she said. ``We had a business relationship. I wouldn't even call him a good friend.'' A prenuptial agreement calls for Ivana to receive $25 million, custody of the couple's three children and the mansion in Connecticut. But Mrs. Trump wants more. New York Newsday quoted Trump associates as saying Trump planned to up the ante to $100 million. That report was flatly denied by Trump's lawyers, Jay Goldberg and Stanford Lotwin, who added in a statement that the pre-nuptial is ``ironclad.'' Mrs. Trump's spokesman, John Scanlon, was out of the office and could not immediately be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Awakes _ On Wrong Side of Plane Bed?
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts new 7th graf to further focus on reasons behind Bush's statements about press coverage.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush complained testily Thursday about news accounts which he said portrayed him as deceptive, declaring he would hold fewer news conferences and initiate a ``new approach'' toward reporters. ``From now on, it's going to be a little different. ... So we've got a new relationship,'' Bush told reporters traveling with him aboard Air Force One to the four-nation Colombia drug summit. ``It will be pleasant. It will be fun. But it's different,'' said the president, who has averaged one question and answer session with reporters each week since taking office 13 months ago. Later, Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said the president was ``just kidding'' in asserting that he would have fewer news conferences and in declining comment on a series of questions. ``He was having fun,'' Fitzwater said. The president, who apparently read a wire service account of his testy mood on the plane, protested to reporters later: ``I'm not fuming.'' Bush's pique apparently was triggered by an ABC-TV report Wednesday night recapping instances in which Bush's words were belied by subsequent events. The president was criticized on the same score in a Feb. 26 article in The New Republic entitled, ``The Deceiving Line.'' Most recently Bush told a news conference on Monday that it wasn't time yet for a conference among the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France on the future status of Germany. ``Not at this juncture,'' he told the news conference. Yet, the next day, a major agreement was announced in Ottawa by Secretary of State James A. Baker III on a German reunification push that would include a summit among the four powers that vanquished Germany in World War II. ``When I told you ... that I didn't think there'd be a deal and there shortly was a deal, then I'm hit for deceiving you,'' Bush groused Thursday. Bush, a onetime CIA director, has conducted much of his foreign policy in secrecy. Two missions to China by national security adviser Brent Scowcroft came despite a Bush announcement in the aftermath of the Tiananmen Square crackdown that he was barring high-level exchanges between the two countries. The president later insisted that Scowcroft's trips to Beijing were ``visits'' and not ``exchanges,'' and thus not covered by the Bush edict. Bush, who usually maintains a bantering relationship with reporters, said, ``I think we've had too many press conferences. It overdoes it. It's overexposure.'' By answering few questions directly, he said, ``I'm not going to be burned for holding out or doing something deceptive.'' The president, who slept the night before on Air Force One so he would be well-rested for Thursday's pre-dawn flight here, even gave a prickly response when asked if he had gotten a good night's sleep. ``I had a very good night's sleep. I can't get into the details of that because some will say it's too much sleep, some will say it's too little. ...,'' he said. Bush parried a series of questions from reporters, most of them dealing with the drug summit. ``I'm not going to discuss what I'm going to bring up,'' Bush said when asked about his agenda for the day's conference in Cartagena with the presidents of Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. ``I'm not going to discuss whether there's any surprises or not. This is a new thing. This is a new approach.'' He then said his non-answers were ``a trial run'' for later dealings with the media. In fact, Bush, who answers reporters questions about once a week, planned to finish his day in Colombia with yet another news conference. Bush's comments with reporters came shortly before his jet touched down here, where a U.S. press center was set up at the airport. Bush flew by helicopter the 60 miles to Cartagena and was returning here before flying home to Washington. Asked about an NBC-TV report that Colombian President Virgilio Barco had made a deal with some drug lords in his country not to extradite them to the United States if they turned over drug labs, Bush snapped: ``I have no comment whatsoever on that. I have no comment on whether I know about it or not. I can't comment on whether it's true or not.'' Bush did not mention which particular news reports had irked him the most. However, Thursday's editions of the Washington Post had a story on what it called ``the debate between President Bush and the press over secrecy and deception.'' And ABC-TV had a news report on Wednesday night by White House correspondent Brit Hume on the same subject. Hume was one of several reporters invited to a recent off the record lunch at the White House with Bush, at which the subject reportedly came up. News accounts said that Bush told the reporters at the lunch that he had undertaken no further secret diplomatic missions _ like Scowcroft's clandestine visits to China. Then, the next day, it was disclosed that Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger had gone on a secret mission to London to notify U.S. allies of Bush's latest plan to reduce troops in Europe. Bush also gave what some have seen as misleading comments on his surprise seaside summit at Malta in December with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The president in September had said that there were no plans for a superpower summit before 1990, but he later revealed that the session had been arranged as early as last July.

DOC.HEAD: Defense in Murder Case Won't Dispute Defendant's Identity
DOC.TEXT: A defense attorney has acknowledged for the first time that his client, arrested seven months ago, is John List, the subject of a worldwide manhunt after the 1971 slayings of five members of his family. A prosecutor said Thursday that will make no difference in the case against List, who was arrested on a tip after an ``America's Wanted'' TV broadcast that included a plaster bust of how he might look 17 years after the slayings. ``We've got to prove the identity anyway,'' said Assistant Prosecutor Brian D. Gillet. List is charged with murder in the 1971 slayings of his mother, wife and three children in their 19-room Westfield home. He was arrested in June in suburban Richmond, Va., but told authorities he was Robert P. Clark. His second wife, Delores, said her husband was a victim of mistaken identity. But investigators identified List through fingerprints from his Army record. List's attorney, Elijah Miller Jr., said at a hearing Wednesday that the defendant's identity was not at issue. ``The only thing we said before was that they (the state) had to prove it was John List,'' said Miller. ``Now they don't have to prove it.'' The FBI and prosecutors maintain that List assumed a new identity after the slayings, working as an accountant in Colorado and Virginia. He remarried in 1983 and was known to neighbors as a quiet, church-going man. The defense is seeking to keep prosecutors from using as evidence a five-page letter in which List is alleged to have confessed to his church pastor that he killed his family because they were veering away from God. Miller contends the letter should not be allowed into evidence because of the confidentiality that exists ``between priest and penitent.'' Jury selection begins March 20.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Says Many Hospitals Lack Policy for AIDS Testing of Patients
DOC.TEXT: Preliminary results of a survey show that many hospitals fail to protect patients' rights when trying to determine whether patients are infected with the AIDS virus, researchers said Thursday. ``If you are about to be admitted to a hospital, ask your doctor what he intends to do with the blood he draws, and if he plans to test for AIDS, what he intends to do with the results,'' said Dr. Charles E. Lewis, who analyzed the results of the survey. Lewis, a professor of medicine, public health and nursing at the University of California School of Medicine in Los Angeles, said around 17 percent of hospitals don't have policies to protect patients' rights on the AIDS issue, and of those that do, ``a distressing proportion'' are inadequate. Lewis declined to say how many are inadquate or discuss some other aspects of the study because his analysis of the data has not been published. He and one of his co-workers on the survey, Howard E. Freeman, who has a doctorate in sociology and is a professor at UCLA, discussed some of their preliminary results at an AIDS conference. The survey of 716 hospitals, about 14 percent of the nation's non-federal, short-term general hospitals, was conducted between January and August of last year by Louis Harris & Associates of New York. Lewis said about half the hospital administrators surveyed were unaware of the guidelines put out by the federal Centers for Disease Control, which recommend that hospitals establish policies. The CDC guidelines also recommend that if hospitals test patients for HIV, they first get their consent. Freeman said the survey found that about 15 percent of hospitals do not always inform patients they will be tested for the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS, and a third do not always counsel a patient about the disease before they are tested. About 4 percent of the hospitals surveyed don't always inform patients of HIV test results, and two-thirds of the facilities put the results in the patient's file, he said. In addition, about a quarter of the hospitals said they sometimes or always transfer to another hospital patients identified as being HIV positive, he said. Some hospitals say the reason for transfer is that they are not familiar with HIV and AIDS treatment procedures, and other say they are concerned about transmission of the virus to hospital workers. Freeman said that while precautions must be taken to guard against hospital workers becoming infected through contact with an infected patient's blood, the chances of transmission are small. ``It has more to do with ... fright and fear of the virus,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms, Snow, Freezing Rain And Unusual Temperatures
DOC.TEXT: Rain, snow and freezing rain fell over much of the nation Thursday, snarling traffic and weighing down power lines, and temperatures hit record lows in the West and record highs in the Deep South. Freezing rain over the central section of the Texas Panhandle changed to snow over western sections of the Panhandle, and snow extended across northeastern New Mexico, eastern Colorado, eastern Wyoming, western Kansas, Nebraska, South Dakota and North Dakota, the National Weather Service said. Snow was scattered over eastern Idaho, and reached from northern Idaho and the Idaho Panhandle to the Washington and Oregon coasts. Snow changed to rain at lower elevations along the northern Pacific Coast. Freezing rain, ice and a mixture of rain with snow extended from southern New England to northern New Jersey, northeastern Pennsylvania, southern and central New York state, southern Lower Michigan, northern Indiana, southern Iowa, northern Missouri and northeastern Kansas. Winter weather watches extending into Friday were posted for northern Maine, Upper Michigan, the northwestern half of Wisconsin, northeastern Minnesota, much of Nevada, and the Sierra Nevada and northeastern plateau of California. A warning of an overnight hard freeze was posted for the deserts of southwestern and south-central Arizona. At midday, showers and thunderstorms extended from eastern Louisiana to Mississippi, the northwestern half of Alabama, eastern Tennessee and Kentucky. A tornado touched down east of Mere, La., damaging a mobile home and slightly injuring three people. In Mississippi, hail about the size of nickels fell west of Newton, half-inch diameter hail fell at Union and thunderstorm gusts causes damage near Union, the weather service said. Showers reached across northern West Virginia, northern Maryland, southern New Jersey, much of Pennsylvania, Ohio, much of Indiana, southern Illinois, much of Missouri, northern and central Arkansas, southeastern Oklahoma and north-central Texas. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to noon CST included 2.18 inches at Jonesboro, Ark.; 1.8 inches at Meridian, Miss.; 1.69 inches at Dyersburg, Tenn.; 1.43 inches at Fort Knox, Ky.; and 1.15 inches at Louisville, Ky. Temperatures dropped to record lows Thursday in northern California: 25 degrees at Bakersfield, 24 at Fresno, 32 at Moffett, 29 at Sacramento airport, 30 at downtown Sacramento, 36 at San Francisco, and 23 at Santa Maria. The previous record of 31 at downtown Sacramento had been on the books since 1883. But the Gulf Coast basked in record heat, with 90 degrees at Brownsville, Texas; 85 at San Antonio, Texas; and 83 at Shreveport, La. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 2 below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont., to 93 at McAllen, Texas. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 34 below zero at West Yellowstone.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Prompts Bulgaria to Halt Nuclear Plant Construction
DOC.TEXT: The Communist government on Thursday ordered a halt to the construction on a nuclear power plant on the Danube River after nearby residents staged a general strike. Also Thursday, Premier Andrei Lukanov met a delegation representing 23,000 workers at Sofia's giant Kremikovtsi steel plant who are threatening to walk off the job Monday in demand of higher pay and better working conditions. The government news agency BTA said Lukanov planned to continue the talks Friday at the plant, whose red smoke wafts across the capital daily. The government ordered construction halted on the country's planned second nuclear plant at Belene on the Danube, which is on Bulgaria's northern border with Romania. The decision came after reports that Svishtov, a town 18 miles east of Belene, was paralyzed by a general strike Thursday in protest of a parliamentary decision to continue building the plant. Public protest has flared over Belene because it is in an area believed susceptible to earthquakes. A parliamentary commission traveled to Svischtov, 125 miles northeast of Sofia, to try to calm public fears, government-run media said. The new openness in Bulgaria's media, since hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov was forced from power in November, has produced a series of articles about mishaps at the country's currently operating but trouble-plagued nuclear plant at Kozloduy. The plant, 75 miles north of Sofia, also lies on the Danube. Construction work on Belene, which like Kozloduy is based on a Soviet design, has just begun. About 9,000 people work at the site.
