DOC.HEAD: Chicagoans Brave February Blizzard-Like Conditions
With AM-Storm Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chicagoans danced a winter ballet Thursday amid inhospitable weather that made the hardiest Midwesterners leap to avoid slush puddles, shuffle to keep from slipping on ice and dive to escape bus splashes. ``This is treacherous,'' John Peeples said as he failed in a daring attempt to jump a slush puddle. ``I feel like I'm maneuvering through an obstacle course.'' Chicagoans, like residents of other parts of the Midwest, spent much of their day digging out from up to 10 inches of snow that began falling on Valentine's Day. The storm stranded many commuters, knocked down power lines and briefly closed both major city airports. Rain started falling Thursday afternoon. ``There's cold. There's snow. There's rain. And here's where I'm going to stay today,'' said John Renier, pointing to his home in the city's Lincoln Park neighborhood. Renier, a native of Arkansas, said this was his first winter in Chicago in which snow forced him to shovel out his walk and his car, both buried under a mountain of snow. ``I was really looking forward to the first time I would have to shovel this,'' he said as a fine rain fell. ``I can see I haven't missed much.'' Farther down the block, University of Chicago law student Ken Simpler frustrated many neighbors struggling to dig their cars out of the snow when he jumped into his four-wheel-drive vehicle and pulled right out. ``This thing is good two seasons of the year _ one, when it snows like this, and then in the summer when I can take the top off and enjoy myself,'' he said. The storm ended an unusually balmy six-week period, when temperatures rose above freezing almost daily, occasionally climbing into the 60s. Restaurant owners in the city and suburbs lamented the foul weather that sent potential customers scurrying for the comforts of home. ``It was more like the Valentine's Day Massacre,'' said Denise Ellis, coordinator of the dining room at Kendall College culinary school and restaurant in north suburban Evanston. ``It's normally one of our busiest days of the year and we had only 17 couples all night,'' Ms. Ellis said in a telephone interview. ``And I think we got lucky because we're near people's homes. I'm sure the downtown (Chicago) restaurants did even worse.'' Hardier Midwesterners, however, claimed the storm was just a drop in the bucket compared to other bad weather. ``Now, the snowstorm in '67, that was something!'' said Josephine Woods of Rogers Park as she stood on an elevated train platform lecturing other morning commuters on the proper way to dress in such conditions. ``There's nothing nobody can do about the snow, but you've got to try to wear enough clothes to keep you warm,'' said Ms. Woods, who pointed to the two jackets she wore on top of a full-length ski suit and thermal underwear. Bill Lederer of Lincoln Park took the day off from work to enjoy a little cross-country skiing after spending seven hours trying to get home from work the previous evening. ``It's normally an hour drive,'' Lederer said, miniature icicles hanging from his cap. ``But I don't think this is so bad. ``It relieves the monotony of winter and gives everybody something to talk about.''

DOC.HEAD: Getting Bolivian Farmers to Switch from Coca No Easy Task
With AM-Drug Summit, Bjt
LaserPhotos CART19,22
DOC.TEXT: Presidents at the drug summit on Thursday called anew for Latin American farmers who grow coca to switch to other crops. But Bolivian authorities have tried that for years and found it a tough row to hoe. It has been only recently that the program here showed signs of progress. President Jaime Paz Zamora, who attended the meeting in Cartagena, Colombia, says ``coca leaf must be reduced in exchange for development.'' ``It is not just a question of substituting one hectare of coca for oranges or coffee, but the development of the country because coca is an integral part of the economy. ``It means transforming Bolivia economically so that it will no longer depend on coca-leaf farming and cocaine production for a large share of its export earnings.'' A hectare is slightly less than 2{ acres. Coca leaf is the raw material that becomes cocaine after processing. In their communique on the war-on-drugs, presidents Bush, Paz, Virgilio Barco of Colombia and Alan Garcia of Peru noted that persuading Andean farmers to turn from coca production to legal crops would have ``significant, immediate and long-term economic costs'' on Colombia, Peru and Bolivia. It said Bush pledged to request an economic aid package from Congress for fiscal 1991 to 1994 to help offset these losses. Bolivian farmers have begun in recent months to eradicate significant numbers of coca plants, but only after increased drug enforcement programs in Colombia and Bolivia led to a sharp drop in coca-leaf prices. The United States believes the two policies must go hand-in-hand: urging farmers to grow substitute crops, and cracking down on the illegal drug trade itself. The Chapare is a tropical region in the heart of Bolivia that produces an estimated one-third of the leaf used to make cocaine. Past efforts to eradicate coca plants there failed. Farmers were unwilling to switch to other crops that were not profitable and for which markets did not exist. Before Colombia began its drug crackdown last August, farmers destroyed an average of 200 hectares _ 494 acres _ of coca a month under the Bolivian crop substitution program. But the overall area devoted to coca cultivation increased from 34,135 hectares in 1988 to 38,250 hectares in 1989, U.S. government figures indicate. Farmers harvested four crops of coca leaf a year and had no problem marketing their leaves to coca paste producers. Coca paste is flown from the Chapare to northern Bolivia, Colombia or Brazil where it is processed into cocaine base, which becomes refined into pure cocaine. Following the crackdown in Colombia, however, and an intense cocaine interdiction program in Bolivia, farmers have been unable to sell their leaves to paste producers and traffickers. As a result, coca-leaf prices have fallen and farmers are flocking in increasing numbers to government agencies to sign up for crop substitution programs. In December and January farmers destroyed 1,266 hectares of coca in exchange for $2,000 for every hectare destroyed. In early February, 100 pounds of coca leaf was selling for $5 to $8 while the cost of production is estimated at $30. The U.S. ambassador to Bolivia, Robert S. Gelbard, told The Associated Press on Thursday: ``The fact that the voluntary eradication program has begun to show significant progress in the last two months proves that interdiction, eradication and alternative development programs are three interdependent parts of an integrated strategy and must be pursued simultaneously and with equal strength.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Brief news conference has ended; president is departing Colombia.
DOC.HEAD: BARRANQUILLA, Colombia: drug traffickers.
DOC.TEXT: The president said the United States will provide $2.2 billion worth of aid over a five year period to help underwrite the drug war and to promote crop substitution in the Andean coca growing nations. At his airport news conference, Bush said he had told the other leaders that the United States is making headway in dealing with drug demand at home. He said ``I'm not satisfied with it,'' but the situation is improving. The president said he will work with the Latin American coca-producing countries to encourage other crops. ``These economies are hurting because of the kind of export problems they are encountering,'' he said. But he said trade problems are not one-sided, that they involve the United States as an importing nation, too. Bush said none of that should be an excuse for growing the illegal crop behind cocaine. Bush's security against the possibility of terrorist attack by the drug cartel had overshadowed the drug meeting in the days before it was held; the president said he'd had full confidence in his safety all along. At his final appearance in Colombia, Bush said he wasn't surprised that the journey and the meeting had been secure and without incident.

DOC.HEAD: Argentina, Britain Agree to Renew Diplomatic Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes, more terms of agreement, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Argentina and Britain agreed Thursday to restore full diplomatic relations nearly eight years after they fought a 74-day war over the Falkland Islands. After two days of talks in Madrid, the announcement was read in Spanish by Lucio del Solar, ambassador at large for Argentina, and in English by Sir Crispin Tickell, British ambassador to the United Nations. Britain agreed to lift a 150-mile military protection zone it has enforced around the South Atlantic islands since a task force sent by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher defeated Argentine invaders in June 1982. New security arrangements for the archipelago 300 miles off Argentina's southeast coast, which are home to about 1,900 people and thousands of sheep, are to involve advance notice by both sides of military maneuvers in the area. The presence of an estimated 2,000 British soldiers at Mount Pleasant outside Port Stanley, the Falklands capital, was not mentioned in Thursday's agreement, although Argentina had previously called for a reduction. Argentina and Britain also agreed to consult on relations between the European Economic Community and Latin America, and to establish a Working Group on South Atlantic Affairs. In London, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said of the agreement: ``It underlines the fact that we have no quarrel with Argentina, and this has been achieved without any sacrifice of sovereignty. So it's a very good agreement and I hope it's a turning point and will lead to a new relationship.'' President Carlos Menem of Argentina told reporters in Buenos Aires: ``Everything is resolved. Aside from having eliminated _ definitively, I believe _ the possibilities of an armed conflict, it opens wide possibilities for us in the ... European Economic Community.'' Javier Perez de Cuellar, the U.N. secretary-general, declared: ``I very much welcome the decision by both governments to re-establish diplomatic relations. This immediately creates an atmosphere of confidence.'' The battle for the South Atlantic islands, which Argentina calls the Malvinas, cost the lives of 712 Argentines, 255 Britons and three islanders. Dissatisfaction over the war, which Argentina's military government claimed to be winning until shortly before the surrender, contributed to the end in 1983 of nearly eight years of military rule. Thursday's agreement stiplulated that talks would continue on fishing rights and that the International Red Cross would arrange visits by Argentines to war cemeteries in the Falklands. Garcia del Solar called the accord ``very satisfactory,'' and Tickell said the decision to end the military zone by the end of March ``set a new base for relations between our two countries.'' ``There is no secret understanding, no confidential memorandum,'' he said. ``It's all here.'' A breakthrough in October provide for renewed consular ties, resumption of air and maritime links and moves toward lifting all trade restrictions. By mutual consent, the latest talks did not touch on sovereignty claims. Britain says it colonized the islands in 1766 when John MacBride founded Port Egmont. Spain gained control but permitted the British to remain until 1774, then abandoned the islands when it ceased to govern Argentina in 1810. Argentina traces its claim in the Treaty of Tordesillas, which assigned New World territories to Spain and Portugal in 1494. It says the British occupied the islands by force in 1833 when Capt. John Onslow expelled the Argentine population.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds Doubts About Social Security Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Nearly half of working American adults do not believe Social Security will be able to pay them benefits when they retire, according to a survey released Thursday by a private research institute. The December survey of 1,001 adults found that 49 percent of those who had not yet retired were confident Social Security would be able to pay them benefits, 47 percent did not expect to get benefits and 4 percent were unsure. The survey, conducted by The Gallup Organization, was commissioned and released by the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a non-profit, non-partisan research group. The institute's president, Dallas Salisbury, said the results indicate people are ``unrealistically pessimistic'' about the Social Security system, and that they have not been well educated about how it works. Salisbury said confidence in Social Security could drop further as public debate continues on a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut Social Security taxes to keep the government from using Social Security revenue for general government operations. The debate ``is bringing into question the ability of the system to pay future benefits,'' Salisbury said. President Bush has criticized the Moynihan proposal and claims that it could jeopardize benefits for future retirees. The survey found that confidence in Social Security benefits was highest among those who were closest to retirement, with 76 percent of those aged 55 and older expecting to receive benefits compared with 46 percent of those aged 18-34. In other results, 50 percent of those who had not yet retired planned to retire by age 62, and 11 percent said they planned to retire by age 50. Just 29 percent were aware that the age at which full retirement benefits are paid gradually will rise from 65 to 67 beginning in the year 2000. The survey also found that 53 percent of those who had not yet retired planned to continue working after they begin collecting Social Security benefits. However, 18 percent of those people changed their minds after being advised that Social Security benefits are reduced for workers whose earnings exceed a specific threshold, $9,360 in 1990. The survey had a margin of uncertainty of about three percentage points either way.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Stock Rebounds as Recall Picks up Speed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for UNDATED AM-Perrier on News Advisory. A version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.TEXT: Store owners in Israel, Australia and Switzerland pulled bottles of Perrier sparkling water from the shelves Thursday as a general worldwide recall got under way. But beverage industry analysts remained divided about whether the tony brand in the distinctive green bottle will ever recover its prestige. The recall affects 160 million bottles of the water in 120 countries and could cost the company up to 200 million francs, or $35 million, officials said. Perrier President Gustave Leven announced the worldwide recall Wednesday after traces of the cancer-causing chemical benzene were found in recent weeks in some bottles shipped to the United States, Canada, West Germany, Denmark and the Netherlands. Premier Michel Rocard saluted Perrier's move to withdraw some 160 million bottles of its water from sale as ``a courageous decision.'' Marketing and beverage experts in the United States disagreed on whether the brand will be able to recover. ``The answer is a qualified `Yes,''' said Neil Berlant, managing partner of Water Research Associates, a Los Angeles-based merchant banking firm specializing in investment in the water industry. The qualification, he said, was that ``they don't determine that the problem is indeed with the spring.'' Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark Inc., a management consulting company based in Los Angeles, said the company's altered explanation of what caused the contamination of some of its bottles hurt chances for recovery. Company officials initially attributed the contamination with benzene to cleaning equipment that had been cleaned improperly, but later in the week said it resulted from a dirty filter that was designed to remove benzene. ``We do a lot of work in the water business, and I don't know of any single source with benzene in it,'' Pirko said. ``I think Perrier has seen its day.'' Jesse Meyers, who publishes the newsletter Beverage Digest in Greenwich, Conn., said that barring any new negative surprises in the recall story, the brand could come back stronger than ever. ``I think Perrier has done as much as any company could in eliminating the problem,'' Meyers said. In another development, the investigative Commission des Operations de Bourse announced that analysis of heavy options trading volume in the company's shares last Friday turned up no evidence of insider trading. Perrier bottles had been pulled from the shelves in the United States, Canada, West Germany, Denmark and the Netherlands before Wednesday's general recall. Bottles were also withdrawn in Japan as a precautionary measure. On Thursday, thousands of bottles were taken off the shelves in Switzerland and Israel when health officials in those countries said traces of benzene had been found in test samples. The water's Australian distributor, Coca-Cola Amatil, withdrew a further 960,000 bottles to comply with the recall, though tests for benzene had not been completed. Benzene, a chemical used in cleaning solvents, turned up in tests on Perrier water run by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration early this month and prompted a weekend recall of 72 million bottles. Managing Director Frederik Zimmer of Perrier said Wednesday that benzene entered the bottled water due to a dirty pipe filter at the underground spring at Vergeze in southern France. The company separates the water from natural carbon dioxide gas in the spring and both are piped separately to the bottling plant, where the gas is reinjected into the water, Zimmer said. A filter on the gas line that cleans the carbon dioxide of small amounts of naturally occurring benzene was not changed for several months, Zimmer said, allowing traces of benzene to slip through. The filter should be replaced every six weeks, Zimmer said, blaming negligence by workers. Zimmer said investigators found the filter was the cause of the benzene traces on Sunday. Other company officials had said Monday that contamination occurred when a worker used benzene solvents to degrease equipment. Zimmer said that was false. The company waited three days to notify the public of how the benzene entered the bottled water because it wished to run further tests and be sure of its evidence, Zimmer said. Perrier has advised distributors to dispose of the water on site and return the bottles to France, where they will be cleaned, refilled with fresh water, dated and exported. The company hopes to be back to normal on the global market in 2{ months.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor Barry Indicted on 5 Drug Charges, 3 Perjury Counts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material top 14 grafs with Barry quotes; arraignment within 10 days; penalties
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry was indicted Thursday on eight charges of possessing crack cocaine and lying repeatedly to a federal grand jury questioning him about drug use. ``I know that when a trial is held I will be exonerated,'' Barry declared. Barry was undergoing treatment at a Florida substance abuse clinic when the grand jury returned the indictment to a federal magistrate. He enrolled in the clinic after his arrest last month in what authorities say was a videotaped hotel drug sting. He said in a statement that the indictment ``represents a continuation of the political lynching and excesses that the Justice Department in this multi-year, multi-million dollar effort to investigate me and the Barry administration. Barry said he had no plans to resign. His lawyer, R. Kenneth Mundy, said Barry would return from Florida for arraignment within 10 days and plead innocent. Mundy said the charges ``aren't as devastating, as harsh as I expected them to be'' but that a felony conviction would be ``disastrous'' for the mayor. In the face of rumors that have dogged him the past several years, Barry steadfastly denied ever using drugs. In his statement Thursday, Barry said he was undergoing treatment for ``the disease of alcoholism.'' Only one of the charges filed Thursday stems from the videotaped hotel room encounter between Barry and Rasheeda Moore, a one-time Barry girlfriend who is cooperating with investigators. The other charges result from his association with Charles Lewis, who has pleaded guilty to drug conspiracy charges. The 14-month investigation has focused on Barry's ties to Lewis. Barry has told top political aides he would abandon his hopes for a fourth term, but sources close to the mayor have said he would refrain from making any quick public statement about his political future any time soon. The mayor has turned the day-to-day operations of the District of Columbia government over to a top deputy. The felony perjury counts all stem from questions a grand jury asked him about visits to Lewis' Washington hotel room in December 1988; four of the five misdemeanor possession charges result from the same investigation. The fifth possession count represents the formal lodging of a charge in connection with his Jan. 18 cocaine possession arrest. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said of the perjury charges, ``Mr. Barry falsely testified ... that he was unaware of any narcotics activity by Mr. Charles Lewis, when he stated that Mr. Lewis had never given him, Mr. Barry, any narcotics, and when he stated that he, Mr. Barry, had never given any narcotics to Mr. Lewis.'' Stephens would not take questionsafter reading a brief statement to reporters. Each of the three false declaration charges carries a five-year maximum prison term and a maximum fine of $250,000. Each possesion charge carries a maximum sentence of one year in a jail and a fine of $100,000. If convicted of a felony, the 53-year-old mayor would be required to resign, with city council chairman David Clarke becoming acting mayor. A special election would be held within 120 days of any resignation, unless that date fell within 60 days of the regularly scheduled Nov. 6 general election. Clarke, one of four announced Democratic candidates vying for Barry's job, described the legal developments as ``a tragedy for Marion and for the city.'' Jesse Jackson also has been considered a possible candidate for the post but has said he will not run against Barry. Since his arrest, Barry's political support in the city has dwindled and several supporters have urged him not to seek another term. There also have been calls for his resignation. Council member Betty Ann Kane said the grand jury indictment ``certainly undermines all the excuses being made that this was some sort of plot by the U.S. attorney to get the mayor,'' and she said Barry's resignation ``might be in his best interests and the city's best interests.'' Stephens has said the investigation of Barry began in December 1988 after city police aborted an attempt to make an undercover drug purchase from Lewis, a longtime friend of the mayor, after learning Barry was in Lewis' room. Lewis, who pleaded guilty to two cocaine conspiracy charges last November, testified that he supplied Barry with crack cocaine. He agreed to cooperate with the probe when prosecutors offered to drop more serious drug charges against him. Rumors of Barry drug use have followed him for much of the past decade. In one episode, convicted cocaine dealer Karen Johnson was jailed in 1984 for eight months for contempt of court after refusing to tell a grand jury whether she used drugs with Barry or sold them to the mayor or other top city officials. Barry, who is married, acknowledged having a ``personal'' relationship with Johnson, but denied using drugs with her. Another woman, Maria McCarthy, of Greensboro, N.C., was jailed for contempt of court on Tuesday after refusing to testify about her relationship with Barry, according to her attorney. Throughout, Barry steadfastly, and sometimes angrily, rejected all questions or suggestions that he was involved with drugs. When he announced that he was entering the Hanley-Hazelden Clinic, the mayor only said that he was ``taking steps to heal my body, mind and soul.''

DOC.HEAD: Street Violence Interrupts Protest Over Economic Program
DOC.TEXT: Thousands marching against government austerity measures fled in panic Thursday when police fired rifles and tear gas after hooded youths smashed store windows. Three people were injured, police said. The violence came 11 months after rioting left about 300 dead following protests over subsidy cuts on food and public transportation. About 8,000 union members and supporters marched in the capital while thousands of others marched across the country in protest of government reforms aimed at cutting a $34 billion foreign debt, fourth-largest in Latin America. The march in Caracas was interrupted when a group of adolescents overturned garbage cans and shouted insults at police. About 20 of the youths began breaking windows in Simon Bolivar Center, a complex on Plaza Caracas, where the march was to end. Police rushed in firing tear gas and shotgun blasts in the air. Three people were injured in the brief confrontation, including Rafael Calma, a photographer for a Caracas newspaper, hit by a bottle thrown by a bystander in the crowd, said police. Police did not say how the other two people were hurt. ``It was the same group of troublemakers. A small group. We acted responsibly,'' said metropolitan police sheriff L.B. Gomez, standing his ground as protesters chanted, ``Police off our streets! The streets are ours!'' ``It's the fault of the government's economic package,'' said a leftist congressman, Ricardo Guttierez, participating in the march. The march was called by the 4 million-member Confederation of Workers, CTV, Venezuela's largest umbrella labor group. The CTV has called on President Carlos Andres Perez to back off on austerity measures it says has hit poorer Venezuelans the hardest. Labor leaders have planned protests this month after Perez' year-old Social Democratic government planned to cut subsidies on gasoline. The economy last year contracted by 8.1 percent and inflation rose to 80 percent under the effects of the austerity measures. Unemployment is about 11 percent, according to independent estimates, up from 8.7 percent last year.

DOC.HEAD: CARTAGENA: substitution programs.
2. MITIGATION OF THE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC IMPACT OF THE FIGHT AGAINST ILLICIT DRUG TRAFFICKING
DOC.TEXT: As the Andean Parties implement or continue to develop effective programs of interdiction of the flow of illicit drugs and of crop eradication, they will need assistance of the fast disbursement type to mitigate both small- and large-scale social and economic costs. The Parties will cooperate to identify the type of assistance required. The United States is prepared to provide balance of payments support to help meet foreign exchange needs. The United States will also consider funding for emergency social programs, such as the successful one in Bolivia, to provide employment and other opportunities to the poor directly affected by the fight against illicit drugs.
DOC.HEAD: 3. TRADE INITIATIVES, INCENTIVES TO EXPORTS AND PRIVATE FOREIGN INVESTMENT
DOC.TEXT: An increase in trade and private investment is essential to facilitate sustained economic growth and to help offset the economic dislocations resulting from any effective program against illicit drugs. The Parties will work together to increase trade among the three Andean countries and the United States, effectively facilitating access to the United States market and strengthening export promotion, including identification, development and marketing of new export products. The United States will also consider providing appropriate technical and financial assistance to help Andean agricultural products comply with the admission requirements. The Parties may consider the establishment of economic and investment policies, as well as legislation and regulations to foster private investment. Where favorable conditions exist, the United States will facilitate private investment in the three Andean countries, taking into account the particular conditions and potential of each.
DOC.HEAD: B. UNDERSTANDING REGARDING ATTACKING ILLICIT DRUGS
DOC.TEXT: The Parties reaffirm their will to fight drug trafficking in a comprehensive manner attacking all facets of the trade: Production, transportation and consumption. Such comprehensive action includes the following: Preventive actions to reduce consumption and therefore demand. Control and law enforcement activities against illegal cultivation, processing, and marketing of illicit drugs. Control of essential chemicals for the production of illegal drugs and the means used for their transport. Seizure, forfeiture, and sharing of illegal proceeds and property used in committing narcotics-related crimes. Coordination of law enforcement agencies, the military, prosecutors and courts, within the framework of national sovereignty of each of the Parties. Actions to bring about a net reduction in the illegal cultivation of coca. The Parties undertake to engage in an ongoing evaluation of their cooperation, so that the President of the United States, as appropriate, may request Congress to provide additional assistance to the Andean Parties. Given that the Parties act within a framework of respect for human rights, they reaffirm that nothing would do more to undermine the war on drugs than disregard for human rights by participants in the effort.
DOC.HEAD: 1. PREVENTION AND DEMAND
DOC.TEXT: The Parties undertake to support development and expansion of programs in comprehensive prevention, such as preventive public education in both rural and urban areas, treatment of drug addicts, and information to encourage the public opposition to illegal drug production, trade and consumption. These programs are fundamental if the drug problem is to be successfully confronted.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: CARTAGENA: successfully confronted.
DOC.TEXT: The Parties recognize that prevention efforts in the four countries will benefit from shared information about successful prevention programs and from bilateral and multilateral cooperation agreements to expand efforts in this field. To this end, the Parties undertake to contribute economic, material and technical resources to support such comprehensive prevention programs.
DOC.HEAD: 2. INTERDICTION
DOC.TEXT: A battle against an illicit product must focus on the demand for, production of and trade in that product. Interdiction of illegal drugs, as they move from producer to consumer, is essential. The Parties pledge to step up efforts within their own countries to interdict illegal drugs and to increase coordination and cooperation among them to facilitate this fight. The United States is ready to provide this fight. The United States is ready to provide increased cooperation in equipment and training to the law enforcement bodies of the Andean parties.
DOC.HEAD: 3. INVOLVEMENT OF THE ARMED FORCES OF THE RESPECTIVE COUNTRIES.
DOC.TEXT: The control of illegal trafficking in drugs is essentially a law enforcement matter. However, because of its magnitude and the different aspects involved, and in keeping with the sovereign interest of each State and its own judicial system, the armed forces in each of the countries, within their own territory and national jurisdictions, may also participate. The Parties may establish bilateral and multilateral understandings for cooperation in accordance with their interests, needs and priorities.
DOC.HEAD: 4. INFORMATION SHARING AND INTELLIGENCE COOPERATION
DOC.TEXT: The Parties commit themselves to a greater exchange of information and intelligence in order to strengthen action by the competent agencies. The Parties will pursue bilateral and multilateral understandings on information and intelligence cooperation, consistent with their national interests and priorities.
DOC.HEAD: 5. ERADICATION AND DISCOURAGEMENT OF ILLICIT CROPS
DOC.TEXT: Eradication can play an essential part in the anti-drug fight of each country. In each case, eradication programs have to be carefully crafted, measuring their possible effect on total illicit drug production in each country; their cost-benefit ratio relative to other means of fighting illicit drugs; whether they can be most effective as voluntary or compulsory programs or a combination of the two; and their probable political and social consequences. The parties recognize that to eradicate illicit crops, the participation of the growers themselves is desirable, adopting measures that will help them obtain legal sources of income. New economic opportunities, such as programs for alternative deveopment and crop substitution, shall be fostered to help to dissuade growers from initiating or expanding illegal cultivation. Our goal is a sustained reduction in the total area under illegal cultivation. Eradication programs must safeguard human heath and preserve the ecosystem.
DOC.HEAD: 6. CONTROL OF FINANCIAL ASSETS
DOC.TEXT: The parties agree to identify, trace, freeze, seize, and apply other legal procedures for the disposition of drug crime proceeds in their respective countries, and to attack financial aspects of the illicit drug trade. In accordance with their respective laws, each of the parties will seek to adopt measures to define, categorize, and criminalize money laundering, as well as to increase efforts to implement current legislation. The parties agree to establish formulas providing exceptions to banking secrecy.
DOC.HEAD: 7. FORFEITURE AND SHARING OF ILLEGAL DRUG PROCEEDS
DOC.TEXT: The parties pledge to implement a system for forfeiture and sharing of illegal drug profits and assets, and to establish effective programs in this area. In United States cases related to forfeiture of property of illegal drug traffickers where Bolivia, Colombia, and Peru provide assistance to the United States government, the government of the United States pledges to transfer to the assisting government such forfeited property to the extent consistent with United States' laws and regulations. The Parties will also seek asset-sharing agreements for Bolivia, Colombia, and Peru with other countries.
DOC.HEAD: 8. CONTROL OF ESSENTIAL CHEMICALS USED IN THE PRODUCTION OF ILLICIT DRUGS
DOC.TEXT: The control in the United States of the export of chemical substances used in the processing of cocaine is vital. In addition, there is a need for greater control of the import and domestic production of such substances by the Andean Parties. Joint efforts must be coordinated to eliminate the illicit trade in such substances.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: CARTAGENA: such substances.
DOC.TEXT: The Parties agree: -- to step up interdiction of the movements of essential chemicals that have already entered the country, legally or illegally, and are being diverted for illicit drug processing. This includes controlling choke points as well as establishing investigative and monitoring programs in close cooperation with all the Parties' law enforcement agencies. -- to further develop an internal system to track essential chemicals through sale, resale and distribution to the end user. -- to cooperate bilaterally and multilaterally to provide each other with information necessary to track domestic and international movements of essential chemicals for the purpose of controlling their sale and use. -- to support the efforts under the Organization of American States (OAS) auspices to develop and implement a regional inter-American agreement on essential chemicals.
DOC.HEAD: 9. CONTROL OF WEAPONS, PLANES, SHIPS, EXPLOSIVES AND COMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT USED IN ILLEGAL DRUG TRAFFICKING
DOC.TEXT: Illicit drug trafficking is heavily dependent on weapons, explosives, communications equipment, and air, maritime and riverine transportation throughout the illicit cultivation and the production and distribution process. The Parties agree: to strengthen controls over the movement of illegal weapons and explosives and over the sale, resale and the registration of aircraft and maritime vessels in their respective countries, which should be carried out by their own authorities. The Parties agree to establish wihtin their own territory control programs that include: the registration of ships and aircraft; the adoption of legal standards that permit effective forfeiture of aircraft and vessels; controls on pilot licenses and training; registration of airfields in their respective countries; development of control measures over communications equipment used in illegal drug trafficking to the extent permitted by their respective laws and national interests. The United States agrees to work with the Andean Parties to stem weapons exports from the United States to illegal drug traffickers in the three Andean nations.
DOC.HEAD: 10. LEGAL COOPERATION
DOC.TEXT: The Parties pledge to cooperate in the sharing of instrumental evidence in forms admissable by their judicial proceedings. The Parties also agree to seek mechanisms that permit the exchange of information on legislation and judicial decisions in order to optimize legal proceedings against the traffic in illicit drugs. The Parties recognize the value of international cooperation in strengthening the administration of justice, including the protection of judges, judicial personnel, and other individuals who take part in these proceedings.
DOC.HEAD: C. UNDERSTANDINGS REGARDING DIPLOMATIC INITIATIVES AND PUBLIC
DOC.TEXT: OPINION

The scourge of illicit drug trafficking and consumption respects no borders, threatens national security, and erodes the economic and social structures of our nations. It is essential to adopt and carry out a comprehensive strategy to promote full awareness of the destructive effects of illegal production, illicit trafficking and the improper consumption of drugs. Toward this end, the Parties commit themselves to use all political and economic means within their power to put into effect programs aimed at achieving this goal.
DOC.HEAD: 1. STRENGTHENING PUBLIC OPINION IN FAVOR OF INTENSIFYING THE FIGHT
DOC.TEXT: AGAINST ILLEGAL DRUG TRAFFICKING

Public awareness should be enhanced by means of active and determined diplomatic action. The Parties pledge to strengthen plans for joint programs leading to te exchange of ideas, experiences, and specialists in the field. The parties call upon the international community to intensify a program of public information stressing the danger of drug trafficking in all of its phases. In this regard, the Parties undertake to give active support to Inter-American public awareness and demand reduction programs, and will support the development of a drug prevention education plan at the Inter-American meeting in Quito this year.
DOC.HEAD: 2. ECONOMIC SUMMIT
DOC.TEXT: The 1989 Economic Summit in Paris established a Financial Action Task Force to determine how governments could promote cooperation and effective action against the laundering of money gained through illegal drug trafficking.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Paula Zahn Leaves ABC; Next Stop: `CBS This Morning'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf, `A source ...,' to UPDATE that Friday is Kathleen Sullivan's last day; picks up 7th graf, `In a statement ...'
DOC.TEXT: ABC News anchorwoman Paula Zahn, bound for ``CBS This Morning,'' said goodbye on the air Thursday to her ``Good Morning America'' colleagues, not mentioning CBS but saying, ``I have a wonderful opportunity to go into.'' Although CBS had no comment on reports she is joining CBS News, her agent, Richard Leibner, confirmed she is headed there. He declined to elaborate. ``After a few tiny details are wrapped up, there's no question that she'll be at CBS,'' said Leibner, who handled negotiations for Diane Sawyer when she left CBS last year to join ABC as co-anchor of ``Prime-Time Live.'' Zahn's ABC contract ended Thursday. A source close to her contract talks said ABC hoped she would stay there but didn't make a counteroffer to CBS' bid, a four-year pact paying about $1.1 million annually. Zahn, who joined ABC News in the fall of 1987, has been co-anchor of ``World News This Morning'' and the news segments of ``Good Morning America'' since May 1988. The latter program is produced by ABC Entertainment. A source familiar with negotiations for her services said that Zahn would succeed Kathleen Sullivan as co-anchor of the bottom-rated ``CBS This Morning'' and probably would start work Feb. 26. Friday will be Sullivan's last day on the program, according to a memo sent staff members by the show's executive producer, Erik Sorenson, who said Faith Daniels would be her temporary replacement next week. In a statement, ABC News President Roone Arledge praised Zahn's work and said, ``We wish her all the best in her new assignment.'' ``ABC was terrific to her, she loved it there'' and appreciated what Arledge and others did for her, Leibner said. ``But an extraordinary opportunity doesn't come down the pike that often. It's a sad departure to a new adventure.'' Zahn's move to CBS has been expected ever since Ron Konecky, Sullivan's agent, said last week that CBS is taking Sullivan off ``CBS This Morning.'' Sullivan and Harry Smith have been co-anchors of the show since it began in 1987. In her farewell to viewers and ``Good Morning America'' co-host Charles Gibson and weatherman Spencer Christian, Zahn said that it had been ``an absolute pleasure'' working at ABC News. ``I have a wonderful opportunity to go into,'' she said. ``The details are being worked out at this moment, so we can't really talk specifically what they are about. You can expect the announcement soon.'' No replacement for her has been chosen, an ABC spokeswoman said. Zahn, a native of Naperville, Ill., previously was an anchor and reporter at Los Angeles TV station KCBS, where Sullivan began in 1977. Zahn started her career a year later at WFAA-TV in Dallas. Sullivan's CBS contract expires in November. Konecky said last week that CBS had given no specific reason why they wanted to replace her and had set no date for her to leave. He said he was discussing other possibilities for her at CBS. When Sullivan leaves the program, it will mark the second time this year that a network anchorwoman has been replaced on a morning program. In a controversial shift last month, Jane Pauley, co-host of NBC's ``Today'' for 13 years, was succeeded by Deborah Norville. The move hasn't helped that show in the ratings. According to A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings, ``Today'' last week was second to ``Good Morning America'' for the sixth consecutive week. ABC's show averaged a 4.4 rating and ``Today'' 3.7. CBS' show, third in ratings since it began, although doing better in the Nielsens than its predecessor, ``The Morning Show,'' had a 2.7. Each rating point represents 921,000 homes.
Here is a transcript of President Bush's news conference following the drug summit.

PRESIDENT BUSH: Well, we depart Cartagena having forged an unprecedented alliance against the drug trade. This afternoon, my colleagues, President Barco and President Garcia, President Paz Zamora and I, signed the Document of Cartagena, which sets forth the principles of this alliance. In signing the document, we've committed ourselves to the first common, comprehensive international drug control strategy. We in fact created the first anti-drug cartel. The document, which creates a flexible framework under which the four of us will coordinate our activities, covers the major issues of economic assistance, demand reduction, expanded law enforcement and interdiction activities, the involvement of military resources, where possible _ appropriate; and the control of precursor chemicals, automatic weapons and other key components of the narcotics trade; the pursuit of profits and sharing of seized assets, and a commitment on the part of all of us to continue to gather regularly to coordinate our activities. In addition to signing this Document of Cartagena, we begin the process of executing bilateral agreements in support of the document today. Secretary of State (James A.) Baker executed the agreements with Peru on tax information exchange, public awareness and extradition, and with Bolivia on public awareness and the export of defense articles. Director (William) Bennett (of the Office of National Drug Control Policy) executed a bilateral agreement with Bolivia on the control of precursor chemicals. Equally important, the four of us today had an opportunity to discuss in total candor the problem that illegal drug trafficking and use presents to each of our societies. I also had the opportunity to review with my colleagues the greatly expanded counter-narcotics activities of the U.S. government. The $2.2 billion, five-year program to which the United States is committed to support our partners in this struggle was discussed in some detail. In addition, I had the opportunity to explain our plans to expand the $7.5 billion inside the United States on treatment, prevention, and criminal justice support. I believe they were impressed with the major increase in resources which we've committed to reducing demand in our country. I must say I also listened very carefully to the challenges that each of the three countries face, and have come away with the new ideas worthy of consideration with a better personal understanding and appreciation of the problems that my allies face in this struggle. And I cannot leave this beautiful country, Colombia, without once again emphasizing that President Barco, and all of his citizens who have joined him in this brave fight against drug trafficking, are an inspiration to me, and an inspiration to the American people. I came here today to make the point as clear as I could that they do not, and will, not stand alone. They will have the steady and sustained support of the United States. I want to try to help them in the multilateral institutions, help President Barco in asset sharing, and opening up markets as best we can.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: CARTAGENA: drug trafficking.
DOC.TEXT: The United States will host the next Economic Summit on July 9-11, 1990, in Houston. The United States will use this opportunity to seek full attention on a priority basis to the fight against illegal drug trafficking. The Parties call upon the Economic Summit member countries, and on the other participants in the Financial Action Task Force, to give greater emphasis to the study of economic measures which may help to reduce drug trafficking. In particular, the Parties call upon the Economic Summit countries to take the steps necessary to ensure that assets seized from illicit drug trafficking in Bolivia, Colombia and Peru are used to finance programs of interdiction, alternative development and prevention in our countries.
DOC.HEAD: 3. MULTILATERAL APPROACHES AND COORDINATION
DOC.TEXT: The Parties intend to coordinate their actions in multilateral economic institutions in order to ensure for Bolivia, Colombia and Peru, broader economic cooperation with the framework of a sound economic policy.
DOC.HEAD: 4. REPORT TO THE UN SPECIAL SESSION ON ILLICIT TRAFFICKING IN
DOC.TEXT: DRUGS

The United Nations has recognized that the problem of drug trafficking presents a grave threat to the security of the states and economic stability. It has called for a Global Action Plan and it has convened a Special Session, February 20-23, 1990, to discuss the magnitude of this problem. Ths will be a proper occasion to reiterate the need to bring into force as quickly as possible the UN Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Pyschotropic Substances, which provides for energetic measures against illegal drug trafficking, while recognizing the ancestral and traditional uses of coca leaf. The Parties request that consideration by given during the Special Session to the inclusion of the cooperative efforts outlined in this document to develop concrete programs for strengthening multilateral responses to the drug problem, as recommended in Resolution No. 44-141 of the United National General Assembly.
DOC.HEAD: 5. REPORT TO THE OAS MEETING OF MINISTERS AND CICAD
DOC.TEXT: The Organization of American States has called an Inter-American meeting of Ministers responsible for national narcotics programs, to be held on April 17-20, 1990 in Ixtapa, Mexico. The Parties urge that the meeting of Ministers and the Inter-American Drug Abuse Control Commission (CICAD) give priority to the understandings set forth in this document and lend support to their early implementation withinthe context of regional cooperation against drugs.
DOC.HEAD: 6. MADRID TRILATERAL MEETING
DOC.TEXT: The parties stress the importance of the document issued by the Trilateral meeting in Madrid and the efforts undetaken in Europe, particularly the participation on the European Community, with a view to adopting specific policies and initiatives against illicit trafficking of drugs.
DOC.HEAD: 7. WORLD MINISTERIAL SUMMIT TO REDUCE DEMAND FOR DRUGS AND TO COMBAT THE COCAINE THREAT
DOC.TEXT: The Parties note with satisfaction the convening of a World Ministerial Summit to Reduce Demand for Drugs and to Combat the Cocaine Threat, to be held on April 9-11, 1990 in London. This meeting will serve to highlight the role demand reduction must play in the international community's efforts to reduce the trade in illicit drugs and will underline the social, economic and human costs of the trade. The Parties agree to coordinate their actions and future strategies in this area with the objective of building upon this important initiative.
DOC.HEAD: 8. DEMARCHES TO TRANSIT COUNTRIES
DOC.TEXT: Through specialized agencies of the United Nations such as the Heads of National Law Enforcement Agencies, our countries participate in important coordination efforts. The Parties undertake to strengthen cooperation with transit countries on interdiction of traffic in illicit drugs.
DOC.HEAD: 9. WORLD CONFERENCE AGAINST ILLICIT DRUG TRAFFICKING
DOC.TEXT: In order to progress towards the goals agreed upon at the Cartagena Summit, the parties call for a world conference in 1991 to strengthen international cooperation in the elimination of improper consumption, illegal trafficking and production of drugs.
DOC.HEAD: 10. FOLLOW-UP MEETING TO THE CARTAGENA SUMMIT
DOC.TEXT: In order to folow up on progress of agreements arising under the foregoing understandings, the parties agree to hold a high level follow-up meeting within a period of not more than six months.
DOC.HEAD: End of Text, 5 Takes
BARRANQUILLA: we can.
DOC.TEXT: I want to thank him and his many colleagues for the most hospitable arrangements that we encountered here in Barranquilla, and over in Cartagena. It was a great pleasure to be here, albeit very, very briefly. So thank you again President Barco, and I offer you my profound appreciation for your steadfast efforts in the fight against narcotics. I'll take just a few questions, because we're scooting on. Yeah, Helen? Q: Mr. President, how long do you think it will take to replace the coca plant, and how much will it cost? A: Well, I know we did not go into replacement cost, and I expect any program that tries to shape their economy, to move it out of planting which is very difficult for those governments to control, is going to take some time. And I can't give you a time estimate on that. Terry. And then we'll go _ Q: Mr. President, are you surprised that the narco-terrorists didn't strike today, that there was no either attack on you or any bombing in this country just to register displeasure with your visit? A: Well, you know, I got a question at the press conference over there on security, and I want to thank not only the security people here, but our own security people, Secret Service and others who were concerned with the security of the President, and I am not surprised. Yeah, Britt? Q: Mr. President, I gather you chose to _ not to raise today that rather ticklish question of a U.S. Navy radar net somewhere off the coast here. Why not, sir? A: Well, there was no discussion of a radar net. There was so much misunderstanding over what was intended in the first time _ first place that it's not timely to do that. However, there was discussion of interdiction and my reasserting to those countries, all three of them, my intention to interdict narcotics coming into this country. But there wasn't the _ the stories on the U.S. task force were so distorted that I felt it was better to keep talking in general terms about our military interdiction efforts, rather than asking for support from any one of the three countries. Q: Do you feel now, after this meeting, that your understanding with these leaders may have been enhanced to the point where you might soon be able to raise that topic again? A: Well, it depends what _ in what way _ yes. Well, in the first place, I feel the understanding is enhanced, and it was a frank meeting. I mean, they were very frank with us on things that maybe they wanted me to do more of or disagreed with, but I think that the idea of working cooperatively for interdiction is very important. You heard President Barco's answer there in _ at Cartagena on that question. So we're not going to push. We're not going to do something of that nature without a cooperative effort, but there are efforts in terms of interdiction on the high seas that the United States will continue to do. Yeah, these three right here _ these three. Q: Mr. President, you acknowledged in the document today that the U.S. has a responsibility to help these economies wean themselves from the drug trade. Do you see that responsibility as job-for-job and dollar-and-dollar? A: No. But I see us making every effort we can to help them,because they do have some severe problems. And I mention now trying to help Colombia, for example, in the multilateral agencies, for example. There's a lot of ways to try to help, but I don't think it is a job-for-job kind of approach.

DOC.HEAD: BARRANQUILLA: of approach.
DOC.TEXT: I don't think we can do that. I don't think there's a way the United States can do it, or that any of the individual leaders can do it. We had a long discussion about the supply and demand of cocaine, how market prices affect what the farmers do in Peru or Bolivia. So it isn't a job-for-job question. Q: Mr. President, any successful interdiction strategy would require increased military-to-military cooperation. Is the U.S. already installing a ground radar system in Peru, I mean in Bolivia or _ Colombia, I'm sorry _ or in any way helping the Colombians now to install a ground radar system? A: No, but I'd have to defer that question to someow nothing of it, but I know there was a report that was written up that proved to be totally inaccurate because I was just told that there was a report saying there was some 200 people building a ground rbody here. I knadar station. But I simply don't know it if there is, and I'd be surprised, frankly. Q: Do you know to what extent the U.S. and Colombia are in fact cooperating militarily now, in terms of interdiction efforts? A: Well I _ yes, I know that. Q: Can you share that with us. A: No. Next? Q: Why not, sir? A: Because I don't feel like it, and because some of the things we do with Colombia, if I shared it with you, maybe the drug narco-traffickers wo _ a disease that affects millions of Americans, including such notable and courageous individuals as former first lady Betty Ford. I have derived great benefit from my stay here at the alcohol rehabilitation center in Florida, and I know that recovery is a lifelong process to which I have dedicated myself. But for now, as I go through this healing process, I want to make sure that my wife and our son are psychologically and emotionally comfortable, after all that we have through and will be going through, as a family. I do not want them badgered and dogged at every turn. They do not suffer from the disease, I do. Any consequences should be mine to bear, not theirs. I am extremely proud of the way my management team, headed by City Administrator Carol Thompson, has handled the affairs of government in my absence. I know this budget period is a tough time for Carol; my staff director, Maudine Cooper; Deputy Mayors Bob Pohlman and Wylie Williams; Director of Special Services, Tina Smith; and the agency directors who must explain the serious realities of the city's financial picture during an election year. I know citizens need assurance that their needs will be met, and that the same high quality government services will continue uninterrupted in spite of the mean-spirited and calculating people who would like to see us fail as a local government. I put a strong management team in place, and I can reassure you that government is operating smoothly, efficiently and effectively _ and under the Barry philosophy of quality, compassionate, competent, and caring service. I want to say to all that when I decided to go away to deal with my health concerns, my political decisions were placed on hold and will be determined within the next 60 days. Anita Bonds is the only person designated and authorized by me to speak on political matters. My lawyer, Kenneth Mundy, and I are now preparing to go to court and win this case. I will have no announcement about my political future at this point. I hope the media will respect my right to continue my recovery, in private, and allow me to obtain the full benefit of treatment for this disease. During my absence, I urge you to respect the rights of my wife and my son to lead private lives as we go forward during this highly political legal procedure. I ask that you confine your questions about the legal case to my attorney. Any other questions about me should be directed to my press secretary, Lurma Rackley. To all of you who continue to remember me, my family, and this city in your prayers, I sincerely thank you.

DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, how can we expect the Bolivians and Peruvians not to grow coca if we block their exports of flowers, citrus, sugar? A: Well, I don't know if you heard the question. The question is: How can we expect them not to grow coca if we have other trade problems? And you mention sugar and flowers. I think the leaders here recognize that growing coca for the international drug market is immoral and wrong. And I think they believe that, and so they need assistance. If we have a flower problem, and we do, I think we take 80 to 90 percent of the cut flowers from Colombia _ we've got to try to help on it. I don't know that we can solve it. Coffee is a major problem for Brazil and the other countries, and we're trying _ I mean, for Colombia and also Brazil and the other countries with whom we met _ (aside) please, just one minute. I'm not going to get to you, I don't think, because this may be the last one. And so we have to work with them very cooperatively, but _ in trying to get a coffee agreement. But what I did get from these people, and I think I knew it ahead of time but had it reinforced, was that these economies are hurting because of the kinds of export problems they are encountering. I have a problem in trying to explain it to them that there's, you know, consumers in the United States, the largest market for coffee, they don't necessarily want to pay higher prices for it. The same for flowers. So, we've got _ what we did on the flowers is explain the procedures at the Commerce Department and say that we would try to help in negotiating that. But the point is it shouldn't be linked to whether _ to whether people, you know, condone the growing of a crop that is illegal and that they're trying to stop, as a matter of fact. Q: Will you _ Q: Mr. President, will you address that? A: (Inaudible.) Q: (Off mike) _ Europe and Japan in future negotiations? A: You're the guy. Yes! We're going to talk about that at the G-7 (Group of Seven economic summit meeting) in Houston, just as we did in Paris last year. It's a very important agenda item for the G-7, and the more they get involved, because they're user countries, the better it will be. So, I'll give a full report to the G-7 and other European countries on this ice-breaking meeting here, and you can be sure it will be on the agenda at the G-7 summit in Houston. Listen, thank you all very much. It's been a long day.
