List 10 Best Cities for Working Moms _ Minneapolis-St Paul Best
DOC.TEXT: Quality child care, good public schools and abundant job prospects are among the attractions that put Minneapolis-St. Paul at the head of Working Mother magazine's Top 10 list of U.S. metropolitan areas. The magazine published the rankings in its March issue distributed to newsstands Thursday, saying the list was based on exhaustive research into every major city in the United States. Working Mother said the Minnesota Twin Cities region was especially attractive because the local government and business community take an active role in helping families, particularly with child care. The magazine said that Minneapolis and St. Paul, with their longstanding tradition of political progressivism, have become a mecca of business and government support for working parents. The other metropolitan areas on the list, ranked in order, are: Pittsburgh; Raleigh, N.C.; Milwaukee; Orlando, Fla.; Seattle; Phoenix; Boston; San Jose, Calif.; and San Francisco. The magazine said the last three on the list were considered models in terms of progressive attitudes toward families with working parents, but that their high cost of living made them unaffordable for many. It said the criteria for judging included affordable, accessible child care and a quality school system, after-school programs, parks and other leisure-time facilities and a cost of living low enough to make it feasible to enjoy short-term pleasures and save for long-term goals like college. In addition, the magazine said, the cities were ranked based on an abundance of job prospects, decent salary levels and employee benefits, opportunities for career advancement, and the ``almost intagible'' involvement of the business community as well as state and local governments in quality-of-life and work issues. Working Mother, a 10-year-old magazine based in New York, has a circulation of about 460,000.

DOC.HEAD: 35 Million Americans Have Arthritis; 6 Million Won't See Doctor
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-five million Americans report suffering from arthritis, and 6 million admit they haven't seen a doctor about it, according to a survey released Thursday by federal health officials. ``This confirms our suspicions that people are seeing (pain-killer) ads on TV and treating their arthritis themselves _ and very possibly doing damage to themselves,'' said Steve Erickson, spokesman for the Arthritis Foundation, based in Atlanta. The highest incidence of arthritis was in Florida, 18 percent, while the lowest was in Alaska, 9 percent. More than 3,000 people were asked in 1987 if they had experienced various arthritic conditions in the past year, if they had consulted a physician about the condition and if their arthritis was limiting their work or their household lives, the national Centers for Disease Control said. Nationwide, the survey found, 14.6 percent of the population reported arthritis and 12.1 percent had consulted a doctor about it, leaving 2.5 percent _ about 6 million people _ who hadn't. The feeling that nothing can be done for arthritis, beyond taking over-the-counter pain medication, ``is a real big misconception,'' Erickson said. ``There are a lot of things you can do.'' The problem will probably get worse if pain relievers are the only treatment, he said. ``These findings indicate the need ... to determine why these persons have not sought medical care, and to identify approaches for overcoming barriers to care,'' the CDC said in its weekly report. Women reported higher rates of arthritis than men, 18 percent to 11 percent. Women also were more likely to have seen a doctor about their arthritis _ 15 percent to 9 percent _ and were more likely to report limits in their activity _ 4 percent to 2 percent. Overall, 3 percent said arthritis was limiting their activities. There was little racial difference in arthritis reporting: 15 percent for whites and 14 percent for blacks. As might be expected, arthritis rates increased with age. Eleven percent of respondents aged 35-44 reported arthritis compared with 23 percent of those 45-54; by the 75-and-over group, the rate was 53 percent, compared to just 3 percent in the under-35 group. The high rate of arthritis in Florida ``is due to its relatively large population of elderly persons,'' the CDC said. Alaska's low rate can be attributed in part to its high Native American and Pacific Islander populations, ``among whom the prevalence of arthritic conditions is low,'' the report said. Erickson said too few people are aware of the warning signs of arthritis, such as joint swelling, early morning stiffness, recurring joint pain or inability to move a joint that lasts for more than two weeks. People with those symptoms should see a doctor, the Arthritis Foundation said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Officers Demand Resignation of Ceausescu Brass
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with civilians joining officers, sentences in Sibiu, other detail. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Officers demanding the firing of military leaders who served dictator Nicolai Ceausescu protested for a fourth day Thursday, joined by more than 2,000 civilians. The officers said they would continue until the dismissal of Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru, Interior Minister Mihai Chitac and others who were in the military hierarchy before Ceausescu was overthrown and executed in December. Fifty-eight officers who spent three nights inside government headquarters on Victory Square left the building early Thursday after Premier Petre Roman agreed to investigate Militaru and Chitac. They continued their protest outside and about 2,000 civilians joined them late Thursday, including Hihai Stanescu, Romania's best-known cartoonist. The crowd dwindled when heavy rain began. Alexandra Marielise Popescu, a 34-year-old translator who joined the crowd with several friends, said: ``The army helped us in the revolution and we must help them. ``We think they're in danger because of the Securitate,'' Ceausescu's secret police. ``They are trying to penetrate into the old structure again, and to hold positions.'' Silviu Brucan of the National Salvation Front, which took power during the uprising, told The Associated Press the officers ``are almost 80 percent right, but an army without discipline is not an army and all officers should understand this.'' Official media said seven Securitate officers were sentenced in Sibiu, central Romania, for ``complicity in genocide'' by trying to crush the revolution. Col. Iulian Rotariu, Securitate commander in Sibiu, got a 20-year prison sentence and sentences for the others ranged from 15 to 18 years. Sibiu was governed by Ceausescu's son Nicu, who was captured Dec. 22. Authorities have said he will be tried, but he has not been seen by the public since his arrest. Officers in Victory Square said similar protests were under way in the western city of Timisoara, where the uprising began, and the Black Sea port of Costanta. The Bucharest protest, which began Monday, was the military's first challenge to the revolutionary government it helped create. Many officers said they felt the people's victory was threatened because former Communists in the military were trying to protect their positions. Roman said the new commission would investigate the role of individual officers during the revolution and reconsider military appointments and promotions made since Dec 22, the day Ceausescu was overthrown. He was executed three days later. Dr. David Vasile, who has the military rank of lieutenant major, said: ``Rapid measures should have been taken immediately after the restoration of democracy to change all the top people in the army.'' Vasile was charged with insubordination under Ceausescu for refusing to obey orders. He said most of the top brass were agents of the Securitate or cooperated with the agency. ``The interest they have now is to cover themselves,'' he said. The officers have accused Interior Minister Chitac of being a ``direct participant'' in repressive actions in Timisoara, citing unconfirmed reports that a videotape exists showing Chitac shooting demonstrators. They accuse Militaru, who came out of retirement to be defense minister, of creating ``a state of tension in the army,'' and demand he be replaced by a civilian.

DOC.HEAD: Court Convicts German Hackers of Selling Computer Codes to Soviets
DOC.TEXT: A court convicted three West German hackers on Thursday of selling Western military computer codes to the Soviet KGB secret police, and gave them suspended sentences ranging from 14 months to two years. Chief Judge Leopold Spiller said sentences were suspended because ``it could not be proven that substantial damage had been done to ... (West Germany) or its NATO partners'' through the hackers' actions. But he also said the three purposely sold the computer codes for money to the KGB. Court records show one defendant, Peter Carl, made at least 25 contacts with the Soviets and received $54,500 for the computer information, which he split with the others. Carl, 35; computer specialist Dirk Brzezinski, 30; and computer programmer Markus Hess, 28, were arrested in March 1989 after an investigation by U.S. and West German officials revealed they had obtained passwords and codes giving them access to major military and research computers in the United States, Western Europe and Japan. Carl drew 24 months; Hess, 20 months; and Brzezinski, 14 months. A fourth man, Karl Koch, 30, was arrested in the case, but committed suicide last May. U.S. officials said last year that the hackers were stopped short of obtaining any highly classified information. Investigators said at the time of the arrests that codes and passwords for computers in Japan, Britain, France, Italy, Switzerland and West Germany were also obtained and sold to the Soviet by the hackers. All three defendants admitted guilt in obtaining codes to sell to a Soviet KGB agent in East Berlin. At the trial, which began on Jan. 11, Carl testified he could identify the agent only as ``Serge'' and said he did not wish to reveal anything more about the Soviets in open court for fear of reprisals.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Hurt in Chopper Crash Dies
DOC.TEXT: A 13-year-old boy injured in the crash of a sightseeing helicopter last weekend died Thursday without regaining consciousness, a hospital spokeswoman said. Robert Faller and his father, Bernard, were among five people aboard the helicopter when it plunged into the East River on Saturday. The boy, strapped in his seat, was underwater for 20 minutes before divers reached him. The others, all adults, were rescued quickly, and escaped serious injury. Robert suffered a heart attack, and was put on a respirator at Bellevue Hospital. Doctors never tested for brain activity ``because his condition was too unstable,'' said Karen Crowe, a Bellevue spokeswoman. The boy died at 10:42 a.m. Thursday, she said. The pilot of the helicopter, a Bell Jet Ranger 206-L operated by Island Helicopter Corp., said he believed a gust of wind swung the aircraft into the water as it lifted off from a riverside heliport.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Embassy, Colombian Defense Ministry Deny Report of Radar Net
DOC.TEXT: Colombian officials and the U.S. Embassy on Thursday denied press reports that the United States sent radar equipment and troops to the city of Bucaramanga to establish a radar network for drug interdiction efforts. However, Columbia and the United States last year announced they were setting up a radar station on the Colombian Caribbean island of San Andres to monitor air traffic, and equipment for that station began arriving two months ago, according to an embassy spokeswoman. The United States is ready to help set up a series of radar stations in Colombia, Bolivia and Peru to interdict the small planes that fly tons of cocaine into the United States each year, a U.S. diplomat in Bogota told The Associated Press last week. The diplomat spoke on condition that he not be identified by name. The diplomat said the United States had begun preliminary discussions with the Latin American countries about setting up the net, but added that the plan was still at an ``embryonic'' stage. It was not on the table for President Bush's summit meeting Thursday with the presidents of Peru, Bolivia and Columbia, he said. Crates unloaded by U.S. soldiers at Cartagena were not radar equipment, as reported by NBC News, but medical supplies, said the embassy spokeswoman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. She said the medical supplies brought in by military cargo plane on Monday were for an agricultural corporation helping peasants in the northeastern state of Santander. The president of the corporation, German Enrique Corzo, confirmed the shipment was medical supplies, as did Colombian Defense Ministry spokesman Col. Eduardo Arevalo. Arevalo said members of the cargo plane's crew were the only U.S. military personnel who had arrived in Colombia. At his news conference following the drug summit, President Bush said he knew nothing of any such radar station being built. Asked to describe how the military services of the United States and Columbia were cooperating to interrupt the drug traffic, Bush declined, giving as his reasons: ``Because I don't feel like it, and because some of the things we do with Colombia, if I shared it with you, maybe the drug narco-traffickers would find out about it, and I don't want to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: State Drops Case Against Minister Accused of Meeting with PLO
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Yosef Harish said Thursday he was dropping an investigation into charges that a cabinet minister violated Israel's anti-terrorism law by meeting with PLO officials. In January, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir accused Science Minister Ezer Weizman of meeting with PLO officials and forced him to quit the 12-member Cabinet. It is unclear if Weizman will be readmitted to the Cabinet. Harish said he was ending his review of secret material gathered in a police investigation of Weizman's meetings because there was ``no acceptable evidence'' that the minister knowingly met with PLO officials. An ammendment to Israel's anti-terrorism law makes it illegal to knowingly hold unauthorized contacts with members or representatives of the PLO, which Israel considers a terrorist organization. In the occupied territories Thursday, Palestinian activists beat and stabbed to death a fellow Arab on suspicion of cooperation with Israel, Arab reports said. They identified the man as Saadi Ismail el-Lidawi, 27, a taxi driver from Rafah, a town in the occupied Gaza Strip. His death raised to 183 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs since the start of the 26-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. At least 656 Palestinians have been killed and 43 Israelis have died during the rebellion. In a five-page official statement released by Harish, the attorney general stated that: ``There is no acceptable evidence ... that Minister Weizman has committed any violations.'' The statement also pointed out that Weizman has parliamentary immunity from prosecution. The statement said an investigation led by Chief of Police David Krauss revealed that Weizman had met the PLO's representative in Geneva, Nabil Ramlawi, in June. The statement also said in November Weizman held a telephone conversation with Ahmed Tibi, an Israeli Arab, who was visiting Tunis. Shamir had accused Weizman of passing cabinet secrets to PLO leaders in Tunis during a telephone conversation. Harish said Weizman had not violated the anti-terrorism law because he met Ramlawi by accident and did not know of his role in the PLO. He also said Weizman's telephone conversation with Tibi could not be considered illegal because Tibi is an Israeli citizen and not a member of the PLO. ``I feel justice has been done,'' Weizman told The Associated Press. ``I am very satisfied.'' Weizman, 65, a former defense minister who defected to Labor from Shamir's Likud refused to comment when asked if he would demand to return to the inner cabinet.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Hear Hazelwood Tape After Tanker Ran Aground
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 21 grafs with recording of Hazelwood after grounding; picks up 13th graf, `Kunkel, who...'
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in Joseph Hazelwood's trial heard a tape recording Thursday of the skipper's harried voice reporting the tanker Exxon Valdez had run aground and that he was ``trying to steer off the reef.'' The recording was of conversations between Hazelwood and the Coast Guard in the minutes after the nation's worst oil spill early last March 24. ``Exxon Valdez, over,'' began the first transmission of Hazelwood's voice. He said, ``We should be on your radar. We've fetched up hard aground ... evidently we're leaking some oil and we're going to be here for quite a while.'' The Coast Guard responded, ``You're about a mile north of Bligh Reef?,'' to which Hazelwood said, ``That's correct.'' He promised a status report. Within minutes, the captain of the port, Coast Guard Cmdr. Steven McCall, was on the radio asking for more information. ``We're working our way off the reef,'' Hazelwood said. ``Right now we're trying to steer off the reef.'' McCall then urged Hazelwood to ``take it slow and easy,'' promising that help was on the way. He warned against doing ``anything drastic to try to get under way'' and told Hazelwood, ``I wouldn't do much wiggling.'' Prosecutors allege Hazelwood tried a potentially hazardous maneuver after the grounding which could have capsized the crippled ship. Other witnesses have said Hazelwood ordered the engines of the ship restarted about 20 minutes after the grounding and gave commands to move forward. Hazelwood's lawyers maintain he was trying to stabilize the tanker on the reef, not take the dangerous action of trying to move off the reef. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is charged with one felony count of second-degree criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted, the former tanker skipper could draw up to 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Earlier Thursday, the vessel's chief mate testified he had warned Hazelwood that the seaman who had the helm before the disaster ``needed practice in steering.'' James Kunkel, corroborating earlier testimony by another officer in Hazelwood's trial, said he'd sailed with seaman Robert Kagan four years earlier and on that voyage Kagan could not perform a simple task such as painting a bulkhead without constant supervision. He said he discussed Kagan's performance with Hazelwood before the Exxon Valdez began its trip into Prince William Sound. ``I mentioned I'd sailed with him before and I thought he needed extra supervision and extra practice in steering,'' Kunkel said of his conversation with Hazelwood. ``His steering ability needed to be watched.'' Kunkel said that after sailing with Kagan in June and July 1985, he wrote an evaluation that said Kagan needed special attention and ``tended to drift off'' while steering. He noted that when assigned to paint a bulkhead, Kagan was unable to proceed unless someone watched him to make sure he used the right paint and the right brush. Kagan was at the wheel of the Exxon Valdez when the tanker ran aground on jagged Bligh Reef, spewing more than 10 million gallons of North Slope crude. Kagan, who was under the supervision of Third Mate Gregory Cousins, testified he had been ``timid'' about steering since a previous journey when he had been reprimanded for oversteering. Cousins testified that Kagan understeered the Valdez, failing to turn hard enough to avoid the grounding. Cousins said he thought Kagan didn't understand the steering orders. Previous witnesses have said Hazelwood was unaware of Kagan's problems, but Kunkel contradicted that. Kunkel, who was in charge of loading the 987-foot tanker with oil, gave the first detailed description of the ship's computerized oil measuring devices and of security systems designed to prevent spills. He recounted racing to the cargo room after the tanker hit the reef and seeing the oil gauges dropping. The smell of oil was everywhere, he said. Kunkel said he sat down at a computer, entered some calculations and received a message that ``the ship was no longer meeting required stability ... the ship should not go to sea.'' In the first few hours, he said, the Exxon Valdez lost about 138,000 barrels, and by the time the final calculations were made, it spilled 260,000 barrels _ or 10.92 million gallons. Kunkel said he notified Hazelwood of what was happening and discussed preparations for possibly abandoning ship. He said the captain chose not to sound a general alarm immediately because he feared panic among the crew. The prosecution contends Hazelwood endangered the lives of crew members by not awakening them immediately after the accident. Ultimately, it was not necessary for the crew to abandon the Exxon Valdez.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Up to $30 Million Wasted Each Year on Useless Hospital Diarrhea Tests
DOC.TEXT: Americans are needlessly paying $20 million to $30 million a year for useless hospital tests to detect organisms that cause diarrhea, a new study says. Many doctors automatically order bacterial or parasite tests on patients who develop diarrhea while hospitalized, even though most hospital-acquired diarrhea is caused by a toxin detected by a different test, the study said. Doctors generally know this, but are hesitant to omit routine tests in the absence of proof, said the study led by Dr. Don L. Siegel of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. Siegel and his team analyzed test patterns on stool specimens of inpatients and outpatients with diarrhea at the hospital from September 1985 through August 1988. They assumed that outpatients with diarrhea and inpatients who had developed it within three days or less of hospitalization brought the malady in with them, while other cases developed while patients were in the hospital. The researchers looked at two tests _ bacterial cultures and exams for parasites _ to detect the presence of organisms commonly brought in from outside, such as Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter and others. Results for the three-year period showed that among 191 positive stool cultures and 90 positive exams for eggs and parasites, only one occurred in a person who developed diarrhea in the hospital, the researchers said. The rest occurred in people who had brought the diarrhea in with them, the researchers reported in Friday's Journal of the American Medical Association. Yet half of the 3,000 specimens sent to the hospital laboratory each year for the two tests came from patients who had been in the hospital more than three days, the researchers said. ``Half the workload ... was for nothing,'' Siegel said in a telephone interview Thursday. Overall, about 2.2 percent of the tests were positive. The researchers then compared those test patterns with ones for a test to detect the toxin manufactured by a bacteria called Clostridium difficile, which usually is responsible for hospital-acquired diarrhea. They found that a quarter of those samples were positive for Clostridium difficile toxin, regardless of when patients were admitted. Clostridium difficile can be present in the digestive system without causing trouble because it is kept in check by the other bacteria that aid in digestion, Siegel said. When antibiotics or chemotherapy kill the other bacteria, the Clostridium difficile multiply, causing diarrhea, he said. The researchers concluded that the toxin tests were appropriate, but that the cultures and parasite tests could be eliminated for patients who had been hospitalized for more than three days, because they were useless. Even the one positive test among the cultures occurred in a person who was in the hospital for a kidney transplant three weeks after dining with her family at a restaurant where a Salmonella outbreak had occurred. The outbreak sickened all of the patient's relatives, indicating the patient brought the infection in with her. The hospital subsequently eliminated routine stool cultures and parasite tests on patients who developed diarrhea after more than three days of hospitalization, saving an estimated $25,000 a year, the researchers said. A recent survey of 6,500 hospitals nationwide indicated 2 million stool cultures and 2 million stool parasite tests are performed annually. At a cost of $20 and $10 each, respectively, if 30 percent to 50 percent were eliminated because they are unwarranted, resulting savings would total $20 million to $30 million, the researchers said.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Security Hovers Over Four-Nation Summit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf 5: ``Asked at,'' with Bush comment; INSERTS 13th graf: ``Also, near,'' with another bombing
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers wore camouflage uniforms and had automatic rifles at their sides. Helicopter gunships made passes over the city and its beaches while frigates patrolled the bay _ all part of an extraordinary security blanket thrown over the drug summit. Typifying the protective measures was a swarm of helicopters that accompanied President Bush from Barranquilla, 60 miles northeast of here, to the summit site at a heavily fortified naval base. The helicopters rode fast and hugged the terrain in what was described as an evasionary tactic against any attack. The presidential chopper landed fast. It blew hats and helmets off security guards spaced around the parade grounds as a U.S. counter-assault team looked on _ its members wearing casual slacks, polo shirts and huge backpacks. ``First class. We've got the best, the best,'' Bush said at one point in boasting about the security detail. Asked at his news conference following the summit if he were surprised that the meeting was not attacked, the president thanked everybody concerned with security arrangements and said, ``I am not surprised.'' The U.S. security forces had taken extraordinary measures to guard Bush following a report in December that Colombian drug lords had taken a $30 million contract on the president's life and reports that surface-to-air missiles had been acquired to shoot down his plane. Two U.S. warships, the Nassau and the Sampson, were cruising off the Colombian coast. The Nassau carries a Marine amphibious assault company that can be used in the case of an emergency. Colombian navy frogmen checked the bay, apparently looking for explosives near the Spanish fortification where the presidents were meeting. The air corridor between the Caribbean coastal cities of Barranquilla and Cartagena was closed to civilian aircraft. Two American Blackhawk helicopters belonging to Colombia's army joined in the security cover enveloping Cartagena Bay. There was no apparent sign of danger to Bush or to his summit partners _ Presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Alan Garcia of Peru and Jaime Paz of Boliva. And yet, apparently protesting the Bush visit, young people burned a Coca-Cola truck and a commuter microbus in the northwestern city of Medellin, in front of the University of Antioquia, the Colombian radio network Caracol said. In the central Colombian town of Barancabermeja, a toll booth on the highway was blown up with dynamite and a wall near the booth was painted with the message in Spanish, ``Gringos Get Out Of Colombia!.'' Also, near Barranquila Airport, a small bomb damaged a voltage regulator on a power line that fed the air conditioning of the airport where Bush landed two hours later. Later Thursday, an armed group kidnapped an American Roman Catholic priest as he and some nuns were heading to a nearby church to celebrate a mass, the RCN radio network reported. The Rev. Francis Amico was kidnapped as he and nuns of the Mother Theresa order ``were leaving the Saint Andres (St. Andrewsw) parish, in the eastern part of Cali,'' the network reported, quoting a parish's priest. RCN report said no group or organization had immediately claimed responsibility for the abduction. The priest works for a Canadian religious order. In advance of the Thursday summit, security had been heightened in Cartegena Bay near the finger of land where Bush and the others held talks in a presidential guest house. A Colombian frigate had stationed itself just off the coast of the peninsula and small patrol boats were speeding along the shores with machine guns pointed inland. Across the bay from the peninsula, authorities had forced the fishing boats that normally crowd Cartagena's docks to leave, and except for some decrepit ships too damaged to move, the wharves were empty. Naval authorities closed off Cartagena's bay to private boat traffic and were guarding it with frogmen, frigates, high-speed patrol boats and at least one submarine. Helicopters hovered above high-rise luxury hotels, where guests were being required to submit to fingerprinting. Cartagena's streets, normally packed with traffic and pedestrians in the early morning hours, were practically abandoned. Scores of troops also surrounded the convention center where much of the international press watched Barco's welcoming speech broadcast on a giant screen television from the guest house across the bay. Soldiers stood on the roof of the convention center as military patrols roamed the sun-baked streets below.

DOC.HEAD: Hawke Announces March 24 Election for Record 4th Labor Term
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf with details on economic situation
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke on Friday called a general election for March 24 in a bid to gain a record fourth consecutive term for his labor government. Hawke, 60, said the electorate ``faced clear and stark alternatives'' in a vote for his government's record on managing the economy. ``We can as a nation make the choice to continue on the path of steady growth, or under the Conservatives we can choose to forsake the future in a traumatic rerun of the late '70s and early '80s,'' he said. Hawke consistently rates as one of Australia's most popular leaders ever, despite his tearful confessions on national television about infidelity many years ago, his daughter's one-time heroin addiction and his problems with alcohol. Recent opinion polls show support for the ruling Australian Labor Party at 45 percent compared with the Conservative Liberal-National Party coalition of 42 percent. Labor currently has 85 seats in 148-seat House of Representatives, which chooses the government. The Liberal Party has 45 seats and its coalition partner National Party has 18 seats. The coalition, now led by Andrew Peacock, was in power from 1975 to 1983. Hawke, in his announcement, also targeted the environment as an issue, warning a return to a coalition government would lead to environmental degradation. ``We, as a nation, simply cannot afford to go back to the blinkered ideology of our Conservative opponents,'' he added. Hawke's announcement, at a news conference, left 36 days for campaigning, three above the minimum required by parliamentary law. He said the country's 10 million voters could not have withstood a longer campaign, adding, ``We would have collectively gone bonkers.'' Hawke said he expected to be victorious and lead the government to an unprecedented fifth term before retiring. The Labor Party under Hawke was first elected to government in March 1983, and was re-elected in early polls in 1984 and 1987. An announcement of elections had been widely expected and the deadline for calling the poll was May 12. Term of government is three years. The timing of the election comes at a time of generally low credibility for the government over the high 17 percent interest rates that have hurt home buyers and small businesses.

DOC.HEAD: Ryzhkov Stands Firm On Japanese Islands; Signs Treaties With Australia
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov on Thursday said his country's relations with Japan will not improve while Tokyo insists on the return of four Soviet-occupied islands seized during World War II. ``If further pressed (on this issue) I don't think we can have a productive relationship with Japan or any prospect of advancement,'' the No. 2 man in the Kremlin told reporters before departing for Sydney, his last stop on a three-day Australian visit. He described his talks with Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke as ``very exciting.'' He concluded the Canberra visit with his delegation signing six bilateral agreements, including a trade deal and a pact providing for access for Soviet trawlers. The two countries also signed agreements on human rights, peaceful uses of nuclear energy and protection of the environment. Ryzhkov said the fishing agreement did not go far enough. The Soviet side suggested that in addition to port access, Soviet fleets should be allowed unlimited access to Australia's huge fish resources. In return, Ryzhkov said, the Soviet Union was willing to sell part of the catch to Australia and trade it for Australian mutton and lamb. He denied claims that Soviet boats could be used to spy in the region. Ryzhkov arrived in Australia Tuesday from Bangkok and flies on Friday to Singapore, host of the next Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation meeting. Japan is not on his itinerary. In December, Soviet and Japanese officials failed to reach an accord to formally settle World War II because of the dispute over the Kuril Islands, seized shortly before the war ended in 1945. The Soviets have called on Tokyo to renounce its claim to the small islands north of Hokkaido, Japan's northernmost island.

DOC.HEAD: President Apologizes for Killings, Criticizes Police
DOC.TEXT: President Ali Saibou apologized Thursday for the police killings of student demonstrators and said officers will not interfere in a rally planned Friday to protest the shootings. Brig. Gen. Saibou said no government minister gave the order for police to open fire during last Friday's student demonstration, and he promised to find out who allowed the police live ammunition. He called the shootings a ``police blunder.'' The military government says three students were killed. Students put the death toll at 12. Saibou was attending a drought conference in Cameroon at the time and since has called emergency meetings of politicians and administrators, to whom he addressed his remarks Thursday. Niger's trade unions called for a general public rally Friday to insist on their constitutional right to protest peacefully. Saibou said the government will tolerate the demonstration on condition it is peaceful. Students have been demanding better-equipped libraries and laboratories, and guaranteed jobs in the government, which has stopped hiring civil servants as part of an austerity program. The government has set up a commission to investigate their grievances but says their demands are excessive in a country that is among the world's poorest.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker Admits Responsibility for East German Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD details on municipal elections, Eppelmann, charges, where Honecker resides. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Communist chief Erich Honecker took blame for the East German crisis and admitted that countrywide local elections in May were manipulated, according to a statement Thursday night on East German TV. Outrage over the municipal elections was a major factor in the peaceful popular uprising headed by pro-democracy forces that led to Honecker's ouster Oct. 18. The 77-year-old, ailing former leader has been accused of widespread abuse of powers and fraud during his 18-year Stalinist rule and faces trial next month for high treason and corruption. Rainer Eppelmann of Democratic Awakening, a prominent East Berlin cleric and one of eight opposition officials added to Communist Premier Hans Modrow's caretaker government on Feb. 5, read the following Honecker declaration on TV: ``According to my earlier declarations, I admit being politically responsible for the crisis in which the state and the people of ... (East Germany) are suffering now. This extends to the circumstances that led eventually to the manipulation of the election results on May 7, 1989. ``At the same time, I want to stress that I never in my life made political decisions out of egoistic motives and that I feel free of any guilt in a juridical sense.'' Honecker tried to hold out against the tide of reform that coursed Eastern Europe last fall, but thousands upon thousands of people from his frontline Soviet bloc state began escaping to the West in August through Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia. That set off rallies inside East Germany that finally forced leadership changes. Huge protests marked the 40th anniversary of Communist rule, and on Oct. 18, Honecker was replaced. The rallies continued, reaching 1 million on Nov. 4. On Nov. 9, East Berlin opened its western border and dismantling of the Berlin Wall began. Honecker and other former leaders were placed under house arrest for investigation of corruption on Dec. 4. On Jan. 30, Honecker was freed from prison and put in a nursing home on a court order. But hours later he was under arrest again and now awaits trial. He currently resides in a Lutheran Church home. East Germany, meanwhile, is in a desperate economic crunch and is seeking help from West Germany, as talk of German reunification spreads through the world.

DOC.HEAD: Biologist Nominated As MIT President, Asian-American to Lead UC-Berkeley
DOC.TEXT: A biologist was nominated to become president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and an engineering scholar became the first Asian-American selected as a University of California chancellor, officials said Thursday. Phillip A. Sharp's nomination to become MIT's 15th president will be voted on March 2 by the 96-member MIT Corporation, which governs the school, school spokesman Bob D'Iorio said. At University of California-Berkeley, Chang-Lin Tien, a 54-year-old Chinese immigrant, will become head of the school July 1. Sharp was nominated by a faculty search committee, a faculty advisory committee and the MIT Corporation's executive committee. Sharp, director of the university's center for cancer research, would be the first biologist to head MIT, which is in Cambridge, Mass. His 1977 discoveries on DNA are credited with dramatically changing the field of molecular genetics. Paul E. Gray, MIT's president since 1980, said last year that he would step down as of this summer. Sharp, 45, joined the MIT faculty in 1974 as an associate professor of biology in the center for cancer research. He became director of the center in 1985. MIT _ with about 10,000 graduate and undergraduate students, nearly 1,000 faculty and about 8,000 staff members _ is famed for its achievements in science and biology. Tien spent spent 29 years at the Berkeley campus before becoming executive vice chancellor at UC-Irvine 18 months ago. He replaces Ira Michael Heyman, who is retiring June 30 after 10 years. ``This appointment is an expression of commitment to the Berkeley faculty and to the university's increasingly multicultural population,'' Tien said in a statement. The Board of Regents affirmed UC President David P. Gardner's recommendation at their regular meeting Thursday at UC's Laurel Heights campus. The high-profile Berkeley campus, recognized not only for its academic performances but also its history of student political protest, has 38,000 students and 11,000 faculty and staff employees. It is considered the most ethnically diverse major university in the nation. Tien, the first Asian to head a campus in the 122-year-old state university system, is an authority in heat transfer technology and a member of the National Academy of Engineers, his field's most prestigious professional association. While at Berkeley, he won the distinguished teaching award and was honored for his scholarship in West Germany, Japan and China. He came to the United States in 1955 after earning a bachelor's degree at the National Taiwan University.

DOC.HEAD: Vassar Students End Protest, Leave Building
DOC.TEXT: Vassar College students, upset over a remark allegedly made by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, ended their 35-hour occupation of a campus building Thursday after officials agreed to hear their grievances. Jeff Rosenberg, a member of the Vassar Student Union which helped organize the occupation, said about 100 protesters also left the building because Moynihan has relinguished an honorary chair and the $1,000 stipend it carries. The students began their occupation Wednesday to protest an offensive remark allegedly made by Moynihan, D-N.Y., to a black Jamaican woman he did not know was a Dutchess County official. Falomi Gray, head of the county youth bureau, claimed Moynihan made a racial remark after she challenged him during a Jan. 29 lecture for his comment that the United States is ``a model of a reasonably successful multi-ethnic society.'' Gray said Moynihan told her that if she doesn't like it in the United States, she should pack her bags and go back to where she came from. Moynihan has said he does not remember making the remark. The students left Vassar's main administration building around 4:15 p.m., said college spokeswoman Dixie Sheridan. ``We are committed to negotiating the issues they presented,'' she said Earlier Thursday, the students said they would consider leaving only when college President Frances Fergusson apologizes for appointing Moynihan to the Eleanor Roosevelt Chair, an honorary lecturing post. Other student demands included establishment of an ``intercultural center'' for minority meetings, a rabbi for Jewish students and complete access for the disabled to all buildings. ``We will continue our discussions with them in order to ensure that the issues raised are being fully addressed by the campus community,'' Fergusson said in a statement. In Washington, meanwhile, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., rallied to Moynihan's defense. ``Pat Moynihan a racist? You've got to be kidding!'' Dole said in a statement. ``Pat has spent his life fighting for minorities, the down and out and left out. ... This strange story coming out of Poughkeepsie is absolutely preposterous.''

DOC.HEAD: Swedish Government Quits After Parliament Rejects Economic Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new material and editing. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Social Democratic government of Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson resigned after Parliament rejected its economic austerity program on Thursday. The five opposition parties combined to defeat Carlsson's bill 190 to 153 came after a nationally televised six-hour debate. Six members were absent. The measure, aimed at ending strikes and controlling inflation, now at nearly 9 percent, would have frozen wages, prices, corporate dividends, rents and local taxes for two years. The bill was drafted after a bitter strike closed all of Sweden's banks earlier this year. Major cities also were threatened with strikes that would close down bus and subway operations, pre-schools and other municipal services. Right after the vote Thursday, Carlsson went to the office of Speaker Thage G. Peterson to hand in the government's resignation. Carlsson stays on with a caretaker Cabinet. The Social Democrats have governed Sweden for 51 of the last 57 years, but their prospects were jolted later Thursday when Swedish radio confirmed that Finance Minister Kjell-Olof Feldt would not stay on in any event. Carl Bildt, leader of the center-right Moderates, commenting before the report was confirmed: ``If it's true, it means the end of the government.'' Reports circulated for days that Feldt, a politician held in high esteem even by the non-socialist opposition, would leave. The Swedish news agency TT (Tidningarnas Telegrambyra) quoted an unidentified government source as saying government lack of support for Feldt's economic policies was the apparent reason he decided to step down. Social Democratic deputies told TT, on conditiion of anonymity, that Feldt's imminent resignation was more serious for the Social Democratic movement than the government crisis itself. The speaker later met privately with opposition leaders to sound them out about a new government. Another round of meetings is set for Friday morning. The government's resignation plunged Sweden into political confusion, with no party or alliance apparently able to form a workable government without major compromises. Political analysts said the most likely outcome would be a reconstituted Social Democratic government, with the tacit support of the Communists. The Social Democrats control 156 seats and the Communists 21 in the 349-member Riksdag. But that would require a major revision of the economic plan, which Carlsson argued was necessary to put a lid on inflation without jeopardizing the cornerstone policy of full employment. A possible alternative would be an alliance with the 20-member Environment party, which took a tough bargaining position in earlier negotiations. The Greens demanded heavy outlays for ecology and public transport and the scrapping of a new jet fighter under development. Bildt said the alliance of Social Democrats and Communists effectively blocked a non-socialist alternative, unless new elections were staged. ``Carlsson and his policy have failed and he has resigned. At the same time he's afraid to face the voters,'' Bildt said. Opinion polls published before the political uproar began gave the Social Democrats their worst showing in more than 45 years, with a 34 percent approval rating. But the three centrist parties, which governed in coalition from 1976 to 1982, also would not gain a majority in a new election, the polls predicted. If no one succeeds in organizing a new government, an election will be called 35 to 90 days after efforts break down. The next scheduled election is September 1991. In the debate, Carlsson told Parliament his program was aimed to defend full employment, which he called the ``basis of a fair society.'' He said the opposition criticized the wage-prize freeze without offering an alternative. He said Swedish products would soon be priced out of world markets _ a disaster for a nation of 8.5 million people relying heavily on exports. Independent economists blame the unemployment rate of about 1 percent for driving up prices and encouraging labor unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Army Orders 80,000 to Evacuate Homes in Western Uganda
DOC.TEXT: The army has ordered tens of thousands of people to abandon their homes in western forests and mountains that have been infiltrated by rebels, it was reported Thursday. New Vision newspaper said at least 80,000 people, mainly peasants, began leaving the slopes of the Rwenzori Mountains Jan. 15 after an estimated 500 guerrillas crossed the western border with Zaire. Smarts Kiggundu, the army commander in the region, 250 miles west of the capital Kampala, said the evacuation was necessary to ease the search for the rebels, New Vision reported. The Rwenzururu Movement, were led by Amon Bazira, a former member of ousted President Milton Obote's Cabinet is fighting the current government of President Yoweri Museveni. Crispus Kiyonga, finance minister and parliamentary representative in the region, has suggested housing the refugees on an airfield, according to the newspaper. A government official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the peasants are currently housed in school buildings, community halls, and unused public buildings. The Rwenzururu Movement, an obscure group formed in the 1950s, demanded a separate state when the British ruled the East African nation. The group continued agitating for a separate state even after Uganda's independence from Britain in 1962 but was considered by Ugandan authorities a mere nuisance. Museveni, who fought a five-year bush war against Obote, seized power in February 1986 after chasing from office the generals who had ousted Obote six months earlier.

DOC.HEAD: `Miss Margarida's Way,' Starring Estelle Parsons, Revived on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: You'd never confuse Miss Margarida with Mr. Chips or Miss Dove, those saintly molders of impressionable minds created by the Hollywood dream machine. Or even with Miss Grundy, the crotchety nemesis of Archie, Veronica, Jughead and all the rest of those perpetually teen-age students found only in the funny papers or comic books. Miss Margarida has more ferocious predecessors. Try Attila the Hun. Or Nero _ with a dash of Hitler, Stalin and just about any tinhorn South American dictator of the last 50 years. Miss Margarida could hold her own. She is the centerpiece of ``Miss Margarida's Way,'' Roberto Athayde's scathing political comedy about a tyrannical teacher who terrorizes her eighth-grade students _ and the audience as well. The play, first done on Broadway in 1977, was revived Thursday night at the Helen Hayes Theater with the same star, Estelle Parsons. The years haven't diminished Parsons' awesome performance. She's a hurricane, an actress riding a whirlwind of a part and not once falling off. The evening begins with a shattering school bell, as Miss Margarida strides to the stage _ a simple setting of desk and blackboards _ from the back of the theater. ``There's no good teacher without a good class,'' she intones unctuously. ``You must cultivate obedience.'' Obedience is what Miss Margarida is after in the course of Athayde's play. She'll get it any way she can. The woman will flirt, coo and carry on if that's what it takes. Learning is only incidental. A lesson in biology becomes a lesson in seduction as Miss Margarida fluffs her hair, applies makeup with a shovel and sashays around the stage. But when things don't go her way, she turns ugly. ``Miss Margarida's Way'' works on two levels. Athayde's play has obvious political connotations. The teacher can be seen as a metaphor for any repressive authority. The playwright, who is Brazilian, counted on that when his work was done in his own country in the early '70s. But it can also be seen as an absurdist comedy, an exercise in black humor about a teacher who gives lessons in the futility of life. ``Nobody asked your opinion about getting in and now you can't get out,'' Miss Margarida says to her class about what to expect from school and life. The script allows for a certain amount of give-and-take between actress and audience. And Parsons brilliantly takes anything theatergoers give and then throws it back at them. Not all of the shenanigans are spontaneous. There is also an actor planted in the audience, but his contribution is minimal in all the ruckus Parsons stirs up. The play gets a little messy and repetitive at times. The harangues turn shrill occasionally, but the star can pull out of a downward screech before it stops the show cold. A few words of warning. Don't show up late for school. If you do, you might find yourself on stage, sitting in a corner and wearing a dunce cap. And don't sass the teacher. Miss Margarida takes no prisoners.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Slept Aboard Air Force One, Too
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf: `Margaret Tutwiler,'' with two grafs to CORRECT that Bush helicoptered to Andrews with Bush, sted drove separately
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Drug Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Acting on an invitation from President Bush, travel-weary Secretary of State James A. Baker III also slept aboard Air Force One in a hangar at Andrews Air Force Base before flying Thursday to Colombia for a drug conference. He slept on a sofa, made into a bed, in a compartment used usually by first lady Barbara Bush that is partitioned from Bush's bedroom aboard the jetliner. Bush telephoned Baker with the offer Wednesday morning, and he accepted. He had returned Monday night from a nine-day trip to Czechoslovakia, the Soviet Union, Bulgaria, Romania and Canada that covered 15,490 miles. Margaret Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said Baker worked in his office until 6 p.m. Wednesday and then went home for dinner. Baker then went to the White House, where he joined Bush in the brief helicopter flight to the air base in Maryland where he boarded Air Force One in its hangar. Baker slept under light blue blankets that bear a black U.S. Air Force insignia. In 1979, former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance similarly slept aboard an Air Force jet in a hangar at Andrews before a pre-dawn departure on a trip to Ecuador.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa Says Poland Must Be German Reunification Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 14-15 `Such assurances...the Soviets' with 1 graf to CLARIFY that Poland not a country when invaded during WWI. Pickup 16th graf ``Nothing but...''
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa said Thursday Poland must be present at German unification talks where Polish borders are discussed, and President Wojciech Jaruzelski called it a ``question of life or death'' for Polish citizens. ``It is one-third of our territory, one-third of the population and 85 percent of our access to the sea,'' Jaruzelski said. ``For Germany, the (former German) territories that now belong to Poland ... are rather a question of history and sentiment, and sometimes a card in a electoral game,'' he told the German ARD television network in an interview, excerpts of which were also broadcast on Polish television. He said he recognizes Germany's right to self-determination, but a parallel right should exist for Poland, ``which has had heavy historic experiences and for which guarantees of stable borders are a question of life or death.'' Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki insists that Poland be at talks on reunification planned by East Germany, West Germany and the four occupying powers of World War II: the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France. Mazowiecki said Wednesday that Poland could not tolerate such talks being held without being there itself to make sure that a reunified Germany would respect Poland's western border _ which some Germans have challenged. Right-wing German politicians have never abandoned claims to 40,000 square miles of territory Poland was awarded from Germany at the end of World War II _ compensation for an even larger area taken from Poland by the Soviet Union. After meeting privately with Mazowiecki and discussing the German question, Solidarity leader Walesa endorsed his demand about Poland's attending talks. ``I think one cannot discuss Polish borders without Poland's presence,'' Walesa told reporters. He differed with Mazowiecki, however, in demanding on Thursday that the Red Army withdraw from Poland this year. Mazowiecki's Solidarity-led government has adopted a more tolerant attitude, saying the 40,000 Soviet troops in Poland should leave only after creation of a new security arrangement for Europe. Defense Minister Gen. Florian Siwicki cited ``stormy processes'' going on in Germany in issuing a statement Thursday which said withdrawal of Soviet troops from Poland must be approached ``very carefully.'' West German Foreign Minister Hans Dietrich-Genscher rejected on Thursday Poland's request to be included in the talks, but he repeated that no Polish territories would be included in the reunited Germany. Such assurances have been unconvincing for many Poles, whose homeland was the victim of a united Germany in two world wars. ``Nothing about us, without us,'' government spokesman Henryk Wozniakowski said Wednesday, quoting a Polish proverb to push the point that Poland should be at the German reunification talks. President Francois Mitterrand and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed on Thursday at a meeting in Paris that a European summit on German reunification would be desirable, probably in April after March 18 elections in East Germany. ``The German question can only be solved under a European roof,'' said Kohl, ruling out a neutral Germany as envisioned by East Germany's Communist leader, Hans Modrow. Kohl rebuffed a statement by Mitterrand that the Oder-Neisse line should immediately be recognized as a united Germany's eastern border with Poland. ``When we have a common government and Parliament, this government and Parliament will have to give the answer,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Calls Perestroika a Peaceful Revolution that Will Succeed
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet foreign minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, told Canadian lawmakers Thursday that the restructuring of Soviet economy and politics was a ``peaceful revolution'' that will succeed despite its foes. In a 40-minute, nationally televised address to a joint session of Parliament's defense and foreign affairs committees, Shevardnadze said of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms: ``It is a vexed process, a highly troublesome process. There are people who would prefer to see a different path of development and there are radicals on both sides. ``But it is, on the whole, a peaceful revolution. It's the development of a new society, a new sense of civic responsibility,'' he said. ``We believe in the success of perestroika.'' Legislation is being drafted for a total reform of economic relations which will include the right to private property, Shevardnadze said. ``We are excluding the exploitation of man by man. Everything else is permitted,'' the foreign minister said. He conceded that the Soviet Union is ``indeed sick'' with ethnic strife and economic problems, but said it is beginning to recover and ethnic clashes will be brought under control. ``We continue to think that in the very near future we will be successful in stabilizing the country. We understand that this is not just a concern for the Soviet people but also for the whole world. We recognize our responsibility to our own people and to the world,'' the Soviet minister said. Speaking in Russian through an interpreter, he admitted that past Soviet leaders sometimes hoped to ``squeeze the United States out of the European arena,'' but said the Kremlin now wants Canada and the United States ``highly involved'' in drafting new security, disarmament and economic arrangements for Europe. Shevardnadze indicated that Moscow wants the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to plan a new, peaceful order in Europe and believes it can serve as guarantor of Soviet security interests. The conference, which produced the Helsinki Accords on human rights, has as members all European countries except Albania, plus Canada and the United States. He said the conference must hold serious discussions on new military doctrines for Europe that would be based on defense, not offense. Shevardnadze challenged Washington to be more flexible with arms control on the high seas and in space. The minister said the Soviet Union welcomes the dramatic changes sweeping other East bloc countries, and that imposed ``distorted socialism'' there could not have continued indefinitely. He made clear it was up to the people of the two Germanys to decide their future, but suggested that Europe, the United States and Canada might hold a referendum on German unification so German leaders could see how others view the issue. Shevardnadze was in Ottawa for the Open Skies conference _ negotiations between NATO and the Warsaw Pact to allow unarmed surveillance flights over each other's territory. He stayed for a two-day official visit, returning to Moscow after his appearance at the parliamentary committees.

DOC.HEAD: Four Presidents Forge What Bush Calls `Anti-Drug Cartel'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 14-17: ``Bush returned,'' with remarks on plane
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and three Latin American leaders, conducting a tense summit under an air, sea and land security shield, forged agreement Thursday on a new joint drug-fighting strategy. Bush called it ``the first anti-drug cartel.'' Flanked by the leaders of the three largest cocaine-producing nations, Bush called the summit an ``ice-breaking'' event. He vowed to step up attempts to curtail the demand for narcotics at home, saying ``we are making progress'' but that more needs to be done. A joint communique signed by Bush and Presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia, Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia and Alan Garcia of Peru apparently ruled out the use of U.S. military forces in the Andean region. ``Each country may involve its armed forces in this fight within its own national territory,'' it said. In their meeting, they steered away from some of the most controversial drug initiatives, such as the idea of a naval cordon off Colombia, and chose instead to deal in broader themes. That helped keep harmony among sometimes differing leaders. Extraordinary security precautions were taken to protect Bush and his three summit partners, with some 5,000 uniformed troops watching over the proceedings. Battleships presented an imposing force off shore and helicopter gunships hovered nearby. But Colombian guerrillas made their own point, one of defiance. They kidnapped an American priest in Cali, the third U.S. citizen taken prisoner by rebels this week. Also, a small bomb exploded Thursday morning, 4{ miles from Barranquilla Airport, damaging a voltage regulator of a line that fed the air conditioning of the airport where Bush landed two hours later. Summing up his talks with the Latin American presidents, Bush told reporters, ``I owe it to the children of America, the United States, ... to these three presidents, to guarantee them that we will do everything we can to cut ... the demand for narcotics in the United States.'' That was a message that had been awaited by the three Andean president, who came to the summit complaining that the United States had not done enough at home to curtail demand for drugs. Back in Washington, D.C., the U.S. capital, federal prosecutors sent a separate message _ announcing the indictment of Mayor Marion Barry on eight counts of perjury and possession of a controlled substance. ``Every tactic and every weapon pales into insignificance compared to the need to reduce demand,'' Barco said. ``The only law that the narco-terrorists do not break is the law of supply and demand.'' Zamora, with a nod to the sweeping reforms that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev had introduced to his part of the world, said a new openness had been attained here. ``A perestroika has begun,'' he told reporters at a wind-up news conference. Zamora said the leaders had talked about creating an ``alternate economy'' so the peasants of the coca-growing and processing nations would not be dependent on the crop for their livelihoods. After the meetings, he said, ``We understand the true magnitude of the problem and how to face it.'' Bush returned to Washington on Air Force One without incident. William Bennett, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, told reporters on the return flight that the session was a success in that it developed a clearcut consensus between the United States and the three Andean drug-producing nations on developing a common drug-fighting strategy. ``This could be the day these things came to maturity,'' he said. Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aaronson said, ``This is a real sea-change in the international debate about drugs.'' At the end, Garcia, who once threatened to boycott the summit to protest the U.S. invasion of Panama, spoke of the need for a vigorous crop substitution program, and with a smile, asked, ``Where's the beef?'' Said Garcia: ``What has changed here is concepts, so that we never go back _ a better relationship between Latin America and the United States.'' Barco said, ``No,'' when asked if Colombia would be willing to have U.S. naval forces patrolling in international waters off Colombia's coast to keep track of drug shipments. ``It is not necessary,'' he said. Responding to Colombian complaints that U.S. trade policy has harmed its major legal exports such as coffee, cut flowers and sugar, Bush promised to work to help open more U.S. markets. In their communique, the summit nations called for a ``world conference against illicit drug trafficking in 1991.'' The four nations agreed to hold a high-level followup to Thursday's session within six months, but specified no level of U.S. aid to help the South Americans. Bush previously had pledged $2.2 billion over five years to aid the Andean countries economically and militarily in waging the drug war. He said Thursday he did not foresee any immediate increases in that commitment. But he did say the four had taken significant steps to work together on the problem. ``We in fact created the first anti-drug cartel.'' The statement recognized that persuading Andean farmers to substitute legal crops for coca, the leaves of which are used to make cocaine, would have ``significant, immediate and long-term economic costs'' on the three South American countries. Responding to Colombian complaints that U.S. trade policy has harmed its major legal exports such as coffee, cut flowers and sugar, Bush promised to work to help open more U.S. markets. U.S. officials also reached agreement with Bolivia to help stem the movement of U.S. firearms into South American nations and signed tax accords with both Bolivia and Peru aimed at establishing a system to trace drug profits and money-laundering schemes. Gunboats patrolled Cartagena Bay. The sparkling blue waterway was closed to harbor traffic. Frogmen checked the bay. Helicopters buzzed overhead. Some 5,000 security guards roamed the nearly empty streets. A squadron of fighter bombers and a fleet of warships stood by. Dogs sniffed for bombs. The bomb at Barranquilla airport exploded at a high-tension electricity tower in the village of Soledad, the manager of the electric comany for the state of Atlantico, Eduardo Berano de La Rosa told the Associated Press. He said he could not estimate how big the bomb was but from the little damage that it caused, it could not have been very powerful. No group has claimed responsibility for the bombing, he said. The president was ready to offer summit partners the use of Navy ships to cast a radar screen over Colombia to detect drug-carrying aircraft. But that idea aroused Latin American sensitivies last month when it was portrayed as a blockade. As a result, U.S. officials said Bush would not even mention the ship idea unless it was raised by someone else. U.S. officials warned in advance that Bush was not bringing more money beyond the aid package already presented, calling for $423 million for fiscal 1991 in military, law enforcement and economic assistance for the three countries. Bush's trip here was regarded largely as a gesture of solidarity with Barco, who has waged an unrelenting, six-month war against the drug lords. Colombian forces have seized tons of cocaine and hundreds of millions of dollars worth of property. They killed Gonzalo Rodrigues Gacha, a leader of the infamous Medellin cartel. It has not been a war without casualties. There have been 262 terrorist acts blamed on drug bosses since the government crackdown began Aug. 18. The attacks, mostly bombings, have claimed 209 lives.

Vietnamese forces may be operating again in Cambodia just five months after Hanoi reported all of its troops had been withdrawn for good, according to reports reaching top U.S. officials. The officials said Wednesday the reports indicate renewed Vietnamese involvement in the conflict was the result of battlefield setbacks suffered by the Hanoi-backed government in Cambodia. Representatives of the United States and the four other permanent members of the United Nations Security Council compared notes on the issue on Monday and Tuesday in New York where they discussed ways to advance the Cambodian peace process. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978 and installed a friendly government after ousting the Khmer Rouge regime, which has been held responsible for the deaths of more than 1 million Cambodians during almost four years in power.

A limited choice of contraceptives in the United States is leading to increases in abortions and voluntary sterilizations, according to a report by the National Research Council. Called ``Developing New Contraceptives,'' the study released Wednesday said Americans have fewer contraceptive choices than in other countries due to government policies that discourage research and product development. The contraceptive methods now available in the United States, the report said, ``leave major gaps in the ability of people to control fertility safely, effectively and in culturally acceptable ways.'' Contraceptives are used at some point in the lives of 95 percent of the 54 million sexually active American women between ages 15 and 44, the report said. It said about 20 percent of this number have been voluntarily sterilized.

Oscar voters all but ignored acclaimed, daring films like ``Drugstore Cowboy,'' and ``Do the Right Thing'' and cast their lots for mainstream titles such as ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' At the same time, the voters overlooked the year's box-office blockbusters ``Batman,'' ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' and ``Lethal Weapon 2.'' The nominations by the more than 4,700 members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences suggested that if independent filmmakers were looking for praise from Hollywood, they were looking in the wrong place. ``Do the Right Thing,'' writer-director Spike Lee's fiery account of racial confrontation in New York City, landed on 81 film critics' top 10 lists, and took the best picture, best director and best music awards from the Los Angeles Film Critics Association.

Perrier has ordered distributors worldwide to dump 160 million bottles of its bubbly water because a toxic chemical contaminated some shipments. Officials say the move will disrupt distribution for three months. In yanking shipments from distribution in 120 countries, Perrier President Gustave Leven said officials ``don't want the least doubt, as minimal as it might be, to weigh on the image of the quality and purity of our product.'' Officials estimated the recall will cost the company $35 million. Earlier this week, about 72 million bottles of Perrier were withdrawn from the U.S. market after benzene was detected in tests by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The recall was extended to Canada, and a Japanese subsidiary said it would withdraw Perrier from stores. Traces were also found earlier this week in samples from Denmark and the Netherlands, prompting a recall there. Perrier's distributor in Australia today ordered the recall of 40,000 cases.

EDITORS PHOTO EDITORS We are planning to move CART31, showing President Bush listening to Peruvian President Garcia, in color on the mainline. We are trying to get the photo in now from Cartagena, but can not give an exact time when it will begin moving due to phone line problems. The AP

DOC.HEAD: Albania Clings to Stalinism and Is More Isolated Than Ever
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Sheep now feed off grass and overgrown weeds covering millions of bunkers that were built years ago to seal off Albania. Today, the fight against the world's ``corrupting effects'' takes a different form. Western culture, although carefully monitored by bureaucrats and intellectuals, seeps through the increasingly porous borders of Europe's most isolated nation. Western ideas contrast sharply with Albanian orthodoxy but there is little open evidence of any grass-roots disaffection threatening to topple the last European refuge of Stalinism. Reports of anti-communist riots in the northern city of Skhoder in January apparently were unfounded. Officials here charge they were fabricated by the state-controlled media in Yugoslavia, which is at odds with Albania over the fate of millions of ethnic Albanians in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo. ``We do not want to assimilate; we want to preserve our national identity,'' said Ymer Minxhozi, general secretary of the Albanian Union of Journalists. ``We have no homosexuality, no prostitution, no drugs and no black market,'' he told a group of visiting Western journalists. The bunkers, first built during World War II to guard against a land invasion, were vastly expanded after the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact marched into Czechoslovakia in 1968. Now they are falling into disuse. No one knows exactly how many bunkers there are, but one official estimated at least one for every Albanian _ 3 million. ``The bunkers in Albania do not move ... they have no feet or wheels. They do not threaten anyone,'' Deputy Foreign Minister Socrat Placa said in an interview. During its 45-year history as a Stalinist state, Albania has had little to do with the world beyond its borders. It still reveres the memory of Josef Stalin and adheres strictly to Marxist-Leninist doctrine. Albania cut ties with the Soviet Union in 1961 because of its de-Stalinization program and with China in 1978 because of China's perceived deviation from Marxist-Leninist policies after Mao Tse-tung's death. Enver Hoxha, the founder of the communist state in Albania, died in 1985, but his policies and personality cult survive. A Hoxha museum opened last year, a marble and glass temple among Tirana's dilapidated and windowless buildings. Hoxha's successor, Ramiz Alia, is credited with introducing some openness and acknowledgement of deficiencies of the Albanian system. Mistrust and hostility toward Moscow and Washington remain, however. Placa made no effort to disguise his satisfaction when he heard a Western news report on a visiting reporter's radio of an explosion at a Soviet military base in Czechoslovakia. ``Good, good, very good. ... Of course it may have some consequences but is a good lesson for Gorbachev,'' Placa said. Nevertheless, Placa said, discussions were under way to further increase ties with ``both East and West.'' Albanians are able to view Italian, Yugoslavian and Greek television. Scrawled on a shutter of a backstreet shop in Tirana were the words, ``IRON MAIDEN,'' a leading British heavy-rock band. In another part of town, someone had repeatedly written ``liri'' (freedom) on a kiosk wall, an uncommon slogan in a country with a powerful secret police, the Sigurimi. Activities of the Sigurimi were assailed last year, however, in a best-selling novel by writer Neshat Tozaj, who works as a criminal investigator in the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The novel, ``Thikat'' (Knives), portrayed the Sigurimi as falsifying evidence and making illegal arrests and detentions. Publication of a book exposing abuses of the secret police could indicate a relaxation of censorship or, as some Western observers suggested, a power struggle to restrict the Sigurimi. ``The artistic qualities of the book were criticized but it touched on certain themes in our society. ... Life must be reflected in literature,'' said Nasi Lera, secretary of the Albanian Union of Artists and Writers. Authorities still want to stop controversial material about Albania from reaching abroad. Visiting Finnish television journalists found on their return home evidence of tampering with an interview with Foreign Minister Reiz Malile, which had been filmed by a local crew. Malile had acknowledged on camera that Albania had some political prisoners but added, ``It's not a problem.'' That section of tape was replaced by a segment of an Albanian song contest. Modern Western literature is translated into Albanian, and William Faulkner, Ernest Hemingway, Saul Bellow and Truman Capote are better known than Spanish, Italian or French writers, said Ismail Kadare, Albania's best-known modern author. ``We don't approve of pornography ... and our greatest problem is mediocrity. But that's a worldwide problem,'' Kadare added in an interview. ``The West definitely has a corrupting influence ... even though we must respect them for their marvelous scientific achievements and progress,'' a 21-year-old woman said. She added she would like to go abroad in a student exchange program, then said, ``But things are so good here.''
