DOC.HEAD: Soviet Jews in Israel Having to Prove They're Jewish
DOC.TEXT: Asya Gomelsky says she survived two pogroms in her 83 years but never expected her Jewishness to be called into question in Israel. That is what happened when Mrs. Gomelsky's 50-year-old son Boris asked the Interior Ministry for identity papers for his family now that it has arrived from the Soviet Union. The Gomelskys were turned down on grounds that they had no documents proving they were Jewish _ birth certificates, for example. Those who are rejected can get rent subsidies and other benefits as immigrants, but their ID cards do not say ``Jewish.'' Without that word, the they may have trouble with marriage, divorce or other personal matters controlled by Israel's ultra-Orthodox establishment. The Gomelskys' story and similar tales surfacing with the new rush of Soviet immigrants have sparked protests by Soviet activists and complaints by four Israeli liberal parties over policies of the Interior Ministry, which is controlled by the ultra-Orthodox Shas party. ``Do you know what it is to question the Jewishness of those who have suffered for generations in the Soviet Union for being Jewish,'' Robert Golan, head of a Soviet activist group, told the Jerusalem Post. Mrs. Gomelsky, who appeared on Israel Television after the rejection, touched many Israelis with the tale of her sufferings during Russia's 1917 Revolution and civil war. ``I survived two pogroms and was persecuted as a Jew, and here in Israel they tell me I'm not Jewish,'' Mrs. Gomelsky wept. ``In 1919 ... they wanted to rape my elder sister and when my father tried to protect her they cut him with sabers, and we ran away to hide in the fields.'' After the broadcast, several ministers questioned Interior Minister Arye Deri, a member of Shas, in a Cabinet meeting. Soviet activists warned the following day they would take to the streets over Deri's policies. But on a visit to Interior Ministry offices here a reporter found several recent Soviet arrivals who came for identity cards still were being turned away under the same policy. ``Go home and come back when you have papers showing you are Jews,'' an official told them. While law requires documentation, some Israelis maintain that in the case of Soviet immigrants it is better to risk the few who might be frauds than to humiliate the many who are not. For years, the Interior Ministry also has been ruled by the ultra-Orthodox, for whom the mostly secular wave of Soviet Jews can mean change. The expected arrival of up to 300,000 Soviet Jews in the next three years could undermine Israel's delicate balance of internal political power in which three ultra-Orthodox parties and a religious one usually hold the key to forming coalition governments. Neither of the country's two major parties, the right-wing Likud bloc or center-left Labor Party, has ever won enough seats in the 120-member Knesset, the Israeli parliament, to govern on their own. That means each scrambles to bring the religious parties into coalitions. Over the years, Israel's religious community used this power to pass laws favoring the Orthodox and enforce rules forcing businesses and entertainment spots to close from sundown Friday till sundown Saturday, the Sabbath. The ultra-Orthodox fear this may change with the Soviet Jewish immigration wave, which they claim includes many couples of mixed marriages and even non-Jews. In mid-January, the ultra-Orthodox weekly publication Yom Hashishi claimed that Israeli officials in Moscow ``reject immigration requests of elderly religious Jews, preferring young intellectual couples in spite of a large percentage of mixed marriages among them.'' ``This selection will change in the coming years the face of the Israeli society.'' Religious Affairs Minister Zevulun Hammer fueled the controversy by saying up to 30 percent of the Soviet immigrants were non-Jews trying to find a way to get out of the Soviet Union. Israel's Law of Return grants automatic citizenship to Jews _ including descendants of Jewish men _ and their spouses, even if they are non-Jewish. The Orthodox establishment recognizes as Jews only descendants of a Jewish mother or persons who underwent an Orthodox conversion. It wants the law changed to include this definition. To back up their case, Religious Affairs Ministry officials announced they found 30 non-Jews who allegedly used false papers to come to Israel last year, when some 12,000 Soviet Jews immigrated. ``Each day, there're infiltrations of non-Jewish immigrants,'' complained Yigal Bibi of Hammer's National Religious Party. In protesting the Interior Ministry policy on birth certificates, Yair Tzaban of the leftist Mapam Party said it was better ``to risk accepting a small number of non-Jews ... disguising themselves as Jews, rather than humiliate thousands of others.''

DOC.HEAD: Many Parochial Schools Merge To Cut Costs And Boost Efficiency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS from 4.6 million students to 5.6 million in 10th graf. Moved originally as b0233 Feb. 14.
DOC.TEXT: About a dozen Roman Catholic parishes in downtown Milwaukee pooled resources to form a centralized school system with four campuses. Also, on the city's south side, plans are mapped to link 42 parochial schools into a regional system, with a joint board, budget and shared facilities and staff. The aim is both to combine resources to strengthen the schools and effect economies through interparish distribution of costs, said the the Rev. Ralph C. Gross, chancellor of the Milwaukee Archdiocese. ``We're trying to take some of the school pressure off individual parishes so they can be more fruitful, worshiping communities,'' he added. Such changes in many cities signal a gradual but far-reaching transformation in the church's patterns for educating the young. Under strains of financing and personnel, the single-parish parochial school is fading before the larger cooperative enterprises, but with special efforts to preserve an intimate atmosphere and close ties with parents. ``All sorts of new patterns are emerging,'' said Sister Catherine T. McNamee, president of the National Catholic Educational Association in Washington She said the ``restructuring of schools,'' including consolidations, mergers for different grade levels and other collaborative configurations have come as populations shifted among city areas and to suburbs. However, the combinations seek to maintain a basis in geographical proximity, she said, such as urban ethnic parishes a few blocks apart, of French, Polish and Italian origins for example, forming a joint school. ``Now they've combined for the whole neighborhood,'' she said. Various difficulties have cut Catholicism's elementary and secondary schools in half over the last quarter century, reducing 5.6 million students in 12,300 schools in 1965 to 2.6 million students in 8,800 schools now. But despite continuing problems, including added expenses of lay teachers that pervasively have replaced the once low-cost but now scarce teaching sisters, the school shrinkage seems abated. ``It's pretty much stablized,'' Sister McNamee said, noting that some enrollments are edging back up, expanding rapidly in the lower grades. ``We're holding up fairly well now.'' Similar comments came from several dioceses, where checks found many of them consolidating former single-parish schools. Past decline ``is tapering off,'' said the Rev. George Norton of the Rochester, N.Y., diocese. Realignments connecting some schools or prospects of it were reported in St. Louis; Baltimore; Green Bay, Wis., Newark, N.J., Cleveland and Brooklyn, among others. In Erie, Pa., the dioscesan chancellor, Monsignor Robert Smith said a newly established advisory board was weighing various linkages of schools and parishes. ``It's the challenge of the times for being viable,'' he said. The church's huge outlay for schools for the nation's young parallels the efforts of public schools but with one glaring difference _ no help from community taxes. Sister McNamee pointed out that families of children going to Catholic schools pay full taxes for public schools ``but get no benefit from it'' or any relief in maintaining the alternative system. She said it would cost public schools an estimated additional $10 billion annually to take on the load of enrollments in Catholic schools, but Catholics alone have to bear it, while also paying public school taxes. Not only that, she said but 12.3 percent nationally of youngsters in Catholic schools are non-Catholics. The proportion is much higher in inner- city Catholic schools, whose enrollments run from 60 percent to 80 percent non-Catholic. The Rev. Philip J. Murnion, director of the National Pastoral Life Center, said Catholic financing of a ``major alternative'' school system for whites, blacks, Chinese or whatever without public help is a ``whole new mission.'' ``It's a remarkable process funded by the Catholic conscience,'' he said, noting that it also undergirds freedom of choice in education. Studies indicate that academic effectiveness of Catholic schools surpasses that of public schools. What has greatly increased the costs of church schools is the steep, prolonged decline in sisters who in the 1940's provided 92 percent of the teachers, with only 8 percent lay people. Now it's about reversed. Eighty-five percent now are lay people, their pay necessarily considerably higher but still ``very modest and way back of public schoolteachers,'' Sister McNamee said. ``It's nowhere near where it should be.'' The turnabout from religious sisters to lay teachers came as the total number of nuns in the country fell from a peak of 181,400 in 1965 to only 104,400 now, a decline of 76,000.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Prisoner: Enough Violence
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Doherty, who has fought British rule in Northern Ireland with rocks, rifles and machine guns, has a new weapon of choice clipped to the breast pocket of his orange prison overalls. ``I've come to believe that the pen is mightier than the sword,'' he said in an interview at the federal jail where he's spent 6{ years. ``That's my message when I do an interview or answer a letter. I don't say, `Up the IRA!' or `Send more arms.' I don't mention the IRA. I stress what you can do politically to change things.'' Doherty, who pronounces his name DOCK-erty, has ample time to reflect on the advantages of the ballot box to the bomb. He has been at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan longer than any inmate in its history, longer even than most of its guards. He has done his time under three wardens and four captains. Doherty's path to the MCC began a decade ago with a gunfight in Belfast between his IRA unit and British troops. Doherty was captured and convicted of murdering a British officer. Facing two life terms, he escaped from jail and fled to New York City, where he was arrested by the FBI in 1983. The British demanded his extradition, but a federal judge accepted Doherty's argument that the killing was not a common crime but a political act, part of the IRA's campaign to drive the British from Northern Ireland's six counties and reunite the province with the Irish Republic. Doherty could not be extradited. Doherty's case has since bounced from court to court; the British have not been able to get him back, but he has not been able to go free, despite more than a half-dozen court rulings in his favor. His case has become a metaphor for his homeland's intractable troubles. To Irish nationalists and human rights activists, Doherty is ``a symbol of the battle against tyranny,'' according to Paul O'Dwyer, former New York City Council president and an activist for the Irish cause. Doherty's prison visitors have included Cardinal John J. O'Connor, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and 10 congressmen. In his victory speech, Mayor David Dinkins demanded ``Justice for Joe Doherty!'' More than 100 members of Congress have signed resolutions supporting his requests for bail and asylum, and similar measures have passed several dozen state, county and local legislatures. But Doherty's musings about the limits of armed rebellion have upset some Irish nationalists. Late last year the New York Daily News quoted him as saying that the IRA's armed rebellion ``can't go on,'' that its ``strategy hasn't worked,'' and that it should consider a unilateral cease-fire. ``I see another soldier shot dead by the IRA and I think, I read this five years ago, 10 years ago, 20 years ago,'' he said. ``If we carry this war on another 20 years, it'll be such a waste of life.'' In an interview two days after his 35th birthday last month, Doherty smiled ruefully and shifted in his chair when he was asked about the reaction to his relatively dovish comments. ``A lot of people have said to me, `You're in prison, Joe, you're away from the situation.''' One of his critics is Michael Flannery, an elderly IRA veteran and its best-known American supporter. He said Doherty's emphasis on political rather than military tactics shows ``he doesn't know Irish history.'' Politics and diplomacy have failed the Irish in the past, Flannery said, because they lend legitimacy to British-created institutions yet do not strike at the source of British power. Doherty said some of his remarks have been taken out of context; he still supports the IRA and does not regret having fought the British. But he also said that since his imprisonment his views have changed. He described himself as part of a generation that is determined to end the war that flared 20 years ago when British soldiers, sent to protect Northern Ireland's Catholic minority from Protestant attacks, clashed with a revived IRA. ``My generation is taking over now, and we're more flexible, more willing to compromise, less nationalistic,'' he said. One summer Doherty was visited by an 11-year-old nephew who was about to return to Belfast. Doherty said that when he asked the boy what he was going to do when he returned home, he replied, ``I'm going to join the IRA and shoot British soldiers.'' ``I don't want little Sean to be sitting at the kitchen table, stripping a Thompson machine gun like I was,'' Doherty said. ``I don't want this to get passed to another generation.'' Doherty repeatedly expressed optimism, rare in discussions of Northern Ireland, that political and diplomatic initiatives could soon bring peace. ``Look at Eastern Europe. The world's changing so fast,'' he said, snapping his fingers. ``This puts a lot of pressure on the British. They'll soon be the only nation in Europe with troops on the street.'' He said the consolidation of the European Economic Community in 1992 will make the border between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic seem all the more absurd and offer the British a convenient excuse to go home. The IRA should consider a cease-fire, he suggested, and measure the British response. The British, he predicted, would grab a chance to negotiate a gradual pullout. Doherty states his case calmly and eloquently. Since the age of 17, he has spent all but 18 months of his life on the lam or behind bars, and the jailhouse has been his schoolhouse. Virtually illiterate when he left school, Doherty learned Gaelic, Irish history and debating in a camp for IRA prisoners outside Belfast. Doherty's education has continued at the MCC, even though his maximum security status forbids classroom attendance. He subscribes to many publications, answers 20 to 30 letters a day and writes messages for rallies and meetings, many of them related to his defense. He also writes poetry. Two of his poems have won prizes in federal prison system competitions; one brought him a check for $25 courtesy of Edwin Meese III, whose decision as attorney general had kept him in jail. Despite his frustration over his case, which now is before the U.S. Court of Appeals in New York, Doherty is confident about Northern Ireland. ``The war is coming to an end, after 800 years,'' he said. ``As soon as the British leave, I'll burn my (IRA) beret. The IRA is only the symptom, the product of a situation that never worked.''

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Another Look: Doherty
A Life in Jail and in Court
DOC.TEXT: Some significant dates in the case of Joseph Doherty, an Irish Republican Army soldier convicted of murder in Northern Ireland who is being held in a federal jail in New York: 1971 _ At age 16, already a member of an IRA youth group in Belfast, he is detained and questioned for three days by police. 1972 _ Jailed five months on suspicion of subversion. 1973 _ Jailed nine months for illegal possession of a pistol. 1974 _ Arrested when van in which he is riding is found to contain explosives; sentenced to 12 years, plus 18 months for trying to escape. 1979 _ Convicted in the murder of a British officer in a gunfight between British troops and Doherty's four-man IRA unit. 1981 _ Facing two life sentences, breaks out of jail. 1982 _ Flees to New York City after several months hiding in Ireland. 1983 _ Arrested by FBI; British seek his extradition. 1984 _ Federal judge bars extradition, ruling that officer's killing was not a common crime but an act related to IRA's political goal of a unified Ireland. 1985 _ U.S. government seeks Doherty's deportation; he opposes the move but says that if deported, he wants to go to Republic of Ireland. 1986 _ Immigration judge orders Doherty deported to Irish Republic; U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service appeals, seeking to deport him to United Kingdom. 1987 _ Board of Immigration Appeals rejects INS. 1987 _ The Irish Republic approves a new extradition agreement that virtually ensures Doherty would be handed over to the British if deported to the republic. Doherty switches tactics and seeks political asylum in United States. 1988 _ Citing U.S.-British relations, Attorney General Edwin Meese III reverses immigration judges and orders Doherty deported to United Kingdom. 1988 _ Board of Immigration Appeals grants Doherty a hearing on political asylum request. 1989 _ Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, Meese's successor, reverses appeals board and bars asylum hearing. 1990 _ Doherty's lawyers challenge Meese and Thornburgh rulings before federal appeals court.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, Feb. 19

DOC.HEAD: 28 Haitian Children Adjust to New Life in America
An AP Photo Package
LaserPhotos NY330-333 on schedule
DOC.TEXT: Kathy Blackburn perches on a stool in front of 28 bowed heads, bullhorn in hand, repeating the Lord's Prayer. A burst of giggles erupts, but the mother of this brood _ 17 boys and 11 girls _ is a picture of tolerance. ``I hear kids from the time I wake up until the time I go to sleep,'' she says. Then she adds, ``There are times I've been frantic.'' Mrs. Blackburn, 42, and her husband, Dan, 45, came home to Indiana at the end of December. The two Christian missionaries and their wards, all orphaned or abandoned Haitian children ranging in age from 3 to 14, are temporarily living in a drafty church camp about 50 miles southeast of Indianapolis. The Blackburns, who have two grown children of their own, began taking in homeless children shortly after becoming missionaries in 1969 and at one time thought about opening an orphanage. Now they plan to adopt all the children, four of whom are mentally retarded. In 1987, violence in Haiti forced the Blackburns to flee to the Dominican Republic. Last December, they finally received permission from the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service to bring the children to the United States. The children are Rosie and Mary, both 14; Becky, Yvonne and Jim, 12; Tom, Sam, Bobby, Cheryl and Jo Anna, 11; Steve, Marva and Liz, 10; Jemima, Abigail, Aaron, Jeremiah, Benji, Noah and Gideon, 9; Matthew and Jake, 8; Rachael, 7; Thaddeus, 6; Mike and Caleb, 4, and Andy and Mark, 3. In Haiti, the family had a house; in Indiana, they sleep in a dormitory heated by a wood stove and use an outdoor privy. Down the lane is the ``chow house,'' the hub of the family's social life. A hand-made sign posted on the refrigerator says:``A late meal is a hardship with 28 kids. Please have consideration for the cook. Thanks.'' Blackburn does the cooking and supervises the older boys, who wash dishes and sweep floors. The girls do the laundry and care for the younger children, giving baths and changing clothes. Mrs. Blackburn says the secret to managing 28 children and a household is not to fear mistakes. Parenthood is ``something you can't cram for at the last minute,'' she says. ``We do it by making mistakes, by trial and error. ... It's just something you keep working at.'' The Blackburns have many of the same dreams other parents have. ``I'd like them to have music lessons, learn to ride a bike, know history and know it well, and be well-educated within their own bounds,'' Mrs. Blackburn says. The children are taught by the Blackburns and volunteer teachers, who come to the camp to give lessons in math, science, reading, writing and sign language, the last a device to keep the noise level down. ``These kids aren't overstimulated,'' Mrs. Blackburn says. ``They enjoy stuff more. A jet going overhead and a beautiful sunset is a really big deal. They not only appreciate, but they comment on it.'' Rosie recently went with Blackburn to a department store, where she took her first elevator ride. ``It's continual questions. Even getting into a car is a big deal for them,'' Blackburn says. As part of their arrangement with immigration authorities, the Blackburns may not accept government support. Instead, they rely on regular donations from about 20 churches and whatever else comes in. Local businesses have donated secondhand clothes and leftover baked goods. The family has received clothes, food, toys and money from strangers who have heard about them in news reports. ``We're not taking a vow of poverty, but one of the things I want to discourage is excess, the mindset that you don't need one thing, you need 10,'' Mrs. Blackburn says. The Blackburns' most pressing need is permanent shelter. The church camp opens May 1, and they must be out. The Rev. Lee Creech, who has supported the Blackburns' missionary work for 20 years, heads a committee seeking a home for them. ``More people are in awe than anything else that someone would attempt to do this,'' says Creech, pastor at New Bethel United Methodist church in Decatur County. ``I think it's the best way for someone else to say, `I am my brother's keeper.'''

DOC.HEAD: `The Kennedys of Boston' _ Slow Start, But Worth Watching
DOC.TEXT: ABC's miniseries, ``The Kennedys of Massachusetts,'' begins so slowly that viewers who tune in the first episode are likely to tune out the rest. More's the pity, for there are worthwhile things in this production. What saves the miniseries from Hollywood's usual Kennedy hagiography is splendid acting, not William Hanley's dramatization of Doris Kearns Goodwin's best seller, ``The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys.'' The best performance is that of William Petersen as Joseph P. Kennedy Sr., an unusual stretch for an actor best remembered for the film ``Manhunter,'' in which he played an emotionally maimed FBI agent tracking a serial killer. Petersen creates a living, breathing Joe Sr. from scant material, and his aging of the character is much more than makeup. An underrated actor, Petersen can only boost his reputation with work like this. Praise also goes to William Weber, who plays the weedy young JFK from the inside out. Weber's effective performance hauntingly captures JFK's manner and characteristic charm without forcing the lace-curtain Irish accent. A startlingly mature Tracy Pollan plays the rebellious debutante Kathleen ``Kick'' Kennedy, who defied her parents to marry outside the Roman Catholic Church. Pollan creates a believable Kick, and when her character is killed in a wartime plane crash, a great deal of energy leaves the miniseries. As Rosemary Kennedy, Deidre Lovejoy plays with strength and dignity the mentally retarded daughter drowning in a family of overachievers. Randle Mell, with perhaps five minutes on screen, evokes a genial Bobby Kennedy who was a poised, astute political operative. Praise goes also to production designer Jan Scott and cinematographer Laszlo Scott, who filled lush interior locations with golden light and detailed period touches, letting the actors dominate the foreground. All that said, ``The Kennedys'' ultimately fails under director Lamont Johnson's misguided attempt to keep faith with a 1,000-page history of 55 years of private and public Kennedy lives. It's too much material, even for a miniseries. ``The Kennedys'' has triumphs and tragedies aplenty, but its stuttering, episodic pace forces a simplistic narrative and paints details with a broad brush, creating a false history from what is only ``historical drama.'' The seeming eternal first episode focuses on Mayor John ``Honey Fitz'' Fitzgerald (Charles Durning) and publican-ward boss P.J. Kennedy (Pat Hingle) and the courtship of their children, Rose Fitzgerald (Annette O'Toole) and Joe. Durning and Hingle, two of America's great character actors, have six minutes to evoke Boston's bloody ward politics from a script that only casually implies Honey Fitz's red-handed role in them. And there is a stupid anachronism. It is 1906 and Rose asks Harvard freshman Joe if he's read ``The Jungle'' by Upton Sinclair. ``Isn't that one of those `Tarzan of the Apes' books?'' he facetiously replies. No, Joe, ``Tarzan of the Apes'' won't be published until 1914. If you'd said ``Kipling, eh?'' we might have bought it. ``The Kennedys'' picks up steam when Joe, who is becoming one of the richest men in America, extends his business and extramarital ventures to Hollywood. After his notorious love affair with actress Gloria Swanson (excellently played by Madolyn Smith Osborne) ends and Joe wraps up his Hollywood interests, ``The Kennedys'' sinks into another trough in its sine-wave emotional scheme. Another sustained peak arrives with Joe Sr.'s appointment as U.S. ambassador to Britain and the young adulthood of Jack, Kick, and Joe Jr. (played by Campbell Scott) as the world plummets into war. Sadly, Jack's reluctant entry into politics and his rise to the presidency seem to take up only about 15 minutes and the story ends at his inaugural speech in 1961.

Alas, she wryly told a New York advertising industry lunch this week, their chat was two weeks ago, before Trump and his wife split. Poking fun at herself, Chung said she now realized ``why he answered some questions the way he did. I said, `Is your wife, Ivana, your best friend?' And he said, `I wouldn't call it my `best' friend.'' Later in the interview, Chung said, ``I said, `What are you missing in life?' And he said, `Excitement.'''

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe's Challenge
Part V: Japan Lukewarm to Expanding Business in Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits.
DOC.TEXT: When Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu toured Europe last month he demonstrated Japan's economic might by announcing almost $2 billion in aid to Poland and Hungary, dwarfing what the United States has committed. In contrast, private Japanese industries, known for their aggressive expansion elsewhere, are reluctant to plunge into a part of the world they see as inexperienced, ill-equipped and still emerging from 40 years of communism. A few prominent deals have been done. Suzuki Motor Co., for example, recently agreed to set up an automobile plant in Hungary, the first Japanese company to enter a joint venture with Eastern Europe since the tumultuous political changes there. But Eastern Europe remains virtually untouched by Japanese business. In 1988, Japan trade with the region totaled about $1.47 billion, excluding the Soviet Union. That's less than 1 percent of Japanese trade worldwide. Although many Japanese firms have offices in Eastern European nations, only about a dozen joint ventures have been established. No Japanese company has yet invested in Poland, East Germany or Czechoslovakia. Japanese businessmen have a range of reasons for holding back. High inflation rates, a heavy debt burden and inconvertible currencies make it difficult to profit in Eastern Europe, in their view. Restrictions on exports of high technology to the East bloc, a vestige of the Cold War that remains entrenched, also have reduced the spectrum of trade opportunities for the Japanese, who are leading exporters of high-tech items. Nonetheless, the changing political and economic landscape of Eastern Europe has piqued Japan's interest. The government has allocated $750 million for export insurance to encourage Japanese firms to trade there. To Daihatsu Motor Co., however, economic reform and Japanese government aid cannot alleviate the tremendous risks it sees. One of Japan's smallest automobile manufacturers, Daihatsu has tried for more than five years to set up an assembly plant in Poland. Although it developed an ambitious plan to build a 12,000-vehicle-a-year plant with Polish automaker FSO, Daihatsu failed to acquire enough financing and the plan collapsed. Last fall, FSO approached Daihatsu again. This time, said spokesman Wataru Shindo, the company has considerably scaled down plans _ it will export about 6,000 unassembled Charade models to Poland. ``We don't know whether we'll be able to meet our costs. At a scale of 5,000 to 6,000 cars, even if we fail there will be little damage done,'' Shindo said. Japan's largest glass manufacturer expressed the same caution. Asahi Glass Co. has been negotiating with Poland to set up a plate glass factory in the southern city of Sandomierz. The risks remain high, said Asahi official Shigehiko Tomita, and no commitment has been made. Tomita said trade insurance and other Japanese government support was necessary, but stability in Eastern Europe was more important. ``The political and economic situation in Poland is still fluid, and the risks great. The country has high inflation, and even though we think that democratization will proceed, we need to have some protection,'' he said. Shigeki Ura, a senior officer with merchant trader C. Itoh and Co. in Eastern Europe, doubted Japanese firms will attempt any large-scale investments. Nevertheless, he added, ``As businessmen specializing in the Eastern European market, we should not be so optimistic, but not so pessimistic. Economic reform and democracy will give us chances.'' Ura said Japanese firms differ fundamentally from European firms in their attitude toward developing the Eastern European market. The Japanese want clear-cut laws in place specifying what is permissible for foreigners, but some European investors are willing to overlook legal vaguenesses, Ura said. Despite Japan's reluctance, its neighbor South Korea seems eager to exploit opportunity in Eastern Europe. Yoo Chang-soon, chairman of the Federation of Korean Industries, South Korea's largest business organization, said recently that ``prospects are bright'' for direct investment there. ``Some big entrepreneurs have already studied plans for direct investment in communist countries,'' he said. South Korea established diplomatic relations with Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia only last year and has a $91 million trade surplus with those countries.

DOC.HEAD: After the Lambada _ the Funana
DOC.TEXT: Why get all hot and sweaty thrashing about the dance floor to a lambada when you can grind your hips and still keep your cool to the beat of a funana, a tabanca or a coladera? Attention music lovers, the next dance craze could very well come from Cape Verde, one of the world's original musical melting pots. ``We Cape Verdians take our music at least as seriously as our politics, but it's difficult to talk of original and indigenous here,'' said Tober da Silva, a high school teacher in Praia and a music historian. ``Over the course of time, music has profitted, though some people would say suffered, from our crossroads position between Africa and America,'' added Mario Bettencourt, who as ``Russo'' plays bass with Cape Verde's top pop group, Os Tubaroes (The Sharks). ``We've drawn influences from every people that has passed through here,'' he said. And those peoples are many. Jutting out of the tropical Atlantic, 385 miles off the West African coast, the 10 formerly Portuguese volcanic islands first flourished as a trading post for African slaves bound for the Americas. The slaves left behind basic African rhythms, before exporting them to Brazil, where the Angolan semba became the samba. The islands eventually became a mid-ocean crossover point for whaling ships, then cargo steamboats and more recently jets from three continents. Crew and tourists from South American ships re-imported the altered, syncopated beat. Also lured to South America were Cape Verdian musicians who had adopted strains of Portugal's melancholy fado folk songs and fused everything into what Russo calls Cape Verde's mournful ``Afro-Latin'' sound. There's been a growing Western interest in international or ethnic music. In recent years, American and European musical tastes have made stars of such musicians as Senegalese singer Youssou ``the Lion'' N'dour, Brazil's Milton Nascimento, Polish singer Basia and salsa's Ruben Blades. And in recent months, the French-marketed Brazilian lambada _ a sexy, gyrating dance to a Latin-rock beat _ has become an international commercial success. ``The lambada's success should help us get a more international projection,'' said Zeca Couto, keyboard player for Tubaroes. The band consists of seven musicians, whose regular jobs range from import-export clerk to chief of protocol at Cape Verde's parliament. Tubaroes has a new contract with a Lisbon-based recording company to release two new discs this year. Their last album, ``Bote, Broce e Linha'' _ what fishermen say in Portuguese Crioulo when casting their lines _ sold around 10,000 copies. The group considers that to be a heady success, shared only by Cape Verdian musicians who have emigrated. But the Tubaroes' deep-rooted belief in music of the people, for the people and by the people won't let success go to their heads. They still jam four nights a week in a ramshackle storeroom, before singing weekends in their Di Nos nightclub in Praia, where Cape Verdians dance the funana and coladera. ``I don't agree with living abroad. People (abroad) don't experience the day-to-day life here and so they can't make real Cape Verdian music,'' said Ildo Lobo, the group's frontman and vocalist. The group sing mornas, slow, melancholy songs about typical problems of island life. But even their up-tempo funanas and coladeras have bitingly critical texts. According to da Silva, those songs, traditionally accompanied only by accordion and a two metal bars scraped together and called ``ferrinho,'' were banned before independence from Portugal in 1975. ``We deal with problems faced by women ... with emigration _ every house in these islands has some sort of problem linked with emigration,'' Lobo said. Some 700,000 Cape Verdians have left the islands in search of a better life. More than 350,000 live and work in the United States, primarily in Massachussetts and Rhode Island. The Tubaroes have played in Boston five times. ``We're still subject to imported influences. Our people abroad send us all types of music, and we are changing. But what you hear most here is Cape Verdian,'' Lobo said. But Cape Verdians don't ignore culture from other parts of the world. At one main crossroads in downtown Praia a group of schoolchildren sporting Bob Marley shirts and rastafarian hair styles dance to the latest craze _ zouk music from the French Antilles. On the wall behind them, graffiti artists have written the names Madonna and Michael Jackson.

DOC.HEAD: TACOMA: and punished.''
DOC.TEXT: Treatment in most states combines two approaches. One teaches offenders to sabotage deviant fantasies by sniffing something unpleasant like ammonia or by imagining the consequences, such as police breaking into a bedroom and catching a child molester in the act. The second approach uses group and individual therapy to break through the wall of denial and rationalization sex offenders use to convince themselves their behavior is OK. More intrusive techniques have been tried, including shock therapy and so-called chemical castration, the use of hormones to reduce sex drive. But no treatment has produced anything better than inconclusive results, Petrella said. And even methods that are encouraging by medical standards _ say, a treatment that keeps two-thirds of sex offenders from repeating their crime _ are unacceptable by social standards. In the end, letting a single Earl Shriner back on the streets is a risk few are willing to take. Since Shriner's attack on her son, Helen Harlow has learned a lot about sex crimes. She's learned that people who abuse others often were abused as children. She even looked at Shriner once in court and wondered how he must feel to have a jury deciding the rest of his life. But compassion goes only so far. Doctors say corrective surgery performed on the boy since last May and additional operations as he matures should make him physically whole again. But the family may never be rid of the emotional pain inflicted by Shriner. ``A lifetime sentence is a lifetime sentence,'' Harlow said. ``We were given one, and I think he deserves one, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Congress, in Decade of Brain, Considers Curbing Commemorations
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Entering the Decade of the Brain, Congress, which so designated the 1990s, is thinking about curbing its habit of passing resolutions to commemorate days, weeks, months and years for causes somebody deems worthy. The thinking probably will go on for quite a while, because commemorative measures are a quick, cut-rate, harmless way to do a favor for a constituent, a contributor or an interest group. While the brains behind this mini-reform say all those resolutions waste time and money and make Congress look silly, passing them is one of the things the House and Senate do most efficiently. In the first year of the current Congress they cranked out 88, including the brain decade, National Library Card Sign-up Month and the International Year for Bible Reading. Some are a bit tricky. Congress voted to designate last July 14 as National Day to Commemorate the Bastille Day Bicentennial. It also set aside National Tap Dance Day, which was May 25, although the measure marking that occasion didn't pass until five months after it was over. That parliamentary lapse was not typical _ most name-the-day measures pass quickly and unanimously. ``Somewhere along the way, we've let our zeal for commemoratives get out of hand,'' said Sen. Ernest F. Hollings, D-S.C., introducing a bill to restrain the practice. Reps. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., and Claudine Schneider, R-R.I., proposed similar measures last year, and there are more than enough co-sponsors to pass a bill should it get to a House vote. Reform, after all, is as safe and popular a pursuit as passing commemorative resolutions. A decade ago, Congress adopted only 34 commemorative resolutions. In the 100th Congress, the count was up to 258. Hollings said the current 101st Congress probably will produce more than 300. At a House hearing earlier this month, McCurdy said the practice feeds the public perception that Congress wastes too much time on trivia. Schneider called it an embarrassment and said it makes members of Congress look foolish. To cut the crop of congressionally endorsed observances, the bills propose creation of an advisory commission on national commemorative events to sort through all the proposals and decide which ones deserve to be designated. The panel would be authorized to recommend its chosen days, weeks and months directly to the White House. That way, such an occasion as National Pledge of Allegiance Day, last observed on Sept. 8, 1989, could be proclaimed without further action. The commission would be patterned on one that now screens the thousands upon thousands of commemorative stamp proposals the Postal Service gets each year, helping to winnow them to the 40 or so that finally are issued. It would have 11 members, including two from the House and two from the Senate. That sounds like the makings of a new, if miniature, bureaucracy. The sponsors of the bills say not, and insist the system they propose would cost less than Congress is spending now to produce, process and print its flood of commemorative resolutions. Hollings said the commission members would be reimbursed for their expenses when they met but would operate without any paid staff. But advisory commissions do have a way of hiring help and posting claims on the budget. The Congressional Budget Office thinks any savings on commemorative resolutions would be more than offset by the cost of the new panel. Hollings argues that the current way exacts other costs, diverting the time and energies of Congress members and aides from substantive work. ``We should honor our constituents not by passing commemorative after commemorative, but by spending our time working on legislation that will make a real difference in their lives,'' Hollings said. Meanwhile, the occasions to be noted in the new session of Congress are accumulating _ Federal Employees Recognition Week, Drinking Water Week, Be Kind to Animals Week, just to commemorate a few. And about that brain decade, which began Jan. 1. It was designated in connection with the 160th anniversary of the birth of a Silas Mitchell, credited with founding the science of neurology. ``The decade of the brain,'' said Rep. Silvio O. Conte, R-Mass., when he proposed the resolution. ``Think about it.''

DOC.HEAD: THE GRAMMYS 1990
Going to Jail for Rock 'n' Roll
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Too $hort in 22nd graf, A year ..., is cq; ``License to Ill'' in 39th graf, ``The Beastie ..., is cq.
DOC.TEXT: ``I don't see that any type of music would have any bad influence on people. I just can't figure it out ...'' _ Elvis Presley.

Rock 'n' roll. Kids love it, parents hate it. And as the music industry celebrates itself at the 32nd annual Grammy Awards on Wednesday, parents groups, religious organizations and state legislatures have declared war on rock. Some rock lyrics, they say, advocate sex, drugs, subversion and violence, and they aim to put a stop to that. For more than 30 years, rock 'n' roll has been a multibillion-dollar winner for record companies. But for every tune welcomed by parents such as Billy Joel's ``We Didn't Start the Fire,'' which has been praised for offering youngsters an instant history lesson, others are condemned as unfit for children. Legislators have stepped in with a direct message. It's a small, yellow flourescent sticker on records, compact discs and cassettes: ``Warning: May contain explicit lyrics descriptive of or advocating one or more of the following: suicide, incest, bestiality, sadomasochism, sexual activity in a violent context, murder, morbid violence, illegal use of drugs or alcohol.'' That's what a bill recently passed by the Pennsylvania House of Representatives would require for records containing any of the above in song lyrics. A proposed Missouri law would add ``nudity'' to the list. Florida would include ``sexual activity.'' Iowa, Arizona, Maryland and Oklahoma have also drawn up legislation, and Virginia, Alaska, New Mexico, Illinois, Delaware and Kansas are considering similar measures. While rock 'n' roll and all its lyrics go prime time on the Grammys, record stores around the country are being pressured to keep things clean: _The 450-store national Trans World chain now sells stickered products in its Florida stores only to those 18 or older as the result of a ``sting'' operation by Florida attorney Jack Thompson in which minors purchased unedited versions of rap group 2 Live Crew's records. The 52-store Spec's Music chain, based in Florida, and the 70-store Nashville, Tenn.-based Sound Shop chain have adopted similar policies. _Last year, Tommy Hammond, a record shopkeeper in Alexander City, Ala., was convicted of obscenity for selling 2 Live Crew's ``Move Something'' LP, which contains a tune titled ``S&M.'' Although the customer was a local police officer, Hammond was told by the arresting officer, ``Nobody's old enough to buy it in this state.'' Hammond was fined $500 by the city court and has appealed to a circuit court. _In May 1989, Ouachita County Sheriff Jack Dews seized a number of rap and heavy metal tapes from the WalMart chain and Hear the Blues record stores in Camden, Ark. ``They had them displayed in open cases, some on open counters,'' Dews said. ``A 10-year-old could buy them and they were clearly labeled as obscene.'' Rap and heavy metal are the prime targets, but mainstream stars have also come under attack. Madonna's ``Like a Prayer'' commercial for Pepsi was pulled after a threatened boycott by Mississippi preacher Donald Wildmon, who heads the American Family Association. Mick Jagger said Columbia Records asked the Rolling Stones to delete words from the inner sleeve of their ``Dirty Work'' album. ``One of the things that Hitler was real good at and very shrewd in doing was developing the youth,'' said Mike Shelton, a police officer in Union City, Calif., and author of the training manual ``Punk Rock & Heavy Metal: The Problem-One Solution.'' ``Much of that was about distinct uniforms, distinct lifestyles and distinct music. Music can influence particular young people,'' he said. Tipper Gore, president of the Parents Music Resource Center (PMRC), agrees. She says youngsters are influenced by ``the glorification of violence.'' A year ago, multiplatinum-artist Bobby Brown was dragged from the stage of the Municipal Auditorium in Columbus, Ga., and arrested for ``dancing suggestively.'' In Cincinnati, rappers NWA and Too $hort were fined for giving ``obscene'' performances. In April 1989, platinum-selling Metallica, a heavy metal group, was forced to cancel a show at Notre Dame University because of ``bad publicity.'' Ever since Elvis Presley appeared on ``The Ed Sullivan Show,'' censors have sought to confine rock 'n' roll to the waist up. Rock's defenders insist the latest wave of criticism is simply the same old song. ``To me the rock 'n' roll attitude is live and let live,'' said Bill Adler, of Rush Artists Management, whose clients include rappers Public Enemy, Run-DMC and LL Cool J. ``I don't believe the issue is a couple of dirty rap records. What's going on here is there's kind of a cultural war in progress. This music has always been under attack by elements of the Christian fundamentalist right ever since it first surfaced in the mid-1950s.'' But organizations such as PMRC, which pressures record companies to label products, claim customers have a right to know what's in the stores. PMRC insists it's not looking to pull the plug on rock, but merely to jiggle the wires. PMRC prefers a voluntary system much like the rating system for movies between filmmakers and the Motion Picture Association of America Inc. ``Specifically, we're interested in material that is impacting children,'' executive director Jennifer Norwood said. ``We don't monitor every record. It has more to do with than just a four-letter word. We are dealing with material that is so graphic.''

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: so graphic.''
DOC.TEXT: In 1985, PMRC and the Recording Industry Association of America reached agreement on voluntary labeling. Records with lyric content relating to ``explicit sex, explicit violence or explicit substance abuse'' would carry the label ``Explicit Lyrics _ Parental Advisory,'' or have lyrics visible on the jacket. However, the industry has not always honored the agreement, Norwood said. ``The Beastie Boys didn't carry a label,'' she said of their ``License to Ill'' LP, ``and it had 95 references to drugs and alcohol. Motley Crue has never been labeled, and they carry numerous references to sex and graphic violence.'' Voluntary legislation isn't enough for some state legislators. Rep. Don Hermann of Iowa has sponsored a labeling bill, and said recently in an interview with Billboard that he's ``sick'' of songs with lyrics ``outside the norm, like this Elton John song about `Sally' that isn't a girl at all but about a homosexual.'' Judith Toth, a Democrat in the Maryland House of Delegates, has proposed a labeling law that would impose up to a $1,000 fine and up to one year in jail for a first offense, and $5,000 and up to three years imprisonment for subsequent offenses. ``There's just a movement within rock groups that doesn't care,'' she said. The movement includes most rap groups and ``skinhead music'' performers, whose lyrics Toth says degrade racial and ethnic minorities. Opponents to mandatory labeling include the record industry association, civil liberties groups, music critics, a number of rock stars _ notably Frank Zappa _ and the National Association of Recording Merchandisers, which represents retailers. Beach Boy Mike Love, whose group was attacked by former Secretary of the Interior James Watt for attracting the ``wrong element,'' contributed money to the PMRC. But Donny Osmond, a Mormon and longtime supporter of conservative causes, has condemned labeling. In the middle are the retailers themselves, who insist their hands are tied between satisfying local complaints and respecting freedom of expression. They have not hesitated, however, to point an accusing finger at the recording industry. ``It would be our hope that the manufacturers would take it upon themselves to determine product that may contain objectionable material and choose either not to publish that or to affix warning labels to that product,'' said Jim Williamson, a Trans World vice president. ``I'd like to see the manufacturers take a responsible stand,'' said Vicky Carmichael, vice president of Spec's. ``It's a tough situation. No matter what you do, someone is going to be unhappy. We want to do what is good for our business and do what's right. We have some customers who purchase the explicit lyrics and some who are offended.'' But what defines ``offensive'' or ``obscene''? Should minors be permitted to purchase Kurt Weill's satirical opera ``The Threepenny Opera,'' which features murder, bigamy and prostitution? ``Yes, it's sticky,'' Carmichael admitted. ``I think's this country is swinging back more conservatively. I see it happening _ the penalties they want to have.'' Retailers also fear mandatory labeling would turn them into involuntary censors. A record store owner might have to monitor every album in the store to make sure no ``explicit'' lyrics were left unmarked. ``There's no way in the world a person could do that,'' said Hammond, the Alexander City record store owner. ``Even if I could do that, who am I to try to tell another person what they can or can't listen to. I can't even tell you what pornography is. How am I supposed to tell others what it is?'' Labeling opponents have accused the record industry of caring more about dollar signs than yellow stickers. Critics note that the industry association's agreement with the PMRC came while the industry was lobbying Congress for a tax on blank cassettes and insist that artistic freedom is still not a primary concern. ``All the record industry wants is to be able to do business,'' said Lee Ballinger, an associate editor for the newsletter Rock & Roll Confidential. ``They want to lobby the government for a uniform labeling bill. They want to make money, they don't care.'' Charles Ruttenberg, the general counsel for the retailers association, denies this, insisting that record industry people have the same concerns as anyone else: ``I think that all the people I've talked with, they all have families, they have children. I don't think they're in it just to make money. They're trying to make sure children aren't injured.''

DOC.HEAD: Rock Lyrics and Terrorism
With BC-AP Arts: Grammys-Legislation, b0586-b0587
DOC.TEXT: The Middlesex County, N.J., prosecutor's office monitors the music and literature of hate crime suspects as part of a special task force. ``The component evaluates the effects of heavy metal lyrics on the acts of vandalism,'' county prosecutor Alan Rockoff said about the Joint Unit to Stop Terrorism, which was formed four years ago in response to an outbreak of racist and anti-Semitic incidents. ``We've found not only the heavy metal influence but a progression from heavy metal music and the fixation or obsession with violence, weapons and thunderbolts and knives, things like that, that has evolved as sort of a genesis into these white supremacists affiliations,'' he said. ``They seem to be putting graffiti on buildings now and attacking people solely on the basis of color.'' Rockoff said that when a hate crime is committed, the procedure is to find probable cause and then obtain a search warrant for the suspect's home. ``With that search warrant, we make observations in the homes and particularly the rooms. What motivates them? What literature do they read?'' But the New Jersey branch of the American Civil Liberties Union objects to the procedure. ``I think that it's unconstitutional because what someone reads or listens to is part of the private person,'' said ACLU legal director Deb Ellis. ``It's not a crime to be part of an Aryan organization or read Aryan literature. What you're looking for is evidence of the actual illegal act.'' But, said Rockoff, ``There is no apology that has to be made by law enforcement offcials for trying to uncover the motivation or commission for criminal acts. ``You want to know why he picked on the particular icon. You look for evidence, whether it's rope or whatever. When you are in the inner sanctuary, you have a perfect right to try to learn what motivated that young person.'' The prosecutor cited a case in which a group of young people were indicted for placing swastikas, anti-Semitic slurs and statements such as ``6 Million More, Why Not?'' on the walls of the B'Nai Brith Hillel Foundation at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. ``We have learned that some of the individuals involved had affiliations to a white, Aryan supremacy organization. From that literature we have gained a great deal of insight into skinhead culture. ``We're not looking at any idealogical movement or political movement or liberal or conservative or civil rights or law enforcement,'' Rockoff said. ``Nor do I want to be called a zealot. ``It is not an idealogical police force. I am not a censor. I am just a cop trying to do his job.''

DOC.HEAD: Tiny Molluscs Imperil Water Supplies, Power Plants, Fishing
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Wilfred LePage saw his first zebra mussel Feb. 1. By September, thousands of the tiny molluscs jammed the intake of the water treatment plant he manages, cutting the flow 20 percent and nearly sparking a water emergency. ``There is no cheap solution to it and there's no real cure to the problem,'' said LePage, water treatment superintendent in Monroe, Mich., on Lake Erie's western edge. At the eastern end of the lake, in Dunkirk, N.Y., the green-and-yellow striped shellfish first appeared Oct. 3, and now infest a Niagara Mohawk Power Corp. generating plant. December's deep freeze stopped them from clogging water intakes but they quickly settled inside the plant. ``They like it where it's dimly lit, they like it where it's warm, and they don't like a lot of turbulence. This place is ideal for them,'' said Robert C. Henderson, a chemical lab supervisor at the plant. ``By July, we're going to have a massive problem with them.'' Three years after they were introduced to North America and after only one year in Lake Erie, zebra mussels have spread throughout the lake and have been spotted at the entrance to Lake Ontario and along the St. Lawrence River. It's an invasion scientists say could affect farming, fishing and daily life along virtually every body of fresh water in North America in the next few years. The mussels are mostly about a half-inch long, although they can reach 2 inches during their five-year lifespans. They eat by filtering microscopic food particles from the water, and love intake pipes of water and power plants because the current brings them a steady supply of fresh food. A mussel can filter more than a gallon of water an hour, said R. Warren Flint, a scientist with the Great Lakes Program at the State University of New York-Buffalo. As a result, they will leave water cleaner than before. ``From an aesthetic perspective, that would certainly be a benefit, I guess,'' he said. Europeans have used zebra mussels to clean algae-choked ponds, and the shells can be used to add calcium to livestock feed, said Charles O'Neill, with the Sea Grant program at the State University College at Brockport. The mussels also are a good source of food for diving ducks and some kinds of fish, including sturgeons and eels, Flint said. But with millions of them at work filtering microscopic food, they could deplete the supply for the small fish that support the billion-dollar walleye- and bass-fishing industry. And the bad news could spread beyond the lake and its shoreline. Farmers and golf courses that draw irrigation water from the lakes can expect problems, and beachgoers will have to wear shoes because of the shells, O'Neill said. ``It can affect everything from the electricity at your outlet to the water at your tap,'' O'Neill said. ``It's not just an environmental problem.'' Like their distant cousins, the blue mussels, zebras ought, in theory, to be edible by humans, Flint said. But when Canadian researchers tried steaming a bunch, O'Neill said, ``What they got was a stench that cleared the lab.'' The mussels have plagued Europe for more than a century and are believed to have arrived in North America on a freighter that emptied its ballast tanks in Lake St. Clair, upstream from Lake Erie, in 1986. Scientists are studying the possibility that the Lake Erie infestations came from several ships rather than that single 1986 event, O'Neill said. But Flint said one colony could have infested the lake because one mussel can lay 30,000 to 50,000 eggs a year and the larvae can swim for up to two weeks before growing shells. ``They could easily get across Lake Erie or Lake Ontario in that period of time,'' he said. For public water systems, controlling the mussels is a matter of applying chlorine, ozone or other disinfectants at the mouth of the intake pipe rather than waiting until the water is inside the plant, say scientists and plant operators like LePage who have already faced the problem. Power plants have a different problem, because officials are reluctant to let them put chlorine or other disinfectants in cooling water discharged back to the lake, Henderson said. Niagara Mohawk and the state Department of Environmental Conservation are negotiating a solution. James Sell, chief operator of the Dunkirk water plant, is studying ways of getting chlorine to the pipe's mouth, like building a platform over the intake or running a smaller chlorine pipe out through the intake. ``We're better off than the people in the western end of the lake,'' Sell said. ``At least we have some time to do something by spring.'' The City Council hasn't been persuaded to pay up to $100,000 for the plans, but Sell, who keeps three living mussels in a jar to show visitors, said, ``I don't see much option for them if they want a water supply.'' Farther inland, many water officials are unaware of the problem or not prepared to do anything about it. Michael Burke, director of the state Health Department's bureau of public water supply protection, said the department was studying the problem but doesn't see the need to issue warnings. ``I think the word's getting to them, particularly those with large surface intakes in the Great Lakes. It is coming out in industry papers and things of that sort.'' O'Neill and other scientists said the state should do more to get the word out, because it is only a matter of time _ and not necessarily very much time. ``The chances of them getting into the western reach of the Erie Canal is good,'' O'Neill said. ``The canal is an ideal place for them to live. It's warm. It's shallow. Most of it has rock riprap to attach to.'' Pleasure boats can also carry mussels and their larvae in their engine housings and other places where water collects. Once the mussels get into Lake Michigan, they will almost certainly spread through the Chicago River and into the Mississippi River basin, O'Neill said. ``Any area in North America that is utilizing surface water should be concerned.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Kills 33 Romanian Babies, 20 Others Stricken ^LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: A mysterious AIDS outbreak has killed 33 infants or toddlers since July and stricken 20 others in a country not prepared to prevent the spread of the fatal disease. The victims are from 4 months to 3 years old and come from three areas: Bucharest in the south, southernmost Giurgiu and Constanta on the Black Sea Coast to the southeast, said Dr. Ludovic Paun of the Infectious Diseases Department at the Victor Babes Hospital here in the nation's capital. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome was first diagnosed in Romania in 1985, but it wasn't until July that it began showing up in young children, he said. ``It was a big surprise for us, for everybody. It's incredible.'' Since 1985, 69 people have been diagnosed with AIDS in Romania, and 45 have died. Fifty-three of the cases _ and 33 of the deaths _ were in children. A total of 371 Romanians have been shown in initial tests to be carrying the AIDS virus, Paun said. Of those, 268 are children. Victor Babes Hospital, which specializes in infectious diseases, is treating 65 patients with AIDS or AIDS-related infections in an isolated, three-story building at the edge of the 600-bed complex, Paun said. The three adult AIDS patients have separate rooms, but the infants are crammed into wards crowded with white-painted iron cribs, separated into rooms for those with confirmed AIDS and those with related infections. In one room _ with the word ``Confirmati,'' or confirmed, on the door _ 10 infants stared out from cribs spread with blue, brown or plaid blankets. One about a year old had sunken cheeks and thin, white hair. ``We have to keep them together because we can only heat so many rooms and to have them in a controlled situation for the staff to handle,'' said Paun. Authorities do not know how so many children became infected since a thorough epidemiological investigation has not been completed, Paun said. ``All these children came from institutions, from orphanages or hospital units for'' children who are undersized for their age. ``It might have been possible for the disease to spread through instruments that were not properly sterilized,'' he said. AIDS cases among Soviet children have in at least two instances been traced to infected needles; many East bloc nations do not have disposable syringes that are common in the West. Authorities are now investigating individual orphanages and hospitals, said Dr. Dan Daiculescu, a colleague of Paun's. ``What's important is how they contracted it. This is a tragic problem.'' In only five cases did parents of the infected children have positive blood tests for AIDS, but not all parents were tested, Paun said. He added that since the children were at least several months old when first tested, doctors were uncertain how many of the victims might have been born with AIDS. More than 15,000 blood tests conducted since 1985 do not indicate there is a ``special community'' of AIDS victims in Romania, the way that homosexuals and drug users are at greater risk in the West, Paun said. Romanian doctors are only beginning to learn about AIDS, he said, and the public knows almost nothing of the disease that damages a body's immune system, since little was published during the rule of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. As part of Ceausescu's program to increase Romania's population from 23 million to 30 million by the turn of the century, condoms were only available on the black market at high prices until the dictator's downfall in December. Daiculescu said a radio and TV campaign was needed to warn Romanians of the dangers of AIDS, but that no money was available for such a project. ``We don't have the material suport we need,'' Paun agreed, adding that the hospital did not have AZT or other up-to-date drugs for treating AIDS patients. At one point during a tour, the children in one ward were all crying, and Daiculescu explained they just had injections antibiotics. The Romanian Health Ministry is organizing five regional centers to test for AIDS to more carefully measure how widespread the disease is, Paun said. Doctors are managing to cope with the spread of AIDS, he said, but there are fears that they might be overwhelmed by many more cases. ``We don't have very many patients but in the future we may have a problem. ``The virus is present and the danger is present.''

DOC.HEAD: Home-Grown Inventor Works on Perpetual Motion Machine
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: James Sorg can visualize the bearings and wheels spinning flawlessly, and is convinced that one day they'll do the same in real life, a machine churning endlessly, powered only by gravity. ``Gravity is an energy source that does not pollute, does not need storage, does not need transportation,'' said Sorg, 53. ``Everyone in the world has an adequate supply. No country would need what another country has got.'' The farmer and airline worker says that after 46 years of figuring and tinkering, he has found a way to disprove a basic law of physics. In his barn, the 12-foot-tall wheel studded with barbells and rollerskate parts only rotates a couple times before coming to a stop. But it's just a rough draft. Bureaucrats and scientists scoff, but they laughed at Christopher Columbus, too, Sorg said. ``They can't understand. They say, `You're crazy. Get out of here.' Mentality of that nature used to teach that the world was flat.'' Sorg's ``gravity-operated machine'' shares the barn with a restless calf on his 100-acre farm, where he also is developing a new breed of cattle. ``I'm always thinking about something,'' he said. ``When I was 7 years old my uncle bought an old brass candy scale. I thought if you could just bring the weight across from one side to the other you could keep it swinging back and forth forever.'' Sorg, who never went to college or studied physics, said he made dozens of stabs at perpetual motion before deciding on the flywheel design in 1980. After a long struggle, it was patented in March as an ``energy conservator'' because the U.S. Patent Bureau won't even consider perpetual motion machines. Perpetual motion can never occur, said Joseph Chalmers, head of the physics department at the University of Louisville. The laws of thermodynamics say any engine will lose energy through friction, ultimately coming to a stop. ``We don't just enunciate these laws to hear ourselves talk,'' he said. Human nature being what it is, of course, there's no shortage of people who over the years have been willing to attempt what others say is impossible. Sorg's machine has an 8-foot-wide metal wheel with 12 weights on axles mounted around the perimeter, each directly opposite another and linked to its mate by a cable. As the wheel turns and a weight rises to top center, an arm connected to it meets a cam, causing the weight to move away from the wheel. ``The cable between the opposite weights raises the one at the bottom, which makes the one at the bottom weightless at the bottom of the flywheel and places its weight at the top of the flywheel, which adds force at the top of the flywheel which causes the rotation,'' Sorg explains. As he sets the weights in the proper position, his machine strains forward, and when the brake is released it begins turning slowly, making two revolutions before a weight sticks in the wrong position. If the machine was precisely balanced, it would spin until it wore out, Sorg said. ``They say it's not supposed to move on its own, but it does. They say it's not supposed to turn even one full revolution, but it does.'' Chalmers said the device might be useful as a way of conserving energy, but lifting the weights will use the same amount of energy as is given by the opposite weight falling. At the same time, energy is lost to friction. ``A similar machine was proposed well over 100 years ago, with levers and what-not around a circle. You give it a spin and it probably spins for a long time. But in terms of going forever, it's certainly not going to do that.'' Although every scientist he seeks to convince rejects his ideas, Sorg is steadfast. He continues to work on two models and plans a third. ``Somebody someplace will be interested enough to come out here to see it just out of curiousity,'' he said, ``and they'll be able to help me find a machine shop to build it the way it needs to be.''

DOC.HEAD: Teens, Young Adults Seem Most Vulnerable to Suicide Clusters
DOC.TEXT: Teen-agers and young adults are most vulnerable to suicide clusters, in which one suicide seems to trigger at least one more, a study suggests. Analysis of federal records for 1978-1984 found that clustering occurred some two to four times more often in the age groups 15-19 and 20-24 than in older age groups, researchers said. A cluster was defined as two suicides in the same county within seven, 14 or 30 days. Each time period was analyzed separately. For the seven-day period, for example, researchers found 1,420 such pairs of suicides among teen-agers 15 to 19, 6 percent higher than would be expected by chance. Clusters account for relatively few suicides among young people, but they may be particularly preventable, wrote the researchers from Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons and School of Public Health, the New York State Psychiatric Institute and the federal Centers for Disease Control. The CDC has developed recommendations for a community plan to prevent and contain suicide clusters, they said.
DOC.HEAD: Study Says Pill Helps Prevent Chlamydia-Caused PID
DOC.TEXT: Birth control pills may offer some protection against pelvic inflammatory disease caused by chlamydia _ the most common sexually transmitted disease in the nation _ but not PID caused by gonorrhea, researchers say. Chlamydia, a bacterial infection, is blamed for about half the cases of PID in women. It can lead to chronic pelvis pain, miscarriage and infertility, and infants born to infected mothers can suffer pneumonia and eye infections. ``This is a little different than previous studies that have said that birth control pills protect aginst PID, period,'' said Dr. Paul Wolner-Hanssen of the University of Washington. ``This is kind of a good news, bad news result. What we say is, `Yes it's true, it does protect you aginst PID if you have chlamydia, but it does not protect you against PID if you have gonorrhea.''' The researchers led by Wolner-Hanssen studied 141 women with PID who attended one of three clinics at the university's Harborview Medical Center and 739 randomly selected, sexually active women with no signs of the disease. A comparison of women who had chlamydia and PID with those who only had chlamydia showed that those who had chlamydia but took oral contraceptives were five times less likely to get PID than those who used another or no method of birth control, Wolner-Hanssen said. The results were not significant when women with gonorrhea were compared, suggesting the pill does not protect them. The results did not differ appreciably when adjusted for age, race, years of education, age at first intercourse, frequency of intercourse, or history of the sexually transmitted diseases, but the researchers noted the study could have been influenced by factors such as willingness to seek health care. The study was published in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Devises Improved Computer Storage Technology
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A new technique could increase the storage capacity of compact disks by 1,666, according to its developer, who says it would allow 18,000 Encyclopedia Britannicas or 10 days' worth of music on one CD. A 12-inch compact disk using the technology could hold a terabyte _ a trillion bytes, or characters _ of information, says Tuan Vo-Dinh, a physical chemist. A conventional CD can hold 600 million bytes, the equivalent of about 270,000 typewritten pages; a terabyte would be nearly 450 million pages. An set of Encyclopaedia Britannica has about 25,000 pages. Conventional CD storage uses lasers essentially to burn holes into a disk. A computer needs only ``ones'' and ``zeroes'' to work. The burned bits could be ``zeroes'' and the untouched, reflecting bits ``ones,'' or vice versa. Even the hole burned by a laser is bigger than the 1,000 molecules Vo-Dinh says he can alter. The number needed to store a bit _ eight bits make a byte _ could be cut to 100 or so. ``The theoretical limit is one molecule. But you would need a very sensitive detector to see just one molecule.'' Vo-Dinh's technique, called Surface Enhanced Raman Optical Data Storage, is based on a phenomenon discovered in the 1920s called the Raman Optical Effect, which says the light-emitting properties of molecules can be altered. SERODS lends itself to confidential data storage because it can reflect signals at a particular frequency, said Guven Yalcintas, director of technology for Oak Ridge National Laboratory, where Vo-Dinh works. ``A selective frequency is very difficult to decifer,'' Yalcintas said, adding that SERODS also holds the potential for three-dimensional data storage, increasing its capacity and versatility even further. Yalcintas estimates it will take about $5 million and two years to make a commercially viable product, but says there already is interest. ``The Navy is interested in sending out paperless ships. NASA is interest in using it to store images and bring them back to Earth. The National Archives are interested. The Air Force is thinking about it to store a very large amount of information, a picture of the surface, and present an image to the pilot,'' he said. ``You can count on and on and on.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Feb. 19

DOC.HEAD: Prudential and Jones Lang Wooten Launch $2 Billion Real Estate Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Programme is cq in 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: The Prudential Insurance Co. of America and Jones Lang Wooten have announced a $2 billion real estate investment program to buy property around the world. It is Prudential's first major step to extend its real estate activities beyond North America, the company said in a statement released Wednesday. The Prudential Global Real Estate Investment Programme is designed to help companies acquire a real estate portfolio spread among major cities in several countries. Plans are to invest in prime real estate assets over 3-5 years. Robert E. Riley, chairman of the Prudential Realty Group, and Keith Douglas-Mann, chairman of Jones Lang Wooten, said in a joint statement: ``Each member of the program's elite investor group brings significant knowledge of its own part of the world.'' The combined experience and resources will complement each other. Cities under consideration for investment include Frankfurt, West Germany; London; Paris; Sydney, Australia; and Toronto; as well as Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and Washington. Eight companies have committed a total of $2 billion to the program, including: Prudential; Nationale-Nederlanden NV, the Netherlands; Australian Mutual Provident Society; Government of Singapore Investment Corp. Pte Ltd. (GSIC); and SPP, Sweden. The names of the three other companies that have committed money have not been disclosed, said Melanie Keenan, spokeswoman for Jones Lang. The Prudential Realty Group, headquartered in Newark, manages more than $45 billion in real estate assets and has 24 offices throughout the United States. Jones Lang Wooten, based in London, has 58 offices worldwide, including a U.S. headquarters in New York. It specializes in investment and corporate real estate services.

DOC.HEAD: ICC Reduces Service on D&H Railway
DOC.TEXT: Service on Delaware & Hudson Railway lines were to be cut back today, pending a hearing Friday before a federal agency to consider a proposal to keep the bankrupt railroad on the tracks, according to a bankruptcy trustee. Francis P. Dicello, court-appointed trustee for D&H, said he had not seen the order issued by the Interstate Commerce Commission Wednesday night, but was told ``it reduced service for the next two days'' pending the outcome of the hearing. No other officials could be reached for comment on the order. The ICC is expected to consider a proposal to keep D&H running for at least 30 days. The proposal was submitted by the New York Susquehanna and Western Railroad, a subsidiary of Delaware Otsego Corp. In addition, Canadian National Railroad said it will help cover some of the costs NYS&W will incur if the proposal is approved. NYS&W and Canadian National both lost in efforts to purchase D&H during proceedings in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington. Dicello, who was appointed trustee in 1988, chose Canadian Pacific Ltd. as the successful bidder for D&H in January over NYS&W and four other bidders. Canadian National wanted to make a bid in court last Friday, but lost its financial backing before the hearing. CP had agreed to purchase the ailing railroad for $35 million, but the transaction was contingent on whether it could obtain track rights from Conrail from Harrisburg, Pa., to Hagerstown, Md. An agreement could not be reached and CP withdrew its purchase offer. D&H faced shutdown proceedings at midnight Wednesday if there had been no action by the ICC. During an emergency hearing in bankruptcy court Wednesday to determine D&H's fate, Walter Rich, NYS&W president and chief executive officer, said if D&H is allowed to continue to operate, it could continue to provide service with no disruptions to 99 percent of its shippers. D&H is the nation's oldest continually operating railway. The ICC designated NYS&W to operate D&H after the rail line went into Chapter 11 bankruptcy in 1988. Creditors have about $100 million in claims against the railroad. NYS&W's proposal to keep D&H operating has the backing of the Federal Railroad Administration. ``We've been fighting to try to save the railroad for weeks now,'' said Gil Carmichael, federal railroad administrator. Carmichael said he was encouraged to see a partnership formed between Canadian National and NYS&W to finance continued operations of D&H, instead of the states of New York and Pennsylvania using taxpayers' money to keep D&H running. He would not speculate on whether NYS&W and Canadian National would make a bid for D&H. But Carmichael did say he has known ``Rich wanted to buy D&H for a long time and CN wanted to be a player in it,'' based on last week's failed attempt to bid for the line. The Conrail tracks at issue with CP are on a route that connects with CSX and Norfolk Southern railroads at Hagerstown. D&H already connects with the two railroads at Philadelphia and Buffalo, N.Y. CP's purchase agreement was to have expired at midnight Tuesday, but was extended. In the absence of a purchase agreement and with no pending bids Wednesday, Dicello said officials had planned to begin shutting down shipping over D&H rail lines if the ICC had not intervened. A complete shutdown would have taken four to five days, according to Stanley Samorajczyk, an attorney for Dicello. Plans would then be made to begin selling off D&H's assets.
