D&H, which began in 1824 as a canal company, runs 20 to 25 trains daily in New York, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Quebec. It owns 550 miles of track and has traffic rights to another 1,000, according to Ken Willsey, Delaware Otsego spokesman. A shutdown would put 672 employees out of work and eliminate the hope of return for 100 to 150 others on furlough, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Drano's Maker Gets New President
DOC.TEXT: Drackett Co., the Cincinnati-based maker of Windex, Drano, and other cleaning products, is losing its third president in six years. The company confirmed Wednesday that Douglas G. Cowan, who has been Drackett's president since April 1988, would take an indefinite leave of absence for health reasons. Cowan, 56, is believed to have heart problems. Taking his place will be Thomas L. Dahl, president of branded consumer products for Weyerhaeuser Co., a paper products and lumber company from the Seattle, Wash., area. Dahl, 44, officially will join Drackett today as executive vice president. He will become president April 1. Drackett spokesman David S. Perkins confirmed Cowan's plans. In 1984, Nick Evans, who had been Drackett's president since 1966, left the company to become a senior executive at its parent company, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. William F. Flatley took Evans' job, but left in 1988, also for a spot in the parent company. Cowan, who joined Drackett in 1983, was promoted from senior vice president following Flatley's departure. Cowan came to Drackett after 27 years at the Procter & Gamble Co. of Cincinnati. When he left P&G as director of product development for packaged soaps and detergents, P&G sued Drackett, saying Cowan would leak trade secrets. The suit was settled out of court. Before joining Weyerhaeuser, Dahl was president of the infant care business at Kimberly-Clark Corp., where he made that company's Huggies disposable diaper the No.1 brand, displacing P&G's Pampers.

DOC.HEAD: GMAC, Hughes Lag; EDS Surges
DOC.TEXT: Interest costs cut fourth-quarter and 1989 profits at General Motors Corp.'s financing arm, and the expense of job cuts reduced earnings at the automaker's electronics and aerospace unit, the companies said. While General Motors Acceptance Corp. and GM Hughes Electronics Corp. reported declines, the third major GM subsidiary, Electronic Data Systems Corp., said Wednesday its profits grew as it added data services customers. GM and Ford Motor Co. were scheduled to report earnings today. Chrysler Corp. released results Tuesday, including a $664-million fourth-quarter loss due to belt-tightening staff cuts and plant closings. GMAC, the auto finance, insurance and mortgage branch, said its costs of borrowing funds increased to an average of 9.33 percent in 1989 from 8.28 percent in 1988. Costs of low-interest financing incentives offered GM car buyers are subsidized by the automaker and don't impact GMAC results, spokesman John Andrews said. GMAC reported net income of $251.2 million for October-December, down from $257.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. Gross revenue for the quarter was $3.6 billion, up from $3.4 billion a year earlier, GMAC said. For the year, GMAC said it had net income of $1.11 billion, down from $1.19 billion in 1988. The company said 1989 gross revenue was $14.5 billion, up from $13.5 billion in 1988. GMAC doesn't have a separate issue of stock based on its earnings. EDS earnings are the base for GM Class E stock. GM Class H stock is linked to GM Hughes Electronics profits. GM Hughes Electronics, parent company of Hughes Aircraft Co. and Delco Electronics Corp., built four communications and one weather satellite launched in 1989. The company reported fourth-quarter net income of $183 million, or 46 cents per share of GM Class H stock, up from $169.5 million, or 43 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1988. Quarterly revenue dropped to $2.9 billion from $3.1 billion a year earlier, the company said. For the year, GM Hughes Electronics reported net earnings of $781.2 million, or $1.94 a share, on revenue of $11.4 billion, compared with $802.1 million, or $2.01 a share, on revenue of $11.2 billion in 1988. Net earnings would have been $812 million, or $2.02 a share, without non-recurring charges of $30.8 million, or 8 cents a share, for early retirement and severance costs to cut Hughes employment to 66,000 from 75,000, spokesman Bruce McCristal said. EDS said new data services customers including Cummins Engine Co. and Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc. helped it boost profits 15.5 percent for the quarter and 13.3 percent for the year. EDS reported quarterly net income of $119.5 million, or 50 cents per GM Class E share, up from $103.4 million, or 42 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1988. Revenue was $1.43 billion for the quarter, up from $1.3 billion, EDS said. EDS reported net income of $435.3 million, or $1.81 a share, on revenue of $5.47 billion for 1989, up from $384.1 million, or $1.57 a share, on revenue of $4.84 billion in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Utility Company Lost Almost $500 million
DOC.TEXT: Entergy Corp., parent of utilities in Arkansas, Louisiana and Mississippi, says it lost nearly $500 million last year, mainly because of a third-quarter, $900 million writeoff of the unfinished Grand Gulf 2 nuclear power plant in Mississippi. The company's fourth-quarter income tumbled 74.1 percent. Entergy, which last year changed its name from Middle South Utilities, abandoned Grand Gulf 2 in 1985 when it was only 34 percent complete. The 1989 loss came to $2.31 a share, Entergy said. Because of the scrapped plant, Entergy took a loss of $679.3 million or $3.32 per share in the third quarter. Fourth-quarter 1989 results also were hurt by the Grand Gulf 2 writeoff. Net income slumped by 74.1 percent to $15.1 million compared with $58.3 million in the fourth quarter of 1988. Per-share earnings fell from 29 cents to eight 8 cents. Total operating revenue rose 2.2 percent to $883 million from $863.5 million. Energy sales to retail customers climbed 2.7 percent to $54 million for the year from $52.58 million in 1989. Entergy reported that total electric sales in the quarter increased 2.4 percent. That was mostly a result of an 18.1 percent jump in wholesale revenues, the company said. ``The Grand Gulf writeoff is a one-time hurdle that will benefit us in the long term,'' said John Cowan, an Entergy executive. ``The writeoff did not materially affect our cash position nor did it impact our ability to continue to pay dividends on our common stock each quarter at the current level.'' Writing off Grand Gulf 2 was part of a settlement Entergy reached with various state and local officials. In return for Entergy accepting its losses on the abandoned project, local officials agreed to drop all challenges to the wisdom of building and operating the Grand Gulf 1 plant. Grand Gulf 1 supplies electricity to, and increased rates for, customers of Arkansas Power & Light, Louisiana Power & Light, Mississippi Power & Light and New Orleans Public Service Inc. The challenges, if the findings went against the utility and were upheld by the courts, could have forced Entergy companies to absorb more of the Grand Gulf 1 costs. The settlement also resolved a Federal Energy Regulatory Commission audit case involving Grand Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing, McDonnell Douglas in Running For Chinese Venture
DOC.TEXT: Boeing Co. hopes to join China in a project to build 150 planes, but aerospace competitor McDonnell Douglas Corp. is also in the running, a Boeing official said. Dean Thornton, president of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, said Wednesday that Boeing hopes to complete the deal by the end of this year. Thornton spoke at the opening of Singapore's Asian Aerospace 90 air show. ``We are in serious talks with China as is McDonnell Douglas,'' Thornton said. ``The Chinese want support from an established aircraft manufacturer.'' Negotiations for the project between China and the two aircraft manufacturers have been going on for more than three years. Both companies want to build a short-range aircraft the Chinese call a Trunkliner. The plane would be used primarily by China's five regional aircraft companies on domestic runs. The planes would be about the same size as a Boeing 737-300 or a McDonnell Douglas MD-90. Both can seat about 150 passengers. McDonnell Douglas already has a joint project with China that has turned out 13 MD-82 planes and is scheduled to produce 25 aircraft total. Last year, the Civil Aviation Administration of China purchased four planes from Boeing, six from McDonnell Douglas, three from Airbus Industries and 11 Yun-7s made in China.

DOC.HEAD: Collapse of Big Firms Reflects Decline in Industry, But Others Survive
DOC.TEXT: While some big real estate companies have collapsed during a sharp decline in the market, others have avoided trouble by redirecting their business and showing more restraint, experts say. ``If (companies) are well managed, they may not raise as much money, but at least they're surviving,'' said Fuhrman Nettles, vice president of Robert A. Stanger & Co., a firm that follows the real estate investment industry. On Tuesday, VMS Realty Partners in Chicago announced it was suspending most payments to creditors and investors because of ``severe cash flow problems.'' At the same time Integrated Resources Inc. in New York, once a major seller of tax-sheltered real estate investments, filed for bankruptcy protection. Their troubles followed the fall of Southmark Corp. in Dallas, another major real estate company that filed for bankruptcy last year. The decline in the industry, however, became apparent after 1986, when federal tax law revisions made real estate investments less attractive. That year, real estate companies raised more than $10 billion from investors; by 1989, the figure had dropped to an estimated $3.5 billion. Officials at First Winthrop Corp. in Boston saw the changes coming, and redirected investments from those that offered tax breaks to those that focused more on cash returns, said Bruce Guzowski, chief operating officer for the company. For example, where the company previously got investors to put their money into subsidized housing, which provided tax credits, First Winthrop in 1986 bought a portfolio of hotel and other commercial properties on the resort island of Nantucket. ``The benefits of real estate from a tax perspective went away with the 1986 tax act,'' Guzowski said. First Winthrop also cut its operations ``across the board,'' he said, declining to elaborate. ``I think we saw the market was shrinking and saw a need to shrink the company,'' he said. Other companies, however, apparently tried too hard to keep growing despite the tax law changes and real estate slumps that were hitting the Southwest and about to hit the Northeast. ``Human enthusiasm takes a long time to wear down,'' Nettles said. Regarding the developments this week with VMS Realty and Integrated Resources, Nettles said: ``It appears as though they didn't respond well. It appears both companies followed an expansionist policy.'' A common source of trouble for some companies was the high-yield junk bond market, the same risky financing mechanism that helped the downfall of the Wall Street investment firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Integrated Resources, deprived of tax shelter investments, moved aggressively into insurance and mutual funds financed largely through junk bonds. Southmark used junk bonds to finance rapid growth, but the company was crushed by debt when the real estate market collapsed in the Southwest. First Winthrop, however, avoided the junk bond market. ``Fortunately, it's not something we used,'' Guzowski said. ``We've always financed with equity, not debt.'' ``Let's just say I think we made a wise decision,'' he said.

The stock market was marginally higher in early, uneventful trading today. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 2.03 points at 2,626.35 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 10 to 9 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 473 issues up, 405 down and 539 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 24.51 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the market remained quiet, as it has been in the previous two sessions. ``It's a period of just sitting on the sidelines waiting to see what's going to happen,'' said Hildegarde Zagorski, a vice president at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Market participants continued to monitor the unfolding of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s liquidation. The firm, which sought bankruptcy court protection earlier this week, is in the process of transferring its businesses to other Wall Street firms. Separately, the market was uninspired by an upbeat Commerce Department report showing a 29.6 percent jump in housing starts during an exceptionally warm January. Among blue chip issues, Reader's Digest, which just went public, was trading at 21\ a share; Baker Hughes was unchanged at 26], and IBM was up | at 104]. The company, as expected, introduced a new family of workstations. Ford Motor gain \ to 44~; the automaker reported a 28 percent drop in 1989 profits, but the report was in line with market expectations. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.14 to 183.35. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.07 at 358.85. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.22 to 2,624.32. Advancing issues slightly outnumbered declines in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 749 up, 681 down and 519 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 138.53 million shares, against 144.44 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Unveils New Sports Vehicle
LaserPhoto LX1
DOC.TEXT: After a multimillion-dollar investment and retraining program, Ford Motor Co. has begun full-scale production of its new Explorer sports-utility vehicle. ``Sport-utility vehicles are the fastest-growing segment of the truck market and, with the Explorer, we will be fully competitive in that segment,'' incoming president Philip Benton Jr. said during ceremonies marking the start-up at the assembly plant here. ``We've bet nearly $600 million on that outcome,'' Benton told employees and state and local officials Wednesday. Benton, who drove the first Explorer off the assembly line, said his company may become much more truck-oriented in the future, especially in Europe. ``I can't tell you exactly how or when this truck expansion in Europe will take place but I'm convinced that it will _ and that Ford, with world-class products such as the Explorer, will be a leader,'' said Benton, who is scheduled to become the company's president March 1. Benton predicted that the Explorer, available in two- and four-door models, will sell at perhaps twice the volume of the Bronco II, which it is replacing. The Bronco II came in only a two-door model, and Ford officials conceded that climbing into the back seat almost requires gymnastic talent. The plant is expected to turn out 85 Explorers an hour, with sales to the public beginning next month. The first three vehicles off the line Wednesday were purchased by employees. The Explorer is a family of compact five- or six-passenger utility trucks, available in either two- or four-wheel drive, with an improved electronically fuel-injected V-6 engine and either manual or automatic overdrive transmissions. Referring to the European market, Benton said Ford expects it to adopt ``the American idea that trucks are for carrying people as well as cargoes. Trucks constitute fully one-third of the industry's volume each year, and are 40 percent of the (Ford) division's North American volume.'' Benton said that percentage is climbing because as part of its strategy, the company ``will be building more and different kinds of trucks, for our customers and for our international partners.'' Later this year, Ford will build two-door 4x4 vehicles at the Louisville plant for its partner Mazda to sell as the Navajo through its U.S. dealer network. ``It marks the first time a U.S.-based vehicle manufacturer will make a product for a Japanese company,'' Benton said.

DOC.HEAD: Debuts Line of Workstations Aimed At Fast-Growing Market
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Grafs 1-8 UPDATE with news conference, quote, picks up 6th graf pvs, The workstation...
DOC.TEXT: IBM unveiled a line of computer workstations today that experts say should help the computer giant win a stake in an important market it never has mastered. ``The opportunity is big _ it's growing at over 30 percent a year, and it's mostly a new opportunity for IBM,'' President Jack D. Kuehler told a news conference. Kuehler said the new workstations, designed for business users, ``outperform the newest and best that our competitors offer.'' International Business Machines Corp. aides showed reporters nine high-performance workstations and computer file-servers, with prices ranging from $13,000 to more than $74,000. Industry analysts say the machines are impressive for their operating speed and features and should be received favorably by engineers, their target market. Workstations are desktop machines that are much more powerful than personal computers. Some even match the power of mainframes. They are used for such processing-intensive tasks as computer modeling of new products. While the workstation market is a small segment of the overall computer industry, it is among the fastest-growing, and uses for the machines are expanding. IBM introduced a workstation line several years ago, the RT line, but it captured less than 3 percent of market. Experts consider the machines underpowered and overpriced. The workstation field is dominated by Sun Microsystems Inc., Digital Equipment Corp. and Hewlett-Packard Co. The new IBM machines, like the workstations they replace, are based on a version of the Unix operating system, the underlying software that directs basic computer functions. Unix, developed by American Telephone & Telegraph Co., is becoming the computer industry standard, allowing machines from different manufacturers to be linked together. Until now, IBM had not wholeheartedly embraced Unix, preferring its own proprietary operating systems instead. The fact that the workstations are Unix-based shows IBM is serious about this market, analysts say. Like the older IBM workstations, the new models also are based on reduced-instruction-set computing technology, or RISC, which simplifies the circuitry of a computer's central processor to increase speed and offer cost savings. The powerful machines are expected to offer color, 3-D graphics capability. Analysts say one factor in the success of the new line, called the RISC System 6000, will be the availability of applications software, or the programs that provide the actual uses of a computer, such as engineering modeling. Though the machines are Unix-based, IBM uses its own version of Unix, called AIX, that is not compatible with Unix applications programs written for other companies' machines. That means programs must be rewritten for the IBM workstations. IBM has been working with software companies for some time to develop programs for the new machines.

DOC.HEAD: Parent's Filing Doesn't Mean Subsidiaries Will Survive
With PM-Drexel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. plans to reorganize under federal bankruptcy laws, but the parent company of the junk bond pioneer has no operations and none of its securities-related holdings are expected to survive. Through its subsidiaries, the group operates a broad financial services business best known for its broker-dealer, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which buys and sells securities such as the high-risk, high-yield bonds dubbed ``junk.'' Although court papers state that DBL Group intends to file a reorganization plan under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws, the company already has begun dismantling its subsidiaries by selling assets. ``It's just a way of preserving a corporate asset structure,'' Drexel spokesman Steven Anreder said Wednesday. ``There's never been any operations. It's just held subsidiaries and continues to hold subsidiaries.'' DBL Group has no payroll and its primary function is to handle some investments, leases and properties, and to serve as a holding company for its subsidiaries. In addition to the broker-dealer, subsidiaries include Drexel Burnham Lambert Government Securities Inc., which buys and sells Treasury securities issued at government auctions, and Drexel Burnham Lambert Trading Corp., which trades commodities such as metals and oils. The broker-dealer subsidiary is involved in businesses such as stock and bond trading and underwriting, and merger and takeover advising. It has a 600-member stock research and trading operation the company is trying to transfer, possibly for free, to another firm. Drexel's main U.S. offices are in New York and Los Angeles, and it has outposts in London, Paris, Singapore and Hong Kong. Drexel last year sold a U.S. retail brokerage network that handled stocks and bonds for individual investors. The bankruptcy court filing lists total assets of $3.7 billion and liabilities of $2.89 billion. Creditors number more than 2,000 _ more than 1,000 each for unsecured debt and common stock held by Drexel employees. A list of top creditors excludes Drexel insiders. Michael Milken, the former head of Drexel's junk bond division who left last year after being indicted by the government on racketeering and fraud charges, is said to have more than $200 million in claims. A Drexel spokesman said the firm does not consider him a creditor. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard C. Buschman III will handle the case, lawyers involved said Wednesday. Individuals familiar with Drexel said the parent company manages some illiquid investments _ which cannot be converted to cash _ such as bridge loans made to firms that have undergone leveraged buyouts. The parent also handles real estate leases and properties for some subsidiaries, including Drexel's downtown Manhattan headquarters. Court papers show the parent has more than $800 million in lease obligations. All stock in privately held Drexel was issued by the parent. Lambert Brussels Associates Limited Partnership, which is controlled by Groupe Bruxelles Lambert SA, owns about 26 percent of the parent. The Belgian group's managers Wednesday proposed writing off its stake in the company. Employees own about 54 percent of Drexel's parent through common stock; Milken, for instance, was required to give up his 6 percent stake _ then estimated to be worth about $100 million _ as part of a civil securities fraud settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Eagle-Picher to Start Producing Batteries for Electric Cars
DOC.TEXT: Eagle-Picher Industries Inc. says it is preparing a Missouri plant to produce batteries for electric vehicles later this year for what the company hopes will be a growing market for the vehicles. ``You could say we have high hopes for it,'' John W. Painter, president and chief operating officer of Eagle-Picher, said Wednesday. The diversified manufacturing company has its headquarters here. The plant at Joplin, Mo., would initially employ about 50 people and possibly more later, Painter said. The 40,000-square-foot plant will operate as part of Eagle-Picher's Joplin Electronics Division, which makes batteries for use in toys, computers and the nation's space program and does research of new battery products. The Joplin plant will make nickel-iron batteries for electric-powered vehicles. Gas-powered vehicles use conventional lead-acid batteries. The Joplin division has been working on a nickel-iron battery since 1980 under cost-sharing contracts with the U.S. Department of Energy, and has produced limited numbers of the batteries as research prototypes. Eagle-Picher has spent several million dollars on the research, Painter said. Eagle-Picher and a consortium of utilities supporting the project plan to spend a combined $4 million on the Joplin plant, Painter said. Eagle-Picher will contribute about $300,000, he said. Painter said he expects that electric-powered cars, which have been experimental for years, could go into widespread production within 15 years. They already exist in limited uses, such as electric-powered golf carts.

DOC.NOTE: $adv18
For release Sunday Feb. 18
DOC.HEAD: Philip Morris Cigarette Sales Growing
DOC.TEXT: With help from the Marlboro man, an enormous advertising budget and growing demand overseas, the No. 1 cigarette maker is selling more smokes than ever despite a shrinking market at home. In many respects, the success of Philip Morris USA reflects the scrappy tenacity of the domestic tobacco industry, which has taken an aggressive _ some critics would say hostile and unethical _ approach to selling cigarettes and combating health groups that want to restrict smoking. ``There are 55-to-60 million adults in this country who have made the choice to smoke,'' said Steve Weiss, a Philip Morris spokesman. ``What's frightening is that these anti-smoking groups are attempting to impose their own morality on the adult American public by trying to control the information they receive.'' Philip Morris hasn't been immune to the growing anti-smoking movement in the United States, which has played a role in reducing the market by about 2 percent a year. That shrinkage is partly why Philip Morris USA's New York-based parent Philip Morris Cos. acquired Kraft Inc. and Miller Brewing Co. years ago _ to protect itself by diversifying. Nonetheless, the tobacco arm of the conglomerate has been strengthening relative to competitors, with weapons that range from intense advertising to lobbying in Washington to a sales assault on virgin territory abroad. Nearly half the roughly $636 million in domestic cigarette advertising in 1989 was spent by Philip Morris, the trade newspaper Advertising Age has reported. Philip Morris held almost 42 percent of the U.S. cigarette market last year, said John Maxwell Jr., who follows the industry for Wheat First Securities in Richmond. The company had a 39.3 percent market share in 1988, up from 37.8 percent the year before. Overseas too, Philip Morris is doing extremely well. In Japan, for example, the company has benefited from a relaxation on imports and a demand for the mild Virginian tobacco it uses, to be blended with Japanese cigarettes. Pavlos Alexandrakis, who follows the industry for Argus Research, an investment advisory firm in New York, predicted that bigger and better-financed tobacco companies such as Philip Morris will get even bigger. ``They can advertise more,'' Alexandrakis said. ``They can throw more money behind product development and research.'' By contrast, Philip Morris' closest domestic competitor, RJR Nabisco Inc., may have little leeway in throwing money at new products, partly because it was sold last year in a record $25 billion takeover financed largely by debt. The one major new cigarette RJR has attempted, primarily aimed at blacks, generated a storm of accusations that the company was contributing to the health problems of minorities. RJR abruptly scrapped plans to test its Uptown brand last month in what was widely seen as a marketing catastrophe. Philip Morris' brands are so self-sustaining that the company is not as pressured to concoct new ones, analysts say. Among the best known are Marlboro, Virginia Slims, Benson & Hedges and Parliament. Of those, Marlboro is king and is the strongest among new smokers. ``One out of four cigarettes smoked is Marlboro,'' Maxwell said. ``Marlboro outsells the next largest international cigarette over two to one.'' The range-toughened Marlboro man has been an icon of Philip Morris ads since 1955, when it introduced the macho smoker with the butt dangling from his lips. The company has reacted angrily to recent efforts by anti-smoking groups to do away with him. The American Cancer Society, for instance, is promoting legislation to be introduced in Congress this year that would limit cigarette ads to the brand name, the product and text about it. ``People are being lured into something that kills them,'' said Joann Schellenbach, an American Cancer Society spokeswoman in New York. ``One in six people that start smoking are going to die from something cigarette-related. That's worse than Russsian roulette.'' The Surgeon General estimates that cigarettes cause an estimated 390,000 deaths a year in the United States. Weiss said he saw little chance that Congress would further restrict advertising by tobacco companies, already proscribed from peddling cigarettes on television and radio and forced to put health warnings on other ads. ``There's a tremendous amount of opposition in this country to tinkering with the commercial free speech rights of any manufacturer,'' Weiss said. Perhaps more than other cigarette makers, Philip Morris has seized upon the free speech issue as a tool to defend its business. The company even got its name on TV with an ad campaign about its sponsorship of a Bill of Rights commemoration, which some critics saw as a subtle way of promoting cigarettes. Philip Morris has promoted cigarettes in other unconventional ways. At the company's cigarette factory in Richmond, for example, adult visitors are offered free cigarettes and all visitors can write friends on Philip Morris postcards with company-paid postage. The company also writes thank-you notes to visitors who sign the guest register. Hazards of smoking aren't mentioned. Smoking critics have become increasingly galled at what they see as the sleazy tactics used to peddle cigarettes by Philip Morris and other companies. Many say they are particularly angered by subtle appeals to the young. The tobacco industry has agreed to a code that it will not use models under 25 to promote cigarettes. But many anti-smoking activists say the industry subverts that code by using over-25 models who appear to be kids. Others complain that cigarette makers intentionally place advertising billboards in places frequented by children. ``We have photographs of billboards near schoolyards and they're really showing youthful-looking people,'' said Harold Freeman, president of the American Cancer Society. ``Naturally, they're appealing to young people.'' Weiss denied Philip Morris targets young people or non-smokers. The company participates in a program in the schools to reinforce the fact that smoking is an adult choice, Weiss said. ``If you look at our advertising, you'll see that the Marlboro ad is somebody that is in their late 30s and 40s,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Feb. 18

DOC.HEAD: BP Posts 65 Percent Profit Gain In Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: British Petroleum Co. PLC on Thursday reported a 65 percent jump in fourth-quarter net profit and a 44 percent gain for 1989, aided by a rise in crude oil prices and record results in its chemicals business. BP, which owns Standard Oil Co. of Cleveland, Ohio, said its net profit for the three months ended Dec. 31 came to 448 million pounds, or $709 million converted at an average exchange rate for the period, compared with 272 million pounds, or $484 million, in the same period a year ago. Earnings per share rose to 8.3 pence from 4.5 pence. The company's financial statement is based on British accounting methods and cannot be directly compared with those of most American companies. Inventories are valued on the basis of first in first out (FIFO), or on a historical cost basis calculated after tax and interest expense and before extraordinary items, instead of the typical American system of last in first out (LIFO), or current cost basis. On a current cost basis, quarterly profit rose 13.5 percent to 345 million pounds, or $546 million, from 304 million pounds, or $541 million. Per-share earnings rose to 6.4 pence from 5 pence. Revenue for the three months rose 31 percent to 8.33 billion pounds from 6.37 billion pounds. Higher crude prices helped exploration and production earnings and offset lower production volumes and increased taxation, BP said. Average per barrel North Sea brent crude prices rose to $19.18 in the quarter from an average of $13.56 a year ago. Alaska North Slope crude prices averaged $17.27 a barrel vs. $11.69 in the fourth quarter of 1988, BP said. The rise in crude prices resulted in an inventory holding gain of 390 million pounds for the year, compared with a 232 million pound loss a year earlier. BP said its historical net profit for all of 1989 came to 1.74 billion pounds compared with 1.21 billion pounds in the previous year. Earnings per share came to 31.8 pence compared with 20 pence. On a current-cost basis, net profit slipped 5.6 percent to 1.36 billion pounds from 1.44 billion pounds. Annual revenue gained 14.3 percent to 29.6 billion pounds from 25.9 billion pounds. David Simon, BP managing director, said the oil company began repositioning itself in 1989 to become more profitable and competitive in the future. It refocused on its core businesses and completed a major restructuring early this year that included the sale of exploration and production assets for $1.3 billion. The company also moved to improve its worldwide retailing image during the year, Simon said. ``In BP Oil, we started a major program to re-image our worldwide retail network, putting all service stations under the single BP brand,'' Simon said. ``...We also launched in 1989 a major review of our corporate working practices and systems.'' Separately, British Petroleum's board Thursday confirmed Robert Horton as chairman of the company effective March 11. The appointment had been announced last year.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say Feds Decided Drexel Demise Not Threatening
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs, `The holding... to UPDATE with SEC postponing public meeting because of Drexel; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `Drexel previously...
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators let the parent company of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. slide into bankruptcy reorganization in part because they felt they didn't have to save it. While federal banking and securities watchdogs closely monitored Drexel's woes, ultimately they decided the collapse of one of the nation's largest investment banking houses posed little or no danger to the financial markets and banking system. ``I don't think there was any movement to do something,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which insures bank deposits and acts as the nation's top banking regulator. ``I think there was a general sense that we ought to monitor it carefully. But there was no great push to do something once it was found the bond-trading unit and the broker-dealer unit were solvent,'' Seidman said Wednesday. Drexel Burnham Lambert Group, the parent of the securities subsidiaries, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy code protection from creditors Tuesday night after defaulting on $100 million in short-term loans. The Securities and Exchange Commission, which regulates the stock and bond markets, noted that while it oversees the Drexel's broker-dealer arm, it had no legal mandate to assist the parent company. ``The holding company, which is not regulated by us, is what filed for Chapter 11,'' said an SEC spokeswoman, Mary McCue. The SEC today postponed a scheduled public meeting on potential rules changes because of Drexel. ``We're contiuing to monitor the Drexel situation closely, but there is no emergency. We think it's prudent (to postpone the meeting),'' an SEC spokeswoman said. Drexel previously sold off its retail brokerage business and ``in this situation there doesn't appear to be much consumer involvement,'' said Seidman. He acknowledged that the nation's savings and loans hold about $8 billion in junk bonds _ a Drexel speciality. If Drexel's woes drive down the already ailing market in junk bonds, Seidman said, ``that will make S&Ls that hold them insolvent quicker'' and force regulators to take the thrifts over sooner. The SEC is seeking authority from Congress to obtain information about the financial health of the holding companies of broker-dealers _ information currently denied the agency. Bills that would give the SEC such authority are pending in both the House and Senate and have the support of the Treasury Department. ``The continuing problems in the junk bond market point to the need for more complete disclosure and reliable asset valuation,'' Sen. Donald Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, said in a statement issued by his office. Congress is not in session this week, but several staff aides to key committees pointed out that unlike the savings and loan industry _ the target of a massive taxpayer-financed bailout _ securities firms are not federally insured to guarantee investors' losses. The staffers also noted that unlike Drexel, there was a political impetus to rescue individual corporations like Chrysler Corp. and Lockheed Corp. because of the tens of thousands of people across the country their collapse would have thrown out of work. Drexel's downfall marked the largest securities industry bankruptcy filing ever and one of the first exceptions to a long-held regulatory policy that some financial institutions are too big to be allowed to fail. That thinking was behind the government rescue of Continental Illinois National Bank & Trust Co. ``There's been a too-big-to-fail doctrine that has included Chrysler, Lockheed and other industrial units plus some banks. There has always been discussion about how broad it is and when it will be applied,'' said Seidman. ``Clearly in this case the judgment was the failure would not imperil the system,'' he said, calling the health of Drexel's federally regulated units ``a key factor.'' Broker-dealers are required by the SEC to maintain enough capital to offset the risk of the securities they trade in. Drexel's subsidiaries that trade in stocks and bonds, offer merger advice and buy federal bonds from the U.S. government had adequate capital even though the parent company, DBL Group, couldn't obtain loans to staunch a cash crisis. The SEC's refusal to allow the transfer of excess capital to the parent company from the broker-dealer unit helped trigger the bankruptcy filing.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Reports Record Second Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co., which has been torn by bickering among descendents of its founders, reported record second-quarter income and sales Thursday. Net earnings for the thre months ended Jan. 28 rose 11 percent to $105.2 million, or 81 cents per share, compared to $94.9 million, or 73 cents per share, during the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Net sales for the quarter rose 9 percent to $1.72 billion from $1.58 billion. ``A good total company earnings momentum has continued through the second quarter,'' David W. Johnson, Campbell's president and chief executive officer said in a statement released by the Camden, N.J.-based firm. Campbell also reported a 15 percent increase in six month earnings to $188.2 million, or $1.45 per share, compared to $164.2 million, or $1.27 per share, last year. Net sales for the period increased 11 percent to $3.25 billion, compared with $2.92 billion last year. The company's largest division, Campbell U.S.A., had second quarter earnings of $150 million, compared to $125.3 million during the same period a year ago. Division sales rose 8 percent to $1,027 million, compared to $953.1 million last year. Campbell International continued its sluggish performance, reporting a 3 percent increase in earnings to $24.3 million, compared to $23.7 million last years. Sales, boosted by acquisitions, increased 14 percent to $461.5 million, compared to $403.7 million the previous year. Campbell has been the target of speculation in recent months that the food-products company would be sold in the wake of a growing rift in the company's founding family. Some relatives of Campbell's late chairman John T. Dorrance Jr. said they were putting their 17 percent stake in the business up for sale and planned to push for the sale of the entire company. The company's board of directors said last month it would maintain Campbell's independence.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Up On Meal Strength; Grains Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices were slightly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting strength in the European market for soybean meal. Grain futures were narrowly mixed. Analysts said about 60,000 metric tons of soybean meal changed hands in Rotterdam, Netherlands, today at higher prices than in recent days. Wheat for near-term delivery was up amid expectations that China will tender soon for up to half of the 1 million metric tons of subsidized U.S. wheat offered to it last week by the Agriculture Department. But new-crop wheat and corn contracts were lower, pressured by selling linked to a winter storm that has spread beneficial precipitation across croplands from the Great Plains to the Midwest. ``The weather is bearish,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. ``They had a lot of rain and snow in the Midwest.'' In early trading, wheat futures were 2{ cents lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.88\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to \ cent lower with March at $2.43 a bushel; oats were { cent to } cent lower with March at $1.40\ a bushel; soybeans were } cent to 1{ cents higher with March at $5.67} a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .05 cent lower to .13 cent higher with February unchanged at 79.42 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent lower to .08 cent higher with March at 81.90 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .30 cent lower with February at 50.17 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .08 cent to .98 cent higher with February at 49.70 cents a pound. Cattle and pork futures settled mixed on Wednesday.

The stock market moved higher today and activity picked up as wary investors returned from the sidelines. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 8.11 points at 2,632.43 by noon on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 691 issues up, 557 down and 516 unchanged. After stalling in the previous two sessions, trading began picking up steam today. Market participants continued to monitor the unfolding of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s liquidation. The firm, whose parent sought bankruptcy court protection earlier this week, is in the process of transferring many of its businesses to other Wall Street firms. Because the process appears to be orderly, analysts said investors who had been on the sidelines began returning to the market. ``They're getting their courage back,'' said Michael Metz, a vice president at Oppenheimer & Co. ``There's a creaping back into the arena by those who have been underinvested in equities.'' Metz said the market was mildly encouraged by an upbeat Commerce Department report showing a 29.6 percent jump in housing starts during an exceptionally warm January. ``It's raised hopes that we will have a fairly good economy this year,'' he said. Separately, traders are looking ahead to Friday's release of merchandise trade figures for December. The consensus is that the trade deficit will have narrowed considerably, to around $9 billion, when compared with the previous month. Among blue chip issues, Reader's Digest, which just went public, headed the most-actives list and was trading at 22{ a share; Conrail, which has completed a share buyback, fell 2} to 46}, and IBM was up ] at 104[. The company, as expected, introduced a new family of workstations. J.C. Penney fell 1[ to 67] after reporting lower fourth-quarter profits. Some banking issues showed strong gains, including BankAmerica, up 1\ at 28\ and Manufacturers Hanover, up 1[ at 32~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.38 to 183.59. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.30 at 359.08. Volume on the Big Board came to 80.28 million shares at midday, against 69.70 million at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Penney Earnings Off Because of Prior Gain From Headquarters Sale
DOC.TEXT: Fourth-quarter profit at retailer J.C. Penney Co. Inc. fell 15.7 percent, mainly because the sale of its New York headquarters had inflated 1988 earnings, the company reported Thursday. Net income in the 13 weeks ended Jan. 27 was $367 million, or $2.95 per share, on revenue of $5.34 billion, compared with $435 million, or $3.19 per share, on revenue of $4.95 billion in the comparable quarter a year earlier. The previous year's quarter included a $139 million gain, or $1.06 per share, from the sale of Penney's former New York headquarters as a result of its decision to move to Texas. The company currently is based in temporary offices while a new headquarters is built in the Dallas suburb of Plano. Retail sales from the company's stores and catalog operations increased 8.8 percent during the period, to $5.26 billion from $4.84 billion. Other revenue fell 27.3 percent to $81 million from $112 million, reflecting Penney's withdrawal from the casualty insurance business. For the 52 weeks ended Jan. 27, Penney's net income was $802 million, or $5.86 per share, on total revenue of $16.41 million, compared with $807 million, or $5.92 per share, on $15.3 million in the prior year. The most recent period included a $20 million loss, or 16 cents per share, from the discontinuation of Telaction, an interactive television shopping venture. The earlier period also included the profit from the headquarters' sale. Retail sales for the year were up 8.6 percent from $14.3 billion to $16.1 billion. Other revenue dropped 34.9 percent, to $302 million from $463 million. The company said its margin also decreased during the quarter and the year because of increased promotional activity. Margins had improved in the previous year, Penney said, because its lower inventory had resulted in lower markdowns. ``During the 1980s, our repositioning efforts had been physical and directional,'' said Chairman William R. Howell. ``We reallocated our floor space in stores and focused on how our target consumers wanted to be served.'' ``During the 1990s, we will accelerate our efforts toward enhancing our fashion credibility,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of England Steps in to Avert Liquidity Problems at Drexel
DOC.TEXT: The Bank of England on Thursday outlined a special settlements procedure to ease payments on foreign exchange dealings involving Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s British unit. The British central bank said that Drexel's trading clients may make all payments due to Drexel up through Thursday to the Bank of England. The bank said it would hold the money until it was satisfied that Drexel had made counter payments to clients. This arrangement is a stop-gap measure to avoid liquidity problems stemming from market reaction to Drexel's bankruptcy filing in the United States on Tuesday. On Wednesday, Drexel Burnham Lambert Trading Ltd. arranged with the Bank of England to allow it to delay settlements on its foreign exchange and gold trading for one day. The move by the bank wasn't a direct effort to prop up Drexel's operations but merely to ensure that Drexel's dealings were matched up. However, the bank's involvement should calm nerves in the markets resulting from uncertainty surrounding Drexel. The Bank of England said it would hold payments from Drexel's clients until 1600 GMT next Tuesday, awaiting counter-payment from Drexel. If Drexel fails to make the payments, the bank will return the funds to the initial party, it said. The bank said it might extend the holding period if required by individual circumstances. The bank said it wouldn't get involved in any claims brought against Drexel.

DOC.HEAD: Reports $18 Million Quarterly Loss
DOC.TEXT: Truck-builder Navistar International Corp. today reported a loss of $18 million in the first quarter of its new fiscal year and attributed the red ink to lower demand for its products and higher production costs. Navistar said the net loss for the three months ended Jan. 31 amounted to 10 cents a share, compared with net income of $37 million, or 12 cents per share, for the same period a year ago. Revenue for the period totaled $886 million, a 12 percent decline from the $1 billion reported for the first quarter of fiscal 1989. Chairman James C. Cotting said Navistar's results suffered mainly from a slowdown in demand for medium and heavy trucks and engines for such vehicles. He also cited higher costs for labor and materials. Navistar, the nation's largest maker of medium and heavy trucks, said shipments of such vehicles by all North American manufacturers fell 21 percent during the first fiscal quarter, to 66,000 units from 84,000 a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Selling $1.5 Billion in Bonds
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank announced on Thursday that it is selling $1.5 billion worth of bonds paying 8.75 percent interest, in the United States, Europe and for the first time in Japan. The seven-year bonds are being sold at par. Proceeds from the sale will be lent out to Third World countries, for which the World Bank is the biggest source of aid loans. It is owned by 151 governments, including the United States and Japan. This is the bank's second global bond issue of this size. The first, last September, was not sold directly on the Japanese market. The bonds were traded among Japanese customers immediately afterwards, however. Sheldon Rappaport, a spokesman for the bank, said that this time Japanese authorities made concessions to the bank that allowed the bonds to be sold directly to the Japanese market. They were offered by a syndicate with 15 major sponsors, led by Goldman Sachs & Co. and Morgan Stanley & Co. Inc. IBJ International Limited and Nomura Securities were designated as co-lead managers.

DOC.HEAD: Ford, GM Earnings Fall Sharply In Fourth Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 new grafs to UPDATE with GM earnings down 50 percent in quarter; edits to conform. Picks up 10th graf, On Tuesday...
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. earnings fell by 50 percent and Ford Motor Co.'s profit tumbled by 72.9 percent in the fourth quarter, the nation's biggest automakers reported today in results that reflect their industry's recession. GM, the nation's biggest corporation, posted a profit of $700.2 million, in the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with earnings of $1.4 billion during the fourth quarter of 1988. GM's fourth-quarter earnings tumbled to $1.01 per share of common stock, compared with $2.12 the year before. Earlier, Ford posted a profit of $314 million, or 68 cents a share, during the fourth quarter compared with $1.16 billion, or $2.42 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Ford earnings declined largely because of a $424 million loss linked to the sale of its Rouge Steel Co. subsidiary, but even without that factor Ford's fourth-quarter earnings were down 36.3 percent. Together with Chrysler Corp., which Tuesday reported a $664-million loss during the fourth quarter, the nation's Big Three automakers made $370.2 million in the period, down 87.7 percent from the $3 billion the companies reported in profits in 1988. The earnings reflect the slump the auto industry entered in October, as the 1990 model year opened, and the costs of incentives the automakers used to try to spur sales. Automakers have closed plants and laid off thousands of workers as they cut production to bring it more in line with slow sales. The industry began a rebound in January, but that mainly came about because of incentives, which cut directly into profits. GM's fourth quarter earnings came on revenue of $27.7 billion during the 1989 period, compared with $28.85 billion in revenue a year before. Ford's revenue in its automotive and financial services business for the quarter amounted to $24.15 billion, compared with $23.91 billion in 1988. Its automotive revenue fell 4 percent while financial services revenue rose 40.2 percent. GM's profits in its North American automotive operations slumped during the period, but the company did not immediately provide figures. For all of last year, GM's profits fell 13.1 percent to $4.22 billion, on revenue of $112.53 billion, compared with a profit of $4.86 billion on revenue of $110.23 billion in 1988. Annual per-share earnings dropped to $6.33 from $7.17. The year-end figures represent the first time since 1985 that GM outearned No. 2 Ford. GM's major subsidiaries reported earnings Wednesday. General Motors Acceptance Corp. and GM Hughes Electronics Corp. reported declines, but Electronic Data Systems Corp. said its profit grew with added data-services customers. For the entire year, Ford's earnings fell 27.6 percent to $3.84 billion, or $8.22 a share, from $5.3 billion, or $10.96 a share, during 1988. In the United States, the company's profits for 1989 were down 56 percent, indicating that hourly workers will receive sharply lower profit-sharing checks this spring than the average of $2,800 each received last year. The company reported year-end revenue of $96.15 billion, compared with $92.45 billion the year before. Overseas earnings, which have bolstered Ford's worldwide profit for years, fell 3 percent in 1989 to $2.1 billion, mainly because of increased new-product development costs. On Tuesday, No. 3 Chrysler Corp. reported a fourth-quarter loss of $664 million, largely because of a one-time, $577-million charge for two plant closings and the costs of trimming its salaried work force by 2,300 jobs, or 8 percent. That compared with a $433-million profit during the fourth-quarter of 1988. For the entire year, Chrysler posted a $359 million profit, including the $577-million charge in the fourth-quarter and a one-time, $309-million profit in the third quarter from sale of stock in Mitsubishi Motors Corp. On Dec. 15, Ford sold its Rouge Steel operation to Marico Acquisition Corp., a company formed solely to buy the financially troubled steelmaker. That and Ford's announcement last month that its Ford Aerospace Corp. would be sold indicated the company was moving away from non-automotive businesses and back to cars and financial services.

DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Loses Another Round in Court
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp., battling a $3.8 billion bid by Georgia-Pacific Corp., suffered another setback today as a federal judge rejected its motion to block the hostile offer. U.S. District Judge Gene Carter rejected Great Northern's arguments, made in a hearing Monday, that its suitor and rival paper manufacturer should be stopped for violating federal securities laws. Great Northern had accused Georgia-Pacific of concealing plans to sell Maine mills and woodlands if its bid succeeded. The ruling came as Great Northern looked for a friendly buyer in what Georgia-Pacific called a last-ditch effort to resist its offer. Great Northern said Wednesday its investment banker, Goldman, Sachs & Co., had received inquiries from companies but the firm would not say how many comapnies or identify any of them. Great Northern said it had directed Goldman Sachs to seek bids higher than Georgia-Pacific's tender offer of $63 a share. Earlier Wednesday, Georgia-Pacific returned to federal court to ensure it was included in the bidding. Although Great Northern would not identify any of its potential buyers, one New York securities analyst said the only other domestic paper companies that would probably be capable of entering the bidding were Weyerhaeuser Co., based in Tacoma, Wash., and International Paper Co., based in Purchase, N.Y. ``What I don't know is if there are other companies domestically who might be willing to diversify into the paper business,'' said Sherman Chao of Salomon Brothers Inc. However, he added, ``The probability is high that G-P will prevail.'' A Weyerhaeuser spokesman had no comment on Great Northern. A spokesman for International Paper said he did not believe his firm has any interest in Great Northern, but even if it did, it would not comment on any merger talks. When Great Northern announced Tuesday night that it would seek other buyers, it also said it was postponing until March 20 a previously scheduled March 2 meeting at which its shareholders were to consider a Georgia-Pacific proposal to oust the Great Northern board of directors and install candidates nominated by Georgia-Pacific. Georgia-Pacific filed papers in U.S. District Court Wednesday accusing Great Northern of violating Maine corporate law through ``last-ditch efforts to manipulate GNN's own corporate machinery for the benefit of the company's self-interested management and directors.'' Georgia-Pacific asked Carter to restore the March 2 meeting and oversee and supervise the auction for Great Northern. Great Northern also said it had amended its bylaws so that in the event Georgia-Pacific's candidates ended up controlling the board, they still would be forced to use Great Northern's ``poison pill'' defense against hostile takeovers. A poison pill drives up the cost of a hostile bid by allowing Great Northern to issue extra stock at a discount. ``There can be no doubt that GNN's attempt to restrict the power of future directors is in blatant violation of Maine statutes, and well-established principles of corporate law,'' Georgia-Pacific said. Great Northern vowed to contest Georgia-Pacific's challenge.

DOC.HEAD: Whittle Gives Channel One a Sendoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOPS with 7 new grafs from news conference. Picks up 4th graf pvs, Channel One ...
DOC.TEXT: Whittle Communications said today that more than 2,500 schools have signed up for its commercially sponsored Channel One news program for the classroom, which is scheduled to debut nationally on March 5. Christopher Whittle, chairman of Knoxville, Tenn.-based media company, also said the company has sold $200 million in advertising for the first three years of the program, including about $65 million for the first year. That amounts to about two-thirds of the revenue that the company hopes to earn from ad sales. At a news conference, Whittle said the daily show will be seen in 400 schools with 300,000 students on the launch date and that 1,000 schools should be showing it by the end of March. Whittle said the number of schools will rise each week as the company installs television monitors and other equipment in the schools. He said was confident of reaching his goal of signing 7,000 to 8,000 schools with six million students by December. Whittle, who was joined by former U.S. education secretary T.H. Bell, who heads a committee of educators advising Channel One, and others, said the service was ``the most significant educational idea that is going on right now.'' He said his company had awarded a $900,000 grant to the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research and the firm Interwest Applied Research to study Channel One's ``contribiution to education over the next three years.'' And Whittle struck back at critics who say commercial-free programming being made available by the cable TV industry is more suitable for use in the classroom, saying a recent poll his company commissioned indicated few students are being exposed to the cable programming. He blamed lack of equipment, and said the Channel One system alone addresses that issue. Channel One has generated considerable controversy because it would include two minutes of commercials within each 12-minute daily news program. Critics have said it is wrong to allow advertisers to pitch their products in ads to a captive audience of teenagers in the classroom. Whittle has argued that teens are exposed to plenty of commercial messages every day and that the ads were a fair price to pay for getting the news show plus the Whittle-provided television monitors and other equipment needed to show the program. State education officials in California and New York have banned Channel One from their public schools. The state Board of Education in North Carolina recently prohibited schools there from signing up for the program, saying in part that it forces students to watch commercial advertising. That decision will not invalidate contracts that about 100 schools in the state already have signed to get Channel One, provided the show does not infringe on the 5{-hour school day, but the contracts cannot be renewed when they expire. Channel One had originally set a goal of being in 1,000 schools at the launch date, and announced in November that 1,050 schools had signed up. Equipment installation reportedly began in January. In September, Whittle announced it had signed contracts for $51 million in advertising for the first year of the service, more than half of its first-year goal of $90 million in ad revenue. Cynthia Kalish Samuels, a former planning producer for NBC's ``Today Show'' was named executive producer of the Channel One staff in October. Winter said she has assembled a news staff which has begun producing stories.

DOC.NOTE: $adv19
For release Monday Feb. 19
DOC.HEAD: Family Keeps Cigar Tradition Smoldering
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Never mind that cigars have become passe in America's board rooms and the tobacco industry is under siege. Bill Finck isn't about to snuff out the family business. His grandfather, Henry William Finck, started Finck Cigar Co. in 1893 with $1,000 he borrowed against a life insurance policy, establishing a hand-rolling cigar operation in part of an old house. Automation wasn't added until 1963. ``My father didn't like machines,'' Finck, 59, explained as he puffed a Travis Club cigar while walking between clanging machines and shoulder-high tobacco crates at the company's downtown San Antonio plant. Today, the company runs the only automated cigar factory in Texas or any of 19 other Midwest or Southwest states, the Institute of Texan Cultures says. The factory employs 76 workers who sort tobacco, operate cigar wrapper-cutting and filler-packing machines and oversee cardboard box packaging. ``It used to be that every big town had its own cigar factory,'' Finck said. ``I guess there was just too much competition for a lot of the little guys.'' The dozen members of the Cigar Association of America account for about 90 percent of the 2.5 billion cigars produced in the country each year. Although Finck Cigar Co. is not in that elite group, the Fincks don't consider themselves small. The company produces millions of cigars a year, but Finck declined to reveal the exact number or disclose other financial details. ``I don't tell,'' he said. ``We've got to have a little aura of mystery surrounding us.'' Most Finck employees are women _ a cigar factory tradition because female hands are said to be more delicate with the meticulous work. Some have devoted their lives to the factory. Liberata Fernandez has spent 73 of her 86 years working for the Fincks. Fellow worker Rafaela Sanchez has 72 years of service. ``I like everybody around here,'' Ms. Fernandez said. ``It's easy for me.'' Finck credits the tobacco blends and techniques the company has developed throughout the years with keeping its reputation rolling. ``I guess my grandfather knew what he was doing,'' Finck said. ``Nobody can do the combinations that we do.'' The Travis Club brand, marketed regionally, includes 14 types of cigars varying in size, quality and cost. Travis Club Senators are perhaps the most popular, while Travis Club Churchills _ thick 7-inchers _ are among the highest quality, Finck said. The Fincks also are concentrating on a mail order business and producing cigar combinations requested by other companies. Finck Cigar Co. buys a variety of tobacco for creating the blends that go into its products. The huge, brown tobacco leaves are shipped in from such faraway places as Brazil, Honduras and the Dominican Republic as well as from the states of Connecticut, Virginia and North Carolina. Finck has his own quality control methods. The most important element is uniformity, and the best test is to simply look at the tobacco, he said. But Finck also likes to burn a spot with his cigar in a tobacco leaf to check the color of the ash. Finck's penchant for the tobacco business has influenced his 27-year-old son, Billy, a Texas A&M University graduate who helps run the cigar company and also enjoys puffing a stogie while roaming the factory. Some of Finck's other children also have worked there. ``I let all of them come and learn how to lay cigar wrappers,'' he said. ``I think it's good for them. They didn't like it too much.'' Finck himself got involved with the cigar business as a child, and even started chomping on a butt at a young age. ``I smoked the first one in front of my parents when I was 8 _ they thought it was cute.'' Though the cigar company occupies much of his time, Finck also has been involved in ranching and is a lawyer. He keeps a set of law books in his cigar factory office and does legal work related to investor-owned water utilities. Long known as a political maverick, Finck served in the Texas Legislature from 1967 to 1972 and became chairman of the powerful House Appropriations Committee. When redistricting took effect in 1972, Finck lost his office in a Democratic runoff. That didn't keep him out of politics. He later ran for county treasurer with the promise of abolishing the office. He won. He kept the promise, setting fire to one of his paychecks with _ what else _ a cigar. ``Politics and making cigars kind of blend together,'' Finck said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday Feb. 19

DOC.HEAD: Reebok Announces Restructuring, U.S. President Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Reebok International Ltd. said Thursday it had combined its domestic and international Reebok divisions, and the president of the U.S. operation announced his resignation. Frank O'Connell, who was president of the U.S. division the past two years, said he was departing the athletic-shoe company ``with positive feelings.'' ``It was a situation where I didn't see the opportunity to exercise my leadership skills,'' O'Connell, 46, said in a phone interview. ``I don't want to stay unless I could really run it.'' Paul Fireman, chairman and chief executive officer of Reebok, said in a statement that John Duerden will be president of the combined, global business. Duerden, 49, was previously president of the international division. Combining the two divisions ``is the most effective way to maximize the global opportunities for the Reebok brand,'' Fireman said, adding that Duerden's experience will help the company focus on worldwide sales. Under the new structure, Duerden will report directly to Fireman, as will the presidents of other company divisions, such as Avia and Rockport shoes and Boston Whaler boats.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Finish Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with closing quotes.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices finished higher on London's Stock Exchange Thursday, after late afternoon international buying perked up the market. Trading got off to a gloomy start in the wake of Wednesday's 1-point hike in Abbey National PLC's basic mortgage rate to 15.4 percent, above Britain's 15 percent base lending rate. But later in the session, investors were relieved that West German monetary authorities decided to leave key interest rates unchanged. Robust demand for international blue-chip stocks from U.S. investors drove the market still higher, dealers said. By the end of the European day, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 11.72 points at 2,636.04, helping to boost the London market. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed up 15.5 points, or 0.7 percent, at 2,313.8. The Financial Times 30-share iike the thousands of others who toiled for the dreaded STB, the Czech acronym for the now disbanded secret police, Zak is under orders to stay home while an Interior Ministry commission mulls his fate. In keeping with the philosophy of love and dignity preached by President Havel, it's a mild punishment for years of repression Zak helped carry out under the Communist government. The routine leaves Zak and countless other former functionaries across Eastern Europe hours to ponder the fate that has wrenched power from their hands. A year ago the burly, balding Zak confidently rasped out testimony that sent Havel to jail for four months on charges of obstructing a police official. In an interview with The Associated Press, Zak seemed deflated. Seated in his neat apartment in a shabby block on the outskirts of Prague, he groped to describe the change that has torn him from the 20 years of intelligence work he clearly relished. ``It was a bit of a shock,'' he finally conceded during an hour-long interview. When unrest broke out after the Nov. 17 police attack on peaceful students, ``some official structures did not act at all, some went beyond their authority _ and the result was what happened,'' he said. As head of a 30-member department dealing with what he calls ``extremism in independent initiatives,'' Zak was among those who best knew Havel, Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier and an array of other dissidents catapulted by revolution into positions of power. In his classic Bolshevik ``we lost-they won'' view, this transformation was less surprising for Zak than for a startled world watching Czechoslovakia's rapid makeover. He had long gathered information by interrogating the dissidents, listening to informers _ who he insists were unpaid _ and conducting surveillance easily observed by every visitor to dissidents' homes. Zak claimed the dissidents long ago drew up a ``schedule'' of events for 1989 that foresaw the eventual assumption of power. And he's sure things wouldn't have happened so fast without ``certain international support'' for his opponents. There were a few mistakes on the Communists' side, too, he admitted. One was a failure publicly to acknowledge, or perhaps even play upon, differences between the various dissident groups; another was that ``we were forced more and more to carry out preventive measures, and not our own intelligence work.'' It was during these ``preventive measures'' _ the only term Zak used to describe detention or interrogation _ that he spent hours in discussion with Havel, Dienstbier and others, puffing on ``Petra'' cigarettes, the cheap brand smoked by all three men. ``If they had something constructive to say, or something I didn't know before, I was ready to accept, or tolerate it,'' Zak said. Why then was no public action taken to open dialogue with the dissidents? ``Ask the politicians,'' Zak replied. Zak believes the Communists should and will play a significant role in Czechoslovakia. He refused to talk about differences among the former leaders over what to do about the dissidents, saying only that four groups fought for control. Equally loyally, he refused to criticize the decision on Jan. 16, 1989 to arrest Havel. Zak was one of those who detained the playwright after a small demonstration on Wenceslas Square, which Havel observed without taking part. The arrest finally drove thousands of intellectuals who had refused to side openly with the dissidents into signing petitions for Havel's release. It was the start of a revolt that moved with furious pace after Nov. 17. Many former Communist functionaries have found th changes unbearable. At least six people closely associated with the old rulers, including two policemen and former Slovak Communist leader Viliam Salgovic, long reputed to be a KGB agent, have committed suicide since the revolution. Scattered reports in state media indicate many Communists are being fired and finding it hard to get work at even the most menial tasks. Zak said his children met some resentment at school ``when they refused to join in certain actions'' of protest of the authorities. ``And I suppose,'' he said, ``I was also punished by what is happening to me.''

The stock market moved higher and the pace of trading quickened today, but investor enthusiasm for equities was restrained. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 15.09 points at 2,639.41 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 824 issues up, 558 down and 501 unchanged. Trading was stalled earlier in the week, but the market seemed to pick up some steam today. Market participants casually monitored the unfolding of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s liquidation. The firm, whose parent sought bankruptcy court proteciton, is in the process of transferring many of its businesses to other Wall Street firms. Because the process appeared to be orderly, analysts said investors who had been on the sidelines began returning to the market. ``The market has held up well in the face of adversity,'' said Tom Walsh, a vice president at Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. in reference to Drexel. But he noted that traders are looking for a better indication of the nation's economic health, which should come Friday when the government releases merchandise trade figures for December. ``I do not see major commitments from investors until a clear economic picture emerges,'' Walsh said. The consensus is that the trade deficit will have narrowed considerably, to around $9 billion, when compared with the previous month. Meanwhile, stocks continued to fluctuate in a relatively narrow range. ``They seem to be drifting to the higher end of that range, but without any clear direction,'' said Peter Vandenberg, a trader with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Among blue chip issues, Reader's Digest, which just went public, headed the most-actives list and was trading at 22[ a share; Conrail, whose share buyback was oversubscribed, fell 2{ to 47, and IBM, which introduced a new family of workstations, was up | at 104]. Several banking issues jumped higher, including BankAmerica, up 1| at 28|, Citicorp, up 1[ at 24| and Chase Manhattan, up 1\ at 28}. In the auto sector, General Motors was up 1\ at 44\ and Ford rose | to 45\. Both automakers reported sharply lower fourth-quarter profits, but the numbers were in line with expectations. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.92 to 184.13. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.57 at 359.35. Volume on the Big Board came to 116.03 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.NOTE: $adv19
For release Monday, Feb. 19
DOC.HEAD: Americans Threaten Trade Sanctions Over Egypt's Video Business
DOC.TEXT: Barbary pirates once lurked along Egypt's coast to plunder Mediterranean shipping. Their modern-day counterparts lurk in Egyptian video stores, plundering U.S. copyrights. Videocassette piracy has gotten so bad in Egypt that the United States has warned it will respond with trade sanctions unless the violations stop by April. Egypt is among a few U.S. trading partners like Taiwan, South Korea and Thailand that, because of video piracy, risk retaliation under the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988. Egyptians in the purloined video trade said the Americans are concerned particularly about Egypt because of its history as a cultural trend-setter for the Arabs. In Egyptian video shops, ``every U.S. film is pirated,'' said Walid Nasser, an anti-piracy official of the Motion Picture Export Association of America who has a special office in Egypt. Some video dealers said the high cost of going legal could put them out of business. But that is no justification for piracy in the view of U.S. Ambassador Frank G. Wisner, who recently warned that the problem has become an important issue on the Egyptian-U.S. agenda. Wisner said by 1986, video piracy already was costing the U.S. film industry $23 million a year in Egypt, where the business began in the early 1980s. Cairo's video shops and small rental clubs are crammed with Grade B American movies with titles ranging from ``Magnificent Warriors'' to ``Fists of Steel,'' favorites in working-class and rural areas. But more exclusive video rental shops, like those in the city's swank ``sporting clubs'' frequented by expatriates and the Egyptian elite, offer tapes of the latest Hollywood films, often just released in the United States. Many are of abysmal technical quality that reveal bootleg copying, and the work of Moslem Egypt's sex-conscious film censor is intrusive. But the price is attractive, generally the equivalent of $1 or less for two nights' rental, and a censored, scratchy Batman or Indiana Jones remains a blockbuster. Dealing in such pirated videos violates an international convention on copyrights that Cairo signed in 1977. But Egypt's laws protecting films, books and intellectual properties are outdated and ineffectual, providing for penalties no higher than $40 or three months in jail for repeat offenders. ``If fines are strong enough, and if someone is taken to court and put in jail, he won't do it again,'' said the Motion Picture Export Association's Nasser. ``But the law as it is has no teeth.'' A tough proposal to amend Egypt's 1954 law on intellectual property has been in the works for two years. It would penalize piracy with fines of up to $4,000 and three years in prison. Despite U.S. pressure, the amendment has yet to be taken up by Parliament because of other legislation that members consider more pressing. Ambassador Wisner, appearing at a seminar with video-piracy fighter Nasser, warned that Egypt risks joining at least seven other countries on the ``priority watch list'' of governments lax on piracy. He said Hollywood's annual worldwide losses to piracy are estimated at about $1 billion. Wisner said the United States invokes trade sanctions only ``if the situation is grave. It is very important to the United States.'' Sanctions could mean barriers to Egyptian textiles in the U.S. market, for example, which would be a major blow. U.S. figures show such exports to the United States have been doubling each year since 1986 and now total more than $120 million a year. Under the competitiveness act, the office of U.S. Trade Representative Carla A. Hills must tell Congress by April what Egypt is doing to fight video piracy, Wisner said. Egypt organized an Anti-Piracy Squad a decade ago, but the group of a dozen Tax Department officers assigned to regulate 3,000 video dealers nationwide is considered a symbol of weak enforcement. Its leader, Brig. Hussein Abdel-Rahman, denied Nasser's contention that all U.S. films are pirated, but conceded that at least 60 percent probably were. The rest are transferred legally from 35mm film onto videotape by production companies with legally purchased copyrights, he said. Moreover, only 20 percent of the 300 piracy cases filed in 1989 involved American and other foreign films, he said. ``We are not encouraging or neglecting piracy,'' he said. ``Unless a film producer complains to us, we don't have the means to control every video store and club.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday Feb. 19

DOC.HEAD: IBM's New Workstations Enter Fast-Growing Market It's Never Mastered
LaserPhoto NY30
DOC.TEXT: IBM unveiled a line of computer workstations Thursday that the company says outperform and underprice the competition and should help it snare a major stake in a fast-growing market where it never had success. ``The opportunity is big _ it's growing at over 30 percent a year, and it's mostly a new opportunity for IBM,'' said President Jack D. Kuehler. The machines, called the RISC System-6000, also mark the first time that the world's largest computer maker has wholeheartedly embraced the Unix computer operating system that is fast becoming the industry standard.
