International Business Machines Corp. also announced its intention to provide ways to link the new machines with IBM computers that run on its proprietary operating system. An operating system is software that controls basic computer functions, such as executing commands from the keyboard and opening computer files. Kuehler told a news conference that the new machines, designed for use by engineers, ``outperform the newest and best that our competitors offer.'' IBM announced four high-performance workstations and five file-servers, which are used to link computers in a network. The machines range in price from about $13,000 to more than $74,000. IBM said the lowest-price model is the most powerful desktop workstation on the market, beating the offering of Sun Microsystems Inc., considered the workstation leader. The IBM model performs 27.5 million instructions per second, or mips, compared with 12.5 mips for the Sun model. It also is slightly cheaper than Sun's. Industry analysts say the workstations are impressive for their performance, pricing and features. ``From the customer standpoint, I think it's going to get IBM into the door in ways it didn't before,'' said Peter Burris, an analyst for International Data Corp. in Framingham, Mass. Workstations are desktop or side-of-desk machines that are much more powerful than personal computers. Some even match the power of mainframes. They are used for such processing-intensive tasks as three-dimensional computer modeling of new products. The workstation market is small, but is among the fastest-growing computer segments, and uses for the machines are expanding. ``A lot of things start in the scientific market and gravitate out toward other markets,'' said Barry Bosak, an analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. IBM introduced a workstation line several years ago, the RT line, but it captured less than 3 percent of market. Experts consider the machines underpowered and overpriced. ``We made a mistake,'' Kuehler said in an interview. The workstation field is dominated by Sun, Digital Equipment Corp. and Hewlett-Packard Co. Unix, developed by American Telephone & Telegraph Co., allows machines from different manufacturers to work together. Until now, IBM had promoted its own operating systems. Basing the workstations on Unix shows IBM is serious about this market, Kuehler said in the interview. It also is recognition of the huge library of Unix-based software available for workstations, he said. The machines are based on IBM's own version of Unix, called AIX, but are a new generation of the operating system. Analysts said the new AIX is even more compatible with industry standards. Unix-based applications programs _ the software that provides the actual uses of computers, such as word processing _ must be rewritten for AIX. IBM has been working with software companies for some time to develop programs for the new machines. By the end of the year, about 1,500 application programs worldwide will be available, it said. IBM's embrace of Unix has broad implications for the operating standard, said Louise Rehling, a senior vice president at SPSS Inc., a Chicago software company that was among those recruited. ``We think IBM is going to bring a lot of credibility to the Unix markeplace,'' she said. ``The size of the pie will grow as well as the IBM share.'' Like the older IBM workstations, the new models are based on reduced-instruction-set computing technology, or RISC, which simplifies the circuitry of a computer's central processor to increase speed and offer cost savings. But IBM said the RISC system in the new machines is greatly improved. Shipments of the workstations will begin within 90 days, IBM said. Bosak said the workstations would have little short-term impact on IBM's earnings. But they represent an important signal that the company is working to improve its fortunes. Last month, IBM reported its 1989 profit slipped 35 percent from the year before. The company also has embarked on a cost-cutting program that involves the elimination of thousands of jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects GNN's Allegations of Georgia-Pacific Cover-Up
DOC.TEXT: Embattled Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. suffered another setback Thursday as a federal judge refused to block Georgia-Pacific Corp.'s $3.8 billion hostile bid for the rival paper company. Great Northern argued in a hearing on Monday that the $63 a share tender offer should be stopped because Georgia-Pacific executives lied about plans to sell Great Northern's assets in Maine if the merger goes through. Great Northern also asked U.S. District Judge Gene Carter to halt Georgia-Pacific's efforts to oust the Great Northern board in a proxy fight, saying the purported cover-up violated federal securities laws and as a result, its suitor should not be allowed to continue the proxy battle. Carter refused, saying in a 20-page ruling Great Northern had not proved any of its charges. ``Not only has Great Northern failed to meet its burden of showing that Georgia-Pacific had a plan to divest Great Northern assets, which would make its (Securities and Exchange Commission) filings and other public statements untrue, but there is significant evidence suggesting that Georgia-Pacific affirmatively decided not to develop or adopt such a plan,'' the judge wrote. Great Northern had not had time to study the ruling, so had no immediate comment, spokesman Stephen M. Hill said Thursday from the company's headquarters in Norwalk, Conn. Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific has steadfastly denied any plans to sell the Great Northern mills in Millinocket and East Millinocket or Great Northern's 2.1 million acres of the northern Maine woods. But Great Northern produced various memos and notes that it claimed showed Georgia-Pacific has been considering the acquisition of Great Northern since at least 1984, and selling the Maine assets were always part of its strategy. Georgia-Pacific accused Great Northern of forming its arguments out of isolated snippets of information. In response to Great Northern's charges, Georgia-Pacific produced affidavits and depositions from 14 witnesses, including Georgia-Pacific executives, bankers and consultants. All the documents disputed Great Northern's contentions about Georgia-Pacific's plans. Great Northern said the testimony produced by the witnesses could not be believed because it appeared to contradict the memos and notes, which were written before possible sales of the Maine assets became an issue in the state. Carter dismissed that argument, saying, ``since notes are by their very nature abbreviated and sometimes cryptic, an explanation of them is often helpful to the court in determining their significance.'' Carter went on to say he was ``satisfied that the affidavits accurately reflect Georgia-Pacific's intent because all the evidence indicates that Georgia-Pacific strongly resisted an asset sales plan as part of the financing package.'' Great Northern's latest defeat came two days after it announced it had begun soliciting buyers who would offer more than Georgia-Pacific's $63 per share. Securities analysts said Great Northern realized it had lost its battle to remain independent because of a ruling from the court last week that would make it easier for Georgia-Pacific to oust the Great Northern directors. Great Northern would not comment on any of its potential buyers, Hill said Thursday.

The stock market moved steadily higher and the pace of trading quickened today, but investor enthusiasm for equities was restrained. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 14.19 points at 2,638.51 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 818 issues up, 614 down and 491 unchanged. Trading was stalled earlier in the week, but the market gathered steam today. Market participants casually monitored the unfolding of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s liquidation. The firm, whose parent sought bankruptcy court protection, is in the process of transferring many of its businesses to other Wall Street firms. Because the process appeared to be orderly, analysts said investors who had been on the sidelines began returning to the market. ``The market has held up well in the face of adversity,'' said Tom Walsh, a vice president at Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. in reference to Drexel. But he noted that traders are looking for clues to the nation's economic health, which should come Friday when the government releases merchandise trade figures for December. ``I do not see major commitments from investors until a clear picture emerges,'' Walsh said. The consensus is that the trade deficit will have narrowed considerably, to around $9 billion, compared with November. Meanwhile, stocks held to a relatively narrow range. ``They seem to be drifting to the higher end of that range, but without any clear direction,'' said Peter Vandenberg, a trader with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. Among the most actively traded stocks, two new issues led the list. Reader's Digest was trading at 22, up 2 from its initial price, and Growth Fund of Spain, a mutual fund, was trading at 13{, up 1{ from the asking price. Conrail, whose share buyback was oversubscribed, fell 2{ to 47, and IBM, which introduced a new family of workstations, was up { at 104\. Banking issues were touted by analysts, pushing the sector higher. Gainers included including BankAmerica, up 1] at 28], Citicorp, up 1] at 24~ and Chase Manhattan, up 1{ at 29. In the auto sector, General Motors was up 1[ at 44[ and Ford rose | to 45\. Both automakers reported sharply lower fourth-quarter profits, but the numbers were in line with expectations. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.90 to 184.11. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 0.51 at 359.29. Volume on the Big Board came to 138.57 million shares with an hour to go.

DOC.HEAD: Hanson Buys 45 Percent Stake in Largest U.S. Coal Producer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th grav pvs, `Hanson owns ...,' to UPDATE with SEC filing in which Hanson says it may buy all of Peabody.
DOC.TEXT: The British conglomerate Hanson PLC said Thursday its U.S. arm was buying a 45 percent stake in Peabody Holding Co. Inc., the largest coal producer in the United States, for $504 million in cash. Sir Gordon White, chairman of Hanson Industries, called the purchase ``an attractive investment.'' Hanson Industries agreed to buy the Peabody holdings of three U.S. shareholders, Boeing Co., Bechtel Investments Inc. and energy company Eastern Enterprises. U.S.-based Newmont Mining Corp. is the other major shareholder in Peabody, with a 55 percent share. Hanson owns a 49 percent interest in Newmont Mining, acquired as part of its $5.6 billion acquisition of Consolidated Gold Fields PLC in August 1989. Hanson also said in a filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington that it may offer to buy the remaining shares in Peabody. In addition, the conglomerate said it may seek the restructuring or recapitalization of Peabody, or seek the sale of its stake in the company or of some of Peabody's assets. Peabody had pretax profit of $136.5 million on sales of $1.74 billion in 1989. After-tax profit was not available, Hanson said. The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals and consent from Peabody's lenders and Newmont Mining, Hanson said.

DOC.HEAD: Gillette Reports 6 Percent Earnings Growth In 1989
DOC.TEXT: Gillette Co. said Thursday its 1989 earnings grew 6 percent compared with the year before, while fourth-quarter earnings climbed 29 percent for the world's leading razor-blade maker. In the quarter ended Dec. 31, Gillette had earnings of $79.4 million, or 68 cents a share, compared with $61.5 million, or 63 cents a share, in the same quarter of 1988. Revenue for the quarter totaled $1.05 billion, marking the first time the company surpassed $1 billion in sales in any quarter. Revenue for 1988's fourth quarter was $968 million. For all of 1989, Gillette reported net income of $284.7 million, or $2.70 a share, on sales of $3.8 billion, compared with earnings of $268.5 million, or $2.45 a share, on sales of $3.58 billion in 1988. The company said sales in its North Atlantic division, which covers North America and Europe, were ``moderately higher'' for 1989, while the operating profit was virtually unchanged. Dave Fausch, a Gillette spokesman, said the profit for this division was hurt by the performance of the company's toiletry products. In December, the company realigned its toiletry operations, merging them with the shaving division. Gillette also has sold some personal care product lines in Europe. Fausch said Gillette is encouraged about 1990, as the company promotes its new Sensor razor, which was introduced last month with much fanfare. The high-tech razor, priced higher than previous models, is designed to offer a closer shave. The Sensor is part of Gillette's strategy to persuade customers to switch from disposable brands to higher-priced razors with replaceable blades. Fausch said ``the trend lines are going well'' in this initiative.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Gain on Meal Strength; Grains Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose modestly Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting strength in the European market for soybean meal, while wheat futures retreated and corn futures closed mixed. Soybean meal traded more actively and at higher prices Thursday in Rotterdam than it had in several days, analysts said. But the rally in Chicago _ meal for March delivery rose 80 cents to $165.90 per ton _ was weak in comparison, said Anne Frick, senior oilseed analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. Soybean oil futures also strengthened, though, which helped to boost soybean prices, she said. Wheat and corn futures remained under pressure from a winter storm that has brought large amounts of beneficial moisture to croplands from the Great Plains to the Midwest. At the close, wheat futures were { cent to 1} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.86\ a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.42{ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $1.40\ a bushel; soybean futures were 2 cents to 4} cents higher with March at $5.71{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Eruption of the Redoubt Volcano in Alaska fueled energy futures prices Thursday amid concern that oil supplies could be disrupted. However, activity in the petroleum pits continued even after reports that the eruption would have only a minor impact, analysts said. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the main grade of U.S. crude, jumped 77 cents to $22.84 a barrel. Later months posted gains of 40 cents to 48 cents. Among refined products, wholesale unleaded gasoline for March delivery rose 0.75 cent a gallon to 60.64 cents a gallon, April advanced 0.92 cent to 61.64 cents, while later months had gains of more than a penny a gallon. Heating oil for March surged 1.01 cents to 58.65 cents a gallon, April rose 0.70 cent to 57.96 cents and May ended at 56.84 cents, up 0.50 cent a gallon. Analysts said the markets opened on a firm note led by heating oil, which gained strength from rising European demand at a time many refineries are slowing down for annual maintenance checks. The crude market came alive on news that Redoubt Volcano located about 115 miles southwest of Anchorage had erupted. ``The concern was that the eruption might impact Alaska crude supplies,'' said Andrew Lebow, senior broker and analyst for E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. However, energy brokers said the markets continued to rally in heavy trading even after news that the volcano might have only a minor impact on supplies around Cook Inlet but would not affect the crucial Prudhoe Bay supplies or the Alaska pipeline. Traders attributed the strength in products to refinery maintenance turnarounds in Europe that will be followed by turnarounds in this country in March and April.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Fell $374.1 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 497 money market mutual funds fell $374.1 million in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline, to $387.11 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a revised $2.82 billion increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The funds' assets hit a record high $387.48 billion in the week ended Feb. 7. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 244 general purpose funds rose $351.5 million to $131.22 billion, assets of 101 broker-dealer funds increased $43.1 million to $164.46 billion, and assets of 152 institutional funds declined $768.7 million to $91.42 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.65 percent from 7.66 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.68 percent from 7.71 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 43 days, unchanged from the previous week, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.29 percent as of Wednesday from 6.30 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was 5.07 percent, unchanged from a week earlier. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.88 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 7.94 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 7.95 percent; 7.94 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 7.95 percent; and 8.00 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 7.98 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Rises In Brisk Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market came out of the doldrums Thursday to close higher in brisk trading. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 25.23 points to close at 2,649.55. Advancing issues issues outnumbered declining ones by about 11 to 7 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 908 up, 583 down and 469 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 174.63 million shares, up from 138.53 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 202.31 million shares. The market gained ground steadily throughout the day, with banking stocks and two new issues leading the advance. Traders drew confidence from the fact that the market ``survived Drexel,'' said Alfred E. Goldman, a senior vice president at St. Louis-based A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. He was referring to the liquidation of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., whose parent sought bankruptcy court protection earlier this week. The firm has begun transferring many of its businesses to other Wall Street firms, a process that appeared to be going smoothly. ``People now believe we can manage surprises and shocks to the financial system,'' said Hugh Johnson, a senior vice president at First Albany Corp. With that behind the market, Johnson said the focus ``shifted toward what really matters _ economic data.'' The government reported a 29.6 percent rise in January housing starts and a sharp rise in housing permits, both of which were significantly stronger than expected. ``They tend to dispel the notion that we're in a recession, and the case for a recession during 1990 was ... certainly weakened,'' Johnson said. Still, investor enthusiasm for equities remained restrained until a clearer picture of the economy emerges. ``A lot of people are looking at the market through rose-colored glasses,'' Goldman said. ``They are ignoring the southbound trip of bonds, higher interest rates here and abroad, and lower corporate profits for the next few quarters.'' The market could get a jolt Friday, when a number of stock-index futures and options will expire and the government releases merchandise trade figures for December. Heading the Big Board's most-active list were two new issues. Growth Fund of Spain, a single-country mutual fund, finished at 13, up 1 from its initial price, and Reader's Digest closed at 22, up 2 from its offering price. Analysts said heavy trading in these two issues affected overall volume. Several analysts recommended a number of money center and regional banks. Gainers within the sector included BankAmerica, up 1{ at 28{; Chase Manhattan, up 1} at 29\; Citicorp, up 1{ at 25; Manufacturers Hanover, up 1] at 33[ and J.P. Morgan, up 1[ at 37[. In the auto sector, General Motors rose 1 to 44 and Ford was up | to 45\. Both automakers reported lower profits for the final 1989 quarter, but the numbers were in line with market expectations. Elsewhere, Coca-Cola, which boosted its quarterly a dividend and announced plans for a stock split, gained 2] to 69{; IBM, which unveiled a new family of workstations, was unchanged at 103}, and J.C. Penney fell 2} to 65}. The retailer announced lower quarterly profits. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $25.98 billion, or 0.81 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.49 to 184.70. Standard & Poor's industrial index gained 3.38 to 386.51, and S&P's 500-stock composite index advanced 2.88 to 334.89. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 3.05 to 429.61. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 359.60, up 0.82.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Higher, Gold Generally Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar advanced against all major currencies except the Canadian dollar Thursday although there was little news to guide the foreign exchange markets. Gold prices were generally lower. Gold fell $4.30 to close at $412.40 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $413 a troy ounce, down $3.70. Analysts said the dollar rose as traders adjusted their positions after the U.S. currency's recent losses. Robert Ryan, senior foreign exchange trader with the Bank of New York, said concerns about the bankruptcy filing by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. earlier this week had abated. Ryan said there was no fundamental news to influence the market Thursday. However, he said, the dollar could drift higher. Overseas dealers said traders were reluctant to buy a lot of dollars in advance of Friday's scheduled release of U.S. trade figures for December. Dealers reported the West German mark, which has soared in response to the political changes in Eastern Europe, had lost some confidence, but the dollar lacked substantial support to break into any new ground against it. The dollar rose to 1.6935 marks in New York from 1.6750 late Wednesday after closing at 1.6805 marks in Frankfurt, up from 1.6715. The British pound fell against the dollar, closing at $1.6855 in New York, compared with $1.6960 late Wednesday. In London earlier, sterling cost $1.6936, cheaper than Wednesday's late $1.6963. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.5075 Swiss francs, up from 1.4940; 5.7580 French francs, up from 5.6965; 1,258.50 Italian lire, up from 1,244.75; and 1.20405 Canadian dollars, down from 1.20745. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.4950 Swiss francs, up from 1.4920; 5.7130 French francs, up from 5.6845; 1.8940 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8832; 1,248.00 Italian lire, up from 1,242.25; 1.2060 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2062. The dollar closed at 144.775 Japanese yen in New York, up from 144.35. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.45 Japanese yen, up from 144.35. In London late Thursday the dollar closed lower at 144.38 yen. Gold closed in London, the major overseas market, at a bid $415.50 a troy ounce, down from $416.25 late Wednesday. The closing price in Zurich was $415.75 bid, up from $415.52. A bullion dealer in Zurich said the whole market was clouded by anxiety over the extent of the precious metals holdings of Drexel Burnham. Prices would be affected if Drexel, whose parent filed for bankruptcy court protection late Tuesday, unloads its portfolio. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold closed at $416.85 bid, down from $417.25. Silver rose 0.2 cent on the Commodity Exchange to $5.317 a troy ounce. In London, silver traded at $5.35 bid for a troy ounce, up from $5.32.

DOC.HEAD: GM, Ford 4th-Quarter Earnings Tumble; Profit Sharing Down for Auto Workers
DOC.TEXT: Profits plunged by 50 percent at General Motors Corp. and by 72.9 percent at Ford Motor Co. in the fourth quarter, as the nation's biggest automakers on Thursday showed the impact of slow sales and costly buyer incentives. The quarterly results completed a sharp drop in annual earnings for the nation's Big Three automakers, which have been struggling with an industrywide slump that has prompted plant closings and thousands of layoffs. Autoworkers will get more bad news this spring: the decline in profits at GM, Ford and Chrysler Corp., which on Tuesday posted a $664 million net loss for the fourth quarter, will mean little or no annual profit sharing payments this year. GM posted a $700.2 million profit in the three months ended Dec. 31, down from $1.4 billion in the same quarter of 1988. GM's fourth-quarter earnings tumbled to $1.01 per share of common stock, compared with $2.12 the year before. GM's total sales and revenue during the October-December quarter, including non-automotive subsidiaries, fell to $31.36 billion from $32.43 billion a year earlier. Ford reported fourth-quarter profit of $314 million, or 68 cents a share, compared with $1.16 billion, or $2.42 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. Ford's quarterly revenue in its automotive and financial services businesses amounted to $24.15 billion, compared with $23.91 billion in 1988. Ford earnings decline reflected a $424 million loss linked to the sale of its Rouge Steel Co. subsidiary, but even without that factor fourth-quarter earnings were down 36.3 percent. Industrywide, car and truck sales fell sharply when the 1990 model year began in October, mainly because of reduced buyer incentives and higher prices for the new vehicles. Throughout November and December, auto companies funneled money into incentive programs _ which comes directly out of profits _ in an attempt to halt the slide. Compounding the problems, the Big Three faced swelling inventories and prepared to lay off thousands of auto workers during the first quarter of this year. Those layoffs largely have been accomplished and inventories of unsold vehicles have shrunk from a 91-selling-day level at year's end to 70 days at the end of January. Ford Treasurer David McCammon said the company spent an average of $800 in incentives for every car and truck it sold in the fourth quarter, slightly more than double the figure for the year-earlier quarter. He said that on Dec. 31, Ford was spending about $1,000 on incentives for each of its vehicles. As production and inventories get more in line with demand, McCammon said, automakers should be able to rely less on incentives to control new-car inventory and sales. For the first time since 1985, GM's annual earnings outpaced those of No. 2 Ford. GM's annual profit fell 13.1 percent to $4.22 billion, on total corporate revenue of $126.93 billion, compared with a profit of $4.86 billion on revenue of $123.64 billion in 1988. Annual earnings per GM common share dropped to $6.33 from $7.17. GM's major subsidiaries reported earnings Wednesday. General Motors Acceptance Corp. and GM Hughes Electronics Corp. reported declines, but Electronic Data Systems Corp. said its profit grew with added data-services customers. Ford's annual earnings fell 27.6 percent to $3.84 billion, or $8.22 a share, from $5.3 billion, or $10.96 a share, during 1988. Annual revenue rose to $96.15 billion from $92.45 billion. Chrysler on Tuesday said it lost $664 million in the fourth quarter, mainly because of a one-time $577 million charge for plant closings and costs of cutting jobs from its white-collar work force. Chrysler posted a profit of $433 million in fourth quarter 1988. Chrysler's annual profit plummeted 65.8 percent to $359 million. Each of the automakers said their performances in the United States suffered last year, meaning no profit sharing for Chrysler hourly workers, no bonuses for the company's salaried employees and sharply lower profit-sharing payments to hourly workers at GM and Ford. Last year, Chrysler handed out an average of $720 to hourly workers, GM gave out an average of $265 per worker and Ford's hourly employees got an average of $2,800 apiece. GM said Thursday afternoon it would distribute profit-sharing checks of about $50 apiece to its 443,000 U.S. salaried and hourly employees. Ford said it would make a profit-sharing announcement Friday. United Auto Workers union Vice President Ernie Lofton, head of the union's Ford Department, said while workers welcome profit sharing in any amount, ``what's far more important to them and their union is securing existing jobs and creating new union jobs in U.S. Ford factories.'' UAW contracts with each of the Big Three expire at midnight Sept. 14, and union leaders have said job security will be a top issue.

DOC.HEAD: Gold, Platinum Futures Weaken Amid Better Economic News
DOC.TEXT: Gold and platinum futures prices weakened Thursday amid new signs of economic strength, including a record-breaking rise in housing starts and a surge in stock prices. On other commodity markets, copper futures rose; petroleum futures gained; coffee futures slumped; grains and soybeans were mixed; pork bellies surged and livestock futures were mixed. Gold futures fell $4.30 to $5.10 an ounce on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in February settling at $412.40 a troy ounce. Silver futures finished unchanged to 0.3 cent higher with March at $5.33 a troy ounce. The platinum market gave up most of the previous session's gains. Platinum futures settled $4 to $5 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with April at $522.90 a troy ounce. Precious metal traders focused on a variety of bullish factors including the government's January housing-starts report and expectations that another government report Friday will show a reduction in the U.S. trade deficit in December. Positive news about the economy is generally bearish for gold prices since investors tend to buy gold as a hedge against an economic downturn. The Commerce Department's report of a 29.6 percent increase in January housing starts to a record seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.63 million units helped boost the dollar's value against other major currencies, which typically prompts selling of precious metals. Thursday's 25-point rise in the Dow Jones industrial average also quelled investment demand for gold, analysts said. Analysts also cited profit-taking ahead of the upcoming three-day weekend, and rumors that the struggling brokerage firm Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. was again liquidating positions in the precious metal markets to raise cash. Despite the weakness, ``I think the platinum market is still very steady and the gold market also appears to be in a bullish trend,'' said Anne Orton, vice president of Deak International Inc. ``They just didn't seem to have much strength today,'' she said. The housing-starts report also lent support to copper futures on the Commodity Exchange. Copper wire and pipes are heavily used in home construction. Copper futures settled .95 cent to 1.7 cents higher with February at $1.085 a troy ounce. Energy futures rose sharply on the New York Merc, partly reflecting fears that a new eruption of Alaska's Redoubt volcano posed a threat to the oil industry there. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 40 cents to 77 cents higher with March at $22.84 a barrel; heating oil was .50 cent to 1.01 cents higher with March at 58.65 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .75 cent to 1.3 cents higher with March at 60.64 cents a gallon. Coffee futures retreated slightly on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange on news that Brazilian shipping companies and dock workers had reached a wage agreement, averting a strike. Coffee settled .83 cent to 1.02 cents lower with March at 84.98 cents a pound. Soybean futures rose modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting strength in the European market for soybean meal, while wheat futures retreated and corn futures closed mixed. Wheat futures settled { cent to 1 cent lower with March at $3.86\ a bushel; corn was \ cent lower to 1{ cents higher with March at $2.42} a bushel; oats were \ cent to } cent lower with March at $1.40{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 4\ cents higher with March at $5.71 a bushel. Pork belly futures surged on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on news that the United States is exploring the possibility of subsidizing sales of U.S. meat to the Soviet Union. Such a program could be modeled on the Export Enhancement Program for grains in which the Agriculture Department provides grain or grain credits to exporters to sell to targeted nations. Frozen pork belly futures settled .98 cent to 1.8 cents higher with February at 51.10 cents a pound; live cattle futures finished .30 cent to .35 cent higher with February at 79.77 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .18 cent higher with March at 82.02 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .32 cent lower with February at 49.85 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Higher
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Feb. 5, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,251.7 billion from $3,239.2 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,067.8 billion from $4,056.1 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $799.2 billion from $792.6 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the diference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 6.0 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.4 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,222.4 billion, a 6.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,045.1 billion, up 3.1 percent, while M1 rose 4.7 percent to an average of $793.6 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks rose $473 million. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $1.036 billion a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $852 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $436 million in the two weeks ended Feb. 7, down from $575 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $299.2 billion in the two-week period ended Feb. 7, down from $303.2 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Federated-Allied Say Sales Down But Stores Receiving More Goods
LaserPhoto CF1
DOC.TEXT: The Federated and Allied retailing companies are making progress luring merchandise suppliers back during the chains' bankruptcy reorganizations, but sales have declined, their president said Thursday. Sales for the 260 stores that Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. operate in 28 states were up 3 percent in December from the previous year, but declined 9 percent in January and 4 percent in February, said James M. Zimmerman, president and chief operating officer of Federated and Allied. ``We're going to have a very poor fourth quarter,'' Zimmerman told reporters, referring to the fiscal quarter than ended Feb. 3. Zimmerman declined to be more specific. January sales figures will be released March 5, while fiscal fourth-quarter and year-end results are to be released May 3, company spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. Under an ideal scenario, Federated and Allied could emerge from their Chapter 11 reorganizations in eight months, said G. William Miller, the former U.S. Treasury secretary hired Jan. 16 as chairman and chief executive officer of Federated Stores Inc., the newly created parent of Federated and Allied. The two retailers filed Jan. 15 for bankruptcy protection from creditors, listing $7.7 billion in debts. Miller, addressing reporters with Zimmerman and new Federated-Allied Chairman Allen I. Questrom, said his optimistic projection could occur if Federated and Allied develop reorganization plans within the 120 days they are allowed the exclusive right to do so, and creditors and the U.S. Bankruptcy Court give quick approval to them. But, Miller said, ``I don't promise you that that's possible or even feasible.'' He described both companies as viable and profitable, but said they must adjust the staggering debts amassed when parent Campeau Corp. of Toronto acquired Allied in 1986 and Federated in 1988. ``The capital structure is what's broke, and is what brings us here today,'' Zimmerman said. The Chapter 11 filings have noticeably hurt confidence of customers and merchandise suppliers, but Federated and Allied are making progress and are now receiving about 85 percent of the goods they order. In the weeks prior to the Jan. 15 filing, the stores were receiving only about 25 percent of their orders, with merchants refusing to ship the rest, Zimmerman said. The bankruptcy court's approval last Friday of interim financing provided a critical boost for the two companies, Questrom said. The court approved $700 million in debtor-in-possession financing and $1.7 billion in funds to allow the charge-card subsidiaries of Allied and Federated to buy charge-card accounts from the chains, giving them a cash infusion. Questrom, lured away from the Neiman-Marcus chain Feb. 2 with a five-year contract that will pay him $1.2 million annually, said Federated and Allied face a challenge in trying to maintain market share against financially healthy competitors. Questrom said he will focus on luring back more of Federated and Allied's vendors and in adjusting merchandise inventories to keep customers coming in. Zimmerman said he expects no across-the-board layoffs among the combined 100,000 Federated and Allied employees. The companies have suffered no major employee losses because of the Chapter 11 filings, but need to work on retaining employees, Questrom said. ``I think the ball is in our court to run the kind of company where our employees want to work,'' Zimmerman said.

DOC.HEAD: Occidental Names Successor to Armand Hammer
DOC.TEXT: Occidental Petroleum Corp.'s 91-year-old chief, Armand Hammer, will be replaced as chairman by company President Ray R. Irani if Hammer retires or dies, Occidental announced Thursday. The Los Angeles-based petrochemical giant said, however, that the imperious Hammer has no immediate plans to step aside. The announcement said Hammer is in ``very good health'' following heart surgery in November and the death of his wife, Frances, in December. He plans to continue as chairman and chief executive for the indefinite future, it said. Irani, 55, has been widely expected to replace Hammer, who has tried to emphasize in the past few years that Occidental would be able to hold steady without him. Irani was named president and chief operating officer of Occidental in August 1984, leaping over 14 other executive vice presidents after just 14 months at Occidental. He replaced Hammer's former heir-designate, A. Robert Abboud, who quit during a power struggle after four years on the job. Speculators, believing Occidental to be likely a takeover target without Hammer at its head, have repeatedly bid up its stock price on rumors and reports of ill health, most recently following the implantation of a heart pacemaker in Hammer's chest in November. It edged up 87{ cents Thursday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, to $28.25 per share. Hammer and Irani declined interview requests. Asked about the timing of the announcement, Occidental spokesman Frank Ashley said, ``This action was taken to put to rest any rumors about succession at Occidental. ``It was solely Dr. Hammer's suggestion to dispel any rumors,'' Ashley said, noting that Hammer, who prides himself as a private ambassador for peace, continues his globe-trotting. ``He was just in the Soviet Union,'' Ashley said. ``He is keeping a full schedule and his health is fine.'' When Hammer attended a Republican fund-raiser Feb. 6 featuring President George Bush, he showed up at the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles in a wheelchair. Looking frail and raising his arm to acknowledge reporters, he was wheeled around a Secret Service metal detector to a private reception. He didn't speak to reporters. Hammer said he had requested that Occidental's directors name Irani his successor ``to provide for an orderly future management succession.'' During Irani's 5{ years as president, Occidental has shifted its focus from foreign oil operations to domestic. It has grown from revenues of $15.6 billion in 1985 to $20.1 billion in 1989, growth Hammer attributed largely to Irani. Results at Occidental's chemical division, which Irani has headed since joining the company in 1983, improved from a loss of $38 million on sales of $1.7 billion that year to 1989 earnings of more than $1 billion on sales of $5.2 billion. ``Ray Irani has clearly earned this unanimous vote of confidence by the Occidental board,'' Hammer said in a statement. Irani, born in Beirut, Lebanon, has a PhD. in chemistry and began his career as a research scientist. He came to Occidental from Olin Corp., where he was president, joining Occidental as chairman and chief executive of its Occidental Chemical Corp. subsidiary.

DOC.HEAD: Federated-Allied to Creditors: We Didn't Dupe You
With AM-Federated Leadership Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Federated-Allied department store executives told creditors Thursday that the companies didn't deceive them about the financial crisis that precipitated the biggest bankruptcy filing in retailing history. But the executives said they doubted all the $7.7 billion in debt listed in their bankruptcy filings would be fully repaid. Much of the debt resulted from the junk-bond-financed takeovers of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. last decade by the Campeau Corp. of Canada, a real estate developer. G. William Miller, chairman of the newly formed parent company Federated Stores Inc., and the top executives of the two retailers, which operate 260 stores in 28 states, spoke to creditors and reporters at a special meeting. They sought to reassure creditors about the ultimate repayment of the debt but were cautious. ``Some of it will have to disappear,'' Miller said. ``For those who hold the debt, the market is no longer there. We want them to get a reasonable recovery.'' Miller, Federated-Allied Chairman Allen Questrom, and President James Zimmerman read prepared statements and didn't answer questions. Zimmerman told the creditors that by September 1989, it was evident to senior managers that Federated and Allied could not meet their debt payments and that major financial restructuring was necessary. But he said the decision to file for bankruptcy court protection was made in January to prevent further erosion in the value of the businesses. ``There was no plot to deceive any creditors. There was no grand scheme in Toronto or elsewhere to trick anybody,'' Zimmerman said. ``We regret that any of our creditors were left holding the bag with checks that did not clear prior to our filing. ``It is my personal goal _ as well as our corporate expectations _ that the reorganization plan to be developed will maximize the return to all creditors. ``I hope that all of our trade creditors will be paid in full, and we anticipate working with all of our creditors toward that objective.'' Zimmerman pledged to creditors, ``You will find us to be open, honest and straightforward.'' Miller, a former U.S. Secretary of the Treasury, said he assumed leadership last month of the parent company, Campeau (U.S.), on condition that it be renamed and assured autonomy, distancing itself from Robert Campeau, the Canadian real estate developer who engineered the debt-financed takeovers of Allied and Federated.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Only version planned.
DOC.TEXT: The Big Three domestic automakers planned to produce 208,738 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 175,239, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, when 252,973 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. were scheduled to make 124,501 cars this week, compared with 107,032 a week ago and 157,768 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production was scheduled at 84,237, compared with 68,207 last week and 95,205 a year ago. Canadian automakers were to build 24,532 cars this week, up from 14,792 a week ago and 20,454 last year. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 19,602, compared with 18,417 a week ago and 22,566 a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Drop In 2nd-Qtr Profit
DOC.TEXT: News Corp. Ltd., the Australia-based media conglomerate headed by Rupert Murdoch, reported Thursday its second-quarter profit tumbled 62 percent, partly due to higher interest expenses, the impact of a labor dispute and start-up losses from a television operation in the United Kingdom. News Corp. said it earned $86.4 million, or 60 cents per American depository receipt (ADR), for the three months ended Dec. 31, down from $224.3 million, or $1.35 per ADR, a year earlier. Each ADR is equivalent to two News Corp. common shares and the ADRs are traded on the New York Stock Exchange. Revenue was nearly flat at $1.66 billion compared with $1.65 billion a year ago. For the first half of its fiscal year, News Corp.'s earnings plunged 67 percent to $117 million, or 83 cents per ADR, from $357.4 million, or $2.18 per ADR, a year earlier. Revenue for the first half rose 8.3 percent to $3.17 billion from $2.93 billion a year earlier. News Corp. said its results were affected by startup losses in its Sky Television service in the United Kingdom, higher interest expense and the impact of a 14-week dispute by pilots of Ansett Airlines in Australia. The company's U.S. operations turned in a strong performance as its TV stations, its Fox Broadcasting and its magazines registered firm gains.

DOC.HEAD: Options Exchange Censures Four Dean Witter Brokers
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Board Options Exchange on Thursday announced disciplinary measures against six people, including four former Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. brokers, for violating of trading rules. Without admitting or denying the charges against them, all six consented to censures and suspensions from association with any CBOE member for varying lengths of time. Two of the men, including one of the former Dean Witter brokers, also were suspended temporarily from exchange membership. Each of the former Dean Witter brokers was accused of numerous offenses including trading for customers' accounts without proper authorization and executing trades that were unsuitable based on customers' knowledge and experience in financial matters. Two of the former Dean Witter brokers, Bruce A. Dembroski and David H. Coltin, worked in the company's Burlington, Mass., office. Each was suspended for one year from association with any exchange member. Coltin also was suspended for one year from exchange membership. Kenneth A. Rosenthal, a former broker in Dean Witter's Boston office, was suspended for two years from association with any exchange member. Michael W. Pursely, a former broker in Dean Witter's Clearwater, Fla., office was suspended for nine months from association with any exchange member. Also disciplined were two CBOE market makers, or independent floor traders, Gregory S. De Fotis and Jeffrey A. Rahn. De Fotis was accused of failing to contribute to the maintenance of a fair and orderly market and was suspended for four days from exchange membership and from association with any member. Rahn was accused of manipulating trades in such a way that the cost of trading was improperly reduced. He was fined $1,000 and suspended for two weeks from associating with exchange members.

DOC.HEAD: UMW To Go Ahead With Pittston Contract Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-8, `The Pittston ... the contract' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with union briefing.
DOC.TEXT: The United Mine Workers said Thursday it will let its 1,700 striking miners vote on a contract with Pittston Coal Group rather than wait for a final ruling on $64 million in fines against the union. The union had previously said it would withhold a rank-and-file vote until all legal action taken against the UMW for its strike tactics was resolved. ``The union will continue to defend the interests of our members and the organization in the courts, but will no longer defer the ratification vote,'' UMW President Richard Trumka said Thursday. ``Our members at Pittston fought long and hard to secure this tentative agreement, and it is their right to see it and vote on it.'' The tentative contract was reached New Year's Eve with the help of William Usery, a mediator appointed by Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole. The result of the secret balloting Monday should be known Tuesday, more than two years after the expiration of the old contract and 11 months after the start of the bitter strike by miners in Virginia, West Virginia and Kentucky. The union and company have withheld the terms of the settlement, but sources familiar with the agreement said the union won concessions on the two biggest concerns: job security and health and retirement benefits. The Pittson strike drew wide attention because of the use of mass sit-down demonstrations to block coal trucks. Because the union contended Pittston was attempting to break the union, the sparked sympathetic wildcat strikes during the summer involving 46,000 UMW members from Appalachia and the Midwest. Between 150 and 200 union district and local leaders began hearing details of the contract from UMW officials Thursday evening. There were extensive questions about the tentative agreement, which several miners refused to discuss in detail. ``It takes a long time to go through it article by article and there are some new things in it,'' said Mike Buckner, director of research in the union's Washington office. ``We tried to go as slow as members want us to explain everything in the contract,'' Buckner said. ``There are new job opportunity benefits in there and there are a lot of questions about that.'' Buckner declined to discuss any further details about the agreement. The union wants to give the miners an opportunity to see the contract before releasing it to the media, he said. When the settlement was announced Jan. 1, Trumka said a ratification vote would hinge on the settlement of all legal action connected with the strike. On Monday, however, Circuit Judge Donald McGlothlin refused to dismiss $64 million in fines for hundred of violations of court-ordered strike restrictions. ``The wheels of justice are turning slowly in certain courts, and our members at Pittston have waited long enough,'' Trumka said Thursday. McGlothlin rejected arguments made by attorneys for the union and the company, which joined in the motion to drop the fines, and he refused the union's offer of 10,000 hours of community service. However, he gave the attorneys 10 days to come up with another proposal to clear the contempt-of-court fines. On Wednesday, U.S. District Judge Glen Williams agreed to reduce the fines he levied from $960,000 to $280,000.

DOC.HEAD: Pickens Partnership Blames Low Natural Gas Prices For Quarter, Annual Losses
DOC.TEXT: Mesa Limited Partnership, the oil and gas operation run by T. Boone Pickens, blamed lower natural gas prices and higher interest rates for losses in the fourth quarter and all of 1989. The company, which in December suspended quarterly payments to unitholders, said it lost $42.67 million, or 25 cents a unit, on revenues of $77.84 million in the three months ended Dec. 31. That compares with a profit of $13.26 million, or 14 cents a unit, on $81.85 million in revenues in the same 1988 quarter. For the year, Mesa lost $63.02 million, or 24 cents a unit, compared with profits of $46.09 million, or 52 cents, in 1988. Revenues fell to $356.02 million last year from 1988's $370.61 million. The annual figures include gains from sale of oil and gas properties of $29 million last year and $13 million in 1988. In December, Pickens said the company would quit paying its 37.5-cent quarterly distribution to maintain ``financial integrity while gas prices remain low.'' In addition, Pickens said Mesa would package its holdings in the Hugoton natural gas field into a separate trust and sell shares to raise $300 million to help pay down its $1.5 billion in long-term debt. Previously, Mesa had maintained payments on units, which are akin to common stock dividends by a corporation, even though earnings from its oil and gas business didn't support the distribution. Instead, the company made payments from profits gained on Pickens' celebrated stock forays against such companies as Gulf Oil Corp., Phillips Petroleum Co. and Unocal. Mesa said it earned $50.1 million on securities last year, compared with $20.1 million in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: CIGNA Reports 33 Percent Increase In Earnings For 4th Quarter 1989
DOC.TEXT: CIGNA Corp., the insurance and employee benefit group, said its earnings rose 33 percent in the fourth quarter and 26 percent in 1989 as big investment gains helped offset losses from Hurricane Hugo and the San Francisco earthquake. Fourth quarter earnings totaled $184 million, or $2.35 a share, on revenues of $4.14 billion. That compared with earnings of $138 million, or $1.70 a share, on revenues of $3.92 billion for the final quarter of 1988. The company realized $51 million in investment gains after tax in the latest quarter, up from $7 million a year earlier. For the year, earnings totaled $562 million, or $7 a share, on revenues of $15.6 billion. That was up from earnings of $445 million, or $5.34 a share, on revenues of $14.8 billion in 1988. Investment gains for the year rose to $104 million from $8 million a year earlier. The latest year's gain included $81 million from the sale of CIGNA's Horace Mann group of companies. Operating income in the company's property and casualty insurance business plunged to $27 million in 1989 from $249 million in 1988. Pre-tax catastrophe losses totalled $160 million for Hurricane Hugo and the Bay area quake.

DOC.HEAD: KKR-Affiliated Partnership to Buy 3.38 Million Shares of FIB
DOC.TEXT: A partnership affiliated with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. has agreed to boost its stake in First Interstate Bancorp to nearly 10 percent by buying part of the bank's stock offering, First Interstate said Wednesday. The Kohlberg Kravis partnership will pay $111,540,000 for 3.38 million shares, or $33 a share. The partnership also may purchase up to an additional 112,275 shares under the agreement, First Interstate said. The agreement will raise Kohlberg Kravis' stake in the Los Angeles-based bank-holding company to approximately 9.98 percent from 4.6 percent currently. Under the agreement, the buyout specialist firm agreed not to increase its stake for at least two years. The stock is part of an offering of 7.5 million shares First Interstate is making. The bank, the nation's 10th largest with $58 billion in assets, has been struggling to shore up its finances to cope with heavy losses recently on real estate investments in Texas and Arizona. Last month the bank reported a $344.3 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1989 after taking a $400 million charge to cover losses in its Texas subsidiary. ``KKR has been a perceptive and knowledgeable owner of our stock, and we look forward to continuing our relationship with them,'' said Joseph J. Pinola, First Interstate's chairman and chief executive officer. George R. Roberts, a founding partner of the buyout firm, said he expects First Interstate's business strategies will improve the long-term value of its stock. ``We look forward to continuing our role as long-term investors in the company,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Pacific Withdraws, D&H's Future Unclear
DOC.TEXT: A federal agency has ordered limited service be maintained on the Delaware & Hudson Railway until a hearing late this week to consider a plan to keep the ailing railroad running, a bankruptcy trustee said. D&H, the nation's oldest continually operating railway, had faced a midnight deadline to begin shutting down before the order was issued. Francis P. Dicello, D&H trustee, said he had not seen late Wednesday's order by the Interstate Commerce Commission, but was told it called for ``reduced service'' for 48 hours until a hearing Friday to consider a proposal to allow two other railways to run D&H for at least 30 days. No other officials could be reached late Wednesday to comment on the order. The New York, Susquehanna and Western Railroad submitted a proposal earlier Wednesday to operate D&H for at least 30 days, according to Ken Willsey, spokesman for Delaware Otsego Corp., parent of New York Susquehanna. The proposal has the backing of the Federal Railroad Administration. ``We've been fighting to try to save the railroad for weeks now,'' said Gil Carmichael, federal railroad administrator. The ICC designated New York Susquehanna to operate D&H after the rail line filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in 1988. Creditors have about $100 million in claims against the railroad. D&H faced a shutdown after the collapse Tuesday of a planned sale of the railway to Canadian Pacific Ltd. An emergency hearing was held in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington Wednesday to decide D&H's fate. CP had agreed to purchase D&H for $35 million but pulled out of the deal after failing to agree to terms with Conrail on the use of Conrail tracks that connect with D&H lines. In the absence of a purchase agreement and with no pending bids Wednesday, Dicello said officials would begin shutting down D&H if the ICC did not grant a reprieve. A complete shutdown would take four to five days, according to Stanley Samorajczyk, an attorney for Dicello. Plans then would be made to begin selling off D&H's assets. Walter Rich, president and chief executive officer of New York Susquehanna, said if the rail line was allowed to continue to operate, it could provide service to 99 percent of its shippers. Canadian National Railroad said it would help cover some of D&H's operating costs if the New York Susequehanna plan was approved. Canadian National tried to bid for D&H but lost financial backing for its offer last week. Delaware Otsego was among five earlier bidders who lost out in January when Dicello selected Canadian Pacific's bid for D&H. Carmichael said he was encouraged by the partnership between Canadian National and New York Susquehanna to keep D&H running. He declined to speculate on whether either company would make a new offer but noted that ``Rich wanted to buy D&H for a long time and CN wanted to be a player in it.'' D&H, which began in 1824 as a canal company, runs 20 to 25 trains daily in New York, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Quebec. It owns 550 miles of track and has traffic rights to another 1,000, Willsey said. A shutdown would put 672 employees out of work and eliminate the hope of return for 100 to 150 others on furlough, he said.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. took further steps to dismantle an operation that once was the envy of Wall Street, shopping around businesses, liquidating its financial holdings and planning benefits for the thousands of employees likely to be fired. Details of the staggering financial troubles that caused the firm's demise were outlined in papers filed with U.S. Bankruptcy Court by Drexel's parent, which listed more than 2,000 creditors and close to $3 billion in liabilities. The parent company, Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc., filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors shortly before midnight Tuesday after defaulting on $100 million in short-term debt. It was the largest securities industry bankruptcy filing ever.

The junk bond market gained further ground following the bankruptcy filing of junk pioneer Drexel Burnham Lambert, which began peddling its inventory of high-yield, high-risk issues to a handful of prospective buyers. In the junk bond market on Wednesday, gains continued to be centered on high-quality, ``go-go'' issues such as Colt Industries, Safeway, and Duracell, whose prospects for paying off their junk debt are considered less risky.

The Big Three automakers said their early February sales of North American-made cars and light trucks pulled 6 percent ahead of sales a year earlier. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., which all offered buyer incentives in the Feb. 1-10 period, said Wednesday they sold 7.2 percent more cars than in the same period in 1988, while light truck sales jumped 4 percent. A 14.3 percent jump in cars sales at Ford led the surge, while Chrysler reported an 8.4 percent drop in car sales and said its truck sales were down 16.5 percent.

Perrier yanked its bubbly water from distribution abroad and told foreign importers to dump 160 million bottles' worth because a toxic chemical passed through an old dirty filter and contaminated some shipments. The announcement Wednesday was the most drastic image-salvaging step since the disovery of benzene in some Perrier bottles last week. It also marked the first time the company provided a detailed explanation of how the contamination occured.

Business inventories fell in December for the first time in more than a year while sales remained unchanged, the government said. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that inventories were down 0.2 percent to a seasonally adjusted $795.2 billion after rising 0.5 percent in November and 0.3 percent in October. It was the first decline since a 0.1 percent drop in October 1988 and the largest since inventories slipped 0.6 percent in December 1986.

Rising farm income helped hard-pressed rural banks and other agricultural lenders recover in 1989, and further gains are likely this year, an Agriculture Department report said. But the department's Economic Research Service cautioned Wednesday that loan delinquency rates will remain high by historical standards ``because farm financial stress is still present, especially in certain areas adversely affected by weather.''

Congressional analysts said the new capital-gains tax cut proposed by President Bush is tilted even more toward the wealthy than an earlier version, although it would do less to worsen the budget deficit. More than 83 percent of the direct benefit of the tax cut would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year, according to a study released Wednesday by the non-partisan staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation. The same staff estimated that 79.7 percent of the benefit from the cut Bush recommended last year would have gone to that upper-income group.

Greyhound Lines Inc., which operates the Greyhound and Trailways bus systems, is preparing to hire drivers to take the place of union workers who say they will strike when their contract with the only nationwide intercity bus company expires March 1. Contract negotiations with the Amalgamated Transit Union are the first since Greyhound Lines was spun off from Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp. in 1987 for $350 million. Greyhound Lines subsequently bought Trailways Lines Inc. for $80 million, merging the nation's two major intercity bus systems.

Exxon Corp. and the Justice Department are engaged in plea negotiations to settle possible criminal charges stemming from last year's massive Alaskan oil spill, government sources said. Justice Department spokeswoman Deborah Burstion-Wade confirmed Wednesday that discussions were under way, but declined to describe the negotiations or say whether they involved a possible plea bargain over criminal charges.

The stock market rose marginally Wednesday, showing few ill effects from the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials edged up 0.22 to 2,624.32. The dollar weakened slightly against most major currencies. Government bond prices fell. Platinum futures prices posted substantial gains; gold and silver futures retreated; petroleum futures rose; grains and soybeans were mostly higher; and livestock and meat futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Mill Employees Sympathize With Firm That Made Them Owner-Workers
DOC.TEXT: Just over a year ago pin-striped investment bankers from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. were zipping in and out of the tiny town of Omak, helping employees finance a $50 million buyout of their lumber mill. Now that the once cocksure investment house has filed for bankruptcy protection, the workers who become owners and saved their jobs through Drexel's skills expressed sympathy for for the firm's plight. ``They were really a human-oriented company with us,'' Lloyd Groomes, head of the local Lumber and Sawmill Workers Union, said Wednesday. ``They got on board right at the first and joined in with us.'' The deal to purchase Omak Wood Products Inc. was financed by junk bonds and loans to be repaid from future earnings. The workers made no down payment and the plant itself was put up for security. At the time, Drexel touted the deal as the first in which workers bought a healthy company using a significant amount of high-yield, high-risk junk bonds for financing. The firm promoted junk bonds as a way to provide financing for ventures like employee buyouts that traditionally have had a hard time getting funding through banks or the stock market. Ironically, Drexel's filing for protection under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws on Tuesday was the result of a cash shortage triggered largely by a sharp drop in value of its own holdings of junk bonds. Drexel's filing may put a temporary hold on future debt-financed employee buyouts like the one at Omak, one banking analyst predicted. ``This has to have a chilling effect in the short term,'' said Jay Tejera of Dain Bosworth Inc. in Seattle. ``But you won't see the pendulum swing all the way back to where equity is preferential and leveraged capital is impossible to find.'' The employee buyout in December 1988 capped a six-month blitz in which Drexel, which pioneered the use of junk bonds to finance takeovers and buyouts, convinced British financier Sir James Goldsmith that the 630 employees of Omak Wood Products were serious buyers. Goldsmith had acquired the mill as part of his 1985 takeover of Crown Zellerbach Co. Drexel provided a $50 million bridge loan to finance the deal until the employees could obtain permanent funding. It also provided the business expertise mill workers lacked. Pat Flanagan, a vice president of the investment bank, still serves on the mill's board of directors, Groomes said. Without the help of Drexel, the Omak plant would have been sold by Goldsmith to one of several corporations interested in the profitable company, Groomes said. The mill, the largest employer in the town of 4,000 located 150 miles north of Yakima, had been sold three times to out-of-town owners in the previous 32 years. Each sale resulted in job cuts at the plant, which once had 1,200 employees, Groomes said. When workers got word in the summer of 1988 that another sale was coming, they organized and Groomes contacted Drexel, asking for help in financing an employee buyout. Soon, Drexel employees were jetting into Spokane and driving the 150 miles to Omak, he said. ``They gave Sir James a (letter) to assure him we wasn't whistling in the dark,'' Groomes said. ``They said they'd underwrite $35 million before he considered us a serious bidder.'' Drexel eventually put up the $35 million purchase price, plus nearly $15 million in operating expenses. That money carried the employees until they were able to secure permanent bank financing just three months ago, said Bill Kenny, human resource manager at the mill. ``We're saddened by (their) current financial status,'' Kenny said. ``We fully realize that we as an ESOP (employee stock ownership plan) would not be here without the help of Drexel Burnham.'' ``We're doing real well, above our expectations,'' Groomes said of the company. Finding someone to do similar employee buyouts in the future may be difficult, Tejera said. ``A lot of those deals are done already,'' he said. ``You don't have a backlog of deals to do.'' But the technique remains sound, especially in mature businesses that generate cash and don't have high research and development and capital costs, he said. Tejera predicted that insurance companies, pension funds and mid-sized regional banks would step into the void left by Drexel.

DOC.HEAD: Milken, Feds Creditor List No Shows; Drexel Winds Down Operations
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. owes money from California to the Bank of China, but two of its largest potential creditors don't appear in court papers: indicted junk bond maven Michael Milken and the federal government. Drexel does not consider Milken, who is believed to be owed more than $200 million by his former employer, to be a legitimate creditor, Steven Anreder, a spokesman for the firm, said Wednesday. Largely responsible for Drexel's lightning growth in the 1980s, Milken left the firm last June after he was charged in a 98-count federal fraud and racketeering indictment. Milken claims he is owed back compensation and payment for Drexel stock that was required to sell back to the company. Drexel last year pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $650 million to settle related charges. But Drexel still owes $150 million of the settlement to a Securities and Exchange Commission fund established to repay investors who can prove they were harmed by Drexel's actions. SEC Enforcement Director William McLucas confirmed Drexel owes the money but declined to comment further. As Drexel began to dismantle an operation that once was the envy of Wall Street, fears that the collapse would cause turmoil in the nation's stock, bond and commodities markets proved unfounded. Prices of junk bonds rallied for a second straight day, government bonds dipped only slightly and stock prices were stable. ``I think the Street's breathing a sign of relief that there seems to be an orderly liquidation,'' said Lewis Glucksman, vice chairman of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``Drexel was no longer the single dominant figure in junks when this happened,'' he said. ``That's one reason the Street has been able to take his with equanimity. There was no market they were going to rock apart.'' Drexel continued to shop its businesses around, liquidate its securities holdings and plan benefits for thousands of employees likely to be fired. Bitter workers accused the company of concealing its problems. Security guards prevented many employees from taking personal belongings out of Drexel's New York headquarters. ``Maybe about a week and a half ago we had management telling us that even though times were hard at Drexel, they were the same troubles the rest of the Street was having,'' a Drexel junk bond professional in New York said. ```Bear with us,' they said.'' The parent company of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors late Tuesday. Drexel already has liquidated billions of dollars worth of government securities, junk bonds and other securities, and is peddling entire divisions to other Wall Street firms. It's not clear whether it will find any buyers, though. Unlike manufacturing companies that own plants and inventories, an investment bank's main assets are its people and client relationships. With confidence in Drexel's ability to conduct business shattered, it's possible no buyers will step forward. ``A lot of things that supposedly had worth as an entity become liabilities,'' said a top executive at a competing Wall Street firm. ``Any buyer knows there's a forced seller on the other side.'' Drexel, which financed some of the biggest corporate takeovers of the 1980s, collapsed because of a cash shortage caused by a steep fall in value of its billion-dollar junk bond portfolio and an erosion of confidence after the firm admitted to securities crimes. ``They were terribly unprepared for this,'' said a former Drexel senior executive who still has close ties to the firm. Insiders said Drexel failed to make even the most mundane preparations for the bankruptcy filing. The firm's New York car service refused to accept Drexel vouchers for fear they wouldn't get paid. At Drexel's Beverly Hills, Calif., office, one executive had to pay for a plane ticket personally to get to a meeting because Drexel's travel agency refused to extend credit. Drexel's case will be handled by Judge Howard C. Buschman III, 45, who has been on the bankruptcy bench since 1983. The parent company listed liabilities of $2.89 billion and assets of $3.7 billion in the petition for bankruptcy court reorganization. Including subsidiaries, total debt exceeds $3 billion, the papers show. The filing affects only the parent company, not the securities subsidiary. Under federal bankruptcy law, broker-dealers are ineligible for Chapter 11 reorganization. Drexel officials have made clear, though, that its securities business won't survive after the firm's holdings of stocks and bonds are sold. The largest unsecured creditor listed in the filing is Taiyo Mutual Life of Tokyo, owed $69.7 million. Others include the state of California's retirement system at $25 million and Bank of China at $20 million. Resumes and phone calls from Drexel workers flooded other Wall Street firms, executives reported. Drexel has not formally laid off its 5,300 employees but is devising severance packages, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Unions Punishing Eastern Pilots, Attendants Who Returned to Work
DOC.TEXT: Pilots and flight attendants who went back to work and weakened a lengthy strike now face the possibility of fines or other unspecified penalties imposed by their unions. The Air Line Pilots Association is seeking fines of around $10,000 plus $1,000 per day worked during the nine-month strike for each returning pilot, Al Gallo, a spokesman for the Eastern pilots union, said Wednesday. The Transport Workers Union, which represents Eastern flight attendants, has disenfranchised some picket-crossers from voting in union elections but hasn't decided whether it will seek fines. Eastern is providing attorneys for the employees that have received penalty notices, said spokesman Robin Matell in Miami. ``Obviously, a union regards crossing picket lines as an act of disloyalty,'' said Mark Kahn, a labor arbitrator in Detroit. Under their constitutions, he said, most unions have the right to fine members, expel them or consider them in bad standing. ALPA recently sent such letters to 700 to 800 returning pilots, charging them with violating Article 8 of the group's bylaws by crossing a picket line, Gallo said. He said hearings have been held in Washington on 200 to 300 cases, some of which have gone to ALPA's Appeals Board. If cases continue after that they could go to federal courts, Gallo said. Some of the returning pilots, who work at Eastern along with fliers hired to replace strikers, have voluntarily resigned from the pilots union. Around 1,600 to 2,000 formerly striking pilots remain out of work, Gallo said. ALPA, the legal representative of both working and non-working pilots, is seeking a return to work in contract talks with management. But Eastern says its pilot staffing needs have been met and is seeking to protect the jobs of newly hired fliers. The pilots and flight attendants struck in sympathy with Machinists last March 4 but called off the walkout in late November. The Machinists union remains on strike against the airline, which is restructuring as a smaller carrier under federal bankruptcy court supervision. Hearings have been held on a number of flight attendants' cases in Miami, Atlanta, Boston, New York and Newark, N.J., said Sandra Mickley, recording secretary for the Transport Workers local at Eastern. Some union members have been found to be in bad standing, excluding them from voting in union elections or attending meetings, Ms. Mickley said.

DOC.HEAD: Domestic Makers Sales Jumped 7.9 Percent in Early February
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Generous incentives helped boost sales of North American-made cars and light trucks by 7.9 percent in early February, but they didn't help the Big Three automakers stop a loss of market share to Japanese transplants. Combined car and truck sales for General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. were up 6 percent in early February, trailing growth in the overall market. The nation's eight major makers reported that car sales, which trailed last year's pace in January, showed a 10.1 percent increase in the Feb. 1-10 period. Domestic truck sales were up 4 percent. Car buyers responded to aggressive incentives offered by the automakers, said Jeannette Garretty, an analyst at Bank of America in San Francisco. After sales turned down in late 1989, carmakers offered stronger enticements, including the guaranteed rebate program Chrysler Chairman Lee A. Iacocca touted in Super Bowl television ads. Under that program, buyers will receive the difference if Chrysler increases incentives on an eligible vehicles any time through Sept. 30. With the economy sluggish, incentives are likely to persist, Garretty said. Sales won't remain as strong as early February's without ``a lot of work on the part of the manufacturers, which is a euphemism for saying it's going to cost them,'' she said. GM, Ford and Chrysler said they sold 7.2 percent more cars than in early February 1989. Ford led the surge with a 14.3 percent jump.
