Chrysler reported an 8.4 percent drop in car sales and a 16.5 percent drop in truck sales for the period. The company stopped giving rebates on its popular minivan models, which are classified as trucks, on Jan. 31. Chrysler's truck sales so far this calendar year are up 27.2 percent, while car sales are off by 2.9 percent. Chrysler reported Tuesday that it lost $664 million in the fourth quarter of 1989, largely because of costs of cutting jobs and closing plants to trim down for intense competition in the sluggish auto market. GM and Ford were preparing to report 1989 earnings on Thursday. Overall, the eight domestic automakers reported selling cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 19,316 during early February, compared with a rate of 17,539 cars a day in the same period last year. The Big Three's share of the domestic market slipped to 87.6 percent for Feb. 1-10 from 91.5 percent in the same period last year. The remainder was divided among transplants _ the American plants owned by Honda, Mazda, Toyota, Mitsubishi and Nissan. For the year through Feb. 10, North American-made truck sales showed an 11.8 percent rise and car sales were up 4.6 percent. Among the Big Three, Ford said its Feb. 1-10 jump in car sales was accompanied by a 10.9-percent growth in light truck sales. For the year to date, Ford truck sales were up 1.8 percent while car sales were down 2.8 percent. GM said its truck sales rose 10.1 percent and car sales were up 6.7 percent in early February, with an 11.5 percent gain in truck sales and a 3.1 percent rise in car sales for the year.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Merc Vows Probe of New Corruption Allegations
DOC.TEXT: An indicted futures trader allegedly told the FBI that widespread corruption dominates the Chicago Merchantile Exchange, a charge officials at the world's second largest futures exchange are vowing to investigate. ``We are obliged to investigate any claims that are brought to our attention,'' Merc spokesman Andrew Yemma said Wednesday. The statements attributed to Robert H. Bailin, one of 48 people indicted in a federal probe of trading fraud at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, surfaced Tuesday in pretrial documents filed in U.S. District Court by the U.S. attorney's office. Bailin is seeking to have the statements suppressed during his trial. The court documents contain transcripts of FBI interviews of Bailin in January 1989, six months before he was indicted by a federal grand jury. The documents allege Bailin told FBI agents that corruption at the Merc was so widespread that on one day more than twice as many pork belly futures were illegally traded outside the pork belly pit as were traded inside it. Bailin also is alleged to have described kickbacks ``to the big guys upstairs'' _ brokers who telephone orders down to the exchange floor _ and allegedly told FBI agents that the 140-year-old tradition of trading futures by hollering and signaling to other traders in a crowded, recessed pit had been compromised by corruption. ``The open-outcry system does not work at the Merc,'' Bailin is alleged to have told the FBI. Bailin, a 37-year-old trader of Japanese yen futures, and two other indicted yen traders are seeking to suppress statements they allegedly made to FBI agents. The traders contend they were illegally coerced into making the statements during interviews. In a court hearing last month, Bailin said the statements attributed to him by the government were taken out of context, said Edward Genson, one of Bailin's lawyers. But Genson noted in an interview Wednesday that the issue currently before U.S. District Judge William T. Hart ``is not the validity of the statements that were alleged to have been made. The issue is whether the statements were properly taken.'' Twenty yen traders have been indicted so far in the sweeping government probe. Bailin and 15 others who have pleaded innocent are scheduled to go to trial May 21, according to a clerk in Hart's office. Meanwhile Wednesday, the Merc's board of directors issued a blueprint for the 1990s that called for the exchange to regain public confidence and to develop several new sources of revenue. ``In order to maintain our successful momentum, there must be absolute confidence in the integrity of our markets,'' the board's statement said. The board also proposed a new business venture, the CME Resource and Service Co., to develop new products and services for market users. Some of the ventures may include publishing, telecommunications services, accounting services and trade-clearing for markets other than the Merc, Chairman Leo Melamed said.
